The pathos here depends less on retrospect than on presentiment: cp. 37, 46.— This passage illustrates Aristotle's remark that a person who speaks with strong feeling (paqhtikw=s) may effectively impugn the truth of popular maxims (ta\ dedhmosieume/na): Rhet.2. 21§ 13.
patro\s me\n k.t.l. No de/ answers to this me/n. The antithesis is between her woes before and after marriage; of the latter she begins to speak at v. 27.

nai/ous' <e)/t)> e)n *pleurw=ni. This insertion of e)/t) is the best remedy. The word is forcible, as marking that her sorrows began while she was still a young maiden. Cp. Ph.23, where, as here, the text of L has lost e)/t) before a word beginning with e.

To A's reading, nai/ous' e)ni\ *pleurw=ni, there are two objections. (a) While e)/ni (=e)/nesti) is frequent, there is no instance of e)ni/ for e)n in tragic iambics; though Eur. admits it in lyrics. (b) There is no example in tragic iambics of a short vowel thus lengthened before pl at the beginning of the next word; though such lengthening would have been legitimate in the epic hexameter. Cp. W. Christ, Metrik § 18 (2nd ed.).—Paley reads nai/ousa d) (with B): but the de/ would be weak here.

*pleurw=ni. The ancient Pleuron stood in a fertile plain of Aetolia, near the mountain called *kou/rion, a few miles W.N.W. of Calydon. About 230 B.C. that site was deserted, and a new Pleuron was founded more to the S.W., not far from the modern Mesolonghi. (Strabo 10. 451: Leake, North. Gr. I. 115 ff.) In the Iliad Pleuron figures among the chief Aetolian towns (2. 639, with four others: 13. 217, with Calydon only).

Calydon was usually represented as the seat of Oeneus ( Il.9. 529 ff.: Apollod.2. 7. 5: Diod.4. 34); and Ovid calls Deianeira Calydonida ( Ov. Met.9. 112). It is not known whether Sophocles was following some earlier poet in preferring Pleuron. But it is noteworthy that a tragedy of Phrynichus, dealing with the death of Meleager, was called *pleurw/niai (Paus. 10. 31 § 4); and the Chorus would naturally belong to the home of Althaea (the wife of Oeneus).

o)/knon. The v. l. o)/tlon (‘trouble,’ rt tal) is a less fitting word here: the point is the anguish of her dreadful suspense (15, 24). Though o)tlei=n is not rare, the noun occurs only in Aesch. Th.18paidei/as o)/tlon.

<*>lgiston. The positive would be more usual, since ei)/ tis follows; but the superl. is not redundant, if taken as absolute (‘very grievous’), and not relative (‘the most grievous’). Cp. O. C.1006ei)/ tis gh= qeou\s e)pi/statai | timai=s sebi/zein, h(/de tw=|d' u(perfe/rei: and Eur. Andr.6nu=n d), ei)/ tis a)/llh, dustuxesta/th gunh/. Soph. has ei)/per tis a)/llos in Soph. O. T.1118, but more often ei) or ei)/per tis simply (as Soph. O. C.1664, Soph. Ai.488); and so Aesch. Ag.934.

e)/sxon, not ei)=xon, because she thinks of the ordeal, not as a process, but as a past moment of life; cp. Ant.225polla\s ga\r e)/sxon fronti/dwn e)pista/seis. This is better than to give e)/sxon its commoner sense, ‘came to have’ ( Ant.1229, Ph.1420).
mnhsth\r: this legend had already been treated by Archilochus (c. 670 B.C.), and by Pindar: see Introd.

*)axelw=|on. The Acheloüs rises at the centre of Pindus, in Mount Lacmon, the great watershed of northern Greece, and, after a course of some 130 miles from N. to S. , flows into the Ionian Sea. Its lower waters formed the boundary between Acarnania on the west and Aetolia on the east. The modern name, ‘White River’ (Aspropotamo), is due to the yellowish colour which the stream derives from a clayed bed.

To the Greeks, Acheloüs was the king of rivers ( Il.21. 194krei/wn *)axelw/i+os). He was the ‘eldest son of Oceanus and Tethys’: Acusilaüs fr. 11 a (Müller Frag. Hist. I. 101) *)wkeano\s de\ gamei= *thqu\n e(autou= a)delfh/n: tw=n de\ gi/gnontai trisxi/lioi potamoi/: *)axelw=|os<*> de\ au)tw=n presbu/tatos kai\ teti/mhtai ma/lista. The oracle at Dodona,—which was not far west of the river's sources,—‘enjoined sacrifice to Acheloüs in all its responses’ (schol. Il. 21. 194). In Acarnania a)gw=nes were held in his honour (schol. Il.24. 616). The cult of this river-god was, however, not merely local, but Panhellenic. Such pre-eminence is enough to explain how he became a type of phgai=on u(/dwr generally, without assuming the more than doubtful kinship of a)x with aqua. For Greek, it should rather be a)p, as in *messa/pioi.

e)n trisi\n morfai=sin. The power of self-transformation, which Greek fancy gave especially to deities of water, was a lively symbol of the unstable element. Proteus exerts that power against Menelaus ( Od.4. 456), Nereus against Heracles ( Apollod.2. 5. 11), Thetis against Peleus (schol. Pind. N.3. 55, Soph. fr. 155 and 556). Each is desperate, and must try every resource. And so, here, self-change expresses passionate importunity. Mythology found a reflex in daily speech when Greeks said, pantoi=os gi/gnetai deo/menos.

e)nargh\s, in visible form, before the eyes of Oeneus: cp. 224. The word suggests that sense of awe which came to a Greek at the thought of a dai/mwn actually appearing to a mortal: Il.20. 131xalepoi\ de\ qeoi\ fai/nesqai e)nargei=s: ‘'tis perilous when a god is seen face to face.’ Od.16. 161ou) ga/r pw pa/ntessi qeoi\ fai/nontai e)nargei=s: ib. 3. 420 (Athena) h(/ moi e)nargh\s h)=lqe. Verg. Aen. 4. 358 ipse deum manifesto in lumine vidi.
Acheloüs occurs in works of art under each of the three forms which he takes here.

(1) tau=ros. This regular embodiment of a river-god symbolised both the roar of the torrent, and, as Strabo adds, the twistings of the stream (kampai/), a(\s kalou=si ke/rata (10. 458). Coins of Acarnania (after 300 B.C.) show Acheloüs as a bull with human head; and Soph. may have had this type in mind, for it appears on coins of Magna Graecia as early as 500 B.C.

(2) ai)o/los dra/kwn e(likto/s. The image is peculiarly appropriate, since the Acheloüs, in parts of its course, is so tortuous. For ai)o/los, ‘gleaming,’ cp. n. on Ph.1157.A vase-painting shows the Acheloüs, in combat with Heracles, as a serpent with the head and arms of a man, and an ox's horns (Gerhard, Auserl. Vasenbilder, vol. 2, no. 115).

(3) a)ndrei/w| ku/tei bou/prw|ros k.t.l. A human figure, with human face, and a shaggy beard, but with the forehead, horns, and ears of an ox. The Acheloüs appears thus on an archaic coin of Meta pontum in Lucania (Millingen, Anc. Coins of Greek Cities and Kings, pl. 1, no. 21). The words e)k de\ daski/ou geneia/dos, k.t.l., coupled with such evidence, make it clear that bou/prw|ros means, ‘with front’ (not, ‘head’) of ox. In this sense, it is fitter than bou/kranos: and Strabo 's reading (cr. n.) is thus confirmed.

ku/tei. The word ku/tos (rt ku) means ‘a cavity,’ then ‘a vessel’: hence, fig., the human body as encasing the vital organs: Plat. Tim. 74 A a)po\ th=s kefalh=s dia\ panto\s tou= ku/tous. See Appendix.

dierrai/nonto, ‘were sprinkled abroad’: a word applied by Arist. to the ‘diffusion’ of fire by rapid movement, Meteor. I. 3 (p. 341 a 30) to\...pu=r...diarrai/nesqaith=| kinh/sei.—krhnai/ou potou=, the water as it flowed from the krh/nh, fount, of the river. This phrase recurs in Ph.21, and (plur.) in fr. 559. Hesiod Theog. 340 calls the Acheloüs a)rgurodi/nhn.

prosdedegme/nh, ‘expecting’ such a suitor; i.e., looking forward to his becoming her husband (525). Cp. the usage of the epic aor. partic., Il.10. 123e)mh\n potide/gmenos o(rmh/n. The normal Attic sense, ‘having received,’ is inadmissible. She could not yet be doomed to the visits of a wooer who had not even gained her father's consent.

th=sde koi/ths. Though the compound e)mpela/zein elsewhere (as in 748) takes a dat., it can also take a gen., like the simple verb ( Ph.1327pelasqei\s fu/lakos). So a gen., instead of the more usual dat., stands with suntuxw/n ( Ph.320), e)ntuxw/n (ib. 1333), u(panth/sas (ib. 719).
me/n … de/: not, indeed, soon enough to prevent the anguish of which she has spoken (v. 16), yet to her joy.
a)sme/nh| … moi: O. T.1356 n.
e)klu/etai, here simply=e)klu/ei (cp. Ant.1112 n., and O. T.1003), rather than ‘delivers for himself,’ i.e., to be his bride.
diei/poim), tell clearly: O. T.854 n. The place of the first a)\n serves to emphasise tro/pon ( O. T.339 n.).
po/nwn, of warfare, Ph.248 n.
th=s qe/as: for the gen., cp. O. T.885*di/kas a)fo/bhtos.—o(/d), after o(/stis, as in Ant.463 f. The drawback to o( d) here is that it would be unduly emphatic: see Ph.87, Appendix.

24 f. These two verses are plainly genuine. It is idle to condemn them merely because they are not indispensable. Nauck, who spares v. 24, rejects v. 25 because Deianeira ought to speak of her fate as depending ‘on the issue of the combat, not on her beauty.’ As if her beauty was not the cause of the combat. It might as well be objected to v. 465, to\ ka/llos au)th=s to\n bi/on diw/lesen, that Iolè was the victim of war.
e)ceu/roi: cp. Ph.287gastri\ me\n ta\ su/mfora | to/con to/d' e)chu/riske.

*zeu\s a)gw/nios, the supreme arbiter in all trials of strength,—as at Argos he was sqe/nios (Paus. 2. 32 § 7). So Hermes is a)gw/nios ( Pind. I.1. 60 etc.), as patron of the palaestra. The a)gw/nioi qeoi/ of Aesch. Suppl. 189, besides these two, are Apollo and Poseidon,—who presided respectively over the Pythian and Isthmian a)gw=nes, as Zeus over the Olympian and Nemean: see ib. 182—194, and Prof. Tucker's note on v. 163 (=189 Dind.).

27 f. The tone of ei) dh\ is sceptical, as that of ei)/per is usu. confident: cp. Eur. Or.17(quoted by Schneidewin), o( kleino/s, ei) dh\ kleino/s, *)agame/mnwn. The pause after the second foot suits the pensive stress on ei) dh\ kalw=s: cp. Soph. Ant.658a)lla\ ktenw=. pro\s tau=t' e)fumnei/tw *di/a, etc.— le/xos, nom., in the sense of ‘bride’ (cp. 360, and Ai.211). The accus. in Ai.491, to\ so\n le/xos cunh=lqon (‘came into thy bed’), is warranted by the verb of motion, as in Soph. Ph.817, h( de\ su/naimon le/xos h)=lqen. But le/xos custa=sa/ tini could not well mean ‘joined to him in marriage’ (as though le/xos were a kind of cognate acc.).
krito\n, chosen by himself (cp. 245), is also best suited to le/xos as= ‘bride.’ For custa=s) cp. Isocr. Ep. 4 § 8, e)peidh\ cune/sthke/ moi (‘since he has been associated with me’).

prokhrai/nousa (kh=r), feeling anxiety about him, merimnw=sa kata\ to\ ke/ar (schol.). The compound occurs only here: Eur. has the simple khrai/nw as = ‘to be anxious’ ( Eur. Hipp.223, Eur. H. F.518). Distinguish the other khrai/nw, from kh/r, ‘to harm’ ( Aesch. Eum.128, drakai/nhs e)cekh/ranan me/nos).

nu\c ga\r ei)sa/gei k.t.l.: ‘for one night ushers in a trouble, and another, in succession (to the former night), expels it,’ —to make room for some fresh anxiety. This is a poetical amplification of a)ei/ tin' e)k fo/bou fo/bon tre/fw. Each night torments her, as she lies awake, with some new surmise as to her husband's fate.— po/non is governed by both verbs.

diadedegme/nh is used absolutely: its object, if expressed, would have been th\n prote/ran nu/kta: cp. Her.8. 142w(s de\ e)pau/sato le/gwn *)ale/candros, dia deca/menoi (‘in their turn’) e)/legon oi( a)po\ *spa/rths a)/ggeloi. Thus diadedegme/nh serves at once (a) to show that the words nu\c ei)sa/gei kai\ nu\c a)pwqei= refer to different nights; and (b) to suggest the new po/nos—not expressly mentioned—which the second night brings; since the task in which it is dia/doxos to the first is that of harassing the sufferer's mind. See Appendix.

ou(\s kei=no/s pote k.t.l. The point of the comparison, which has been prompted by the word spei/rwn, is merely the rarity of the visits. pote/=‘at some time or other’ (cp. o)ye/ pote, xro/nw| pote/), or perhaps ‘formerly’—while the labours for Eurystheus were going on: it could not, by itself, mean ‘only now and then.’ The sentence begins as if pote/ were to be followed by some such general phrase as dia\ xro/nou:—ou(\s kei=no/s pote...dia\ xro/nou prosei=de, ‘whom he saw only at uncertain intervals.’ The interposed simile, however, leads the poet to employ a phrase adapted to the special case of the gh/|ths,—viz., spei/rwn mo/non ka)camw=n a(/pac. The gh/|ths sees his distant field only twice a year. But it is not meant that Heracles visits his home just twice a year. Nor has e)camw=n any figurative application to him, such as ‘reaping the joy’ of seeing his children. It is an irrelevant detail. This is quite Homeric. See, e.g., Il.13. 62 ff., where Poseidon, soaring into the air, is likened to a bird which soars diw/kein o)/rneon a)/llo: though the sea-god is pursuing no one.
a(/pac seems best taken with e)camw=n only.

ai)w\n, fortune in life; Ph.179.— ei)s do/mous te ka)k do/mwn: this order of words is the most forcible: no sooner did he regain his home, than he had to leave it again. The reversed order (which Brunck prefers) would give greater prominence to his moments of rest.
tw|: Eurystheus (1049), whose name she shrinks from uttering.
a)/qlwn tw=nd), the labours for Eurystheus.

u(pertelh\s, rising clear of them: Eur. Ion1549oi)/kwn...u(pertelh/s (appearing above it): Aesch. Ag.359u(pertele/sai | me/ga doulei/as | ga/ggamon a)/ths.—e)/fu seems to be here no more than e)ge/neto (as in Soph. El.236, and often). Some, however, understand, ‘now that his inborn force has prevailed,’ etc.— tarbh/sas' e)/xw=teta/rbhka. The periphrasis is somewhat rare when the verb is intrans.; but cp. Soph. O. T.731ou)de/ p<*> lh/cant) e)/xei.

e)/kta, the only Sophoclean example of this form (on which see Monro, Hom. Gr. § 13), though we have sug katakta/s in Ai.230.Both Aesch. ( Aesch. Eum.460) and Eur. ( Eur. Bacch.1290, etc.) use kate/ktan in dialogue, but not e)/ktan.— *)ifi/tou bi/an: for the periphrasis, cp. Soph. Ph.314.

e)n *traxi=ni. Heracles was dwelling at Tiryns when he slew Iphitus, as related in vv. 270 ff. Then, with Deianeira and his children, he removed from Tiryns to Trachis, and soon afterwards Zeus sent him forth into servitude (276).— a)na/statoi ( O. C.429 n.) alludes to compulsion used by Eurystheus: the word would not suit a voluntary migration. This had happened fifteen months ago.

ce/nw| par' a)ndri\: Ceÿx, king of Trachis, who is not named in this play. Scut. 353 (Heracles speaks) *trhxi=na de/ toi parelau/nw | e)s *kh/u+ka a)/nakta: o( ga\r duna/mei te kai\ ai)doi= | *trhxi=nos probe/bhke. The Hesiodic *kh/u+kos ga/mos described a marriage-feast given by that king, at which Heracles was a guest. Apollodorus (2. 7 § 7) and Diodorus (4. 36 § 57) mention Ceÿx.
o(/pou, not o(/poi, since be/bhken implies, ‘is now’: cp. O. C.52.
plh\n: cp. O. C.1643a)ll' e(/rpeq) w(s ta/xista: plh\n <*> ku/rios | *qhse<*> pare/stw.—w)di=nas: cp. <*>25.

au(tou=, <*>ctive gen.: cp. Ant.858patro\s...o<*>kto<*> (about him): Ph.1039ke/ntron...e)mou=. <*>ou= is clearly right: the h<*>shness of au)t<*> may be measured by supposing that, <*>stead of it, we had *(hrakle/ous or ta)ndros.

de/ka … pro\s a)/llois <*>e/nte. Twelve years before this time, the <*>acle at Dodona had told Heracles th<*>. at the end of twelve years (824), he <*>ould have rest. Fifteen months befo<*> this time, Heracles had given Deian<*> the de/ltos on which h<*> had written <*>own that oracle (1167). <*>e had then to<*> her that, if he did not return at the <*> of fifteen months, she might assume th<*> he was dead (164 ff.)<*>
a)kh/ruktos. No herald has come, either to announ<*> his approach, or to give any tidings of <*>im.
46 The emphasis is on ka)/stin, not on deino/n. When she ponders the <*>cle, her grave misgiving (43) becomes <*>rtitude.
toiau/thn, giving the ground for a statement: O. C.747 n.
th\n, a rare instance of the art. used as relat. pron. in dial gue without metrical necessity: see O. C.747 n. The motive here may have been a wish to avoid four consecutive endings in n.

phmonh=s a)/ter. If the de/ltos should prove to have foretold the death of Heracles, then she would have received it su\n phmonh=|: it would have been a harbinger of woe.—As to Wunder's rejection of vv<*> 44—48, see Appendix.

polla\ me
 … nu=n d): the thought is, ‘though hitherto I have been silent, now I must speak.’ gowme/nhn takes polla\ … panda/krut' o)du/rmata as ‘inner’ (or ‘cognate’) accus., and th
 *(hr. e)/codon as object: Schneidewin cp. Eur. Med.205a)/xea mogera\ boa=| | to
 e)n le/xei prodo/tan.
frenou=n, pres., since the act may be conceived as continuing or re peated; but fra/sai, aor., with ref. to the particular utterance: cp. Ph.95e)camartei=n...nika=n: ib. 667 f. qigga/nein... dou=nai.

ka)me\ k.t.l. Two constructions are possible: I prefer the first. (1) kai/= ‘and,’ depending on ei), and the apodosis begins with the direct question, pw=s k.t.l. (2) kai/=‘even’ (cp. Ant.719 n., ka)p' e)mou=), and the apodosis begins with ka)me\ xrh/. But the first is more deferential; and the very abruptness of pw=s k.t.l. is natural here.

fra/sai to\ so/n, ‘to prescribe thy part’ (O.C. 625 n.), i.e., to say what it becomes thee to do. There is only a verbal resemblance to I. A. 1167 (compared by Schneid.), h)\ )me\ xrh\ le/gein ta\ sa/; ‘am I to make thine answer for thee?’—The v. l. to/son is weaker, whether taken to mean ‘so bold a speech,’ or (with the schol.) ‘just thus much.’ And the form itself is rare in Sophocles ( Ai.277di\s to/s): ib. 185 lyr. to/sson).

tosoi=sde. Besides Hyllus, the eldest child of Deianeira, legend gave her three other sons, and one daughter (Apoilod. 2. 7 § 8: Diod.4. 37: Paus. 1. 32 § 5). Cp. vv. 1153 ff. For the parataxis (plhqu/eis me/n, a)ta\r ou) pe/mpeis), cp. O. T.419 n.
kata\ zh/thsin: Isocr. or. 17 § 4 xrh/mata dou\s e)ce/pemyen a(/ma kat' e)mpori/an kai\ kata\ qewri/an.

ei) patro\s ne/moi tin' w)/ran tou= … dokei=n: instead of ei) ne/moi tin' w)/ran tou= to
 pate/ra...dokei=n. The gen. patro\s, placed at the beginning of the clause, illustrates the normal Greek tendency to announce the subject of the statement at the outset (as in tou=ton oi)=sq' ei) zw=n kurei=, Ph.444 n.). The second gen., tou= … dokei=n, is ‘epexegetic,’ as defining the w)/ran. But it is not in apposition with patro/s (‘care for his father,—that is, care for his being deemed,’ etc.). Rather the two genitives are linked to w)/ran with slightly different shades of meaning;— ‘care, on his father's account, for his being deemed.’ Instead of tou= … dokei=n, we might have had a relative clause, o(/pws a)
...dokh=|. But, since w)/ran could take a gen., that constr. was preferred as more compact. Cp. Dem. or. 2 § 4 tou/twn ou)xi\ nu=n o(rw= to
 kairo
 tou= le/gein (the speaking-time for these things). Id. or. 5 § 22 labei=n e)bou/leto th
 do/can tou= pole/mou tou= dokei=n di) au(to
 kri/sin ei)lhfe/nai.

dokei=n here=‘be believed to be’: cp. Thuc.6. 17e(/ws...o( *niki/as eu)tuxh\s dokei= e<*>nai, ‘while he has the reputation of being successful’ (not ‘seems’: he really was so). The meaning is, ‘Hyllus ought to go in search of news, if he cared to dispel our painful anxiety.’ The trofo/s chooses words which avoid any suggestion of disaster to Heracles, and say only that his welfare has yet to be ascertained.
ne/moi is better attested than ne/mei, and also fitter, as implying the deferential ei)ko\s a)\n ei)/h, not the blunt ei)ko/s e)stin. See Appendix.

a)rti/pous, with opportune foot (a)rti/ws kai\ h(rmosme/nws tw=| kairw=| poreu/etai, schol.). Cp. the similar phrases for a timely arrival; O. T.78ei)s kalo/n: Ant.386e)s de/on pera=|: 387 poi/a| cu/mmetros prou)/bhn tu/xh|; Ai.1168e)s au)to\n kairo/n: Aesch. Theb.373ei)s a)rti/kollon a)gge/lou lo/gou maqei=n. Elsewhere a)rti/pous=‘with sound foot’ (a(/rtios, well-compacted), as Il.9. 505.And so some take it here, as if it were meant to suggest his fitness for the mission: but this seems frigid. The poet was perhaps thinking of a)/rti rather than of a)/rtios: and a)/rti certainly occurs in composition, not only with verbs (as a)rtiqanh/s), but also with nouns, as a)rti/dakrus ( Eur. Med.903), a)rti/ploutos ( Aesch. Suppl.742). Still, a)rti/pous, as used here, could be taken from a)/rtios, in the sense of ‘fitted’ to the occasion, kai/rios.—qrw/|skei do/mous: Soph. O. C.643do/mous stei/xein e)mou/s. He is hastening to tell his mother the news which he has just heard (67).
pro\s kairo\n: cp. O. T.325 n.
toi=s t) is clearly right: Deianeira can at once act on the counsel by sending Hyllus. With toi=s simply, or toi=s g), the sense would be much weaker: ‘Hyllus can do as I suggest.’
w)= te/knon, w)= pai=, an affectionate form of address, as in Ph.260, Eur. Hec.172, etc.

a)gennh/<*>wn, prop. ‘not begotten’ ( O. C.973), then, ‘of no birth,’ ‘low-born,’ like a)gennh/s and a)genh/s.— kalw=s pi/ptousin, fall happily,—a metaphor from dice: Soph. El.1100ta\ me\n ga\r eu)=, | ta\ d' ou) kalw=s pi/ptonta de/rkomai brotw=n.—e)leu/qeron=e)leuqe/rion: cp. Eur. fr. 828 polloi=si dou/lois tou)/nom' ai)sxro/n, h( de\ frh\n | tw=n ou)xi\ dou/lwn e)/st' e)leuqerwte/ra.
didakta/: for the plur., cp. Ph.524(ai)sxra/), and O. C.554 n. The sing. occurs below O. C., 671.

se\ … to\ mh\ puqe/sqai: for the place of se/, cp. Ant.710a)ll' a)/ndra, kei)/ tis h)=| sofo/s, to\ manqa/nein | po/ll' ai)sxro\n ou)de/n. It is needless to conjecture <*>.— e)cenwme/nou: cp. El.865ce/nos...ke/keuqen (‘he has been buried in a foreign land’). Shaksp. H. VIII. 2. 2. 129 Kept him a foreign man (=kept him out of England).
pou= )stin: for this mode of writing, cp. Ph.16 n.
fe/rein is a certain correction of fe/rei: in answer to his question, she is quoting the slave's speech.
mu/qois, L's reading, is as good as mu/qois g), though no better. L has lost ge in some other places (as Ant.648 Ant., 1241): but, on the whole, it seems best not to assume such a loss here.
i(dru=sqai. The length of his absence prompts her conjecture that he has fixed his abode somewhere: cp. 101 kliqei/s.
me\n here is not answered by a)ll) in 72.

a)/roton, ploughing-season ( Hes. Op.448), hence, ‘year’: cp. 825. So po/a=‘summer,’ Rhianus ap. Paus. 4. 17 § 6 xei/mata/ te poi/as te du/w.—e)n mh/kei xro/nou, ‘at the full length of that period,’ i.e., from beginning to end of the year.
*ludh=|: Omphalè: see on 252.

ei) kai\ tou=t' e)/tlh: ‘if he indeed bore this.’ kai/ here emphasises tou=t' e)/tlh: cp. Ai.1127deino/n g' ei)=pas, ei) kai\ zh=|s qanw/n: and O. T.305 n. If kai/ were taken with tou=to only (‘even this’), it would imply former disgraces. Cp. 1218 n.
a)lla/, like ‘well,’ here refers to D. 's bitter comment: that disgrace, at any rate, is past.
h)\ qanw\n: a fine touch. She is prepared to hear anything now; even that he is dead. And e)cafei=tai was ambiguous.

*eu)boi=da (as in Aesch. fr. 29), contr. for *eu)boi+/da, acc. of *eu)boi+/s. In Soph. El.442 the MSS. give *eu)boi+/das, for which Seidler wrote *eu)boi=das. For the nom., the longer form *eu)boii+/s is used below (237Soph. El., 401).

po/lin is in appos. with *eu)boi=da xw/ran. Oechalia in Euboea was the seat of Eurytus, but it is in accor<*>nce with epic precedent to regard him as reigning over the whole island,— like Chalcodon in the Philoctetes (489 n.), and Elephenor in the Iliad (2. 536 ff.).— h)\ me/llein e)/ti, sc. e)pistrateu/sein: O. C.1074e)/rdous' h)\ me/llousin;
e)/leipe seems to differ from e)/lipe here only as being somewhat more vivid, —i.e., as serving to suggest the moment when he was doing the act (cp. 47 de/lton lipw\n e)/steixe). See Appendix.
th=sde th=s xw/ras pe/ri. There is no reason to suspect xw/ras. The oracle said that, at this time, he was to go through his last labour. The Euboean war, she infers, is that labour.
a)gnow=. As Heracles had long spared Deianeira a knowledge of the prophecy (158), so she had hitherto spared her son.
teleuth\n … telei=n: cp. Theognis 1166 eu)=t' a)\n o(dou= tele/h|s te/rmat' e)p' e)mpori/hn.

a)/ras, having taken up, as a burden to be borne. The midd. would be usual in this sense ( Eur. Ion199ai)ro/menos po/nous): but the act. is also admissible, just as in Soph. Ph.706ou) forba\n...ai)/rwn (n.). So in Il.23. 736 we have the act. a)e/qlia d' i)=s' a)nelo/ntes (‘having won like prizes’), but ib. 823 the midd., a)e/qlia i)=s' a)nele/sqai.

ei)s to/ g' u(/steron, Reiske's simple correction of ei)s to
 u(/steron, is much the best. to
 u(/steron cannot be defended by understanding xro/non: the two passages in which to
 a)ei/ has been explained as to
 a)ei\ xro/non are both corrupt ( O. C.1584, El.1075).—The redundancy of to
 loipo
 h)/dh after ei)s to/ g' u(/steron is not greater than that in Ph.1103 ff. o(\s h)/dh met' ou)deno\s u(/steron | a)ndrw=n ei)sopi/sw ta/las...o)lou=mai: where the text is certain. For other conjectures, see Appendix.— bi/oton eu)ai/wn): cp. O. T.518bi/ou...tou= makrai/wnos.

e)n ou)=n r(oph=| … keime/nw|: cp. O. C.1510e)n tw=| de\ kei=sai tou= mo/rou tekmhri/w|; (‘what sign of thy fate holds thee in suspense?’)—answering the words, r(oph\ bi/ou moi. Alcaeus ap. Vesp. 1235 a)ntre/yeis e)/ti ta\n po/lin: a( d' e)/xetai r(opa=s (‘its fate hangs in the trembling scale’). For r(oph/ cp. also O. T.961 n.

h(ni/k' h)\ sesw/smeqa … oi)xo/mesq' a(/ma. Verses 83 and 85 are probably right as they stand, while v. 84 is spurious. The original form of the interpolation was, however, I think, kai\ pi/ptomen sou= patro\s e)colwlo/tos, intended to follow oi)xo/mesq' a(/ma, in order to supply the condition opposed to kei/nou bi/on sw/santos. Then it struck a reviser that the passage would be more forcible if kai\ pi/ptomen were changed to h)\ pi/ptomen, and v. 85 were omitted.

This view of the original text may be supported by a consideration which does not seem to have been noticed. The very circumstance which prompted the interpolation—viz., the absence of the condition for oi)xo/mesq' a(/ma—is an admirable dramatic touch. For, while Deianeira and her hearers would understand a(/ma as meaning, a(/ma oi)xome/nw|, her death is really to be linked with his victory.

For a similar piece of textual history, cp. Eur. Andr.6, where the true text is nu=n d), ei)/tis a)/llh, dustuxesta/th gunh/: but there was another reading, which made two verses of it:—nu=n d' ou)/tis (or nu=n dh\ ti/s) a)/llh dustuxeste/ra gunh\ | e)mou= pe/fuken h)\ genh/setai/ pote. Of the second v., the schol. there says, oi( u(pokritai\ to\n i)/ambon prose/qhkan. See Appendix.

The synizesis in h)\ oi)xo/mesq) cannot be strictly paralleled: but cp. Ant.535to\ mh\ ei)de/nai. I had thought of h)\ kei/mesq), which derives some support from the fact that h)\ k (sic) oi)xo/mesq) occurs as a variant (cr. n.): but oi)xo/mesq) is better, and is probably sound.

nu=n d' o( cunh/qhs k.t.l. The nu=n here, and the nu=n in v. 90, are both right: only here we must read ei)/a for e)a=|, with Vauvilliers. The repetition of nu=n is excused by the change of sense: in v. 88 it means, ‘as it was’: in v. 90, simply ‘now.’ Cp. El.1334 ff. (‘if I had not taken care, ye would have been lost,’) nu=n d' eu)la/beian tw=nde prou)qe/mhn e)gw/. | kai\ nu=n a)pallaxqe/nte k.t.l.: where the senses of nu=n change just as here. It is well to note that repetitions of common words, which would otherwise be awkward, are often justified by such variations of meaning; see, e.g., the double a)lla\ in Ph.524 ff., and ib. 645 ff.; and the fourfold dh=ta ib. 757 ff.
For other instances of nu=n with a past tense, cp. O. C.273, Ai.445 Ai., 1060.
to\ mh\: it is unnecessary to write to\ mh\ ou): cp. 742: O. T.1387 f. ou)k a)\n e)sxo/mhn | to\ mh\ )poklh=|sai (n.): Ant.443ou)k a)parnou=mai to\ mh/: Ph.348 ff.

kai\ ga u(ste/rw|=kai\ (‘even’) u(ste/rw| ga/r. This use of kai\ ga/r,—where kai/ affects a following adj.,—is somewhat rare; but cp. fr. 86. 9 kai\ ga duseide\s sw=ma kai\ dusw/numon | glw/ssh| sofo
 ti/qhsin etc.: O. T.334kai\ ga a)
 pe/trou etc.: Ai.669kai\ ga ta\ deina\ etc. More often, in such cases, ga/r follows that which kai/ affects, as Ph.1268kai\ ta\ pri
 ga/r.

to/ g' eu)= | pra/ssein: for the place of the art., cp. O. C.265 n. ‘Even to one who is late, good fortune, if he should ever hear of it, brings gain.’ The general sentiment, ‘better late than never,’ is adapted to the particular case. Hyllus is going in search of tidings; and even now, if he hears good tidings, he will have his reward. The words e)pei\ pu/qoito make it clear (I think) that to\ eu)= pra/ssein has here its ordinary sense, ‘faring well,’—not the much rarer sense, ‘acting aright’ (like pra/ssonta kalw=s, O. C.1764 n.). The optat. gives abstract generality, which suits a gnw/mh ( Ant.666 n.).

e)mpola=|. Any profitable action may be said, by a metaphor from trading, to ‘bring in’ gain. The bold phrase here is qualified by the fact that to\ eu)= pra/ssein is followed by e)pei\ pu/qoito. It is not, strictly, the thing ascertained, but the act of ascertaining it, that e)mpola=| ke/rdos.— Distinguish the phrase in Ph.303e)cempolh/sei ke/rdos (‘sell off wares at a profit’).

div2.p: Parodos. (1) 1st strophe, 94—102, = 1st antistr., 103—111. (2) 2nd str., 112—121,=2nd antistr., 122— 131. (3) Epode, 132—140. For the metres see Metrical Analysis.
The Chorus now enters. The free-born maidens of Trachis who compose it are the friends and confidantes of Deianeira, who to them is a)/nassa (137), but not de/spoina (49).

They have not heard the news that Heracles is, or will soon be, in Euboea (74 f.). O that the Sun-god would tell them where he is, on sea or land! Meanwhile Deianeira must not lose heart. Joy follows grief; and Zeus is mindful of his children.

div3.p: ai)o/la, ‘gleaming’ with stars: cp. 11: Eur. fr. 596 peri\ d' o)rfnai/a | nu\c ai)olo/xrws, a)/krito/s t' a)/strwn | o)/xlos.—e)narizome/na might be merely ‘slain,’ but seems here to have its proper sense, ‘slain and despoiled.’ One point which favours this view has not been noticed. The inverted order of the words (‘chiasmus’) has its usual effect for the ear,—viz., to indi cate that flogizo/menon balances e)narizome/na, as kateuna/zei balances ti/ktei. And this is so, if e)narizo<*>e/na implies, not only ‘slain,’ but ‘despoiled,’—thus serving, with ai)o/la, to suggest that bright panoply which Night is still wearing when the Dawn comes to vanquish her,—ere the Sun-god has yet issued from her womb. Cp. Aesch. Ag.279th=s nu=n tekou/shs fw=s to/d' eu)fro/nhs.

The text has been much suspected (see cr. n.), but without reason. The imagery, indeed, does not form a consistent whole: Night is slain, and then overcomes. But this is merely one of many instances in which the poet's language wavers between the figurative and the literal.

kateuna/zei te flogizo/menon. The passage is marred by placing the comma, as some do, after te, and taking the partic. with ai)tw=. Cp. Byron, Corsair, canto III.: ‘Slow sinks, more lovely ere his race be run, | Along Morea's hills the setting sun; | Not, as in northern climes, obscurely bright, | But one unclouded blaze of living light.’

tou=to is in appos. with ton *)alkmh/nas po/qi … nai/ei. The objection to taking karu=cai as governing a double acc. (like le/gein tina/ ti) is, here, that the emphasis on tou=to would then be unsuitable; since, under the circumstances, the knowledge which they desire about Heracles can be only, po/qi nai/ei.

po/qi moi po/qi pai=s. In the MS. reading, po/qi moi po/qi moi pai=s, either the second moi, or pai=s, must be omitted: the antistrophic words are blefa/rwn po/qon, a)ll) (107). The strong reason for retaining pa<*>s is that, as the constr. would have been so clear without it, it is very unlikely to have been inserted; while the repetition of moi would have been a most easy error. For to
 *)alkm., followed by pai=s in the relat. clause, Schneidewin cp. Eur. H. F.840gnw=| me
 to
 *(/hras oi(=o/s e)st' au)tw=| xo/los, and id. fr. 1039. 3 o(ra=|s to
 eu)tra/pezon w(s h(du\s bi/os.

Porson is cited by Wunder and other editors as the authority for omitting pai=s. But Porson (on Hec.1030) said only that it is possible to omit pai=s,—adding that it is better to retain it (omitting the second moi):—‘potes ejicere pai=s et legere po/qi moi po/qi moi. Sed alterum melius.’
w)= … flege/qwn: for this direct invocation (continued in 102), following *(/alion ai)tw=, cp. O. T.164profa/nhte/ moi (after *)/artemin and *foi=bon).
steropa=|, usu. ‘lightning,’ here, ‘flashing light’; so the word is used of flashing armour ( Il.11. 83, etc.).

h)\ ponti/as … kliqei/s. The general sense is simply, ‘where is he on sea or land?’ ponti/as, rather than ponti/ous (see cr. n.), is probably right. According to Athenaeus (p. 189 D), au)lw/n is masc. in Attic prose, but fem. in poetry: he quotes Soph. (fr. 503) e)pakti/as au)lw=nas, and Carcînus (fr. 1) baqei=an ei)s au)lw=na. Although, then, po/ntios could be used as an adj. of two terminations, Soph. may have preferred the distinctively fem. form here. In Aesch. P. V.731, however, the word is masc., au)lw=n' e)kpera=n *maiwtiko/n (of the Cimmerian Bosporus).

The constr. is, po/qi (=pou) nai/ei h)\ ponti/as au)lw=nas h)\ diss. a)pei/rois kliqei/s; lit., ‘where he is situated, either on the sea-straits, or in a resting-place on one of the two continents.’ nai/ei thus governs an acc. in the first clause, while in the second it stands intransitively with a partic. For a similar difference in form between the clauses after h)\

h)/, cp. Thuc.4. 5e)n o)ligwri/a| e)poiou=nto (tou\s *)aqhnai/ous), w(s...h)\ ou)x u(pomenou=ntas sfa=s, h)\ r(a|di/ws lhyo/menoi bi/a|: where the acc. u(pomenou=ntas (governing sfa=s) is better taken as depending on the verb than as absol. For nai/ein as=merely ‘to be in a place,’ cp. Soph. O. C.117, pou= nai/ei, said, as here, of a wanderer.

diss. a)pei/rois kliqei/s, lit., ‘resting upon’ them, as on a support; i.e., having found an abode on land, instead of roaming over sea. The phrase was suggested by the epic use of ke/klimai, as said (a) of land which slopes down to the water's edge,—thus, as it were, ‘resting on’ the water; Od.13. 234a)kth\ | kei=q' a(li\ keklime/nh: (b) of a person who dwells on the edge of water; Il.5. 709li/mnh| keklime/nos *khfisi/di (where see Leaf): ib. 15. 740 p)o/ntw| keklime/noi (the Greeks ‘leaning on’ the sea): ib. 16. 67 r(hgmi=ni qala/sshs | kekli/atai. So in Pind. O. 1. 92 the buried Pelops is described as *)alfeou= po/rw| kliqei/s, ‘resting by’ (lit. ‘upon’) ‘the stream of the Alpheus.’ Here, however, Soph. has modified the usage,—the dat. denoting land, not water; and the sense is not, dwelling ‘on the shore of’ either continent, but simply, anywhere within their limits.

This use of dissai=sin is possible only because po/qi precedes. We could not say (e.g.), dissai=s h)pei/rois oi)kei=, meaning ‘he dwells in one of the two continents.’ But it is correct to say, pou= dissai=s h)pei/rois oi)kei=; meaning, ‘where in (either of) the two continents is his home?’

‘The two continents’ (Europe and Asia, Africa being included in the latter) mean, ‘the habitable world.’ Isocr. or. 4 § 179 th=s ga\r gh=s a(pa/shs th=s u(po\ tw=| ko/smw| keime/nhs di/xa tetmhme/nhs, kai\ th=s me\n *)asi/as th=s d' *eu)rw/phs kaloume/nhs. Varro De Ling. Lat. 4 Ut omnis natura in caelum et terram divisa est, sic caelum in regiones, terra in Asiam et Europam. (Sallust, however, remarks that the division into three continents had been more usual: Jug. 17.)

ponti/as au)lw=nas is merely a general expression for the sea. The phrase was suggested by the Aegaean, with its interfusa nitentes | … aequora Cycladas (Hor. C. 1. 14. 19). Paley understands:—‘Is he near home, in the Euripus (au)lw=nas), or midway between both continents, i.e., in the Hellespont?’ Mr Whitelaw, too, thinks that the Hellespont is meant, and that diss. a)pei/rois=‘on a slope looking towards both continents,’—the sea being regarded as an eminence.
kratisteu/wn kat' o)/mma: cp. Il.3. 277*)he/lio/s q), o(\s pa/nt' e)fora=|s kai\ pa/nt' e)pakou/eis. For kata/, cp. 379; O.T. 1087 kata\ gnw/man i)/dris, n.

poqoume/na| = poqou/sh|, a midd. found only here, yet not suspicious, since the context excludes the pass. sense. The ‘longing mind’ is clearly Deianeira's; poqoume/na| could not well denote the ‘anxious’ or ‘tender’ feeling of the Chorus. As punqa/nomai is devoid of emphasis,—like a parenthetic ‘so I hear,’—the order of the words is not too bold.

ta\n a)mfineikh=: cp. 527: Aesch. Ag.686ta\n dori/gambron a)mfineikh= q' *(ele/nan. Not, ‘with two suitors’ (Paley).— a)ei/ belonged, in the poet's thought, to tru/xesqai, but is cut off from it by the adversative form in which the sentence is worked out (ou)/pot' eu)na/zein..., a)ll), instead of ou)/pot' eu)na/zousan). It could not well be taken with poqoume/na|: still less with punqa/nomai.
o)/rnin. The nightingale may be meant (cp. 963, El.148a(\ *)/itun ai)e\n *)/itun o)lofu/retai); but it is also possible that the image is general, as in Ant.423 ff.
a)dakru/twn proleptic: cp. Ant.1200o)rga\s eu)menei=s katasxeqei=n, and ib. 791 n.
blefa/rwn po/qon: cp. fr. 729 o)mma/teios po/qos.

108 It is simplest to construe eu)/mnaston dei=ma o(dou= a)ndro\s, though the adj. might go with a)ndro/s, and dei=ma with o(dou= only. Casaubon's emendation tre/fousan (cp. 28) has been generally received. But the MS. fe/rousan must not be lightly rejected. If right, it means ‘bearing’ as a burden; cp. O.T. 93 tw=nde ga\r ple/on fe/rw | to\ pe/nqos. The word is, however, much more suitable to pe/nqos than to dei=ma. And we cannot compare passages in which fe/rein is said of the temper or mood which a person ‘carries’ within him, as Eur. Hipp.118spla/gxnon e)/ntonon fe/rwn (cp. Soph. Ant.705 n., and ib. 1090). A scribe might easily have written fe/rousan for tre/fousan by a mere slip,— as the true e)/bal) became e)/lab) in Soph. Ph.680, or as in Soph. Ant.180 the true fo/bou seems to have been made in L from sofou: cp. also the variant me/nein for ne/moi below, in 163. On the whole, I believe that tre/fousan is right.

e)nqumi/ois eu)nai=s a)nandrw/toisi tru/xesqai, lit., is afflicted by that desolateness of her bed which is always in her thoughts,=e)nqumoume/nhn eu)na\s a)nandrw/tous tru/xesqai. This may be freely rendered, ‘pines on her anxious, widowed couch.’ But the dat. is really causal, not locative; and the schol.'s explanation of e)nqumi/ois by merimnhtikai=s (‘full of care’) assumes a sense which seems neither necessary nor tenable. Everywhere else e)nqu/mios means ‘dwelling in the mind,’ and is said of that which lies heavy on the soul, as a cause of misgiving or anxiety. So O.T. 739 ti/ d' e)sti/ soi tou=t), *oi)di/pous, e)nqu/mion;—e)lpi/zousan, of evil foreboding, as e)lpi/zei in Ai.799.
du/stanon, Deianeira.

polla\ ga … i)/doi. For ku/mata h)\ no/tou h)\ bore/a (waves belonging to, i.e. raised by, them), cp. Il.2. 396to
 d) (sc. sko/pelon) ou)/ pote ku/mata lei/pei | pantoi/wn a)ne/mwn, o(/t' a)
 e)/nq' h)\ e)/nqa ge/nwntai. Note the last clause as parallel with the mention of two opposite winds here,—showing that Sophocles had that passage in mind.— ku/mat' a)
 … i)/doi is clearly right: eu)re/i+ po/ntw| is a locative dat. of a common kind, like El.174me/gas ou)ranw=| | *zeu/s.

Three other views claim notice. (1) <*>n, not a)\n, should be inserted after ku/mat), and i)/doi taken as a potential opt., ‘might see.’ But in Attic poetry the opt. is so used only where there is some stress on the notion of the possible or conceivable; as in Ant.605ti/s...kata/sxoi; (n.): see O. C., Append. on 170, p. 275 (2d ed.). (2) e)n is to be inserted, but i)/doi changed to i)/dh|, an epic subjunct. of comparison, as in Il.2. 474 f. w(/ste...diakri/nwsin. But there is no Attic example of this; for in Eur. Hec.1026 the e)kpe/sh| of the MSS. should be e)kpesei=. (3) The objection to Zippmann's compromise—ku/mat' e)n...ba/nt) e)pio/nt) a)\n—is the harsh asyndeton, which is foreign to the poet's manner.

ba/nt' e)pio/nta t), lit., ‘having passed by, and coming on.’ The spectator sees wave after wave go by.—Others understand, ‘driven back, and then coming on again’ (Blaydes, ‘ebbing and flowing’). This gives a forced sense to ba/nt).

ou(/tw de\: cp. El.25 ff. w(/sper ga\r i(/ppos...w(sau/tws de\ su/.—to\n *kadmogenh= (cp. O. T.1, n.), not merely because he was born at Thebes (*qhbagenh/s, Hes. Th.530); but because, though Alcmena and Amphitryon were Argive Perseidae, the youthful Heracles had been adopted into the ‘Cadmean’ nobility of Thebes. This was symbolised by the tripod dedicated on the boy's behalf in the Ismenion, after he had served as dafnafo/ros of the Ismenian Apollo. ( Paus.9. 10. 4.)
Construe:

bio/tou polu/ponon (pe/lagos). w(/sper pe/lagos *krh/sion, (to\ me\n) stre/fei to\ d' au)/cei to\n *kadmogenh=. With *krh/sion cp. C. 1. 26. 1 ff. The image is that of a strong swimmer buffeting a rough sea. One wave twists him aside (stre/fei) from his course: the next sweeps him onward, lifting him on its crest. It is characteristic of Sophocles that, in the second clause, he has preferred au)/cei to ai)/rei, through thinking of that which the uplifting wave figures,— viz., the honour won by the hero. For the omission of to\ me/n (implied by to\ d)) before stre/fei, cp. Il.22 157th=| r(a paradrame/thn, feu/gwn, o( d' o)/pisqe diw/kwn. Remark that bio/tou polu/ponon could not stand for to\ bio/tou polu/ponon: and the to\ d) before au)/cei in 1.0 way alters this fact. It is therefore necessary, as it is easy, to supply pe/lagos from what follows.

Among those who receive stre/fei (due to Reiske) are Dindorf, Nauck, Wecklein, Hartung. The last-named, however, takes it as = ‘overturns,’ referring it to the swimmer being plunged down into the trough of the sea. For this sense of stre/fein, see on O. C.1453 f. But here the idea of ‘turning aside or back’ better suits the image of reverses alternating with triumphs. stre/fein was said of the wrestler who ‘twists back’ his foe (Pollux 3. 155: cp. a)postre/yas in Ar. Eq.264).

As to the MS. tre/fei, we may observe:—(1) Eur. Hipp.367w)= po/noi tre/fontes brotou/s may fairly be quoted to show that the sense here might be, ‘troubles make up the life of Heracles.’ (2) But the context seems to show that, instead of this, we require a word (a) which shall convey the idea of vexing, and (b) which can be opposed to au)/cei. For other views of the passage, see Appendix.

a)lla/: (though he is harassed), yet he is not suffered to perish (cp. 88). Since the words to\ d' au)/cei may be regarded as parenthetical, the idea of trouble remains the dominant one in the sentence before a)lla/: hence the antithesis is logical.

a)nampla/khton, ‘unerring,’ in the sense, ‘not stumbling or failing,’ a)/ptaiston (schol.), a)sfalh=. Cp. O. T.472*kh=res anapla/khtoi. As to the forms with and without m, see n. there.— e)ru/kei, a somewhat strange phrase (though qa/naton e)ru/kein tino/s would be natural), since it might suggest that he wished to reach Hades: cp. Il.18. 126mhde/ m' e)/ruke ma/xhs.

w(=n, causal gen.: Il.1. 65eu)xwlh=s e)pime/mfetai: Thuc.8. 109me/myhtai...tw=n ...gegenhme/nwn. The pron. refers back to vv. 103—111, which spoke of Deianeira's laments. There is no real obscurity in this, since her grief is the main theme of the ode, and the second strophe (112— 121) referred to the fate of Heracles as the cause of that grief.

Hense (whom Nauck follows) thinks that this second antistrophe (122—131) requires to be transposed, so as to become the second strophe, immediately following v. 111. But this change is worse than unnecessary. It is liable to the fatal objection that vv. 132 ff. (me/nei ga\r etc.) are then severed from the thought which they develope (vv. 129—131 a)ll' e)pi\ ph=ma kai\ xara\ etc.). They are brought into a context which does not suit them (vv. 119— 121 a)lla/ tis qew=n etc.).

ai)doi=a, Musgrave's correction of a(dei=a, is certain. In L the a( of a(dei=a is at the end of a v., and the loss of i after it would have been peculiarly easy (see Autotype Facsimile, p. 66 A). The difficulty of a(dei=a is not the construction, which, if somewhat harsh, is quite possible: ‘I will counsel in a pleasant vein’ (the adj. used adverbially), ‘though the counsel is adverse.’ The objection is the sense. ‘In a pleasant vein’ must mean, ‘suggesting thoughts of comfort’: as in O. T.82h(du/s, ‘pleasant,’ = ‘bringing good news.’ But, since a)nti/a expresses remonstrance against her despair, there is then no proper antithesis with a(dei=a. Further, the word required by the context is clearly one which shall temper opposition with deference: as ai)doi=a does.

oi)/sw, proferam, ‘bring forward,’ ‘suggest’: cp. O. C. 166 lo/gon ei)/ tin' oi)/seis | pro\s e)ma\n le/sxan. Isocr. or. 7 § 6 tou/twn e)negkei=n e)/xw paradei/gmata. Not, ‘give an adverse judgment,’ like yh=fon fe/rein.
ga\r, prefacing the statement ( O. T.277 n.).
a)potru/ein, ‘fret away.’ The midd. occurs in Ant.339ga=n...a)potru/etai. (Cp. Tac. Hist. 2. 76 si quid... ferociae habuit,...commissationibus deteritur.)

e)lpi/da ta
 a)gaqa
, that brighter forecast which the case permits: cp. Ai.606kaka
 e)lpi/d' e)/xwn.
a)na/lghta, a lot with no pain in it; for the absol. neut. pl., cp. Od.8. 413qeoi\ de/ toi o)/lbia doi=en. Elsewhere a)na/lghtos=‘insensible to pain,’ or ‘un feeling.’

ou)d' o( pa/nta kr. k.t.l.: ‘a painless lot not even Zeus hath appointed,’ i.e., ‘Zeus himself hath not appointed.’ It is the will of Zeus himself that mortals should have pain along with joy. For this use of ou)de/, emphasising a person, cp. 280: O. C.590(n. on ou)de\ soi\). In Il.5. 22ou)de\ ga\r ou)de/ ken au)to\s u(pe/kfuge (as in Od.8. 32, a like case), it is the second ou)de/, belonging to au)to/s, that is parallel with ou)d) here.

e)pe/bale: since the reference is to an eternal law, it seems best to take the aor. as=a perfect, rather than as gnomic (‘usually imposes’). For the sense, cp. Eur. Med.1112pw=s ou)=n lu/ei... | th/nd' e)/ti lu/phn... | qnhtoi=si qeou\s e)piba/llein; Il.6. 357oi(=sin e)pi\ *zeu\s qh=ke kako\n mo/ron.

e)pi\ … kuklou=sin=e)pikuklou=si, by tmesis: ‘come round in turn’ to all. Others prefer to join e)pi\ pa=si, ‘over the heads of all,’ thinking that this suits the imagery (from stars) better; but the first view seems more in accord with idiom. There is no other sound instance of an intrans. kuklei=n in a writer of the 5th cent. B.C.; for in El.1365kuklou=ntai is certainly right; it was so written by the first hand in L, and then altered by another to kuklou=si. But Arist. uses a)nakuklei=n intransitively: De Gen. et Corr. 2. 11 (p. 338 a 4) a)na/gkh (th
 ge/nesin) a)nakuklei=n kai\ a)naka/mptein: and so again in Meteor. 1. 3 (p. 339 b 28). In later Greek, too, this usage was current, as appears from Plut. Mor.160F (delfi=nes...kuklou=ntes) There is no reason, then, for doubting that Soph. admitted the use here; cp. the intrans. e)pinwma=n and prosenw/ma in Soph. Ph.168Soph. Ph., 717.Nauck, holding with Herm. that kuklou=sin must be transitive, adopts his xara
 for xara\, and further changes oi(=on to ai)e
, thus destroying the beautiful simile, and reducing a)/rktou...ke/leuqoi to an equivalent for peritello/menai w(=rai.

a)/rktou strofa/des ke/leuqoi. As the Great Bear moves ever round the pole, so joy and sorrow come round in unceasing rotation. The peculiar fitness of the comparison is in the fact that the Bear never disappears below the horizon: Il.18. 487a)/rkton t)...h(/ t' au)tou= stre/fetai, ‘that revolves in its place,’—‘having no share in the baths of Ocean.’ Ov. Met. 13. 293 immunemque aequoris arcton. Cf. Soph. fr. 399 a)/rktou strofa/s te kai\ kuno\s yuxra\n du/sin.
ou)/t' ai)o/la (94) nu\c k.t.l., the ‘paratactic’ form, instead of, ‘as night does not abide, so neither does woe,’ etc.

kh=res, here merely ‘calamities,’ sumforai/, a sense recognised by Hesych. s. v. kh=res. The sing. oft. has this meaning (cp. 454): but the plur. usu. denotes either (a) ‘the Fates,’ as in O. T.472, or at least ‘death-dooms,’ as in Il.12. 326.

a)ll' a)/far be/bake: the subject is each of the preceding nouns, the verb agreeing in number with the nearest ( O. C.8 n.): ‘but (each) is suddenly gone (from one), while joy, and the loss of it, come to another man in his turn.’

tw=|d) is opposed to the tw=| me\n implied in the preceding clause. It is true that the main point is the changing experience of the individual, rather than the transference of joy or woe to his neighbour. But these two notions are closely linked here by the image of joy and woe coming round, as the Bear revolves about the pole. Cp. Her.1. 207(Croesus to Cyrus), e)kei=no prw=ton ma/qe, w(s ku/klos tw=n a)nqrwphi/wn e)sti\ prhgma/twn, perifero/menos de\ ou)k e)a=| ai)ei\ tou\s au)tou\s eu)tuxe/ein.—For xai/rein te kai\ ste/resqai as nomin. (without art.) to e)pe/rxetai, cp. Aesch. Ag.181par' a)/kontas h)=lqe swfronei=n.

Other views are as follows. (1) The constr. is, a)lla\ xai/rein te kai\ ste/resqai a)/far be/bake (tw=| me/n), tw=| d' e)pe/rxetai. This is less simple. (2) tw=| d)=simply ‘and to him,’—i.e., to the person from whom woe or joy ‘has gone.’ But: (a) tw=| d) surely implies an antithesis. (b) The clause tw=| d' e)pe/rxetai k.t.l. would thus mean merely,—‘and then his experiences begin over again.’

a(\, ‘as to which things,’ ‘wherefore’: Isocr. or. 8 § 122 a(\ kai\ pa/ntwn ma/list' a)/n tis qauma/seien o(/ti proxeiri/zesqe dhmagwgou/s. So the sing. o(/, Thuc.2. 40o(\ toi=s a)/llois a)maqi/a me\n qra/sos logismo\s de\ o)/knon fe/rei.

Others suppose that a(\ is governed by i)/sxein, and that ta/d) is pleonastic. But this view is not proved by the alleged examples. They are:—(1) Eur. Andr.1115w(=n *klutaimnh/stras to/kos | ei(=s h)=n, a(pa/ntwn tw=nde mhxanorra/fos. Here, however, w(=n is masc., referring to the lo/xos mentioned just before, and a comma should follow h)=n. (2) I. A. 155 sfragi=da fu/las<*> <*>n e)pi\ de/ltw| | th/nde komi/zeis. Here the v. l. th=|de is clearly right.
For le/gw as=‘command,’ with acc. and inf., cp. Ph.101 n.

e)lpi/sin i)/sxein: e)n would usu. be added to the dat.: cp. Ant.897e)n e)lpi/sin tre/fw. So Thuc.2. 8o)rgh=| ei)=xon...tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, instead of the regular e)n o)rgh=| (id. 2. 18 etc.). Cp. too Soph. O. C.1678, e)n [MSS. ei)] po/qw| la/bois, with Plut. Alc.18o)rgh=| d' a(/ma kai\ fo/bw| to\ gegono\s lamba/nontes.—ta\n a)/nassan, wife of the son of Zeus, and so having the better reason to hope. — a)/boulon, having no pro/noia for them: cp. Soph. El.546a)bou/lou...patro/s (alluding to Agamemnon's sacrifice of his daughter). Racine has an unconscious echo of this verse, Athalie, acte 2, sc. 7, ‘Dieu laissat-il jamais ses enfants au besoin?’

div2.p: First e)peiso/dion. Deianeira confides to the Chorus her special cause for anxiety at this time,—viz., the oracle. Lichas arrives from Euboea. Deianeira learns the history of Iolè.

div3.p: a)peika/sai: cp. Eur. Or.1298*(ele/nhs to\ kw/kum' e)sti/n, w(s a)peika/sai. These are isolated examples of a)peika/zw so used: for in Soph. O. C.16(where see n.) we must read w(s sa/f' ei)ka/sai. Elsewhere a)peika/zein ti is ‘to express the likeness of a thing,’ either in art, or (as in Soph. fr. 154. 2) by a comparison. Hence Herm. wished to read here the usual word e)peika/sai (cp. 1220). He dismissed the example in the Orestes by saying that there w(s a)peika/sai means, ‘to compare the voice heard with Helen's voice’: but that is obviously a forced explanation. e)peika/zw is <*> to ‘enter upon’ conjecture, e)pi/ giving the notion of advance, as in e)pinow=: <*> a)peika/zw, when used as here, is rath<*> throw off,’ or ‘hazard,’ a guess,—a)p<*> <*>ing used as in a)pokinduneu/w.
qumof<*>, from the epic qumofqo/ros, occurs only here: for the form cp. yuxorragw=.

mh/t' <*>qois … nu=n d) a)/peiros ei)=: i.e., ‘mayest <*> remain ignorant,—as thou now art <*> the combination of a wish with a fact <*> 582 ff., Ant.686 n.— nu=n d) has <*> authority than nu=n t). Greek express<*> had a pervading bent towards antith<*> and this tendency sometimes asserted <*> after a sentence had begun in the <*>actic’ form. Thus here, nu=n d) sprang <*> the thought, ‘you may, indeed, know <*> the future,—though I trust that you will not,—but now, at least, you do <*>’ I therefore keep nu=n d). Each trad<*>nal instance of te … de/ should be care<*> weighed before changing de/ to te. <*> 285 f. Ant., 333 f. Ant., 1151 ff.: Ant.1096, P<*>12 f.<*> and for the negative <quote lang=greek>mh/te</quote> followed by <quote lang=greek>de/</quote>, <title>O. C. 421 f.

t<*> nea/zon k.t.l. The young life grows in ‘regions of its own,’— sheltered, like some tender plant, from scorching heat, from violent rain, and from rough winds. toioi=sde refers to the preceding words, nu=n d' a)/peiros ei)=: i.e., ‘such’=‘thus untroubled.’ For this retrospective toio/sde, cp. Ai.148.bo/sketai: cp. Ai.558te/ws de\ kou/fois pneu/masin bo/skou, ne/an | yuxh
 a)ta/llwn. xw/roisin au(tou=: schol. toi=s i)di/ois au(tou= to/pois. He notices the other reading au)tou=, which Paley supports by the Homeric au)tou= e)ni\ *troi/h| ( Il.2. 237), etc.: but here it would be both weak and obscure. For the image of the sheltered plant, cp. Il.18. 56(Thetis of Achilles), o( d' a)ne/dramen e)/rnei+ i)=sos, | to
 me
 e)gw\ qre/yasa, futo
 w(\s gounw=| a)lwh=s k.t.l.—

qa/lpos … o)/mbros … pneuma/twn: Schneid. cp. Od.5. 478(of qa/mnoi) tou\s me\n a)/r' ou)/t' a)ne/mwn dia/h me/nos u(gro\n a)e/ntwn, | ou)/te pot' h)e/lios fae/qwn a)kti=sin e)/ballen, | ou)/t' o)/mbros pera/aske diampere/s.

The text is as clearly sound as the passage itself is beautiful. But numerous changes have been proposed: for these, see Appendix. Here I will only remark that the genuineness of the words kai/ nin—which most of the conjectures assume to be corrupt—is confirmed by a fragment of the orator Antiphon (no. XXVIII. 10 in Sauppe, Oratt. Att. vol. II. p. 151), where he speaks of education as a permanent influence:—e)n ne/w| sw/mati o(/tan tis th\n pai/deusin gennai/an e)naro/sh|, zh=| tou=to kai\ qa/llei dia\ panto\s tou= bi/ou, kai\ au)to\ ou)/te o)/mbros ou)/te a)nombri/a a)fairei=tai. The last sentence is manifestly a reminiscence of kai/ nin ou) qa/lpos qeou= | ou)/t' o)/mbros k.t.l.
h(donai=s, a dat. of attendant circumstance, ‘amid’ them.

e)cai/rei bi/on, ‘uplifts its life’; a phrase suggested by the image of the plant shooting up (cp. Il.18. 56a)ne/dramen, Od.6. 163e)/rnos a)nerxo/menon), but also implying, ‘exults in its life’: cp. Ai.1066mhde\n deino\n e)ca/rh|s me/nos.—e(/ws without a)/n, as Ph.764, O. C.77, Ai.555: but e(/ws a)/n in Ph.1000, O. T.834, O. C.114, fr. 736. 5.

e)n nukti\, though virtually equiv. to e)nnuxi/wn, belongs by constr. to la/bh|: in the (sleepless) night she receives her portion of those cares which haunt a wife. Cp. 29 f.: Ar. Eq.1290e)nnuxi/aisi | fronti/si.—Not: ‘on the marriage-night.’
h)/toi … h)\, as Ant.1182, Aesch. Ag.662, Eur. Ion431: but h)\... h)/toi ( Pind. N.4. 5) does not occur in

pro\s a)ndro\s … foboume/nh, lit., ‘feeling a fear from the quarter of her husband’; i.e., ‘fearing on his account.’ Cp. El.783nu=n d' a)phlla/ghn fo/bou | pro\s th=sd), where the last three words cohere. It is needless to take the partic. as pass. (‘alarmed by him’).
au(tou=, the masc., because, though thinking of a wife, she puts her thought in an abstract form: cp. El.771ou)de\ ga\r kakw=s | pa/sxonti mi=sos w(=n te/kh| prosgi/gnetai: Ant.463(o(/stis).

kakoi=sin oi(=s=kaka\ oi(=s. The antecedent, when attracted into the case of the relat. pron., usu. follows it ( O. C.56), unless it stands at the beginning of the sentence, in acc. (as below O. C., 283 n.), or, more rarely, in nom. ( O. C.1150). But the peculiar form found here can be paralleled. Plat. Men. 96 A e)/xeis ou)=n ei)pei=n a)/llou o(touou=n pra/gmatos ou(= oi( me\n fa/skontes dida/skaloi ei(=nai...o(mologou=ntai k.t.l. Dem. or. 2 § 2 mh\ mo/non po/lewn kai\ to/pwn w(=n h)=me/n pote ku/rioi fai/nesqai proi+eme/nous. [proi+/esqai never takes a gen., like meqi/esqai.]—It is also possible to take kakoi=sin oi(=s as=oi(/ois kakoi=s: for this use of o(/s, see on O. C.1171, and cp. Dem. or. 18 § 16 e(te/rw| d' o(/tw| kako/n ti dw/somen zhtei=n. But I prefer the other view.

me
 ou)=n dh\: the only Sophoclean instance of this formula, which was always rarer than either me
 ou)=n alone, or me
 dh/ (627). dh/ here really=h)/dh: cp. Ant.823h)/kousa dh/.
h)=mos: cp. O. T.1134 n.
th\n teleutai/an: when he left home (for Lydia), fifteen months before: cp. 39 n.
de/lton: the tablet mentioned in 47, recording the oracle given to Heracles at Dodona.

e)ggegramme/nhn cunqh/maq), ‘inscribed with tokens,’ i.e., the writing in which Heracles had taken down the oracle (1167). The acc. with the pass. partic. denotes the object of the act. verb (e)ggra/fw cunqh/mata de/ltw|): cp. Her.7. 69leonte/as e)namme/noi: Xen. An.5. 4. 32e)stigme/nous a)nqe/mia: Verg. Ecl. 3. 106 inscripti nomina. The word cunqh/mata recalls the Homeric sh/mata lugra/ ( Il.6. 168),—now generally held to denote some kind of alphabetic or syllabic writing (Introd. to Homer, p. 112, n. 1). In later Greek sunqh/mata meant a preconcerted cipher: Polyb. 8. 17. 9 sunq. labw\n kai\ pi/steis (‘a letter in cipher, and credentials’): cp. id. 8. 18. 9 sunqhmatika\ gra/mmata. There is possibly a touch of designed archaism in the poet's phrase; he may have felt that it suited the heroic age to speak of writing as a mystery. This is more likely than that he thought of Heracles as using secret symbols.

a)gw=nas e)ciw/n: cp. Ai.290a)forma=|s pei=ran: Thuc.1. 15stratei/as...ou)k e)ch/|esan: Dem. or. 19 § 163 o(/te...th\n prote/ran a)ph/|romen presbei/an.—ou)/pw, after ou), the compound negative after the simple, is normal (like ou)k e)/stin ou)de/n, etc.); not an irregular repetition, like that in 1014 (n.).
e)/tlh, brought himself to do it: cp. 1070.
w(/s ti dra/swn: for dra=n ti (to do something notable), cp. O. C.732 n.: for the place of ti, ib. 280 n.
e)/t' ou)k w)/n: cp. Ph.1217e)/t' ou)de/n ei)mi: and, for the place of e)/t), also O. T.24 n.

ei)=pe me\n … ei)=pe d): epanaphora: O. C.610 n. The de/ltos (157) contained the oracle only. Heracles first expounded this (hence the aor. part. prota/cas in 164): then he gave his testamentary directions,—not in writing, but merely by word of mouth.

ei)=pe … o(/ ti xrei/h m' e(le/sqai le/xous kth=sin, ‘he said what I was to take for myself as marriage-property,’ i.e., ‘as my property in right of our marriage.’ This means, in accordance with the Attic usage of the poet's age, that she was to take as her own the dowry (proi=c) which she had brought to her husband, together with any gifts that he might have made to her. Thus a widow is described as a)polipou=sa to
 oi)=kon kai\ komio ame/nh th
 proi=ka, [Dem. ] or. 40 § 7. The bride's father (or other representative before the law, ku/rios) kept a record of the proi=c, with a view to its recovery at the husband's death, or in the event of a divorce: Isaeus or. 3 § 35 e)a
 a)poli/ph| h( gunh\ to
 a)/ndra, h)\ e)a
 o( a)nh e)kpe/myh| th
 gunai=ka, ou)k e)/cesti pra/casqai tw=| do/nti [i.e. the father, or ku/rios] o(\ mh\ e)n proiki\ timh/sas e)/dwken: ‘which, when he gave it, he did not record at a certain value, as part of the dower.’ Thus in [Dem. ] or. 47 § 57 a widow claims some pieces of property on the ground o(/ti au(th=s ei)/h e)n th=| proiki\ tetimhme/na.
h(\n te/knois … ne/moi: ‘what share of their father's land he assigned by division to his sons,’ i.e., ‘assigned to them severally.’
diaireto\n: for the verbal adj. of two terminations, cp. O. T.384 n.
The constr. is:
xro/non prota/cas, having first prescribed the time [for the division of the property],
w(s (saying) that,
h(ni/ka xw/ras a)pei/h bebw/s tri/m. xro/non ka)niau/s., when he should have been absent from the country, after his departure, for fifteen months,

to/te xrei/h sfe h)\ qanei=n tw=|de tw=| xr., h)\ … zh=n k.t.l. The words xro/non prota/cas refer to his having expounded the oracle to her before he gave the directions as to his property: w(s depends on the notion of ‘saying’ contained in prota/cas: and the sentence, w(s, h(ni/ka...a)pei/h, xrei/h, explains xro/non prota/cas.

I leave the MS. tri/mhnon … ka)niau/sios unaltered, because it is conceivable that, while tri/mhnon was prompted by the xro/non before it, ka)niau/sios should have been adapted to bebw/s. Cp. the personal constr. with xro/nios ( O. C.441 n.), xqizo/s, pannu/xios, etc. But I should prefer ka)niau/sion.—The repetition xro/non … xro/nw| … xro/nou does not warrant a suspicion (cp. O. C.554 n.): it expresses her anxiety to be precise as to the all-important point.

u(pekdramo/nta is lit., ‘having run out from beneath,’ having ‘eluded’ the imminent danger: Ant.1086tw=n su\ qa/lpos ou)x u(pekdramei=. Her.1. 156h)\n to\ pareo\n u(pekdra/mwsi. As the xro/nou te/los is here a perilous crisis, u(pekdr. is more forcible than the conjecture u(perdramo/nta, which would mean simply, ‘having passed.’
The arguments which have been brought against vv. 166—168 are examined in the Appendix.
toiau=t' e)/fraze … po/nwn. Among the various explanations of the gen. tw=n *(hraklei/wn po/nwn, two seem better than the rest; and I prefer that which I place first.

(1) It is a gen. of connection, equiv. to the gen. with peri/, and going with the whole phrase ei(marme/na e)kteleuta=sqai rather than with either word alone. ‘He said that such things were destined to be accomplished in regard to the toils of Heracles.’ This is only a rarer and bolder form of the gen. used in poetry after verbs of ‘speaking about’ ( El.317tou= kasignh/tou ti/ fh/s;), ‘asking about’ ( Ph.439fwto\s e)cerh/somai), ‘hearing about’ ( O. C.307klu/wn sou=). And there is another passage of Sophocles which shows a similarly bold use of it, viz., O. C.355(mantei=a) a(\ tou=d' e)xrh/sqh sw/matos, ‘the oracles that had been given concerning me’: an example which (to my mind) strongly confirms this view.

(2) It is also possible, though less probable, that the gen. should be taken as partitive with e)kteleuta=sqai: destined to be accomplished as part of (in the number of) his toils. For this we might compare such uses of the partitive gen. as plei=n tou= prw/tou sto/lou ( Ph.73), e)ceta/zesqai tw=n sugxairo/ntwn ( Dem. or. 21 § 202), a)riqmei=sqai tw=n maka/rwn, etc.
(3) po/nwn depends on pro\s qew=n ei(marme/na as if it were a subst. ei(marme/nhn:— ‘he said that such a doom for the toils of H. was to be fulfilled.’

(4) po/nwn depends on e)kteleuta=sqai as equiv. to teleuth\n gi/gnesqai: ‘he said that such events were to be accomplished as the end of his toils.’ I do not think that the Greek words will bear either of the two latter versions.

w(s th
 palaia
 fhgo
 k.t.l. A note on the Oracle at Dodona, illustrative of this passage and of vv. 1166—1168, will be found in the Appendix. The signs were taken from the movement and rustling of the oak's leaves; and these signs were interpreted by the priestesses called *peleia/des. Cp. fr. 414 ta\s qespiw|dou\s i(eri/as *dwdwni/das. Euripides spoke of three such priestesses; but Pindar, like Sophocles, gave the number as two (schol. here). In saying that the oak ‘spake’ (au)dh=sai) by their mouths, he follows the established mode of expression with regard to it. See, e.g., Lucian Amor. 31 h( e)n *dwdw/nh| fhgo\s...i(era
 a)porrh/casa fwnh/n. Constantine Porphyr. 2. 55 *dwdw/nh, e)f' h(=s h( dru=s h( fqeggome/nh ta\ tw=n daimo/nwn musth/ria.

Others understand:—(1) ‘by the agency of two doves’: i.e., the signs from the oak were somehow combined with, or explained by, signs derived from birds. (2) ‘The oak spake from between two doves’; i.e. a symbolical dove, of stone or metal, stood on either side of the tree. The Appendix will show what can be said for or against each of these theories. Here it may be noted that neither seems to accord so well with the phrase au)dh=sai e)k. It was through the inspired lips that the utterance of the oak became a ‘voice.’

*dwdw=ni, as in frr. 413, 415: so fr. 412 *dwdw=nos. The nom. *dwdw/n is not extant; unless it should be restored to a verse which Byz.Steph. , s.v. *dwdw/nh, quotes from Simmias of Rhodes (c. 320 B.C.?), *zhno\s e(/dos *kroni/dao ma/kair' u(pede/cato *dwdw/. For the locative dat., cp. Soph. O. T.900to\n *)abai=si nao/n.
name/rteia: for the Doric form, see on Ant.715 n. Cp. Aesch. Pers.246(dial.) namerth= lo/gon (so Porson for nhmerth=).

tw=nde=the predictions (of the alternative issues, prosperity or death): name/rteia=‘precision,’ i.e. the precise term of fifteen months. sumbai/nei=‘comes right,’ ‘tallies’ (cp. 1174; and with dat., 1164). Thus the sense is:—‘The precise term foretold by these prophecies tallies [with the period which has actually elapsed] at the present time,’ w(s (=w(/ste) telesqh=nai xrew/n, ‘so that they must be fulfilled.’ (With xrew/n we may understand either e)sti/ or ei)=nai: the former is simpler: for the ellipse, cp. Ai.668a)/rxonte/s ei)sin, w(/sq' u(peikte/on.) In other words, ‘This is precisely the time when the fulfilment of these predictions falls due.’ The schol. saw that w(s is for w(/ste (w(/ste o(po/teron praxqh=nai). The change to w(=| is needless, and worse.
Others understand:—(1) ‘The true fulfilment of these words as (w(s) they are to be accomplished’; or (2) ‘the truth of the prediction that (w(s) these things are to be accomplished.’
This is one of those passages in which the manner of Sophocles recalls that of Vergil. The general meaning is simple and clear<*> but a verbal analysis demands the nicest care.

h(de/ws has been variously altered, from a feeling that it is out of harmony with the tone of 29 f. and 149; but the word is well fitted to express that even a sound sleep, when it came to her, was apt to be suddenly broken.
fo/bw| goes with tarbou=san, which it strengthens: cp. O. T.65u(/pnw| g' eu(/donta (n.): Ant.427go/oisin e)cw/|mwcen. ( O. C.1625 and Ph.225 are not similar.)
eu)fhmi/an refers to the ominous e)sterhme/nhn: cp. Ai.361 f. *a*i....a)lla/ me sunda/i+con. | *x*o. eu)/fhma fw/nei.—katastefh=, with a wreath of laurel: cp. O. T.83 n.
pro\s xara\n lo/gwn refers to katastefh=: ‘in view of (suitably to) joyous news.’ Brunck's reading, pro\s xa/rin lo/gwn, would be weaker (‘on account of his tidings’).
prw=tos a)gge/lwn, forestalling Lichas: the words mark his eagerness to assert his claim on her gratitude (190 f.).
ga\r as in 155.
kratou=nta, the pres. (=‘is victorious’), as oft. nikw=n: cp. n. on O. T.437.

a)parxa\s refers more especially to the train of ai)xmalwti/des which the Messenger had seen with Lichas, but can also include the spoils which were to come later with Heracles. For a)parxh/ said of human beings, cp. Arist. fr. 443 (p. 1550 b 39) ap. Plut. Thes.16*krh=tas...a)nqrw/pwn a)parxh\n ei)s *delfou\s a)poste/llein. So in Soph. Ph.202 the captive *foi/nissai describe themselves as a)kroqi/nia *loci/a|.—qeoi=si (for the synizesis, O.C. 964 n.) toi=s e)gxwri/ois, esp. Zeus *oi)tai=os (200), Apollo, and Artemis Ortygia (210 ff.). Cp. 245 (of the captives) au(tw=| kth=ma kai\ qeoi=s krito/n.
ti/na … to/nde: O. C.68 n., Ph.441.The Messenger has been explicit; but she is bewildered with joy. So in Aesch. Ag.268 the Chorus makes the kh=ruc repeat his tidings. Cp. belowAesch. Ag., 876f.
polu/zhlon, in this context, is best taken as=‘exciting much zh=los,’ ‘admired by all’: though it could also mean merely, ‘very prosperous.’ In O. T.381(n.) it means, ‘full of emulation.’
fane/nta adds vividness to the thought of the joy that awaits her: cp. 199 e)mfanh=, 224 e)nargh=.—su\n of attendant circumstance ( O. T.17).
kra/tei nikhfo/rw|: kra/tos is the superior strength, the mastery ( Ph.594 n.), which vi/khn fe/retai: cp. 497: O. C.1088sqe/nei )pinikei/w| (‘triumphant might’).
a)stw=n h)\ ce/nwn, i.e. ‘from whom in the world?’ Cp. El.975ti/s ga/r pot' a)stw=n h)\ ce/nwn. So far as the ce/noi are definitely conceived here, they may be supposed to arrive from Euboea.

bouqerei=: only here. Hesychius gives the right sense,—e)n w(=| bo/es qe/rous w(/ra| ne/montai. A poet might feel that a simple compound of bou=s and qe/ros would suffice for a picturesque epithet of leimw/n: i.e., ‘the meadow of the oxen's summer’ would readily suggest ‘the meadow which is the summer pasture of oxen.’ Those who object to such a compound seem to try it by the standard of prose.—Hesychius adds to his explanation of bouqerei=: kai\ bouqo/rw| to\ au)to/. Wecklein adopts this, as=‘in which oxen jump about’: but surely they must be oi)stroplh=ges to behave so. The word occurs only in Aesch. Suppl.301bouqo/rw| tau/rw| (=qui vaccam salit).—The leimw/n was in the plain of Malis, between Trachis and the Malian Gulf: cp. 194 n.
toi implies that the motive was a natural one, which she will readily comprehend: cp. the frankness of the messenger in O. T.1005, and of the e)/mporos in Ph.552.
ei)/per eu)tuxei=: if he comes with good news, and may therefore expect a cordial welcome (cp. 229).
193 (a)/pestin), ou)k eu)m. xrw/menos, because he does not enjoy much facility (for moving forward). For the partic. in a reply, cp. Ph.1228.

*mhlieu\s: for the Ionic form, cp. Ph.4 n. Trachis was on a rocky spur under the heights (‘Trachinian Rocks’) which bound the plain of Malis on s. and W.; the distance from the (ancient) coastline of the Malian Gulf was about six miles.
a(/pas: not only the *traxi/nioi (the highlanders of Malis), but the *para/lioi also. As to Malis, cp. Introd. Ph.p. ix.
kri/nei=a)nakri/nei: cp. 314, 388, Ant.399.

parasta/s: a crowd has gathered round him (ku/klw|); and the eager people keep pressing close up to him, to put their questions. So this partic. is used of one who comes close up to a person, in a threatening way: O. C.992ei)/ ti/s se... | ktei/noi parasta/s: El.295boa=| parasta=s). Thus, while the conjecture perista/s would merely supplement ku/klw|, parasta/s really adds a new touch.
bh=nai, aor. set forward from the place where he is halting: stronger than bai/nein, keep moving on. Cp. bh=nai said of death, O. C.1226.

to\ ga\r poqou=n k.t.l. I leave to\ … poqou=n in the text, not feeling certain that it is corrupt; though I am disposed to read, with ThomasE. , ta\ ga\r poqei/n). A discussion of other views will be found in the Appendix. Here I note these points.

(1) If to\ … poqou=n is sound, it means, ‘the feeling of desire’ in the questioner's mind. It cannot mean ‘his desire’ in the sense of ‘that which is desired by him’ (to\ poqou/menon schol.). This, at least, is the inference from all the evidence available: see nn. on O. C.267 O. C., 1604.

(2) to\ poqou=n e)kmaqei=n cannot mean, then, ‘to learn what is desired.’ e)kmaqei=n, if it is to govern to\ poqou=n, must be explained as having a pregnant sense, e)kplh=sai maqw/n, ‘to satisfy the desire by learning.’ Some analogies might be quoted ( Ant.399): but the phrase seems impossibly harsh.
(3) It remains, then, to take to\ poqou=n as an acc. of reference: ‘with regard to his curiosity, wishing to be fully informed.’ This is awkward; but it is not inconceivable.

ou)x e(kw/n, e(kou=si de\: the omission of me/n is like that in Ph.971ou)k ei)= kako\s su/, pro\s kakw=n d' a)ndrw=n maqw\n k.t.l. Cp. Ant.276(the fu/lac) pa/reimi d' a)/kwn ou)x e(kou=sin. Here, too, perhaps, the conceit is meant to be a trait of homely humour.

to
 *oi)/ths a)/tomon … leimw=n). The uplands of Oeta were sacred to Zeus (1191). Lands dedicated to gods might be cultivated for the profit of the temples (238 n.). Sometimes, however, they were left idle, or served merely for ornament. It was in such cases more especially that they were said to be a)neime/na. Cp. Plato Legg. 761 C ei)/ ti/ pou a)/lsos h)\ te/menos peri\ tau=ta a)neime/non h)=|, ta\ r(eu/mata a)fie/ntes ei)s au)ta\ ta\ tw=n qew=n i(era\ kosmh=sai. Athen. p. 503 C tou\s a)lsw/deis kai\ suski/ous to/pous tou\s toi=s qeoi=s a)neime/nous. So Demeter reproves the wood-cutter in her grove: Callim. Hymn. Cer. 47 te/knon, o(/tis ta\ qeoi=sin a)neime/na de/ndrea ko/pteis, | te/knon, e)li/nuson. The exquisite verses of Eur. ( Eur. Hipp.75 ff.) describe an inviolable meadow of Artemis: e)/nq' ou)/te poimh
 a)cioi= fe/rbein bota/, | ou)/t' h)=lqe/ pw si/dhros, a)ll' a)kh/raton | me/lissa leimw=n' h)rino
 die/rxetai. In a Cretan precinct of the Dictaean Zeus, it was forbidden to keep flocks or sheepfolds, to sow, or to cut timber (C. I. G. II. p. 1003). With a)/tomon cp. Hesych. a)dre/panon: a)/drepton: qeoi=s a)nakei/menon. *sofoklh=s.
a)lla\, ‘at least’; 320, O. C.1276 n.: su\n xro/nw|, Ai.306e)/mfrwn mo/lis pws su\n xro/nw| kaqi/statai: O. C.1653.

ei)/sw=e)/ndon, as 867, and oft.; but it properly implies motion (336, 492, 693, 900). The form ei)/sw is here used, as in O. C.18, without metrical necessity; and it has been held that the form e)/sw (which does not occur in Ar. ) was admitted in Tragedy only when metre required it: Soph. Ant.491 is, however, an exception.
ste/ghs … au)lh=s: the second word here is a mere synonym for the first; hence Kvíčala conjectures au)th=s: but see n. on O. C.1501.Those ‘within’ are her handmaidens; those ‘without,’ the Chorus.

o)/mma fh/mhs th=sde, a)/elpton e)moi\ a)nasxo/n: for the fig. sense of o)/mma, cp. O. T.987 n. As said of sunrise, etc., <*>sxw is more usual than a)ne/xw: yet cp. Bekk. Anecd. p. 400. 4 a)ne/xein: to\ a)nate/llein to\n h(/lion h)\ th\n selh/nhn.

The wording here, w(s … a)nasxo/n, is so suggestive of an acc. abs. ( O. C.380 n.), that it had occurred to me, as to Mr Blaydes, to ask whether th=sde ought not to be th=sd' o(\: but the answer, I think, is that this would practically make a)/elpton too prominent; the surprise would be more emphasised than the joy.

This lively ‘dance-song’ (u(po/rxhma) is the direct response of the Chorus to Deianeira's appeal (202 fwnh/sat)),—expressing their delight at the good news. As Dr. W. Christ, who calls it ‘a paean to Artemis and Apollo,’ justly remarks (Metrik § 443), its contents clearly point to a distribution of the verses between different singers. (1) The first part, down to v. 215 (*nu/mfas), is an invitation to song and dance; this would be given either by the coryphaeus, or by the leader of one semichorus. (2) The second part, vv. 216—220 (a)ei/rom)...a(/millan), is the response, delivered by the leader of the other semichorus. (3) Then, at v. 221, the whole Chorus joins in with the refrain of the paean, i)w\ i)w\ *paia/n. (4) The coryphaeus then gives the last three verses, which introduce the next scene.—For the metres, see Metrical Analysis.

a)nololuca/tw has been recognised by almost all recent critics and metrists as a certain correction of a)nololu/cete (L) or -ate. But I should keep the MS. do/mois, merely reading a( for o( with Erfurdt. The clue to a right interpretation here depends on two points in the context. (1) Deianeira has called for a joyous cry from the women in the house, and from those outside of it (203 f.). The first words of the Chorus accordingly appeal to the women in the house,—as is marked, not only by do/mois, but by e)festi/ois, adding that the men of the household are to join in. Then, at v. 210, o(mou= de\...paia=n)...w)= parqe/noi, the maidens of the Chorus are invited to raise the paean. (2) The words e)n de\ koino\s a)rse/nwn k.t.l. could not have been used unless a reference to women had preceded; it is not enough that it should follow, in w)= parqe/noi, at v. 210.

Hence we have to choose between these views, of which I prefer the first. (1) a( mello/numfos, ‘she whose nuptials are soon to come,’ is a poetical phrase for virgo nubilis, and denotes the maidens of the household generally. Nauck, reading do/mois...o( mello/numfos, gives this sense to it, but admits that the masc. (‘quisquis nubilis est’) is awkward: rather it is impossible. (2) a( mello/numfos=‘she who is soon to be (re-)united to a husband,’ i.e. Deianeira. This is a forcing of the Greek word which can easily be smoothed over in an English paraphrase, but which would probably have seemed very strange to a Greek. (3) Reading do/mos … o( mello/numfos, ‘the household of maidens,’ i.e. ‘the maidens of the household.’ This seems an untenable usage: moreover the metre condemns do/mos.—Another version of this reading, ‘the house which is soon to receive the husband,’ not only strains mello/numfos, but fails to supply the necessary antithesis to a)rse/nwn.

a)nololuca/tw: the o)lolugh/ or o)lolugmo/s was a cry to the gods, usually expressive of joy or hope, in prayer or sacrifice: and it is especially said of women (e.g. Il.6. 301, Od.3. 450: Aesch. Theb.268 etc.). But this verb denotes a cry of horror in Soph. El.750.

do/mois, rather ‘for the house’ (dat. of interest) than merely ‘in it’; cp. Aesch. Ag.27do/mois | o)lolugmo\n eu)fhmou=nta th=|de lampa/di | e)porqia/zein.—a)lalagai=s, probably due to Triclinius, has been received instead of a)lalai=s by many recent edd., in order that the first foot of the verse may be a tribrach (see Analysis Metr.). a)lalh/ was the more frequent form; but the other occurs as a v. l. in Eur. Phoen.335, as a)lalalai/ is a v. l. for a)lalai/ in Ar. Av.1761: and a loss of al or ag would of course have been easy. The a)lalh/ was a cry of triumph ( Soph. Ant.133 n.).

koino\s, fem.: cp. O. C.751 n. —The acc. to
 eu)f. *)ap. depends on i)/tw klagga\ as=u(mnei/tw: cp. El.123ta/keis ...oi)mwga
 | ...*)agame/mnona: ib. 556 ei) de/ m' w)=d' a)ei\ lo/gous | e)ch=rxes.—*)apo/llw, the shorter form of the acc., as in O. C.1091(lyr.): like *poseidw=, it was used chiefly after nh\ to
, ma\ to
.—prosta/tan: cp. El.637*foi=be prostath/rie,—with reference to his image being placed in front of houses. Paus. (1. 44. 2) saw at Megara a hieron of Apollo *prostath/rios. C. O. Müller (Dorians bk II. ch. 2 § 6) points out that the title prosta/ths was given to Apollo in the Ionian colonies of Miletus, on the shores of Pontus. So, as protector of roads, he is a)guieu/s. Artemis, too, is called prostathri/a, Aesch. Th.449.
a)na/get): cp. Soph. El.125i)/qi to\n au)to\n e)/geire go/on, | a)/nage polu/dakrun a(dona/n: id. Soph. Ph.1350a)na/get' a)na/gete kwkuto/n.

*)/artemin *)ortugi/an. The epithet was usu. understood as meaning ‘born in Ortygia.’ That name, like Nysa, was associated with various places (as Syracuse; Aetolia, schol. Apoll. Rh. 1. 419; Ephesus, Strabo 14. 639); but most frequently with Delos, as a name either for that island itself, or for some islet near it (Rheneia?): cp. Hom. h. Apoll. 16, which describes Artemis and Apollo as born, th
 me
 e)n *)ortugi/h|, to
 de\ kranah=| e)ni\ *dh/lw|. The epithet is parodied by Ar. Av.870*lhtoi= o)rtugomh/tra| (‘Quail mother’) Asteria, Leto's sister, was said to have escaped from Zeus by taking the form of a quail (o)/rtuc): Apollod.1. 2§ 2. One theory explains the name Ortygia as simply ‘abounding with quails’; another (Preller vol. I. p. 238) supposes that the o)/rtuc was taken as the type of a good mother; but the question remains uncertain.

Artemis was worshipped on the coasts near Malis (637 n.), but we have no proof that the name *)ortugi/a was specially given to her there. Perhaps the poet uses it here merely as one of her standing epithets.
e)lafabo/lon (like qanatafo/ra, O. T.180): see on O. C.1092 f.
a)mfi/puron: with a torch in each hand: see on O. T.207.
*nu/mfas: the *malia/des nu/mfai ( Ph.724 ff., n.) of Malian hills. woods, and streams.

a)ei/rom). Homeric verse admits the elision of ai in the verbal endings -mai, -sai (except in the infin.), -tai, -sqai. There is no other example of it in Tragedy; but it does not seem impossible that Sophocles should have used the familiar epic licence in a lyric passage. If we read a)ei/romai ou)d) a)pw/somai, a cyclic dactyl is substituted for a trochee; which does not seem very likely in this metrical context. (Cp. H. H. SchmidtJ. , Compositionslehre p. cxlii., and W. Christ, Metrik p. 378.) In the lemma of the schol. we certainly find a)ei/romai ou)d' a)pw/somai: but that proves nothing.—For the sense (metewri/zomai e)n tw=| xoreu/ein schol.), cp. Ar. Eccl. 1179 ai)/resq' a)/nw, i)ai\ eu)ai/.
