to\n au)lo/n, the instrument associated with religious enthusiasm, and more esp. with the Dionysiac worship. In Attic Tragedy the lyre seems to have been the older instrument (cp. Ar. Ran.1304Ar. Ran., 1285): but after the time of Aeschylus, at least, the au)lo/s was the regular one. Cp. MA. üller, Gr. Bühnenalt. p. 192 n. 3.— w)= tu/ranne clearly refers to the au)lo/s (for the change to the voc., cp. 99)—not to Apollo or Dionysus.—The words ta=s e)ma=s freno/s bring out the spiritual sense of tu/ranne, and express the compelling influence of the flute.
i)dou/ m): this m) must depend on i)dou/: that after eu)oi= depends on a)natara/ssei, the shriek being here literally an ‘interjection.’

o( kisso/s: the ivy was sacred to Dionysus, who is styled kisseu/s (Paus. 1. 31 § 6), kissofo/ros, kissoxai/ths, etc.: cp. Ovid Fasti 3. 767 hedera est gratissima Baccho. It was worn by bacchanals ( Eur. Bacch.81); though there seems to be no proof that it was worn, at least ordinarily, by tragic choreutae. Here, however, the Trachinian maidens imagine themselves to be bacchanals; the music of the au)lo/s suggests the spell of the kisso/s: and they speak as if the ivy on their brows was sending its mystic power through their whole frames, stirring them to the dance. Just so the laurel was the symbol of poetical inspiration.

bakxi/an … a(/millan, the Bacchic competition of eager dancers, i.e., the swift dance itself. a(/milla is oft. thus associated with eager speed: cp. O. C.1062r(imfarma/tois a(mi/llais: El.861xalargoi=s e)n a(mi/llais: Ant.1065tro/xous a(millhth=ras.—u(postre/fwn, lit., ‘whirling a little’ (cp. u(pokinei=n): i.e., just beginning to set the dance in movement. Not, ‘bringing back.’

i)w\ i)w\ *paia/n: the refrain (e)fu/mnion) of the paean: the whole Chorus would strike in here (cp. n. on 205—224). Dindorf adds a second *paia/n, on the assumption that the verse is an iambic dimeter, comparing Ar. Ach.1212, where the MSS. have i)w\ i)w\ *paia\n *paia/n (Metra Aeschyli 1. etc., p. 119). But the MS. reading is kept by most critics, including W. Christ (Metrik, § 443).

i(/d). The MSS. have i)/de i)/d). The hiatus would be justified by the slight pause after i)/de: cp. Ph.832i)/qi i)/qi moi paiw/n (n.). But most edd. agree with Dindorf in omitting i)/de: and they are probably right, since it disturbs the otherwise regular metre of vv. 221—224.
ta/d): the good tidings (180 ff.) of which their minds are full.
e)nargh= (cp. 11 n.) is strengthened by a)nti/prw|ra.

ou)de/ m' o)/mmatos froura\n parh=|lqe: the acc. of the part (=frourou=n o)/mma) follows the pers. pron.; cp. Ph.1301me/qes me...xei=ra. The subject to parh=lqe (‘this sight’) is easily supplied from ta/d) in 223. For the phrase, cp. Ph.151frourei=n o)/mm) (‘that the eye should watch’). The MS. froura\ is possible: the sense would then be, ‘nor has the task of watching with the eye escaped my care.’ But the phrase appears somewhat less natural; and the nom. froura\ may have been generated by parh=lqe.— mh\ leu/ssein: it is unnecessary to insert ou): cp. 90 n.
prou)nne/pw, primum iubeo, with acc. and inf., like le/gw in 137 (n.), and e)nne/pw in O. T.350.
fe/reis: for the change to direct address, cp. O. C.1353 f. (tou=d) followed by w)= ka/kiste). For kai\ emphasizing the verb, cp. O. T.851ei) d' ou)=n ti ka)ktre/poito.

a)ll) replies to the doubt implied in xarto\n ei)/ ti kai\ fe/reis. Hence the two co-ordinated clauses are here equally important: this is not a case in which the main stress is on the clause with de/ (as in O. C.1536, Ph.503).

kat' e)/rgou kth=sin. As ni/kh can be called a kth=ma ( Ph.81), and as e)/rgon itself often=‘a notable deed’ ( Ant.730 n.), so kekth=sqai e)/rgon might well mean, ‘to have made an achievement one's own.’ The phrase in the text, then, seems sound, as meaning, ‘the achievement of the deed’ (=‘the deed achieved’). We cannot understand, ‘the acquisition (booty) made by the deed.’
a)/ndra ga\r k.t.l.: ga/r refers to kat' e)/rgou kth=sin: the welcome befits the deed, for the deed has prospered.

kalw=s pra/ssont) k.t.l.: the sensitive Greek was quick to see his good or bad fortune mirrored in the behaviour of his neighbours: cp. n. on Ph.1353.We must not, then, alter kalw=s to kala/,—a change which Nauck thinks ‘necessary.’

a(\ prw=ta bou/lomai, sc. dida/skesqai. For the plur., cp. 64.—*(hrakle/a, ¯˘˘¯: it is needless to assume synizesis, since a proper name excuses an anapaest in any foot except the 6th. Another choriambic name (*)antigo/nh) holds the same place in O. C.507.Below, in v. 476—the only other place where Soph. has the acc. of *(hraklh=s—most editors write *(hraklh= (L having h(raklei=), since *(hrakle/a, at the end of a verse, must be a trisyllable, and the synizesis of -ea, in that position, would be awkward. So, too, in Ar. Th.26, where the Ravenna MS. has *(hrakle/a at the end of the v., Dind. writes *(hraklh=. In Attic inscriptions the acc. of proper names in -klh=s is regularly -kle/a down to c. 300 B.C.; later it is -klh=n: while -klh= does not occur. The -klh= form is frequent, however, in nonAttic inscr. (as those of Delos, Delphi, Sparta), though not before 228 B.C. (Meisterhans, p. 58).
e)/gwge/ toi: for ge/ toi, cp. O. C.1324.

e)/leipon: 76 n.—In the sequel, Deianeira dies before Heracles is brought home. The answer of Lichas is unconsciously evasive; it is also undesignedly suggestive of a contrast between the hero's present state, and that in which he is to arrive, no/sw| baru/s.—i)sxu/onta/ te kai\ zw=nta. The word zw=nta was prompted by the form of D. 's question; and the double copula, te kai/, links i)sxu/onta with it more closely than the following words are linked by the simple kai/. Hence the whole phrase, ‘strong as well as alive,’=‘not only alive, but strong.’— qa/llonta is more than i)sxu/onta, as implying radiant health: cp. Soph. El.952bi/w| | qa/llont): I. A. 1223 ff. a)=ra/ s' ... o)/yomai | zw=sa/n te kai\ qa/llousan;—kou) no/sw| baru/n: cp. O. T.58gnwta\ kou)k a)/gnwta (n.).

pou= gh=s (e)/leipes), (ei)/te) patrw/|as ei)/te barba/rou (e)/leipes); where did you leave him,—whether it was in Greece or abroad that you left him? ei)/te, either doubled or single, is thus used, with ellipse of the verb, when a statement or a question is to include two alternative suppositions: cp. Legg. 844 D o(\s a)\n a)groi/kou o)pw/ras geu/shtai, botru/wn ei(/te kai\ su/kwn [sc. e)geu/sato],...ei)/t' e)n toi=s au(tou= xwri/ois ei)/te kai\ e)n a)/llwn,...penth/konta o)feile/tw draxma/s. So, with a single ei)/te, O. T.517: with doubled ei)/te, ib. 194 O. T., 1049.In such sentences ei)/te becomes practically equivalent to h)/. But it cannot, of course, replace h)/ in a direct statement or question: i.e., ‘This is either good or bad,’ could not be rendered, tou=to ei)/t' a)gaqo\n ei)/te kako/n e)sti. Hence the following punctuation, adopted by Dindorf, is impossible:

pou= gh=s; patrw/|as ei)/te barba/rou; le/ge. This would require h)\ instead of ei)/te. (Paley, who follows Dindorf, seems to have felt a misgiving; ‘The use of ei)/te for h)\,’ he says, ‘is remarkable.’)—Ellendt prefers a third way of pointing, which L (see cr. n.) also suggests:
pou= gh=s; patrw/|as ei)/te barba/rou, le/ge (‘say whether...’). The objection to this is that it throws too much emphasis on the distinction between Greek and foreign soil.

patrw/|as (gh=s)=patri/dos (as in O. C.1292 etc.), i.e. Hellas, as the land of his ancestors (not as ‘the land of his father Zeus’). Cp. 1060 ou)/q' *(ella\s ou)/t' a)/glwssos. The rumours reported by Hyllus spoke of Heracles as freed from Omphalè, but left it doubtful whether he was yet in Euboea (69—75).

*eu)boi/s: 74 n. The northwestern extremity of Euboea is a small peninsula, which runs out westward just opposite the mouth of the Malian Gulf. It ends in the promontory once called *kh/naion, and now Cape Litháda. Zeus *kh/naios was worshipped on the neighbouring hill-tops (upwards of 2800 ft. in height), as on so many other summits (cp. Ph.1040 n.): Aesch. fr. 29 *eu)boi=da ka/mptwn a)mfi\ *khnai/ou *dio\s | a)kth/n. The legendary Oechalia, which Heracles sacked, was not near Cenaeum, but some 50 miles S. E. of it, in the territory of Eretria (Hecataeus ap. Paus.4. 2. 3: Strabo 10 p. 448). Sophocles shows his knowledge of this tradition by his reference to the hero's march from Oechalia to Cenaeum (750 ei(=rpe).

o(ri/zetai bwmou\s: the verb denotes properly the act of tracing the temenos in which the altars were to stand. Cp. Her.3. 142*dio\s...bwmo\n i(dru/sato kai\ te/menos peri\ au)to\n ou)/rise. In v. 754 the act. o(ri/zei is used: the midd. occurs in Xen. An.7. 5. 13sth/las o(risa/menoi. The plur. bwmou\s (as in 754, 993) might be used of a single altar (cp. Ant.1006), but here prob. denotes several,—the sacrifice being on so great a scale (760 ff.).

te/lh t' e)/gkarpa, tributes (or dues) of fruits; i.e., the revenues derived from a temenos containing fruit-trees or capable of yielding crops. The poet can say, o( ri/zetai te/lh e)/gkarpa, because he is thinking of the temenos itself (cp. 754). Such lands were sometimes cultivated under the direct control of the priests; sometimes they were let to tenants: cp. Plat. Legg 759 E tami/as...kai\ temenw=n kai\ karp<*> tou/twn kai\ misqw/sewn kuri/ous. C. I. G. 4474 (a kw/mh is attached to a shrine of Zeus), o(/pws h( a)po\ tau/ths pro/sodos a)nal<*> skhtai ei)s ta\s kata\ mh=nas sunteloume/n<*> qusi/as kai\ ta)/lla ta\ pro\s au)/chsin tou= i(eroi/ suntei/nonta k.t.l.

eu)ktai=a … h)\ )po\ mantei/as: <*> may have vowed them before the event: or, after it, an oracle may have demanded them. Thus, after the battle of Salamis, the Delphian Apollo claimed a thank-offering from the Aeginetans (Her. 8.122).

fai/nwn, presenting them, in fulfillment of the promise. This is a rare sense of the verb, but somewhat like that in O. C. 721 nu=n so\n ta\ lampra\ tau=ta dh\ fai/nein e)/ph (n.), ‘to make those bright praise<*> seen in deeds.’
eu)xai=s, causal dat.: cp. 1127<*> O. C.332 f.
a)na/staton, proleptic: cp. 106 a)dakru/twn.
w(=n: for the attract., cp. O. C.35<*>
e)n o)/mmasin: Ant.764e)n <*> o(rw=n (n.).

tou= pot' ei)si\: schol. <*> ei)si\ despo/tou. Their appearance in charge of the herald shows that they are captives, and consequently slaves (302): she asks, then, who is their captor. Hence a slight emphasis falls on e)kei=nos (244).
oi)ktrai\ ga/r: ‘(I ask this,) for they deserve pity, unless their present plight deceives me,’—i.e., unless it excites greater pity than I should feel if I knew more.

cumforai\ is much better than the v.l. cumfora=|, which would easily arise from a wish to have the same subject in both clauses. When a common word for fraud, such as kle/ptein, is used in the figurative sense, ‘to produce an illusion,’ it is evidently fitter that the subject to the verb should not be a human being. Cp. Ant.681ei) mh\ tw=| xro/nw| kekle/mmeqa: ib. 1218 qeoi=si kle/ptomai.

e)cei/leq): the midd. here suits au(tw=|: but in ref. to qeoi=s the act. e)cei=len would have been more usual, cp. Ph.1431 n.: [Eur. ] Rhes. 470 qeoi=si/ t' a)kroqi/ni) e)ce/lh|s: Thuc.3. 50klh/rous ... th=s gh=s ... toi=s qeoi=s i(erou\s e)cei=lon.—krito/n: so in Soph. Ai.1302Hesionè is the e)/kkriton dw/rhma given to Telamon as a prize of valour. Prisoners of war often became i(ero/douloi in temples (cp. Her.6. 134: Paus.3. 18. 3).
h)= ka)pi\: for h)= kai/ in a question, cp. O. T.368.
a)/skopon, ‘not to be looked for,’ i.e., here, longer than could possibly have been expected. Cp. El.864a)/skopos a( lw/ba: Ph.1111n.
h(merw=n goes with a)nh/riqmon, not with xro/non: ‘without number of days,’=‘extending to countless days.’ Cp. Ai.601 f. mhnw=n | a)nh/riqmos: O. C.677 n.

The form a)nh/riqmos is of a frequent type. When the second part of a compound adj. has a disyllabic stem (usu. a verbal stem), beginning with a short vowel, this vowel may be lengthened. Such forms were oft. convenient in poetry (as a)nh/rotos, eu)h/nemos, filh/retmos), but many of them were equally current in good prose (as a)nh/kestos, a)nh/nutos, a)nhlew=s, eu)w/numos). The restriction of a)nh/riqmos to classical poetry and late prose (as Athen. p. 253 F) is not due to 1ts form, but to the fact that classical prose preferred a)nari/qmhtos. Tragedy uses a)na/riqmos (a^) where it suits the metre (as in El.225). In Theocr. 15. 45 a)na/riqmoi (a_) is Doric for a)nh/riqmoi.
to\n me\n plei=ston … xro/non: i.e., twelve of the fifteen months (44).— w(s fh/s' au)to/s: cp. 253 w(s au)to\s le/gei. It would have seemed incredible without such testimony.

e)mpolhqei/s may be freely rendered, ‘sold into bondage,’ but its literal sense is rather, ‘made merchandise of,’ or, ‘bought.’ Hesychius, indeed, explains h)mpo/lhsen by a)pe/doto: but, though e)cempola=n=‘to sell off,’ e)mpola=n as=‘to sell’ lacks classical evidence. (Cp. Ph.417e)mpolhto/s, ‘bought.’) praqh=nai (252), pepra=sqai were the proper terms for ‘to be sold’ (as a slave).
tou= lo/gou … fqo/non, dislike (felt by the hearer for the narrator) on account of the telling.
prosei=nai, abs., to be an attendant circumstance ( Ant.1252 n.),—to attend upon the act (of telling).

o(/tou, neut.: (in the case of anything) of which Zeus is seen to be the doer. Cp. Thuc.6. 14to\ kalw=s a)/rcai tou=t' ei)=nai, o(\s a)\n th\n patri/da w)felh/sh|. We cannot make o(/tou masc. (relat. to tou= lo/gou), because o( lo/gos here denotes, not the reported deed, but the (mere) act of reporting it, as contrasted with the causing of it.
pra/ktwr fanh=|: cp. 862: for o(/tou without a)/n, cp. O. T.1231 n. The agency of Zeus is explained below O. T., 274 ff.

The meaning is:—‘You may think that the humiliation of Heracles ought not to be related by his servant to his wife. But this humiliation was imposed by Zeus himself, and can therefore be related without reflecting upon Heracles.’

kei=nos de\: de\ resumes the story after the parenthetic apology (tou= lo/gou... fanh=|): cp. kei=noi d) in 281. Wunder rejects these two verses, (1) because they repeat the substance of vv. 248—250, and (2) because Lichas ought not to pain his mistress by mentioning Omphalè. But (1) these vv. explain e)n *ludoi=s, and define xro/non: (2) the herald's motive for silence concerning Iolè does not apply to the case of Omphalè. Hyllus had already mentioned ‘the Lydian woman’ to his mother (70).

praqei\s … *)omfa/lh|. Hermes, by command of Zeus, took Heracles to Lydia, and sold him in the slave-market to Omphalè: the price was paid to Eurytus, as a poinh/ for the murder of Iphitus ( Apollod.2. 6. 2).

Two tragic poets of the fifth century B.C., Ionof Chios and Achaeus, had written an *)omfa/lh saturikh/. Two poets of the Middle Comedy, Antiphanes (Athen. 112 C) and Cratinus jun. (id. 669 B) wrote an *)omfa/lh, picturing Heracles abandoned to sensuous pleasures. Itis the more noteworthy how Sophocles, in lightly touching on this episode, has guarded his hero's dignity. For he speaks only of servile labours for the Lydian taskmistress (70 It, 356); and marks how the bondsman felt his disgrace (254).

e)niauto\n. The popular version spoke of three years. This was the term assigned by the mythographer Herodorus (c. 430 B.C.?), acc. to the schol.; as it is by Apollodorus (2. 6. 2). If this change was due to Sophocles, we can see the artistic motive. Three months or so, after the bondage, were required for the war in Euboea. If the poet had made Heracles go to Lydia 39, instead of 15, months before his death, there would have been less room for those hopes which contend with fears in the opening scene of the Trachiniae.
labw\n, having incurred: cp. fr. 742 zhmi/an | labei=n: ( O. T.1494o)nei/dh lamba/nwn is not exactly similar:) Thuc.2. 18ai)ti/an...e)/laben.

o(/rkon au(tw=| prosbalw\n: cp. Her.1. 146sfi/si au)th=|si o(/rkous e)ph/lasan: id. 6. 74 o(/rkous prosa/gwn sfi h)= me\n e(/yesqai k.t.l.—diw/mosen. With the exception of the perf. ( Lycurg. § 127), the act. voice is rarer than the midd. (378, Soph. Ai.1233).
h)= mh\n: Ph.593.

to
 a)gxisth=ra tou=de tou= pa/qous, the man who had brought this calamity near to him,—brought it upon him: since Eurytus, by insulting him, had provoked him to slay Iphitus,—the crime for which this pa/qos was the penalty. a)gxisth/r, in this sense, presupposes a trans. a)gxi/zein. That verb does not occur, but would be analogous to e)ggi/zein: and the latter, though usu. intrans., is trans. in Polyb. 8. 6 e)ggi/santes th=| gh=| ta\s nau=s. Compare, too, the phrases of converse form: Il.5. 766h(/ e( ma/list' ei)/wqe kakh=|s o)du/nh|si pela/zein: Aesch. P. V.155desmoi=s...pela/sas (me).—Others understand :—‘the man most nearly concerned in this calamity.’ This is the general sense intended by the schol.: to
 ai)/tion kai\ sxedo
 au)to
 poihsanta tou= pa/qous (where the words kai\... poih/santa are parenthetical): i.e., ‘the (ultimate) cause, and almost the actual author, of the calamity.’ But, though a)gxisth/r might naturally mean, ‘nearest kinsman’ (= a)gxisteu/s), it would be strange to say, a)gxisth tou= pa/qous, as= ‘the person who had most to do with’ that pa/qos.
No emendation is probable. Nauck's au)to/xeira would be possible only if Eurytus had himself sent Heracles into slavery.

cu\n paidi\ kai\ gunaiki\, i.e., with his whole family. Eurytus had several children (266), but the prosaic conjecture paisi\ would only weaken the phrase. Schneidewin cp. Od.9. 199 ou(/neka/ min su\n paidi\ perisxo/meq' h)de\ gunaiki/: where paisi\ is a v.l. This may be parallel: there is nothing, however, to show that the sing. cannot there be taken literally. For the collective sing., cp. Aesch. Theb.197a)nh\r gunh/ te xw(/ ti tw=n metai/xmion.— doulw/sein: the prose word, in ref. to prisoners of war, was not doulou=n, but a)ndrapodi/zein: hence Thuc.8. 28ta\ a)ndra/poda pa/nta kai\ dou=la kai\ e)leu/qera (referring to their previous condition).
e)/ti, as oft. in threats: El.66: Aesch. P. V.908h)= mh\n e)/ti *zeu/s, kai/per au)qa/dh fronw=n, | tapeino\s e)/stai.
kou)x h(li/wse tou)/pos: modelled on the Homeric ou)d' a(li/wse be/los ( Il.16. 737), with a reminiscence also of ou)d' a(/lion e)/pos e)/ssetai (ib. 24. 92).

o(/q' a(gno\s h)=n. The Homeric poems know nothing of a ritual for purification from homicide: the blood-shedder either flies into exile ( Il.24. 480 ff.), or prevails on the kinsfolk of the slain to accept a poinh/ (ib. 9. 632 ff.), and stays at home. Here the schol. supposes that, by a(gno/s, Sophocles alludes simply to the year of exile having expired. This may be so; but it is more probable that Heracles is conceived as also undergoing a formal ka/qarsis. According to other writers, he received this from Deiphobus at Amyclae, after vainly seeking it from Neleus at Pylos ( Apollod.2. 6. 2: Diod.4. 31). So Aesch. makes the exile Orestes receive the kaqarmoi\ xoirokto/noi ( Aesch. Eum.283Aesch. Eum., 449). The homicide who withdrew into banishment was said a)peniauti/zein (or a)peniautei=n),—a word not always restricted to one year: Legg. 868 D e)niautou\s trei=s a)peniautei=n. Cp. ib. E kaqai/resqai me\n tou\s au)tou\s kaqarmou/s, trietei=s de\ a)peniauth/seis diatelei=n. The rites of ka/qarsis for homicide are fully described by Apoll. Rhod., 4. 693—717.

strato
 … e)pakto
: the adj. here merely=ce/non, ‘alien,’ i.e., not belonging to his own home. e)pakto/s is prop. said of allies, or mercenaries, whom a foreign state calls in (e)pa/getai) to its aid: cp. O.C. 1525 n. But here it denotes the allies of an exile,—just as Polyneices is said to bring a stra/teum' e)pakto
 against his country ( Aesch. Theb.583).— Apollod.2. 7. 7 describes this army as composed of Arcadians, Malians, and Epicnemidian Lo crians: but those who cite him here have not observed that he supposes Heracles to make the war from Trachis.
e)/rxetai with acc. of place: O. C.89, El.893.

po/lin th
 *eu)rutei/a/n: cp. O. T.267tw=| *labdakei/w| paidi\ (n.): ib. 450 fo/non | to
 *lai+/eion.—to/nde, as if th
 *eu)ru/tou had gone before: so in Il.5. 640o(/s refers to bi/hn *(hraklhei/hn: in O. C.942au)tou\s to po/lin in 939: in Ph.1364oi(/ ge to *troi/an in 1363: in El.963tw=nde to a)/lektra a)nume/naia/ te.—metai/tion: Zeus was primarily ai)/tios, but Eurytus was the only mortal who had a part in it.

e)fe/stion, added to e)s do/mous, marks how the hospitality of the hearth had been violated. Cp. Eur. Med.713de/cai de\ xw/ra| kai\ do/mois e)fe/stion. The stranger who had been received as an inmate was under the protection of *zeu/s, both *ce/nios and *)efe/stios ( Soph. Ai.492). For the phrase e)lqo/nt' … e)fe/stion, cp. Hom. Od.23. 55h)=lqe me\n au)to\s zwo\s e)fe/stios.
ce/non palaio\n o)/nta: Eurytus was said to have taught Heracles the use of the bow (Theocr. 24. 106 f.).

e)perro/qhse. This verb can denote the blended sound of many voices ( Aesch. Ch.458); esp., the responsive shout of a crowd ( Eur. Hec.553, Eur. Or.901). Here it refers to loud and vehement railing: cp. Soph. Ant.259lo/goi...e)rro/qoun kakoi/ (n.), and ib. 413 e)pirro/qois | kakoi=sin.

From e)perro/qhse a verb of more general sense, such as u(/brise, is to be supplied with a)thra=| freni/. (For the sense of a)thra=|, cp. Ph.1272: Paley wrongly takes it as= ‘deluded.’) This is the easier, since the antithesis between go/gois and freni/ at once suggests a distinction between affronts expressed in speech and those which showed the malicious intention in another way, viz., by acts: two examples of the verbal insults are given, and then one of the other kind (dei/pnois d) k.t.l.). Instances of zeugma quite as bold occur elsewhere in poetry; for the Greek mind was quick to seize the hint of a contrast, and did not always require full expression of it: e.g., Od.15. 374e)k d' a)/ra despoi/nhs ou) mei/lixon e)/stin a)kou=sai | ou)/t' e)/pos ou)/te ti e)/rgon (sc. paqei=n): ib. 20. 312 f. mh/lwn sfazome/nwn oi)/noio/ te pinome/noio | kai\ si/tou (sc. e)sqiome/nou). In these examples, just as here, the antithesis of nouns supersedes an explicit antithesis of verbs.

Others understand :—‘railed against him both with (rude) words and with evil intent.’ To this there are two objections. (1) Since all the supposed affronts are then verbal, the antithesis would require an epithet for lo/gois (such as ai)sxroi=s), to balance a)thra=|. (2) The formula polla\ me\n … polla\ de/ would be out of place, unless two classes of verbal taunts were distinguished by the presence or absence of a spiteful intent; but the context excludes such a distinction.
The text is clearly (I think) sound. It is unwarrantable, as it is undesirable, to strike out polla\ d' … xeroi=n me\n (see cr. n.). Again, it is improbable that a verse has been lost after v. 264.

le/gwn xeroi=n me\n: metre has influenced the place of me/n, which answers to de\ in 267, and ought to come next after le/gwn: cp. Ph.919sw=sai kakou= me\n prw=ta tou=d), e)/peita de\ | ...porqh=sai.—a)/fukta … be/lh, those which Heracles had received from Apollo, and which he bequeathed to Philoctetes ( Ph.198 n.: ib. 105).

tw=n w(=n te/knwn: the sons were four in number, acc. to Hesiod (fr. 70, ap. schol. here),— *dhi/wn, *klu/tios, *toceu/s, *)/ifitos. An ancient vase from Caere, which depicts the reception of Heracles by Eurytus and his family, gives the names of three sons as *klu/tios, *to/cos, *didai/vwn (Preller II. 226 n. 3). Creophylus, the author of the *oi)xali/as a(/lwsis, named only two sons (schol.).

lei/poito: cp. Thuc.6. 72a)nh\r kai\ e)s ta)/lla cu/nesin ou)deno\s leipo/menos.—pro\s to/cou kri/sin: for the prep., cp. Soph. Ph.1306kakou\s | ...pro\s ai)xmh/n: Her.1. 99(ou)k) e)s a)ndragaqi/hn leipo/menoi. By to/cou kri/sis is meant a trial (of the competitors) which the bow decides. kri/sis thus almost =a)gw/n: cp. Soph. Ph.1050 n. There was a legend that Eurytus offered the hand of his daughter Iolè as a prize for the man who should surpass him and his sons in archery. Heracles conquered, but Eurytus broke his promise (schol.: Apoll. 2. 6. 1).—Eurytus, like his father Melaneus, was a great archer. In Hom. Od.8. 226 ff. he challenges Apollo, and is slain by him. The bow of Eurytus, inherited by Iphitus, was given by the latter to Odysseus (ib. 21. 31 ff.).

fwnei= de\, instead of fwnw=n de\ (answering to le/gwn...me
): cp. El.190oi)konomw= qala/mous patro/s, w(=de me
 | a)eikei= su
 stola=|, | kenai=s d' a)mfi/stamai trape/zais (instead of a)mfistame/nh): O. C.351 n. This very trait confirms the soundness of the MS. text. For the historic pres., standing between e)perro/qhse and e)/rriyen, cp. Ant.269le/gei, between h)=n (268) and prou)/treyen (270). The optat. r(ai/oito is admissible (instead of r(ai/etai), because the historic present counts as a secondary tense: cp. Her.1. 63boulh
... e)pitexna=tai, o(/kws mh/te a(lisqei=en k.t.l.: Lys. or. 12 § 12 e)rwtw=sin o(/ph| badi/zoimen: o( d' e)/fasken k.t.l.
a)ndro\s … e)leuqe/rou with dou=los (not with r(ai/oito, as gen. of agent, like plhgei\s qugatro\s th=s e)mh=s, Eur. Or.497): e)leuqe/rou serves merely to emphasise dou=los by contrast.
r(ai/oito: Od.6. 325e)pei\ pa/ros ou)/ pot' a)/kousas | r(aiome/nou, o(/te m' e)/rraien kluto\s e)nnosi/gaios.

The conject. fanei\s de\ dou=los a)ndros a)nt) e)leuqe/rou (cr. n.) has been received by several edd., who cite Ai.1020dou=los lo/goisin a)nt' e)leuqe/rou fanei/s. There, however, the force of fanei/s depends on lo/goisin: ‘represented,’ ‘made out,’ in his taunting words, to be a slave. Here fanei/s would mean simply, ‘found to be.’
dei/pnois, dat. of the occasion: cp. Plat. Symp. 174 A toi=s e)piniki/ois: for the plur., cp. O.T. 779, El.203.

w)|nwme/nos, Heracles. Cp. Eur. Alc.756(of Heracles) poth=ra d' e)n xei/ressi ki/ssinon labw\n | pi/nei melai/nhs mhtro\s eu)/zwron me/qu, | e(/ws e)qe/rmhn' au)to\n a)mfiba=sa flo\c | oi)/nou: ste/fei de\ kra=ta mursi/nhs kla/dois | a)/mous' u(laktw=n. The a)thra\ frh/n (264) of Eurytus seized this opportunity of inflicting an insult.

e)/rriyen e)kto\s au)to/n. A Greek vase, found in Sicily, quaintly illustrates some such incident. The inebriated Heracles is lying on his back outside a closed door, from above which an old woman is pouring cold water upon him. Satyrs and maenads appear at each side of the group. (Benndorf, Gr. und Sicilische Vasenbilder pl. 44.) I am indebted for this reference to Mr MurrayS. , of the British Museum.
w(=n e)/xwn xo/lon: for the causal gen. cp. Ph.327 n.
au)=qis, at a later time: Ant.1204 n.

*tirunqi/an … klitu/n. We cannot be sure that Sophocles had any clear picture of the place before his mind; but his phrase, at least, is not unsuitable. klitu/s, ‘slope,’ does not necessarily imply great elevation. The site of Tiryns is a ridge of limestone rock on the Argolic Gulf (cp. 1151), in which, at some prehistoric time, it formed an island. The length of this ridge, from N. to S. , is about 328 yards: its width about 109. The upper citadel of Tiryns was at the southern end, where the rock attains a height of about 72 feet above sea-level, and of 59 feet above the present surface of the plain. North of this was the lower citadel; and the whole was surrounded by those massive ‘Cyclopean’ walls from which Tiryns derived its Homeric epithet ( Il.2. 559), teixio/essa. See Schliemann's Tiryns, p. 177. Such a site, though not steep or lofty, might correctly be described as the *tirunqi/a klitu/s.—For the u^ in klitu/n, cp. Ant.1144 n., and ib. 1127 lignu/s: so nhdu/s ( Eur. Andr.356 etc.).

i(/ppous noma/das: acc. to Od.21. 22, Iphitus came, i(/ppous dizh/menos, ai(/ oi( o)/lonto | dw/deka qh/leiai, u(po\ d' h(mi/onoi talaergoi/: but Apollod.2. 6. 2 says, klapeisw=n e)c *eu)boi/as u(po\ *au)tolu/kou bow=n. For noma/das, ‘wandering,’ cp. O.T. 1350 n.

a)/llos' … o)/mma, qate/ra| de\ nou=n e)/xont): he was gazing forth from the high place, in the hope of descrying his horses; and, as he could not see them, his thought was wandering to other places where they might perhaps be. Cp. Diod. Sic. 4. 31: Heracles commands Iphitus, a)fora=n, mh/ pou nemo/menai tugxa/nousin: ou) duname/nou de\ katanoh=sai tou= *)ifi/tou k.t.l. Thus qate/ra| does not merely repeat a)/llose, but is opposed to it: as in Her.1. 32a)/llo me\n e)/xei to e(te/rou de\ e)pide/etai. Cp. Theages 129 C boulo/meno/s me laqei=n a)ne/sth,...e)pithrh/sas a)/llose to\n nou=n e)/xonta.

purgw/dous plako/s. The current version spoke of Heracles as hurling Iphitus from a wall or tower. Pherecydes the logographer (5th cent. B.C.) is quoted to this effect (schol. Od.21. 23): to
 de\ *(hrakle/a mhxanh=| tini kai\ strathgi/a| sunefelkusa/menon au)to
 a)/gein ei)s e)pi/krhmnon tei=xos. Apollod.2. 6. 2manei\s de\ au)=qis (Heracles) a)po\ tw=n *tirunqi/wn e)/rriyen au)to
 teixw=n. Diod. Sic. 4. 31 tou=ton me
 a)nabiba/sas o( *(hraklh=s e)pi/ tina pu/rgon u(yhlo
 e)ke/leusen a)fora=n. The word pu/rgos oft.=a city-wall with its towers ( O. T.56 n.). Thus it would satisfy all these statements to suppose that Iphitus was thrown from some high part of the walls which encompassed Tiryns teixio/essa. And by purgw/dhs pla/c Sophocles may well have meant ‘the summit of a tower-like building.’ Modern critics have usually held that he meant ‘the top of a towering rock or cliff’: and so the schol. here explains, u(yhlou= o)/rous. We need not press the argument that it is not well-suited to the locality. But it may be doubted whether a Greek poet would have compared a rock or cliff to a pu/rgos merely because it was high and steep. On the other hand, where purgoeidh/s occurs elsewhere, it refers to a building. Josephus Bell. Iud. 5. 5. 8 (the *)antwni/a, or citadel of Jerusalem) purgoeidh\s...ou)=sa to\ pa=n sxh=ma. Dion Cassius 74. 5 pura\ purgoeidh/s. And it is consonant with the style of Tragedy that, in regard to such a detail, the vaguer phrase purgw/dhs pla/c should be preferred to pla\c pu/rgou.

o( tw=n a(pa/ntwn k.t.l. The emphasis of this verse is designed (like the comment in 250 f.) to bring out the higher and more soothing aspect of the doom suffered by Heracles.—For the strengthening art. with a(pa/ntwn, cp. Aesch. P. V.483ta\s a(pa/sas...no/sous.—path\r *)olu/mpios, not ou(lu/mpios (cr. n.), since the words form a single notion ( Soph. O. T.1199 n.).

prato/n nin e)ce/pemyen, sent him out of the country to be sold (cp. 252 n.): the adj. is proleptic (106 n.).— ou)d' h)ne/sxeto, ‘and did not tolerate’ (his deed): the verb is really absol. (as in Ai.75ou) si=g' a)ne/cei;), though it is easy to supply an acc.: o(qou/nek)=‘because,’ as in 571.—Others understand, ‘brooked not that (cp. 813) he had slain him.’— mou=non: O. T.1418 n.
h)mu/nato, avenged himself: O.C. 873 e)/rgois peponqw\s r(h/masi/n s' a)mu/nomai. The u(/bris of Eurytus would have justified Heracles in challenging Iphitus to open combat.
xeiroume/nw| tw=| *(hraklei= to\n *)/ifiton: for this midd., cp. 1109: O.C. 950, 1009: Ph.92.Of the pass., Sophocles has only xeirwqei/s (below Ph., 1057, and O. C.903).
ou)de\ dai/mones, i.e., they like it as little as mortals do: for the adverbial ou)de/ after ou), cp. O. T.287, El.595, Ai.1242.
kei=noi d): for the resumptive de/, cp. 252.

u(perxli/ontes: this form, attested by the first hand in L and by the schol. (cr. n.), is confirmed by the fact that Aesch. twice uses xli/ein with ref. to insolent triumph. Aesch. Cho.137e)n toi=si soi=s po/noisi xli/ousin me/ga: Aesch. Suppl.914ka/rbanos w)\n d' *(/ellhsin e)gxli/eis a)/gan. The compound with u(pe/r does not occur elsewhere.

e)k glw/sshs kakh=s: here e)k is virtually ‘with’: cp. 875: O. T.528e)c o)mma/twn o)rqw=n k.t.l. (n.): O. C.486e)c eu)menw=n | ste/rnwn de/xesqai. This is better than to take e)k as=‘in consequence of.’
282 For au)toi\ me\n after kei=noi and before po/lis de\, cp. O. C.1008kle/yas... e)me\ | au)to/n t' e)xeirou= ta\s ko/ras t' oi)/xei labw/n: and ib. 462 (n.).
oi)kh/tores: 1161: Ai.517*(/aidou qanasi/mous oi)kh/toras.
ta/sde, instead of ai(/de, by attract. to a(/sper: see on O. T.449.— e)c o)lbi/wn: O. T.454tuflo\s...e)k dedorko/tos: so below O. T., 619 O. T., 1075.

xwrou=si pro\s se/. The accentuation pro\s se/, which is L's, seems right, as implying, ‘to thee, their new mistress.’ If we wrote pro/s se, the emphasis would fall wholly on v. 284: ‘these, who are coming to thee, are now slaves.’
po/sis te … e)gw\ de\: the antithesis between e)fei=to and telw= seems to warrant us in keeping de/ here (instead of changing it to te): cp. 143 n.

a(gna\ qu/mata: cp. Od.21. 258e(orth\ toi=o qeoi=o | a(gnh/: Eur. Ion243a(gna\ *loci/ou xrhsth/ria.—patrw/|w| *zhni\, Zeus as the god of his fathers, the protector of his race, rather than with ref. to the personal relationship: so again in 753.— th=s a(lw/sews, for it, causal gen. (here akin to the gen. of price), with the whole phrase qu/mata r(e/ch|: cp. O.T. 47 w(s se\ nu=n me\n h(/de gh= | swth=ra klh/|zei th=s pa/ros proqumi/as.
fro/nei nin w(s h(/conta: for the redundant nin (after au)to\n d' e)kei=non), cp. O. T.248(n.). For w(s prefixed to the partic., after an imperative verb of thinking or knowing, Ph.253, O. T.848.
kalw=s lexqe/ntos, ‘auspiciously,’ ‘happily,’ told; since the news is good. kalw=s le/gein more usually means to speak (1) sensibly, or (2) speciously, Ant.1047.
nu=n soi te/ryis e)mfanh\s kurei=, now thy joy is manifest, i.e., is assured beyond all doubt (cp. 223 f.).
tw=n me\n, the herald and the captives: ta\ de\, the news that Heracles will soon return. For the gen. absol. co-ordinated with a partic. in another case, cp. O. C.737 n.
pandi/kw| freni/, ‘with a thoroughly justified feeling’ (not, ‘with my whole heart’): cp. 611 n. The adj. occurs only here.

th=|de, sc. th=| pra/cei: tou=to, sc. to\ <*> xai/rein.—suntre/xein, coincide with, be combined with: for this sense of the zerb, cp. n. on O. C.158 ff.—Not (as <*>ood), ‘Such joy must needs accompany [the event] in this way (th=|de).’

The rejection of this verse (see cr. n.) would be deplorable. Deianeira rejoices, but <*>ls a certain sadness, and knows that she cannot help showing it; all the more she wishes to assure them how real her joy is.
toi=sin eu)= skopoume/nois, absol., for those who take just views,—who prudently consider human affairs. For the midd., cp. O. T.964: it was common also in good prose.

tarbei=n to
 eu)= pra/ssonta, instead of tarbei=n u(pe tou= eu)= pra/ssontos (Plat. Rep. 387 C u(pe tw=n fula/kwn fobou/meqa, mh\...ge/nwntai etc.). Cp. Ph.493o(
 dh\ palaio
 e)co/tou de/doik' <*>gw\ | mh/ moi bebh/kh|.

This shadow which flits across Deianeira's joy is the more dramatically impressive for the spectators, because it arises so naturally out of her tender sympathy for the captives. It is a touch worthy of the greatest master.
e)moi\ … ei)se/bh: for the dat., cp. O. C.372 n.
deino\s, of strong feeling: cp. 476.

a)pa/toras, since their fathers are supposed to be dead; for, when a city is sacked, a)/ndras me\n ktei/nousi, po/lin de/ te pu=r a)maqu/nei, | te/kna de/ t' a)/lloi a)/gousi baquzw/nous te gunai=kas ( Il.9. 593). Cp. O. T.1506ptwxa\s a)na/ndrous e)ggenei=s a)lwme/nas.

301 f. For i)/sws in a like conjecture, cp. Ph.180ou(=tos prwtogo/nwn i)/sws | oi)/kwn ou)deno\s u(/steros.—pri
 me
 h)=san, not ei)si/n, because e)c e)leuqe/rwn a)ndrw=n implies e)leu/qerai. The word a)ndrw=n (which some would change to oi)/kwn) has been suggested by a)pa/toras (300).—Nauck's grounds for rejecting these two vv. are: (1) that i)/sws is out of place, since they must have been free-born; but cp. Thuc.8. 28, quoted on v. 257: (2) that pri
 me
 h)=san is wrong, because their origin remains the same.

w)= *zeu= tropai=e. Zeus who turns foemen to flight: see on Ant.143.He is fitly invoked by her, since it was he who had brought the captives to this plight. Not, ‘Averter of evil,’ for tropai=os is not a classical equiv. for a)potro/paios. Plutarch indeed, supplies an in stance in later Greek, Mor.p. 149 D to\n kaqarmo\n...kinei=n dianoei= kai\ pare/xein pra/gmata toi=s tropai/ois (alluding to the exclamation *)aleci/kake just before); unless a)potropai/ois should be read there.
tou)mo\n spe/rma, though it is the mother who speaks (so Aesch. Suppl.275spe/rmat' eu)te/knou boo/s, and oft.).

xwrh/santa. The notion of hostile advance was associated with this verb in such phrases as o(mo/se xwrei=n. But when it is followed by ei)s, e)pi/, or pro/s tina, the poetical usage varies somewhat from that of good prose. (1) The sense of xwrei=n ei)/s tina is usu. friendly in prose, as Thuc.5. 40; more rarely hostile, as id. 4. 95, and Soph. Ph.396.(2) xwrei=n e)pi/ tina is hostile in prose, as Thuc.1. 62, but friendly in Pind. N.10. 73.(3) xwrei=n pro/s tina is friendly in prose, as Thuc.5. 43, and aboveThuc., v. 285; but hostile here. Sophocles would possibly have preferred ei)s to pro\s here, if v. 303 had not ended with se.—The aor. part., not the pres., because she thinks of the onset in its ruinous result: cp. Soph. Ph.1113i)doi/man de/ nin... | e)ma\s laxo/nt' a)ni/as.—poi, in any direction,—i.e., in any of their homes, or in any point of their fortunes. The conject. pou seems unnecessary.

mhd), ei)/ ti dra/seis, sc. dra/seias: cp. El.1434nu=n, ta\ pri\n eu)= qe/menoi, ta/d' w(s pa/lin (sc. eu)= qh=sqe). Remark, as evidence that this suspected verse is genuine, the thoroughly idiomatic use of the fut. indic. with ei), in connection with the prayer: ‘if thou must do it, at least do it thus.’ So O. C.166lo/gon ei)/ tin' oi)/seis | pro\s e)ma\n le/sxan, a)ba/twn a)poba\s | ...fw/nei.—e)/ti after zw/shs is here almost pleonastic: cp. Ant.3(n.).

This verse is a development of mh/ pot' ei)si/doimi: ‘may I never see it; nay, if it is ever to happen, may it not happen while I live.’ Her words unconsciously foreshadow the troubles which, after her death, were brought upon her children by Eurystheus ( Eur. Heracl.). Such an allusion is quite in the poet's manner (cp. n. on Soph. Ant.1080 ff.).

The objection to the verse as illogical assumes that the de/ in mhde/ means ‘or,’ and that, therefore, the wish ‘not to see’ the woe is distinguished from a wish which it includes,—viz., that the woe may not come while she lives. The answer is simply that the de/ in mhde/ means ‘and.’

teknou=ssa: schol. te/kna e)/xousa o(/per *kalli/maxo/s fhsi paidou=sa [paidou=ssa: though Schneider Callim. fr. 431 defends teknou=sa and paidou=sa]. No part of tekno/eis or paido/eis occurs elsewhere. But the adj. is decidedly fitter here than tekou=sa (esp. in view of v. 311): nor is there sufficient ground for the assumption that teknou=ssa would imply several children.

pro\s … fu/sin, judging by it: cp. Ph.885 n.: fu/sis of physical aspect, as O. T.740: but otherwise below O. T., 379.— pa/ntwn … tw=nde, schol. tw=n e)k tou= ga/mou prosginome/nwn. The different surmise in 536 agrees better with 1225 f.
gennai/a =eu)genh/s ( O. C.76 etc.).
o( fitu/sas path/r: the same phrase in Ai.1296: cp. O. T.793 O. T., 1482.
w)/|ktisa: for the aor., referring to the recent moment at which the feeling began, cp. 464, 1044, Ant.1307 n.
o(/sw|per is used as if plei=ston, instead of mo/nh, followed: see O. C.743 n.

fronei=n oi)=den, like swfronei=n e)pi/statai ( O. T.589). Iolè (whose actual relation to Heracles appears from 1225 f.) is feeling not only bitter grief (326), but the new shame and embarrassment caused by the presence in which she stands. While the other captives are comparatively callous, she appears to Deianeira as one whose sense of the calamity is such as might be looked for in a maiden of noble birth and spirit. fronei=n here denotes that fine intelligence which is formed by gentle breeding, and which contributes to delicate propriety of behaviour. So, in Ant.1250, it is conjectured of Eurydicè that, in her grief, she has sought privacy: gnw/mhs ga\r ou)k a)/peiros, w(/sq' a(marta/nein: and cp. the account of Panthea's a)reth\ kai\ eu)sxhmosu/nh in Xen. Cyr.5. 1§ 5.
314 f. For kai\ emphasising the verb, cp. 490, 600, Ant.772 n.: for kri/nois, above Ant., 195.

ge/nnhma tw=n e)kei=qen, an offspring of the folk there (at Oechalia). Others make the gen. partitive (supplying gennhma/twn); but this seems less natural here. For tw=n e)kei=qen as = tw=n e)kei=, cp. 601 tai=s e)/swqen: Ant.1070tw=n ka/twqen. (In 632 ta)kei=qen in not quite similar.)— ou)k e)n u(sta/tois goes with ge/nnhma, not with tw=n e)k., as the schol. saw: ou)k e)n tai=s a)perrimme/nais kai\ eu)tele/si tetagme/nh a)lla\ dh=lon o(/ti prou)/xousa e)n eu)genei/a|. For the litotes cp. Il.15. 11e)pei\ ou)/ nin a)fauro/tatos ba/l' *)axaiw=n.

mh\ tw=n tura/nnwn; sc. ge/nnhma h)=n: for the interrogative mh/, cp. O. C.1502.The plur. (like basile/wn in Ant.1172) denotes ‘the royal house’: so, in O. C.851, Creon calls himself tu/rannos, though Eteocles is reigning.

*eu)ru/tou spora/ tis h)=n; The only natural sense is, ‘had Eurytus any issue?’ She had heard that he had sons (266). But we may suppose, either that she forgets this, or, better, that her question is qualified by its context, meaning, ‘had Eurytus any daughter?’ The other version, ‘was she a child of Eurytus?’ would make tis strangely weak. Further, in a mere surmise, such as this, the less direct inquiry seems the fitter.
a)nisto/roun: cp. Ph.253w(s mhde\n ei)do/t' i)/sqi m' w(=n a)nistorei=s: the simple i(storei=n below Ph., 382 Ph., 397 Ph., 404.
makra/n: O. T.220ou) ga\r a)\n makra\n | i)/xneuon.
cunempo/rwn: schol. cunaixmalwti/dwn.
e)/xeis, compertum habes: Ant. 9 (n.).
h)/nuton: Ant.231 n.

a)ll' h(mi\n, ‘to me at least’: since Lichas has not questioned thee. Cp. O. C.1276peira/sat' a)ll' u(mei=s ge: and ib. 241 a)ll' e)me/.—e)k sauth=s, here=‘from thine own mouth’ (since Lichas cannot tell me), rather than, ‘of thine own accord.’ In El.343, a(/panta ga/r soi ta)ma\ nouqeth/mata <*>kei/nhs didakta/, kou)de\n e)k sauth=s le/geis, the sense is, ‘from thine own mind.’

kai\ closely with cumfora/, a very misfortune. Deianeira is deeply interested by the captive, and feels drawn towards her. She is anxious to know the stranger's story, in order to offer her personal sympathy. These words express the pain and regret which she would feel at not being able to do so. The subtle art of the poet's language here depends on the different shades of meaning possible for cumfora/. When Deianeira at last learns all, that knowledge is to her a cumfora/ in the gravest sense: she knows that, in Iolè, she has received a phmonh\n u(po/stegon (376). But here she is courteously using cumfora/ in the milder sense which it could also bear,—‘a matter of deep regret.’ Cp. Her.1. 216sumforh\n poieu/menoi o(/ti ou)k i(/keto e)s to\ tuqh=nai.

ou)/ ta)/ra k.t.l.: lit., ‘It will be in a manner very unlike the past that she will utter a word’: i.e., if she does speak, it will be very unlike her conduct hitherto. ou)de
 e)c i)/sou must be taken together: for tw=| ge pro/sqen xro/nw| depending on e)c i)/sou, cp. Eur. Hipp.302i)/son d' a)/pesmen tw=| pri/n. dih/sei is a certain correction of dioi/sei: glw=ssan here is fig., ‘speech,’ precisely as in fr. 844. 3 pollh
 glw=ssan e)kxe/as ma/thn, and Soph. El.596h(\ pa=san i(/hs glw=ssan: for i(e/nai glw=ssan could not mean, ‘to unloose’ the tongue: it means ‘to send forth’ an utterance, being a poetical equiv. for i(e/nai fwnh/n: cp. Legg. 890 D pa=san, to\ lego/menon, fwnh
 i(e/nta. The use of diie/nai, as meaning to send speech through the lips, is thus the same here as in O. C.963(fo/nous moi...) tou= sou= dih=kas sto/matos. The attempted interpretations of dioi/sei, and some other conjectures, will be found in the Appendix.
h)/tis, causal ( O. T.1184), justifying v. 322.
ou)dama\, adv.: O. C.1104 n.

ou)/te mei/zon' ou)/t' e)la/ssona: Ant.1245pri
 ei)pei=n e)sqlo
 h)\ kako
 lo/gon: Od.10. 93ou) me
 ga/r pot' a)e/ceto ku=ma/ g' e)n au)tw=|, | ou)/te me/g' ou)/t' o)li/gon: Her.3. 62ou)k e)/sti...o(/kws ti...nei=ko/s toi e)/stai h)\ me/ga h)\ smikro/n.
w)di/nousa … ba/ros (cognate acc.): cp. Ai.790pra=cin h(\n h)/lghs' e)gw/: Eur. Her.990*(/hra me ka/mnein th/nd' e)/qhke th\n no/son.

dih/nemon simply = h)nemo/essan: so Oechalia is called u(yi/purgos (354) and ai)peinh/ (858). The word does not occur elsewhere in classical Greek, but Hermann quotes it from Philo Byzant. De septem mirabilibus 1, where it means ‘fanned by breezes.’ Hermann prefers the first of the two explanations (e)/rhmon, u(yhlh/n) given by the schol.: thinking that the epithet describes the ruins of Oechalia as patulum ventis iter praebentes. This seems very far-fetched; the more so, as the noun is pa/tran.
h( … tu)xh, not the doom of captivity, but rather her present condition of mute and inconsolable grief.
au)th=| g) is emphatic; sad for her, but to be condoned by us: g) is therefore in place.
suggnw/mhn e)/xei: Thuc.3. 44e)/xonta/s ti cuggnw/mhs (some claim to it).
h( d' ou)=n: cp. O. T.669o( d' ou)=n i)/tw: Ai.961oi( d' ou)=n gelw/ntwn: Ar. Ach.186oi( d' ou)=n bow/ntwn. Idiom thus favours h( d); and h(/d) would here be too emphatic.
ou(/tws o(/pws h(/dista: i.e., in silence.

331 Among the attempts to amend lu/phn...lu/phn (cr. n.), the two best, I think, are, (1) a)/llhn … lu/phn, Triclinius: and (2) lu/phn … diplh=n, F. W. Schmidt. In favour of (2), it might perhaps be said that the second lu/phn is more likely to be corrupt than the first. But it is also conceivable that the error should have arisen through the transcriber glancing forward. And, in close connection with pro\s kakoi=s toi=s ou)=sin, a)/llhn seems the fittest word. diplh=n would be less clear (meaning the former kaka/ plus a new lu/ph): it would also be too emphatic for this context.

Almost all edd. retain the optat. la/boi, which is possible (‘Heaven forbid that she should receive...!’). But, as this clause is linked with e)a/sqw kai\ poreue/sqw,—being, in fact, merely a repetition of the command in a negative form,—I feel sure that Blaydes is right in reading la/bh|.
oi(= qe/leis speu/dh|s, back to Cenaeum, so as to be in time for the sacrifice (287): cp. 599.
e)gw\ de\, after su/ q), is warranted by the antithesis, as in 143 (n.), 286.
e)carkh= tiqw=, make them such as they ought to be,—set them in satisfactory order. The word is used in Aesch. Pers.237(plou=tos e)carkh/s).
The a)/ggelos (180), who has listened in silence, now places himself between Deianeira and the door through which she is about to follow Lichas and the captives.

au)tou= ge prw=ton baio\n a)mmei/nas), sc. xw/rei (from xwrw=men in 333). Where ge is thus used in reply, without an expressed verb, the verb can usu. be supplied directly from what immediately precedes (as in 399 nemw= from nemei=s). Here we may compare O. T.678*x*o....ti/ me/lleis komi/zein do/mwn to/nd' e)/sw; | *i*o. maqou=sa/ g' h(/tis h( tu/xh (sc. komiw=).

a)mmei/nas): Sophocles has the form a)mme/nein in four lyric passages (527, 648, El.1389 El., 1397); but there is no other instance of it in tragic iambics. The apocopè of a)na/, so frequent in tragic lyrics, is comparatively rare in dialogue; the examples in iambics are chiefly nouns, as a)mba/ths, prosa/mbasis, a)mbolh/, a)mpnoh/, a)mptuxh/: more rarely verbs; though cp. 396 (n.); Eur. Hec.1263a)mbh/sei. In Eur. Tro.1277a)mpne/ous) is only a v. l. for e)mpne/ous), as in Eur. Phoen.1410a)mfe/rei for a)nafe/rei. An example in Attic prose is Xen. Cyr.7. 5. 12a)mbola/dos gh=s.

a)/neu here = xwri/s, as in O. T.1464a)/neu tou=d' a)ndro/s.—ou(/stina/s t): the t) is placed as if ma/qh|s were to serve for both clauses: but, in the form which the sentence actually takes, this te properly belongs to ma/qh|s, and the second te to e)kma/qh|s. (Cp. Ph.1415ta\ *dio/s te fra/swn bouleu/mata/ soi, | katerhtu/swn q' o(do
 h(
 ste/llei.) For the simple verb followed by the compound, cp. O. T.566 f. e)/sxete —pare/sxomen: Ph.249 f. oi)=sqa—ka/toid). —The masc. plur. ou(/stinas alludes to Iolè: cp. O. T.366su
 toi=s filta/tois (Iocasta).

w(=n t' ou)de\n ei)sh/kousas: her relations with Heracles. The first clause corresponds with the information which the speaker gives in vv. 379 ff.; the second, with that which he gives in vv. 351 ff.

pa/nt), adv., ‘in all respects’; to be taken, not with e)pisth/mhn alone (as if =‘complete knowledge’), but with e)/xw e)pisth/mhn.—Nauck, who pronounces the text corrupt, contends that we can say, (1) tou/twn e)pisth/mhn e)/xw, or (2) pa/nta e)pisth/mhn e)/xw: but that we cannot ‘combine tou/twn pa/nta.’ He compares pa/nta e)pisth/mhn e)/xw with O. C.583ta\ d' e)n me/sw| | h)\ lh=stin i)/sxeis k.t.l., where ta\ d' e)n me/sw| depends on lh=stin i)/sxeis as = e)pilanqa/nei. Hence it appears that he takes pa/nta for an acc. depending on e)pisth/mhn e)/xw as=e)pi/stamai. But pa/nta in our verse is an adverb. This adverb is used by Sophocles, not only ‘to strengthen adjectives’ (Nauck on Ant.721), as in o( pa/nt' a)/nalkis ( El.301), but also with verbs and participles: as Ant.640gnw/mhs patrw/|as pa/nt' o)/pisqen e(sta/nai: Ph.99pa/nq' h(goume/nhn. The adverbial use of pa/nta with e)pisth/mhn e)/xw is none the less correct because a gen., tou/twn, happens to be joined with e)pisth/mhn. In Ant.721, fu=nai to\n a)/ndra pa/nt' e)pisth/mhs ple/wn, the adverb certainly goes with e)pisth/mhs ple/wn: but that proves nothing against the phrase used here.

ti/ d' e)/sti; Cp. O. T.1144ti/ d' e)/sti; pro\s ti/ tou=to tou)/pos i(storei=s; (n.). Here, as there, a mark of interrogation must follow e)/sti, since ti/s can stand for o(/stis only in an indirect question.
tou=, causal gen.; so ti/nos Ph.327(n.).

e)fi/stasai/ me, makest me to <*>lt, th/nde ba/sin (acc. of respect), in this movement (towards the house). For the second acc., cp. Ph.1242ti/s e)/stai m' ou(pikwlu/swn ta/de; (n.): ib. 1301 me/qes me...xei=ra. Schol.: ti/nos e(/neken th\n porei/an kai\ th\n ei)/sodon i(sta=|s kai\ kwlu/eis;

The midd. e)fi/stamai does not elsewhere occur in a causal sense (except in the aor., as Xen. Cyr.8. 2. 19frourou\s e)pesthsa/ mhn). But the causal use of kaqi/stamai ( Aesch. Eum.706frou/rhma gh=s kaqi/stamai, Thuc.2. 6ta/ t' e)n th=| po/lei kaqi/stanto) appears to warrant a like use of e)fi/stamai, where, as here, the context helps to explain it. Cp. also Plat. Tim. 63 C gew/dh ge/nh dii+sta/menoi, ‘separating.’ [But we cannot properly compare O. C.916pari/stasai, ‘you bring to your own side,’ ‘subjugate’: nor Plat. Rep. 565C e(/na tina\...dh=mos ei)/wqe...proi+/stasqai e(autou=: where there is a special reason for using the midd.] The midd. prosorwme/na in Soph. O. C.244 is similarly unique, and has a like justification.

A fact which confirms this view is that e)fista/nai, e)fi/stasqai were regularly used with ref. to a halt. Xen. An.2. 4. 26e)poreu/eto de\ a)/llote kai\ a)/llote e)fista/menos. o(/son de\ xro/non to\ h(gou/menon tou= strateu/matos e)pisth/seie, tosou=ton h)=n a)na/gkh xro/non di) o(/lou tou= strateu/matos gi/gnesqai th
 e)pi/stasin. (For e)pi/stasis, ‘a halt,’ cp. Soph. Ant.225 n.) Polyb. 16. 34. 2 e)pisth/santes...th
 o(rmh/n. Diod.17. 112th
 o(do
...e)pisth/sas. Plut. Cim.1e)pisth/sas...th
 porei/an. Arrian 5. 16. 1 e)pe/sthse tou\s i(ppe/as tou= pro/sw.

Another explanation is: tou= me e)fi/stasai, ‘why hast thou come close up to me, th/nde ba/sin (cogn. acc.), with this (hurried) step?’ But: (1) instead of me, we should then expect moi: which Madvig, indeed (Adv. 1. 227), proposed, though with the further (and needless) change of tou= to e)f' ou(=. Cp. O. T.776pri/n moi tu/xh | toia/d' e)pe/sth. The acc. me is not adequately defended by fr. 155, ti/s ga/r me mo/xqos ou)k e)pesta/tei; where the acc. is like that which can follow e)pibai/nein as = ‘to assail’ ( Ai.138se\ d' o(/tan plhgh\ *dio\s... | ...e)pibh=|): ‘what trouble was not ever coming upon me?’ (2) th/nde... ba/sin here refers more naturally to the movement in which Deianeira is stopped than to a movement which the a)/ggelos makes towards her.

ou)de\ to\n pa/ros … ou)de\ nu=n. The double ou)de\ here must not be confused with a double ou)/te: this is not a case of parataxis,—‘as my first story was worth hearing, so will this one be.’ The first ou)de\=‘not even,’ and the second, ‘no, nor...’: cp. O. C.1402toiou=ton oi(=on ou)de\ fwnh=sai/ tini | e)/cesq' e(tai/rwn, ou)d' a)postre/yai pa/lin.—to\n pa/ros mu=qon: vv. 180—199.
ma/thn: not yeudw=s, as the schol. explains (a sense which must refer to the speaker, not to the hearer), but simply, ‘in vain.’ His promise of good news proved true.
dokw=, sc. ma/thn se a)kou/sesqai.

e)kei/nous, Lichas and the captives: who are moving away into the house, but have not yet disappeared. Their movement, which would begin at v. 335, ends only at 345. As the space to be traversed by them would not be great, we may suppose that Lichas, though he does not overhear the words of the a)/ggelos, has paused near the door of exit, in uncertainty, on seeing Deianeira stop, and is finally dismissed by a gesture of hers, after the words tou/tous d' e)/a (344). Here she forgets the a)/neu tw=nd) of v. 336.
h)\ )moi\ tai=sde/ t) (the Chorus) —i.e. mo/nais: an addition which the emphasis on the pronouns renders needless.

soi\ tai=sde/ t' ou)de
 ei)/rgetai: the verb is clearly passive: the midd. ei)/rgomai occurs only as=‘to keep oneself off’ from something ( O. T.890 n.). And it is simpler to take ou)de
 as nom. than as adv. with an impers. verb. soi\ tai=sde/ t) might be a dat. of interest: ‘for thee and these, nothing is excluded’: but it is truer (I think) to carry on e)ceipei=n. Thus the strict sense is:—‘for the purpose of telling to thee and these, nothing is excluded.’ The ordinary ou)de
 ei)/rgei occurs at 1257.
kai\ dh\: O. C.31 n.

xw( lo/gos shmaine/tw. Blaydes writes o(/ ti le/geis sh/maine/ moi: Nauck too (cr. n.) thinks the text corrupt, chiefly because so/s is absent. But cp. Eur. Hipp.341 f. *f*a. tri/th d' e)gw\ du/sthnos w(s a)po/llumai. | *t*r. e)/k toi pe/plhgmai: poi= probh/setai lo/gos; For the verb, cp. 598 sh/maine. Apitz cites Plat. Gorg. 511 B w(s o( lo/gos shmai/nei: but the sense there is different (‘as our argument indicates’).

di/khs e)s o)rqo/n, conformably with the straight rule of honesty: cp. O. T.853dikai/ws o)rqo/n, truly right (for the prophecy). For the implied metaphor, cp. Eur. Hec.602o<*>den to/ g) a<*>sxro\n kano/ni tou= kalou= maqw/n: for ei)s, fr. 555 ei)s o)rqo\n fronei=n (=kalw=s fronei=n): Thuc.6. 82e)s to\ a)kribe\s ei)pei=n (so the MSS.: w(s Krüger). The gen. di/khs can be joined to o)rqo/n (though without art.), since the latter is felt as a subst.: cp. Soph. Ai.1144e)n kakw=| | xeimw=nos.

h)\ nu=n … h)\ pro/sqen … parh=n: since nu=n can mean ‘just now,’ it is not necessary to supply pa/restin: but it is easy to do so: cp. Xen. An.3. 3. 2e)gw\...kai\ *ku/rw| pisto\s h)=n,...kai\ nu=n u(mi=n eu)/nous (ei)mi/).— kako/s here=a)/pistos, as at 468 it is opposed to a)yeudei=n.—ou) di/kaios is merely a synonym for kako/s (cp. 457), ‘not honest’: cp. 411: Ant.671di/kaion ka)gaqo\n parasta/thn. The antithesis, which is only between nu=n and pro/sqen, is thus somewhat blurred.
a(\ me\n ga\r e)cei/rhkas, standing where it does, is most simply taken as an acc. of respect; though tou/twn might be supplied.
a)gnoi/a: for the a_, see on Ph.129a)gnoi/a prosh=|.
martu/rwn: cp. 188.

*eu)/ruto/n q' e(/loi th/n q' u(yi/p. *oi)xali/an: i.e., slew him, and took the town. Just so in Il.11. 328e(le/thn di/fron te kai\ a)ne/re (the men are slain). This is usu. called a case of ‘zeugma’: but it is not really of the same kind as (e.g.) Her.4. 106e)sqh=ta/ te fore/ousi th=| *skuqikh=| o(moi/hn, glw=ssan de\ i)di/hn: where the verb properly suits the first clause only, and e)/xousi would naturally have been added to the second clause. The poetical use of e(lei=n, in regard to contests, included the senses, (1) ‘to overcome,’ often connoting ‘to slay’; and (2) ‘to gain by overcoming.’ Cp. Pind. O.1. 88e(/len d' *oi)noma/ou bi/an, parqe/non te su/neunon (overcame the father in a race, and won the daughter). So we can say, ‘they conquered their oppressors,’ and ‘they conquered freedom.’ The difference is that we should not say, in one sentence, ‘they conquered their oppressors, and freedom.’ Schneidewin compares Pind. N.10. 25e)kra/thse...strato\n... | kai\... ste/fanon, *moi/saisi/ t' e)/dwk' a)ro/sai. But there is much probability in Heyne's correction of the MS. *moi/saisi/ t) to *moi/saisin (with no comma after ste/fanon).
th\n u(yi/purgon: cp. 327 n.
*oi)xali/an: for the anapaest, excused by the proper name, cp. 233.
mo/nos qew=n: whereas Lichas had represented Zeus as pra/ktwr of all (251).

qe/lceien, with irony; that gentle spell produced these exploits. Cp. 1142 toiw=|de fi/ltrw|.—ai)xma/sai ta/de (cogn. acc.), to do these warlike deeds. The verb has here a general sense, as in Aesch. Pers.756e)/ndon ai)xma/zein, to play the warrior at home: cp. Soph. Ai.97.In Il.4. 324ai)xma\s d' ai)xma/ssousi means, ‘shall wield spears’: whence Ellendt understands here, ‘intorquere hoc excidium.’

ou) ta)pi\ *ludoi=s. Here e)pi\ *ludoi=s=‘in their country’ (248 e)n *ludoi=s): cp. 1100 gh=s e)p' e)sxa/tois to/pois: Her.5. 77e)pi\...th=| xw/rh|.—*u(p' *)omfa/lh|: in subjection to her,—a common sense of u(po/ with dat. (as Thuc.1. 32ei) e)so/meqa u(p' au)toi=s). u(p) is an almost certain correction of the MS. e)p) (see cr. n.), which ta)pi\ may have generated. If e)p) were retained, it could mean only ‘in the power of’: for, in reference to one person, e)pi\ could not possibly mean merely ‘with.’ After e)pi\ *ludoi=s, however, the repetition of e)pi/ in a different sense would here be awkward.
po/nwn latreu/mat), service consisting in toils (defining gen.): cp. 505 a)/eql' a)gw/nwn. ( O. C.105mo/xqois latreu/wn, ‘thrall to woes,’ is not parallel.)
o( r(ipto\s … mo/ros: cp. Ant.36fo/non... dhmo/leuston. A sarcastic allusion to the vivid detail with which Lichas had told the story (270 ff.).

Heracles had really killed Iphitus. The denial here refers only to the place which the murder held in the story told by Lichas. Heracles was instigated, not by the Lydian servitude which punished his crime, or by those affronts (262 ff.) which Lichas represented as having moved him to the crime, but, in reality, by the refusal of Eurytus to give him Iolè.

o(
 refers, not to mo/ros, but back to *)/erws (354), verses 356 f. being parenthetical; just as in 997 h(
 refers to krhpi\s in 992, and not to lw/ban in 996. The conjecture o(\ would enfeeble the passage. o(
 … parw/sas expresses that the divine agent, who should have been placed in the foreground of the story (cp. 862), has been thrust out of sight. Cp. Eur. Andr.29*(ermio/nhn gamei=, | tou)mo
 parw/sas despo/ths dou=lon le/xos.—e)/mpalin le/gei, speaks in a contrary sense. Her.1. 207e)/xw gnw/mhn(...ta\ e)/mpalin h)\ ou(=toi. Il.9. 56ou)de\ pa/lin e)re/ei (‘gainsay’).

a)ll' h(ni/k): here a)lla/ merely serves to resume the story, after the parenthesis: cp. de/ in 252, 281. Others make it strictly adversative: ‘(It was not on account of his enslavement); rather it was when he could not persuade,’ etc.— ou)k e)/peiqe: the imperf. is regularly used with ref. to such failure (e.g., Thuc.3. 3e)peidh\...ou)k e)/peiqon: id. 4. 4 w(s ou)k e)/peiqen).
to\n futospo/ron: not yet identified with Eurytus. That disclosure forms the climax, at 380.

kru/fion w(s e)/xoi le/xos: cp. Her.3. 1ou)k w(s gunai=ka/ min e)/melle... e(/cein, a)ll' w(s pallakh/n.—e)/gklhma is properly the matter of the complaint: ai)ti/an, the imputation of blame for it. For ai)ti/a in this sense, cp. Soph. O. T.656, Soph. Ai.28.
e(toima/sas: cp. Isae. or. 11 § 14 a)gw=nas paraskeua/zein (‘to get up’ lawsuits against one).

e)pistrateu/ei … a)/nakta pate/ra. I keep the traditional text, only with to/nd) (B) instead of tw=nd) (L) in 363: in the poet's time either would have been written *t*o*n*d. If the text be sound, it means:—‘he makes war upon her country, that in which (Lichas) said that this Eurytus was master of the throne.’ But there are three difficulties:

(1) It was needless to say that the girl's patri/s was also the realm of Eurytus: cp. 244 f.: 283 ff.: 315. The excuse must be that the Messenger himself had not yet said so; he is wordy, and anxious, in his own fashion, to be lucid. The reading to/nd), it may be noted, suits this view of him. And tw=nd) (qro/nwn) would be very awkward.

(2) Heracles is subject to e)pistrateu/ei and ktei/nei: but Lichas to ei)=pe. (Heracles cannot be the subject to ei)=pe: he needed not to tell his warriors that Eurytus reigned there; and, on the other hand, despo/zein could not mean, ‘usurped.’) Such a change of subject is very harsh: still, it is not impossible; and, as the narrative of Lichas has been the foremost topic so far, ei)=pe would at once suggest him. An example almost as bold occurs in Thuc.2. 3: oi( de\ *plataih=s... lo/gous deca/menoi h(su/xazon, a)/llws te kai\ e)peidh\ e)s ou)de/na ou)de\n e)newte/rizon. pra/ssontes de/ pws tau=ta kateno/hsan k.t.l.: where the Plataeans are the subject of h(su/xazon and kateno/hsan, but the Thebans of e)newte/rizon.

(3) At v. 377 Deianeira asks, a)=r' a)nw/numos | pe/fuken; i.e., ‘is she of obscure birth?’—and then, for the first time, learns that the girl's father is Eurytus. So she must have understood a)/nakta in 364 to mean, not ‘the king,’ but some (minor) ‘prince’ or ‘chief.’ Yet, even so, her question at v. 377 is strange. (At v. 342 we saw that she ignored a hint given in v. 336: but on this question—the girl's birth—we should have expected her to be attentive.)

The only course which removes all these three difficulties is Hartung's,—who brackets the words th\n tau/ths … pate/ra, so that three verses shrink into one,— e)pistrateu/ei patri/da th=sde, kai\ po/lin k.t.l. This would certainly improve the passage. And it is conceivable that the interpolation should have been due to actors.

Others read tw=n *eu)ru/tou to/nd', rendering: ‘in which (Lichas) said that Heracles (to/nd)) holds’ [or ‘wishes to hold’] the throne of Eurytus.’ But Heracles simply laid Oechalia waste; there was no question of his reigning there.—Wecklein ingeniously reads to\n e)rga/thn (for *eu)/ruton) tw=nd): ‘where Heracles said (to his warriors) that the author of these wrongs was king.’
For the change of tenses, cp. Ant.406 n.

h(/kei, Heracles: he is not, indeed, yet at Trachis (and the words do/mous w(s tou/sde go with pe/mpwn); but, after his distant wanderings, he may be said to ‘have arrived,’ since in his march from Oechalia he has already reached the point of Euboea nearest to his home (237). Heracles being the subject to e)/perse and to e)nteqe/rmantai (368), there would be an exceptional harshness in making Lichas the subject to h(/kei: nor would this suit the sense so well.

do/mous w(s tou/sde: see n. on O. T.1481w(s ta\s a)delfa\s ta/sde ta\s e)ma\s xe/ras. The case for reading e)s is stronger here than there. Yet I refrain from altering, since the house so easily suggests the household.
ou)d' ei)ko/s: ou)de/ here=‘nor,’ rather than, ‘not even.’

e)nteqe/rmantai. This compound is not found elsewhere, while e)kqermai/nw is frequent. But e)/nqermos was common, and is applied by Arist. to a ‘fervid’ temperament (Physiogn. 2, p. 806 b 26: dia/noian...e)/nqermon: 3 p. 808 a 37 eu)fuei=s kai\ e)/nqermoi). Here e)n-, suggesting the inward, hidden flame, seems better than the more prosaic e)k-. In fr. 430. 3 the corrupt ei)=q' a(/lletai is corrected by Valckenaer (after Ruhnken) to e)nqa/lpetai, but by Ellendt to e)kqa/lpetai: and the latter is confirmed by Bekker Anecd. p. 40. 20.

pro\s me/sh| *traxini/wn a)gora=|: me/sh| here implies, ‘open,’ ‘public,’ as in e)/deic)...e)s me/son ( Ph.609 n.): pro/s, lit. ‘close to’; the a)/ggelos had been one of those who stood in the outer part of the crowd, while inner circles were thronging round Lichas; he had thus been able to get away quickly (188—195). In 423 the prep. is the vaguer e)n.

a)gora=|, not ‘market-place,’ but ‘gathering’ (the place was a leimw/n, 188); a sense not rare even in Attic prose: cp. Xen. An.5. 7. 3sunagagei=n au)tw=n a)gora/n: Aeschin. or. 3 § 27 a)gora\n poih=sai tw=n fulw=n.
Join w(sau/tws e)moi/: cp. Her.2. 67w(\s de\ au(/tws th=|si kusi\ oi( i)xneutai\ qa/ptontai.

to\ d' o)rqo
: cp. the words of the messenger to Eurydicè in Ant.1194 f. ti/ ga/r se malqa/ssoim' a)
 w)=n e)s u(/steron | yeu=stai fanou/meq); o)rqo
 a(lh/qei) a)ei/.
pou= … pra/gmatos; Ai.102pou= soi tu/xhs e(/sthken: ib. 314 e)n tw=| pra/gmatos.
u(po/stegon with ei)sde/degmai: cp. El.1386beba=sin a)/rti dwma/twn u(po/stegoi.
w)= du)sthnos, sc. e)gw/: cp. 1143, 1243. Ph.744du/sthnos, w)= ta/las e)gw/.— a)nw/numos: a)/shmos kai\ dusgenh/s (schol.). The reference to origin is brought out by pe/fuken.

This question seems strange after the words ktei/nei t' a)/nakta pate/ra th=sde in 364,—which Deianeira can hardly be supposed to have forgotten. (See n. on 362 ff.) If those words be genuine, we might perhaps regard the question here as merely continuing her own bitter thought,— not as really asking for information:— ‘Wretched that I am! Is this the nameless maiden of whom he spoke?’ (Cp. the bitter self-communing of Oedipus, O. T.822: a)=r' e)/fun kako/s; | a)=r' ou)xi\ pa=s a)/nagnos;) It is not decisive against this view that the matter-of-fact a)/ggelos takes the question literally.
diw/mnuto (cp. 255 n.): Lichas had merely declared that he knew nothing (314—319).
h)= ka/rta: these words begin the reply to a question in El.312, Aesch. Suppl.452: they are the first words of a speaker also in Soph. Ai.1359, Soph. El.1279.

The conject. o)/noma for o)/mma not only removes a difficulty, but is made almost certain by the question, a)=r' a)nw/numos pe/fuken; The words were easily confused: thus in Ai.447o)/mma has been made in L from o)/noma. By o)/noma, as dist. from fu/sin, is meant partly the nobleness of the name itself (akin to Iolaüs, etc.), partly her personal renown for beauty. On the other hand, kat' o)/mma, ‘in regard to her appearance,’ is a phrase for which there is no real parallel: it cannot be justified by the use of o)/yis ( Il.24. 632) in that sense. In Ai.1004dusqe/aton o)/mma is not similar.
fu/sin birth, as Ai.1301fu/sei me\n h)=n | basi/leia (and ib. 1259).

In some ancient texts this verse was given to Deianeira. Among recent editors, Paley shares that view. But: (1) If Deianeira has already answered her own question, the Messenger's speech opens weakly with v. 380. (2) It agrees best with the practice of Sophocles to suppose that h)= ka/rta are a speaker's first words. —Some, indeed, of the MSS. (as B, K, T), which give v. 379 to Deianeira, have h)\ instead of h)=, with the mark of interrogation after fu/sin, and only a comma after diw/mnuto. Thus D. asks, ‘Is she obscure, or illustrious?’ But this is weak.

patro\s me\n ou)=sa k.t.l. The simplest account of the me/n is that *)io/lh de\ kaloume/nh ought to have followed, but, owing to the fact that her name is primarily in question, the second clause be came *)io/lh )kalei=to. The pote/ belongs in sense to )kalei=to, not to ou)=sa: the imperf. refers to her former condition in her own home: cp. 301 h)=san.

*)io/lh: vio/la on the vase from Caere mentioned above (265 f. n.). Cp. Hes. fr. 45 (ap. schol. on 266 above), tou\s de\ meq' o(plota/thn te/keto canqh\n *)io/leian | *)antio/xh. Curtius (Etym. § 590) accepts the connection with i)/on. Some mythologists regard Iolè as ‘the violet dawn,’ who is wedded to the rising sun (Hyllus) after his precursor (Heracles) has passed away in fiery glory (Paley, Introd. to Tr., p. 204). The poet, at least, is innocent of such symbolism.
th=s: 47 n.
bla/stas: the plur., as O. T.717, O.C. 972.

ou)de\n i(storw=n, compared with the words of Lichas himself (317 ou)d' a)nisto/roun makra/n), seems better taken as=‘because he had not been inquiring’ (o(/ti ou)de\n i(sto/rei), than, ‘because he did not know’ (cp. O. T.1484 f.).

Many editors place a comma after e)fw/nei. This implies that dh=qen could stand as the first word of a sentence or a clause. Now there are certainly instances in which the special point of the irony conveyed by dh=qen lies in words which follow it: yet, even then, dh=qen is also retrospective. Aesch. P. V.986e)kerto/mhsas dh=qen w(s pai=d' o)/nta me: here w(s pai=d' o)/nta is the point: but that is no reason why dh=qen should not refer to the whole sentence: i.e., ‘thou hast mocked me, forsooth, as though I were a child,’ represents the sense no less well than, ‘thou hast mocked me as if, forsooth, I were a child.’ The same remark applies to Thuc.1. 127tou=to dh\ to\ a)/gos oi( *lakedaimo/nioi e)ke/leuon e)lau/nein dh=qen toi=s qeoi=s prw=ton timwrou=ntes. Id. 4. 99ou)d' au)= e)spe/ndonto dh=qen u(pe\r th=s e)kei/nwn. This last example would really show dh=qen as the first word of a clause, if it were necessary to take it exclusively with u(pe\r th=s e)kei/nwn: ‘nor, again, were they (the Boeotians) going to make a truce about ground which, forsooth, was Athenian.’ But the sense is rather: ‘nor, again, were they going to make a truce, forsooth, [i.e., as the Athenian proposal implied,] about ground which was Athenian.’ And so, here also, the irony of dh=qen affects the whole sentence, and not only the words ou)de\n i(storw=n.

o)/lointo k.t.l.: a forcible way of saying, ‘Any kind of misdoing might be pardoned sooner than treachery of the kind which we see here.’ Cp. 468 f., soi\ d' e)gw\ fra/zw kako\n | pro\s a)/llon ei)=nai k.t.l.

The comment is aimed at Lichas in the first instance; but its vague form seems purposed, so that the hearers may extend it, if they please, to Heracles. Deianeira herself is in doubt whether the dissimulation practised by Lichas was prompted by her lord (449): Lichas explains that it was not so (479 f.). The schol.'s paraphrase shows that he wished to punctuate thus: o)/lointo, mh/ ti pa/ntes, oi( kakoi/, etc.: ‘perish, not all men, but the evil; and (especially) he,’ etc.
ta\ de\: for the place of the art., cp. 92 n.: for de\ as=a)lla/, Ant.85 n.
mh\ (generic) pre/ponq' au(tw=|: the treachery is aggravated by the fact of the high trust reposed in those from whom it proceeds. Ph.1227e)/pracas e)/rgon poi=on w(=n ou)/ soi pre/pon;
poei=n: for the spelling, cp. Ph.120 n., and ib. p. 234.

peu/qou: Nauck writes puqou=. But the change is as needless here as in O. T.604.Where the sense is, ‘inquire,’ the pres. is right: cp. O. C.993po/tera punqa/noi) a)
 ei) | path/r s' o( kai/nwn: ib. 1155 w(s mh\ ei)do/t' au)to
 mhde
 w(=n su\ punqa/nei. On the other hand in O. T.332 f. ti/ tau=t) | a)/llws e)le/gxeis; ou) ga a)
 pu/qoio/ mou, the aor. is required, as the sense is, ‘learn.’ Cp. above O. T., 66 O. T., 91; and below O. T., 458.

safh==a)lhqh=: El.1223e)/kmaq' ei) safh= le/gw.—pro\s bi/an, i.e., with stringent questioning (such as the a)/ggelos himself applies El., 402 ff.). The phrase is rare, except where physical force is meant; cp., however, O. C.1185ou) ga/r se, qa/rsei, pro\s bi/an paraspa/sei | gnw/mhs.—kri/nein =a)nakri/nein: 195 n.

ou)k a)po\ gnw/mhs, not away from good judgment,—not otherwise than it prescribes: ou)k a)/neu sune/sews (schol.). Cp. ou)k a)po\ kairou=, ou)k a)po\ tro/pou (n. on O. C.900): Plat. Theaet.p. 179 C ou)k a)po\ skopou= ei)/rhken. Others understand, ‘not contrary to my own judgment’ (tou=to ka)moi\ a)re/skei, schol.). Il.10. 324soi\ d' e)gw\ ou)x a(/lios skopo\s e)/ssomai, ou)d' a)po\ do/chs (‘belying thy hope’): ib. 1. 561 a)po\ qumou= | ma=llon e)moi\ e)/seai. But here gnw/mhs seems better taken generally. Distinguish the sense in Eum.674a)po\ gnw/mhs fe/rein | yh=fon (in accordance with one's opinion).

The accent in L here, a)/po gnw/mhs, represents the theory that this prep. should be paroxytone when it means ‘at a distance from,’ as in the phrases cited above, and in a)po\ tei/xeos ( Il.9. 353), a)po\ sei=o (ib. 437), etc. But this was merely a refinement due to comparatively late grammarians: see Ellendt, Lex. Soph. p. 79 a: Matthiae Gr. § 572 n. b.

ou)k e)mw=n u(p' a)gge/lwn: though it would be easy to supply klhqei/s from au)to/klhtos ( Ai.289a)/klhtos ou)d' u(p' a)gge/lwn | klhqei/s), it is needless to do so: cp. Eur. Andr.561ou) ga\r mia=s se klhdo/nos proqumi/a| | meth=lqon, a)lla\ muri/wn u(p' a)gge/lwn.

w(s o(ra=|s. I receive this slight and easy correction of ei)sora=|s, holding that the latter does not admit of any sound defence. Various explanations of it have been attempted. (1) Seidler: ei)sora=|s governs the gen. No one would now maintain this: the alleged instances are irrelevant ( Ar. Ran.815pari/dh| with a gen. absol.: M. 1. 1. 11 ou)dei\s de\ tw/pote *swkra/tous ou)de\n a)sebe\s...ou)/te pra/ttontos ei)=den, etc., where the verb governs the acc., and the gen. is possessive). (2) Hermann: the constr. is, w(s (‘since’), e(/rpontos e)mou=, ei)sora=|s (tou=to, e(/rponta/ me). But w(s must go with the gen. absol. (3) Nauck: w(s e(/rpontos e)mou=, (ou(/tws) ei)sora=|s (e)me\ e(/rponta). But (a) this implies a harsh asyndeton (di/dacon —ei)sora=|s): and (b) the constr. is not justified by Ai.281w(s w(=d' e)xo/ntwn tw=nd' e)pi/stasqai/ se xrh/ (cp. Ant.1179 n.). (4) Matthiae: there is a confusion between ei)sora=|s w(s e(/rpontos e)mou=, and w(s (since) ei)sora=|s e(/rponta eme/. (5) Dindorf: ei)sora=|s is parenthetic. This is the best plea: but it does not suit the idiom of tragedy. The parenthetic o(ra=|s (interrogative) does not support it.

As regards w(s o(ra=|s, Blaydes well points out that a double w(s occurs elsewhere: 1241 ta/x), w(s e)/oikas, w(s nosei=s fra/seis: Ant.735o(ra=|s ta/d' w(s ei)/rhkas w(s a)/gan ne/os; El.1341h)/ggeilas, w(s e)/oiken, w(s teqnhko/ta: and cp. the double w(/ste in Ai.729.
e)k taxei/as: cp. 727, and n. on Ant.994.
su\n xro/nw| … bradei=: O. C.1602taxei=...su\n xro/nw| (n.).

pri
 h(ma=s ka)nnew/sasqai lo/gous. The compound verb is confirmed, as against the kai\ new/sasqai of the MSS. (cr. n.), by the schol.'s paraphrase, a)nakaini/sasqai [this schol. has no lemma]; and more esp. by Eustath., p. 811, 20 (on neioi=o baqei/hs, Il.10. 353), nea=n, ou(= xrh=sis par' *(hsio/dw| e)n tw=|, qe/reos de\ newme/nh ou)k a)path/sei ( Op.462), e)c ou(= kai\ para\ *sofoklei= a)nanew/sasqai lo/gous, to\ a)nakinh=sai. On the other hand, the MS. kai/ is clearly sound: pri
 kai/ here =‘before even’; see on Ant.280.For the apocopè of the prep. in ka)nnew/sasqai, see on 335 a)mmei/nas). The synizesis of ew, assumed by those who write ka)nanew/sasqai, would be very harsh. I doubt whether Eustathius was right in his theory —suggested by nea=n—that a)naneou=sqai lo/gous was a metaphor from ploughing. Had it been so, it ought to have implied, ‘going again over old ground,’ like a)napolei=n e)/ph ( Ph.1238 n.). Here the sense is simply, ‘to renew converse.’ Cp. Polyb. 5. 36 a)ei\ to
 lo/gon a)neneou=to.
to\ pisto\n th=s a)lh- qei/as, the faithfulness of the truth,= the honest truth.

nemei=s, as in ne/mein moi=ra/n tini, because she claims a true account as due to her: 436 f. mh\...e)kkle/yh|s lo/gon. Cp. the pass. in Her.9. 7to\ me\n a)p' h(me/wn ou(/tw a)ki/bdhlon ne/metai e)pi\ tou\s *(/ellhnas: so honestly do we discharge our duty towards the Greeks.

Even without the hint in the schol. (cr. n.), it would have been clear that nemei=s must be read here. ne/meis has been explained as follows:—(1) Wunder: ‘Do you give the pledge of veracity?’—i.e., ‘Are you prepared to swear that you will speak the truth?’ (2) Linwood, ‘colis, observas’: i.e., ‘Do you respect fidelity to the truth?’ (3) Campbell takes ne/meis as ‘possess,’ ‘wield,’ ‘use’; rendering, ‘And dost thou maintain the faithful spirit of truth?’

As to Nauck's change in the order of these verses (cr. n.), it is enough to observe that (1) Lichas could not reply to the question of his de/spoina with such a rebuff as su\ d' ei)s ti/ dh/ me k.t.l. (2) It is out of accord with Deianeira's courteous dignity that she should address Lichas with such words as to/lmhson ei)pei=n, ei) fronei=s k.t.l.

ou(=tos, ble/f' w(=de: the a)/ggelos roughly bespeaks attention for his own question; w(=de=deu=ro (O.T. 7 n.). Cp. O. T.1121ou(=tos su/, pre/sbu, deu=ro/ moi fw/nei ble/pwn: Ai.1047ou(=tos, se\ fwnw=.
su\ d): a reproof of the meddling stranger. Cp. Isae. or. 8 § 24 su\ de\ ti/s ei)=; soi\ de\ ti/ prosh/kei qa/ptein; ou) gignw/skw se.
to/lmhson, an ironical rejoinder: ‘bring yourself to do it,’—‘have the goodness to do it.’ (Not, ‘dare.’) Cp. O.C. 184, Ph.82 Ph., 481.
ei) fronei=s, ‘if thou comprehendest’ (the question). Not, ‘if thou art sane’—which would be too strong here.
i(storw= with double acc., like e)rwtw=: Soph. Ph.621ti/ m' i(storei=s to/de;

406 f. If da/marta were not followed by despo/tin, the change of q) to d) made by Blaydes would be probable: cp. O.C. 1217 n. But, where three relationships of the same persons are mentioned, there is no reason for preferring de/ … de/ to te … te. — leu/sswn ma/taia (adv., cp. O.T. 883 n.), suffering a delusion of the eyes. Cp. 863: C. 3. 27. 39 (an me) Ludit imago | Vana?
di/kaia: for the plur., cp. 64.— The division of the verse between two speakers (a)ntilabh/) gives vivacity: cp. 418, 876.
di/kaios: cp. 348.
poiki/las (i_): cp. 1121: for poiki/los with ref. to subtlety, see on O. T.130h( poikilw|do\s *sfi/gc.

i(storou/menos=e)rwtw/menos, a comparatively rare use of this passive; so Her.1. 24klhqe/ntas i(store/esqai ei)/ ti le/goien.—ou) sighlo\s ei)=: as Creon calls the fu/lac a la/lhma, Ant.320.Possibly an echo of Aesch. Suppl.567le/g), ei)/ ti bou/lei: kai\ ga\r ou) sighlo\s ei)=: where the phrase alludes to the rhetoric of the herald Copreus.
ka/toisqa: i.e., thou knowest whom I mean: O. T.1048o(/stis ka/toide to\n both=r' o)\n e)nne/pei. The conject., ka/toisqa dh=t);—ou)/ fhmi/, assumed that ka/toisqa=gignw/skeis (‘knowest who she is’).

h(\n u(p' a)gnoi/as o(ra=|s. If these words are sound, they mean, ‘on whom you look with (affected) ignorance.’ There is little force in the objection that Iolè is not actually present: the Messenger is calling up the recent scene (314—319), which is so fresh in their minds. The real question is,—could u(p' a)gnoi/as be thus used,—as=‘with’ (not ‘from’) ‘ignorance’? Elsewhere u(po/ denotes some external accompaniment of action, as (1) sound, u(po\ suri/ggwn: or silence, u(p' eu)fh/mou boh=s ( El.630): (2) light, u(po\ lampa/dwn.: (3) a pressure from without, as u(po\ masti/gwn. There is perhaps no instance in which it refers distinctly to the mental or moral circumstances (as distinct from motives) of the agent. In Eur. Hipp.1299u(p' eu)klei/as qa/nh| means, ‘amid men's praises’: even in Eur. Hec.351, e)qre/fqhn e)lpi/dwn kalw=n u(/po, Polyxena alludes not merely to the hopes in her own breast, but to the fair auguries of those who watched her youth. Possibly the use of u(p' a)gnoi/as in this verse may have been felt to convey a certain irony which excused it; as if it implied, ‘with a look of ignorance assumed for the occasion,’—the deceiver's outward equipment for his part.
On the whole, I do not feel sure that there is a corruption. If there is, it probably lies deep. Some conjectures are noticed in the Appendix.

ti/s po/qen molw
: Od.1. 170ti/s po/qen ei)=s a)ndrw=n; Soph. El.779ti/nes | po/qen poreu/esq);—pa/ra is much better here than parw/n, a corruption which may have been induced by molw
 above. In 431, on the other hand, the emphasis of parw
 is fitting.
polloi=sin a)stw=n answers poi/ois e)n a)nqrw/poisi; The conject. polloi=s e)n a)stw=n is admissible (O.T. 178 n.), but unnecessary.
a)gora=|: 372 n.
tau=ta/ g): Iolè's name and birth: ge hints that more is in reserve.

425 If the MS. nai/ be genuine here, it stands, of course, exira metrum, as in I. T. 742 nai/. | pei/sw sfe k.t.l. There, too, it has good MS. authority, but is omitted by Dindorf.
