Here, perhaps, it might indicate a moment of embarrassment on the part of the herald, who now sees that he is detected. The ge after klu/ein makes nai/ unnecessary, but proves nothing against it.

tau)to\: other places where tragic metre proves this form are O.T. 734; fr. 771 ou) ga/r ti boulh=s tau)to\ kai\ dro/mou te/los: Eur. Med.564e)s tau)to\ qei/hn. But metre proves tau)to/n in five places of Soph. (O.T. 325: O.C. 612, 1419: Ph.546 Ph., 1256), as in Aesch. Eum.625, Eur. Or.1280, etc. Aristophanes uses both forms (Nub. 663 tau)to/, Eq.319tau)to/n, etc.).

426 The antithesis is between the whole phrases, do/khsin being the important word in the first, and e)cakribw=sai in the second. e)cakr. lo/gon means here, ‘to render a statement precise,’ by bringing definite evidence in support of it.

poi/an do/khsin; This idiom, so common in colloquial Attic ( Ar. Ach.61 f., etc.), is alien from tragedy; but Schneidewin and others quote Helen. 566 *e*l. w)= xro/nios e)<*>qw\n sh=s da/martos e)s xe/ras. | *m*e. poi/as da/martos; (‘how? “wife”?’).

e)gw\ da/marta; Another colloquialism: cp. Ar. Lys.529 f. e)panorqw/saimen a)\n u(ma=s. | —u(mei=s h(ma=s; deino/n ge le/geis kou) tlhto\n e)/moige.—to/nde ti/s k.t.l.: Soph. Ph.444tou=ton oi)=sq' ei) zw=n kurei=;

431 The emphatic sou= seems better here than sou. It may be noted that, instead of h)/kousen, we should usu. have h)/kousa: see on O. C.6.Shilleto (ap. Pretor here) was disposed, on this ground, to think that vv. 431—433 should be given to Deianeira: but they are not in her spirit.

h( *ludi/a (sc. gunh/)=h( *ludh/ (70), Omphalè. The adj. *lu/dios (frequent in poetry) is used by Soph. in fr. 728 *ludi/a li/qos. And as in fr. 49 he has *ludh=s (for *ludi/as) kerki/dos, so here he admits the converse licence. Bothe and others take h( *ludi/a as ‘Lydia,’—a bold equiv. for ta)fi\ *ludoi=s latreu/mata (356). This is tenable, but seems less natural.— o( th=sd' e)/rws fanei/s, the love for her, as it was manifested,—fanei/s implying that this manifestation was sudden and violent,—like a fire blazing forth: cp. Aesch. Pers.353h)=rcen me/n, w)= de/spoina, tou= panto\s kakou= | fanei\s a)la/stwr h)\ kako\s dai/mwn poqe/n.—For this third clause, reiterating the sense of the first (w(s tau/ths po/qw| k.t.l.), see on Soph. Ant.465—468.

a)posth/tw: cp. El.912th=sd' a)posth=nai ste/ghs: Thuc.7. 28a)posth=nai e)k *sikeli/as. Here a prose-write<*> would have said rather metasth/tw.—nosou=nti lhrei=n: the dat. is bold, but does not warrant suspicion; it follows the analogy, partly of diale/gesqai/ tini, but more especially of filoneikei=n tini (Plat. Legg. 731 A), stasia/zein tini/ (id. Rep. 556 E): the notion is, ‘to hold a silly controversy with a madman.’ Cp. the schol., ou) ga\r filoneikh/sw pro\s au)to/n. (For other examples of bold datives, cp. Ant.1232 n.)
pro/s se tou= … *dio/s: O. C.250 n.

na/pos: the u)/yistos pa/gos of Oeta (1191), as conceived in this play, is well-wooded (1195 f.). It was sacred to Zeus (200 n.). In an oracle of the Clarian Apollo, ap. Euseb. Praep. Ev. 5. 214, it symbolises the blest place which is reached by the rugged path of virtue: e)/stin e)n *trhxi=nos ai)/h| kh=pos *(hraklh/i+os, | pa/nt' e)/xwn qa/llonta, pa=si drepo/menos panhmado/n, | ou)d' o)lizou=tai, be/briqe d' u(da/tesin dihneke/s.—katastra/ptontos: cp. Ph.729qei/w| puri\ pamfah/s, *oi)/tas u(pe\r o)/xqwn (n.).

e)kkle/yh|s lo/gon, ‘steal the story away,’ i.e., ‘keep back from me that which ought to be told.’ Cp. Plat. Rep. 449 C dokei=s...ei)=dos o(/lon ou) to\ e)la/xiston e)kkle/ptein tou= lo/gou, i(/na mh\ die/lqh|s: ‘you seem to be cheating us out of a whole chapter which is a very important part of the story’ (Jowett).—Not, ‘falsify your story.’—Distinguish the use of e)kkle/ptein as=e)capata=n in Ph.55.

Deianeira argues:—(1) 438 —448: he need not fear that she will feel rancour against Heracles or Iolè: (2) 449—454: falsehood would be disgraceful for him,—and, if his motive were kind, useless: (3) 455 f.: detection would be certain: (4) 457 ff.: he need not be afraid of paining her. (5) In vv. 461— 467 she returns to the first topic.
kakh=|, here opp. to xrhsth=|: one who is capable of rancour. (Not, ‘cowardly.’)
ta)nqrw/pwn: human nature generally; not ta)ndrw=n: the latter would be at once less delicate and less pathetic.

pe/fuken: Nauck's pefu/kas) is neither better nor worse than the vulgate. If pefu/kas had been traditional, doubtless some one would have conjectured pe/fuken.—xai/rein … toi=s au)toi=s, to delight in the same things: metabolh\ pa/ntwn gluku/.— Wunder and others understand: ‘joy is not always given by nature to the same persons.’

*)/erwti me/n nun, like O. T.31qeoi=si me/n nun: so in Ionic prose, as Her.4. 145ou(=tos me/n nun tau=ta e)/prhsse.— a)ntani/statai: like the athlete who rises, when called by the herald, and presents himself for the contest: Her.8. 59e)n toi=si a)gw=si oi( proecanista/menoi (i.e., before they are thus summoned) r(api/zontai. So Plut. Sull.7(with ref. to a contest for the consulship) a)ntani/stato d' au)tw=| *ma/rios.—e)s xei=ras, with a)ntani/statai: a terse way of saying, ‘so as to come to close quarters’: Soph. O. C.835ta/x' ei)s ba/sanon ei)= xerw=n (n.); ib. 975 e)s xei=ras h)=lqon. Plut. Thes.5a)gxe/maxoi kai\ ma/lista dh\ pa/ntwn ei)s xei=ras w)qei=sqai (to push forward to close quarters) toi=s e)nanti/ois memaqhko/tes.

pu/kths o(/pws. No one can parry the adroit and rapid blows of Erôs. His antagonist fares like the barbarian opposed to the skilled pugilist (Dem. or. 4 § 40),—o( plhgei\s a)ei\ th=s plhgh=s e)/xetai, ka)\n e(te/rwse pata/ch|s, e)kei=se/ ei)sin ai( xei=res: proba/llesqai d' h_ ble/pein e)nanti/on ou)/t oi)=den ou)/t' e)qe/lei. Schneidewin cp. Anacreon fr. 63. 3 stefa/nous e)/neikon, w(s dh\ | pro\s *)/erwta puktali/zw: but the resemblance is only verbal; the reveller does not wish to resist Love, but to make trial of his might.

ou) kalw=s fronei=: cp. Eur. fr. 271 *)/erwta d' o(/stis mh\ qeo
 kri/nei me/gan | kai\ tw=n a(pa/ntwn daimo/nwn u(pe/rtaton, | h)\ skaio/s e)stin, h)\ kalw=n a)/peiros w)
 | ou)k oi)=de to
 me/giston a)nqrw/pois qeo/n.
a)/rxei kai\ qew=n: so of *ku/pris, fr. 856. 13 ti/n ou) palai/ous' e)s tri\s e)kba/llei qew=n; ib. 15 *dio\s turannei= pleumo/nwn.
ka)mou= ge: instead of saying kai\ brotw=n, she touchingly refers to her own experience: she, certainly, (ge,) can attest the Love-god's power.
pw=s d' ou) clearly goes with what follows; it would be weak as a parenthesis (pw=s d' ou)/;).

oi(/as g' e)mou=, by assimilation to e(te/ras, instead of oi(/a g' e)gw/: Thuc.7. 21pro\s a)/ndras tolmhrou\s oi(/ous kai\ *)aqhnai/ous. The ge means, ‘a poor mortal like myself.’ It should not be transposed and placed after xa(te/ras (‘and another too’).

Wunder and Nauck reject this beautiful verse, because: (1) by ka)mou= ge Deianeira implies that she is stronger than the gods; and also that she has been untrue to her husband: (2) she cannot assume that Iolè returns the passion of Heracles; nor does Iolè's feeling come into account here.
tw)mw=| t' a)ndri\: for te irregularly followed by h)\ (447), cp. Plat. Ion 535 D o(\s a)\n...klai/h| t' e)n qusi/ais kai\ e(ortai=s, mhde\n a)polwlekw\s tou/twn, h)\ fobh=tai.
th=|de th=| no/sw|, the violent passion of love: cp. 544: this was prob. the sense in fr. 615 (from the Phaedra), no/sous d' a)na/gkh ta\s qehla/tous fe/rein. But in 491 the meaning is different.
mempto/s: for the active sense, cp. O. T.969 n.

tou= mhde
 ai)sxrou=, that which is in no way of a shameful kind (generic mh/): cp. Ant.494tw=n mhde
 o)rqw=s... texnwme/nwn: Ph.409mhde
 di/kaion (n.).— mhd' e)moi\ kakou= tinos. As we could say, to\ mh\ e)moi\ kako/n ti (‘what is not any ill to me’), so here it seems simplest to carry on the tou=: though it is not necessary to do so.

This is a remarkable passage, and it is of some moment to understand it rightly. The meaning is not merely that Iolè's relation to Heracles was excused by the omnipotence of Erôs. Concubinage (pallaki/a) was not merely tolerated by Athenian opinion, but, in some measure, protected by law (see e.g., Lys. or. 1 § 31: Isae. or. 8 § 39). Its relation to the life of the family is illustrated by the Andromachè of Euripides; for though Andromachè is Trojan, and Hermionè Spartan, the sentiments are Athenian. A wife (gameth\ gunh/) who tolerates a pallakh/ is there represented as proving her goodness of heart (a)reth/, 226), and her wise moderation (938—942); she ought to be consoled by her higher place, and by the advantage which her children will have over the no/qoi.

But is Deianeira in earnest here; or is she feigning acquiescence, to reassure Lichas? Presently she tells the Chorus that she cannot endure to share her home with Iolè (539—546). Probably Sophocles meant her to be sincere in both places. The faith in her own power to bear the trial is natural at this moment of excitement and suspense. Not less so is the reaction, when she knows the worst, and has had time to think.

ou)k e)/sti tau=t): a)ll) k.t.l.: i.e., ‘it is impossible that I should have bitter feelings towards Heracles or Iolè (and so the danger which you may fear is imaginary); but you, on the other hand, if you are withholding the truth, are doing wrong.’ For ou)k e)/sti tau=ta, finally dismissing a supposition, cp. Ai.470: tau=ta is sometimes omitted, as in 709 below, Ant.289, El.448.
maqw\n … e)kmanqa/neis: cp. 336 f.

au(to\n=seauto/n: O. C.929ai)sxu/neis po/lin | th\n au)to\s au(tou=.—o(/tan qe/lh|s k.t.l.: the form is general, but the reference is to this particular case: when you wish to prove kind (by sparing pain), you will be found the reverse (cp. 458). —For o)fqh/sei, cp. Ant.709.
kh\r, a deadly thing ( Ph.42 Ph., 1166): pro/sestin, said of a quality or a repute which attaches to a man: Ai.1079de/os ga\r w(=| pro/sestin ai)sxu/nh q' o(mou=: cp. ib. 521.

o(/pws de\ lh/seis k.t.l.: and as for the hope of your escaping detection, not even that comes to pass (as a result of reticence). Cp. O.T. 1058 ou)k a)\n ge/noito tou=q), o(/pws... | ...ou) fanw= tou)mo\n ge/nos. Instead of saying, ou)d' au)= tou=to gi/gnetai, o(/pws lh/seis, the speaker puts o(/pws de\ lh/seis first, to mark the fresh hypothesis.
de/doikas … tarbei=s: for the substituted synonym, cp. 347 f.: O. T.54a)ll' ei)/per a)/rceis th=sde gh=s, w(/sper kratei=s (n.).
tou=to, emphatic: cp. Ph.912 n.
plei/stas a)nh\r ei(=s: cp. O. C.563 n.
e)/ghme does not necessarily denote wedlock: Eur. Tro.44(of Cassandra) gamei= biai/ws sko/tion *)agame/mnwn le/xos.— dh/=h)/dh: Soph. O. T.968 n.

The legendary loves of Heracles were as numerous as the local myths which claimed Heracleid <*>escent for clans or houses. Thus his bride Megara connected him with Thebes; Astydameia, with Thessaly; Astyochè, with Epeirus; Epicastè, with Elis; Parthenopè, with Arcadia; Chalciopè, with Cos; the Thespiades, with Sardinia; and so forth. The number of his sons finally grew to about seventy, whose mothers are enumerated by Apollodorus (2. 7. 8).

h)ne/gkat): so Legg. 762 A (quoted by Campbell) tai=s me\n qwpei/ais u(pei/kontes o)nei/dh fere/sqwsan e)n pa/sh| th=| po/lei: i.e., ‘have reproaches for their reward.’ (For the normal use, cp. Phaedr. 245 B fere/sqw ta\ nikhth/ria.) The irony of fe/resqai o)nei/dh is less open than in such phrases as pe/nqh karpou=sqai or da/krua kerdai/nein: we might rather compare our own phrase, ‘to come off secondbest’ (instead of ‘victorious’). For h)ne/gkato...e)k, cp. El.968 f.

h(/de te, ou)d' ei) … e)ntakei/h|, (e)ne/gkait)) a)
 (o)/neidos). For the ellipse of the optat., cp. El.364th=s sh=s d' ou)k e)rw= timh=s tuxei=n, | ou)/t' a)
 su/, sw/frwn g' ou)=sa (sc. e)rw/|hs): Ph.115 n. Though ou)d) (‘not even’) goes closely with ei), yet a)
 is placed between them: cp. O.C. 272 ou)d' a)
 w(=d' e)gigno/mhn kako/s.

e)ntakei/h tw=| filei=n; the subject to the verb is surely Iolè. To make Heracles the subject is not impossible (Greek could be bold in such transitions),— but it would be excessively harsh. Deianeira has already implied that she believed Iolè to be enamoured of Heracles (444). Such a belief would mitigate, rather than increase, the wife's pain. The opposite supposition would be still more humiliating; for it would imply more persistent ardour on the part of Heracles. And it is pathetically natural that Deianeira should assume Iolè's passion as a matter of course.

e)ntakei/h admits of two explanations: I prefer the first. (1) ‘Though she be utterly absorbed in her love’: lit., melted into it,—with her whole soul irrevocably steeped in it. The metaphor is from pouring molten wax or metal into a mould, to which it cleaves. Extant examples of e)nth/kesqai show only the converse way of speaking, as if here we had to\ filei=n e)ntakei/h au)th=|: El.1311mi=so/s te ga\r palaio\n e)nte/thke/ moi: fr. 856. 7 e)nth/ketai ga\r (e)/rws) pleumo/nwn o(/sois e)/ni | yuxh/. But cp. Ant.1311sugke/kramai du/a|: Aesch. Suppl.1029game/tas | ...sunthxqei\s a)lo/xw| (‘husband made one with wife’): Plut. Mor.p. 342 C tai=s e)lpi/sin h)/dh...e)mpefukw/s (‘absorbed in’ his hopes). (2) The other possible sense is, ‘be melted,’ ‘languish,’ with love; tw=| filei=n being then instrum. dat. This is, however, a weaker meaning, and less appropriate. For: (a) it would imply an unsatisfied longing; and (b) Deianeira's thought is rather this:—‘I will not be harsh to her, even though she be resolved never to renounce his love.’
The conject. e)ktakei/h is no improvement: it would mean ‘waste away’: Eur. Or.860e)cethko/mhn go/ois. In Lycophron 498 (qrh/noisin) e)ktakei=sa is a v. l. for e)ntakei=sa.

w)/|ktira: for the spelling, cp. O.T. 13n. dh\ here emphasises the whole phrase w)/|ktira...ma/lista: we cannot hold (with Blaydes) that dh\ ma/lista is for ma/lista dh/, any more than that dh\ po/ll) (153) is for polla\ dh/.

r(ei/tw kat' ou)=ron, go down the stream before the wind. Nothing is gained by changing r(ei/tw to i)/tw ( Aesch. Theb.690 f. i)/tw kat' ou)=ron ... | ... pa=n to\ *lai+/ou ge/nos). For ou)=ron, cp. 815. She means, ‘it is idle to dwell upon what cannot be undone.’
kako\n = a)/piston, yeudh= (347).

pro\s a)/llon k.t.l.: i.e., ‘if thou must use deceit, use it towards anyone rather than me’: cp. Ph.1119stugera
 e)/xe | du/spotmon a)ra
 e)p' a)/llois (n.). The parataxis makes the precept kako
 | pro\s a)/llon ei)=nai absolute in form, though it is only relative in sense: cp. 383 f.: Isocr. or. 6 § 54 pw=s ou)k ai)sxro
,...th
 me
 *eu)rw/phn...mesth
 pepoihke/nai tropai/wn,...u(pe de\ th=s patri/dos...mhde\ mi/an ma/xhn fai/nesqai memaxhme/nous;

piqou= legou/sh|: cp. El.1207piqou= le/gonti, kou)x a(marth/sei pote/. The aor. imper.=‘obey her,’—‘do the thing which she urges’: while pei/qou would mean rather, ‘be persuaded’: cp. O. C.1181 n. Here the context seems slightly in favour of piqou=, though the pres. is also quite admissible. gunaiki\ th=|de: this simple dat. of the pers. with me/mfomai, though not very rare, is less frequent than either (1) me/mfomai/ tina, El.383 f., or (2) me/mfomai/ tini/ ti.

a)ll), ‘Nay, then’: Ph.524.— qnhth
 fronou=san qnhta\: Eur. fr. 796 w(/sper de\ qnhto
 kai\ to\ sw=m' h(mw=n e)/fu, | ou(/tw prosh/kei mhde\ th
 o)rgh
 e)/xein | a)qa/naton, o(/stis swfronei=n e)pi/statai. Arist. Rhet.2. 21§ 6 quotes from an unknown poet, a)qa/naton o)rgh
 mh\ fu/lasse qnhto\s w)/n: also (perh. from Epicharmus, as Bentley thought), qnata\ xrh\ to
 qnato/n, ou)k a)qa/nata to
 qnato
 fronei=n. Cp. Eth. Nic. 10. 7 § 8 ou) xrh\ de\ kata\ tou\s parainou=ntas a)nqrw/pina fronei=n a)/nqrwpon o)/nta ou)de\ qnhta\ to
 qnhto/n, a)ll' e)f' o(/son e)nde/xetai a)qanati/zein.—a)gnw/mona seems best taken as acc. neut. plur. It is true that a)gnw/mwn is usu. said of persons: but (a) analogous compounds are often neut., as Ai.1236ke/kragas... u(pe/rfona, Aesch. Cho.88pw=s eu)/fron' ei)/pw; and (b) in later Greek, at least, we find (e.g.) Lucian Abdic. 24 a)/gnwmon poiei=s: Diod.13. 23ou) ga dunato
... pra/cantas deina\ paqei=n eu)gnw/mona (to receive considerate treatment). If a)gnw/mona were acc. fem. sing., ou)=san could be understood. For a)gnw/mwn, ‘inconsiderate,’ ‘not making fair allowance,’ cp. Soph. O. C.86 n.: and belowSoph. O. C., 1266.

kru/yomai: midd., ‘keep my knowledge to myself’: but it is not practically different from kru/yw here. A midd. force is better marked in Ai.647fu/ei t' a)/dhla kai\ fane/nta kru/ptetai (hides in itself), and ib. 246 ka/ra...kruya/menon. The only other examples of the simple midd. kru/ptomai are late, though the midd. a)pokru/ptomai and e)pikru/ptomai were frequent.
e)/stin ga\r ou(/tws: this is not the ga/r which merely prefaces a statement ( O. T.277 n.): rather it refers to v. 474: ‘the truth,—for it has still to be told by me.’

tau/ths o( deino\s i(/meros: the article is explained by the preceding verse:—‘It is as he says: she inspired that strong passion (of which he has spoken, 431 f.).’ This is a compressed way of making two admissions,—‘love was the real motive, and she was the object of that love.’—Some commentators hold that o( deino\s here means simply, ‘very’ (or ‘most’) ‘potent.’ The evidence for this supposed use of the article is examined in the Appendix.
poq): referring to a time before the death of Iphitus: cp. 359.
dih=lqe: cp. Aesch. Suppl.288ka)me\ ga\r dih=lqe/ ti (‘a pang shot through my heart also’).— th=sd) after tau/ths: Soph. Ant.296 n.
h( polu/fqoros: the adj., though proleptic, takes the art.: cp. O. C.1088to\n eu)/agron teleiw=sai lo/xon (n.).

patrw=|os: a somewhat rare fem., used either (1) for metre's sake, as here, and Eur. Suppl.1146di/ka | patrw=|os: or (2) for euphony, as Aesch. Ag.210patrw/|ous xe/ras, Eur. Her.810tima\s patrw/|ous. Cp. 533: O. C.751 n.
kai\ to\ pro\s kei/nou, what is on his side (in his favour) too: O. T.1434pro\s sou= ga\r ou)d' e)mou= fra/sw (n.).
ei)/ ti th/nd' a(mart., instead of ei)/ ti to/d' a(ma/rt.: O. C.88tau/thn (instead of tou=t)) e)/lece pau=lan, n.
ne/meis=nomi/zeis, O. C.879 n.

ge me
 dh\: as El.1243o(/ra ge me
 dh\ k.t.l. Blaydes remarks that these particles do not elsewhere follow e)pei\, and therefore alters the text (cr. n.). But their combination with e)pei/ here is quite correct: ‘since, however, you do know all,’ etc. Just so they follow a participle in Helen. 1259 didou/s ge me
 dh\ (i.e., when you do give anything) dusgene\s mhde
 di/dou.—kei/nou te kai\ sh
 k.t.l.: Soph. Ph.762sou= te th/n t' e)mh
 xa/rin.

ste/rge: cp. Eur. Andr.213, where Andromachè is giving Hermionè the same kind of advice;—xrh\ ga\r gunai=ka, ka)\n kakw=| po/sei doqh=|, | ste/rgein, a(/milla/n t' ou)k e)/xein fronh/matos.—lo/gous ou(\s ei)=pas e)s th/nd), alluding to the assurance given in 462 ff.: for e)s, ‘with regard to,’ cp. Soph. Ph.1053.The reference is not to Deianeira's reception of Iolè in 310— 334.
e)mpe/dws, unalterably,—i.e., so that the promise shall be kept: cp. 827: Ph.1197i)/sqi to/d' e)/mpedon. The conjecture e)mpe/dous is plausible, but not necessary.
488 f. Either ta)/ll) or xeroi=n ought logically to be absent.
kai\ emphasises fronou=men (‘I do think thus’): cp. 314, 600.

no/son g' e)pakto
 e)carou/meqa, lit., ‘take up (the burden of) a trouble which I should bring upon myself,’—viz., the anguish of a vain fight against all-conquering *)/erws. The schol. rightly explains e)pakto
 by au)qai/reton: as does the schol. on Soph. Ph.343ga/mwn e)pakto
 a)/tan. This view is confirmed by the presence of ge, meaning, ‘at any rate I shall not add to my own woes.’ For a parallel use of e)pa/gesqai, cp. Lys. or. 4 § 19 polu\ mei/zw sumfora
 e)mautw=|...e)pagage/sqai: Dem. or. 19 § 259 au)qai/reton au(toi=s e)pa/gontai doulei/an. For e)carou/meqa cp. Od.10. 84e)/nqa k' a)/u+pnos a)nh doiou\s e)ch/rato misqou/s (‘take up,’ i.e., ‘win’). The simple ai)/romai is often so used, with ref. either to ‘winning’ a prize, or ‘taking up’ a burden ( O. T.1225a)rei=sqe pe/nqos, Ant.907h)ro/mhn po/non). This ai)/romai can be replaced by the rarer e)cai/romai just as fe/romai, in a like sense (462 n.), by the rarer e)kfe/romai: El.60ka)cene/gkwmai kle/os.

Others understand:—(1) ‘I shall not heighten the trouble already brought upon me by others’ (viz., the introduction of Iolè into the house, 376). But this sense for e)carou/meqa is strange: and ge is then weak; hence Nauck read no/shm). (2) ‘I shall not try to shift that trouble from myself’: i.e., ‘I shall not try to put away the grief of these tidings by vain complaints against the gods.’ This last version seems impossible.

qeoi=si dusmaxou=ntes: Ant.1106a)na/gkh| d' ou)xi\ dusmaxhte/on. The compound means, ‘to wage an up-hill fight’: cp. dustokei=n, dusqanatei=n. For the masc. plur., used by a woman with ref. to herself, cp. El.399, Eur. Hec.511.
lo/gwn t): the elision gives a quasi-caesura: cp. Ph.101 n.

lo/gwn … e)pistola\s=‘mandates consisting in words’ (defining gen.), i.e., her (verbal) messages to Heracles, as distinguished from the dw=ra. Sophocles, like Aesch. , uses e)pistolh/ only in the general sense of ‘mandate’ ( Soph. O. C.1601, Soph. Ai.781): Eur. uses it also with ref. to a written letter (I. A. 111 etc.).

prosarmo/sai, lit., ‘adjust’; i.e., ‘give in fitting recompense.’ But Deianeira's choice of the word has been influenced by her secret thought,—already turned towards the philtre which she would apply to Heracles: cp. 687 e)/ws nin a)rti/xriston a(rmo/saimi/ pou. And at the same time the word is unconsciously ominous (cp. 767 prosptu/ssetai).

This is the first mention of the fateful gift. An unobtrusive significance is given to it by two traits of expression. (1) dw=ra is drawn into the relative clause ( O. C.907 n.), and resumed, with a light emphasis, in kai\ tau=t): cp. Ph.1247a(/ g' e)/labes boulai=s e)mai=s, | pa/lin meqei=nai tau=ta. (2) A pause follows the second foot of the verse (a)/gh|s). Cp. 27 n.

a)/gh|s is not meant to be in contrast with fe/rh|s (493): it is here a mere synonym for it (cp. 457). fe/rein is used with ref. to the robe in 602, 622, 758, 774. Cp. O. C.354mantei=) a)/gousa pa/nta (=fe/rousa). On the other hand in 183 a)/gont' a)parxa/s, and 751 a)/gwn tropai=a k.t.l., an attendant train is implied.— di/kaia: cp. 409.
w(=de is explained by su\n p. sto/lw|: it should not be taken with pollw=|, nor as=deu=ro ( O. T.7).

div2.p: First sta/simon. Strophe (497 — 506) = antistrophe (507 — 516): epode 517—530. For the metres see Metrical Analysis.

In the scene which has just ended, testimony has been borne to the omnipotence of Love (441 ff.). The Trachinian maidens set out from this theme. Thence they pass to another, which the same scene might well suggest. Deianeira, the much-tried wife, has now a rival in the affections of her lord. The Chorus recall a far-off day, when, in her youthful beauty, she was the prize for whom Heracles strove with Acheloüs.

div3.p: me/ga ti sqe/nos … ni/kas=megasqenh= tina ni/khn: the victory which she carries off is the glorious proof of her might. Cp. O. C.1088sqe/nei )pinikei/w|.
e)kfe/retai: see on 491.—Others explain: (1) ‘carries a great strength out of victory’—i.e., wins with much to spare: (2) ‘advances in mighty conquering force’ (cogn. acc.).

qew=n, a monosyll.: cp. 183.— pare/ban: for the aor., cp. Ph.1289a)pw/mos) (n.). It is better not to dwell on stories which ascribe weakness to the gods: Pind. O.1. 35e)/sti d' a)ndri\ fa/men e)oiko\s a)mfi\ daimo/nwn kala/: ib. 9. 40 e)pei\ to/ ge loidorh=sai qeou\s | e)xqra\ sofi/a.

*kroni/dan: Zeus is kat' e)coxh/n so called, though his two brothers had the same father. Cp. the Homeric hymn to Aphroditè (4. 38), kai/ te tou= (Zeus), eu)=te qe/loi, pukina\s fre/nas e)capafou=sa, | r(hidi/ws sune/mice kataqnhth=|si gunaici/n, | *(/hrhs e)klelaqou=sa.—ou) le/gw: implying religious eu)fhmi/a: cp. El.1467ei) d' e)/pesti ne/mesis, ou) le/gw.

to\n e)/nnuxon *(/aidan: O. C.1559e)nnuxi/wn a)/nac. Cp. Il.15. 187trei=s ga/r t' e)k *kro/nou ei)me\n a)delfeoi/, ou(\s te/ke *(rei/h, | *zeu\s kai\ e)gw/, tri/tatos d' *)ai+/dhs e)ne/roisin a)na/sswn. The allusion is to Pluto carrying off Persephonè.

*poseida/wna, the regular Homeric form: L, which has poseidw=na here, conversely gives poseidawni/w| (where *poseidwni/w| is most probable) in O. C.1494.Poseidon was as little true to Amphitritè as Zeus to Hera: Propert. 2. 26. 46 Neptunus fratri par in amore Iovi. Thus Tyro (the subject of a play by Sophocles) bore Pelias and Neleus to the sea-god. At Aegina the cult of Poseidon was combined with that of Aphroditè ( Quaest. Gr. 44: Athen. XIII. p. 590 F).
tina/ktora gai/as=e)nnosi/gaion, e)nosi/xqona: Hom. hymn. 22. 2 gai/hs kinhth=ra kai\ a)truge/toio qala/sshs.

e)pi\ ta/nd' … a)/koitin, ‘to win Deianeira as bride’ (predicate): for the prep., cp. Ph.591e)pi\ tou=ton... | ...ple/ousin: Xen. Cyr.1. 2. 9o(/tan...e)ci/h|... e)pi\ qh/ran.—a)mfi/guoi: the prep. expresses the idea, ‘two’; the second part of the compound suggests that of ‘stalwart,’ ‘vigorous.’ Thus the epithet is of the same class as di/stoloi ( Soph. O. C.1055), said of two persons who are travelling. It seems more likely that Sophocles here used a)mfi/guos with an original boldness, than that he was directly thinking of the Homeric e)/gxesin a)mfigu/oisin ( Il.13. 147): where the adj. has been explained as (a) ‘having a gui=on, a limb (of iron), at each end,’—the lo/gxh, and the saurwth/r: or (b) ‘having a lo/gxh curved (gu) on both sides’: but Leaf ad loc. suggests (c) ‘bending to either side,’ ‘elastic.’ The primary notion of gui=on is, ‘a flexible limb.’
Other explanations of a)mfi/guoi here are these:—(1) ‘With massive limbs,’— a)mfi/ being intensive. (2) ‘Dexterous combatants’: cp. a)mfide/cios. (3) ‘Of dissimilar forms,’—i.e., man and bull.

kate/ban, in certamen descenderunt.— Xen. An.4. 8. 27h)gwni/zonto de\ pai=des k.t.l....kai\ kalh\ qe/a e)ge/neto: polloi\ ga\r kate/bhsan.—pro\ ga/mwn, ‘for it,’ i.e., to win it (=u(pe/r): not, ‘before it.’ In pro/, just as in ‘for,’ the two notions are closely linked. Cp. Soph. O. T.134pro\ tou= qano/ntos (on his behalf): Soph. El.495pro\ tw=nde (on this account).
pa/mplhkta: schol. plhgw=n mesta/: cp. 50 panda/krut). (It is overrefining to explain it as referring to the various kinds of blow, 517 f.)

pagko/nita/ t): the dust raised by the comba. is the proverbial symbol of violent effort: neither can win a)koniti/. Cp. Ov. Am. 1. 15. 4 Praemia militiae pulverulenta sequi. Ovid may have had pagko/nita in mind when he described Heracles and Acheloüs as throwing handfuls of dust at each other (Met. 9. 35 f.): Ille cavis hausto spargit me pulvere palmis, | Inque vicem fulvae iactu flavescit arenae. For the accumulated compounds of pa=s, cp. 660 f.
e)ch=lqon a)/eql): 159 n.
a)/eqla (=a)/qlous) a)gw/nwn: cp. Ph.507dusoi/stwn po/nwn | a)=ql) (n.).

potamou= sqe/nos: cp. 38: Il.13. 248sqe/nos *)idomenh=os.—tetrao/rou= tetraskelou=s (schol.): lit., ‘erect upon four legs’: elsewhere always epithet of four horses yoked abreast, or of the chariot drawn by them.
fa/sma tau/rou, a periphrasis expressing his dread aspect: cp. O. C.1568sw=ma/ t) | a)nika/tou kuno/s: Verg. Aen.6. 289et forma tricorporis umbrae (Geryon).

Acheloüs fights, then, as the e)nargh\s tau=ros,—not merely as the a)ndrei/w| ku/tei bou/prw|ros (12). Sophocles is here following the traditional version. The Homeric Scamander, in conflict with Achilles, roars ‘like a bull’ (memukw\s h)u+/te tau=ros, Il.21. 237). e)nteu=qen o(rmhqe/ntes (says the schol. there) to\n *)axelw=|on e)tau/rwsan *(hraklei= a)gwnizo/menon. The taurine form was given to Acheloüs, in that combat, by Archilochus (schol. ib.), by Pindar (schol. Il.21. 194), and by the logographer Pherecydes ( Apollod.2. 6. 5): perhaps, too, by Panyasis, the author of an epic *(hra/kleia. An engraved gem in the British Museum (King, Antique Gems II. pl. 34, fig. 3) shows Acheloüs as a bull, preparing to butt at Heracles. The gem is older than the time of Sophocles, and may, as Mr. Murray S. thinks, have followed the rendering of this subject on the still more archaic throne of Apollo at Amyclae ( Paus.3. 18. 5). Cp. n. on 520. This fight was a favourite theme in art: for the literature, see Roscher, Lex.p. 9.
Ovid (Met. 9. 1—100) departs from the old Greek version: his Acheloüs begins the fight in quasi-human form,—then turns into a serpent (63),—and then, as a last resource into a bull (80).

a)p' *oi)niada=n: a town in Acarnania, on the west bank of the Acheloüs. It was about ten miles from the mouth of that river, which is described by (2. 102) as e)s qa/lassan .. e)ciei\s par' *oi)nia/das kai\ th\n po/lin au)toi=s perilimna/zwn. Marshes, due partly to the lake Melitè, insulated the hill on which the town stood, and made the site a strong one. The name was familiar to Athenians in the poet's time. Oeniadae was long a centre of anti-Athenian influence in western Greece. It was unsuccessfully besieged by Pericles (Th. 1. 111, 454 B.C.); but, under pressure from the other Acarnanian towns, was received into the Athenian alliance by Demosthenes in 424 B.C. (Th. 4. 77). The site (now Tricardo) was first identified by Leake.

Oeniadae was some twelve miles W.S.W. of Pleuron. As Heracles arrives from his famous home to the east, so it is fitting that the river-god should come from the western town which was a chief seat of his worship. The head of the Acheloüs appears on coins of Oeniadae.
*bakxi/as: Ant.1122*bakxeu=, *bakxa=n | o( matro/polin *qh/ban | naietw=n (n.). Heracles was born at. Thebes (116 n.).

a)po\: L's accent, a)/po, represents the doctrine of some grammarians that the accent of the prep. suffered anastrophè when it stood between adj. and subst. (or subst. and adj.): see Ellendt Lex.p. 78 b. There is more reason for this when the subst. precedes; e.g., *ca/nqou a)/po dinh/entos ( Il.2. 877) is more natural than *bakxi/as a)/po *qh/bas. Modern editors differ: nor is their practice always consistent. But in all such cases it seems better to regard adj. and subst. as forming a single expression, and therefore to keep the normal accent.

pali/ntona, ‘back-bent,’ is a general epithet, referring to the shape of the bow; not to its being ‘drawn back’ in shooting, nor to its ‘springing back’ after the shot. It seems properly to have denoted a bow of which the curvature was in a direction contrary to that in which the archer bent the bow when drawing it. See Appendix.
lo/gxas, two spears, in Homeric fashion: cp. Il.3. 17 f., where Paris is armed with ka/mpula to/ca, ci/fos, and du/o dou=re. (Not, ‘pointed arrows,’ as Paley renders.)

r(o/palon, the club, made from a wild-olive tree which Heracles had plucked up by the roots on Mount Helicon: cp. Theocr. 25. 206 ff., where he carries this ba/ktron in his right hand, and his bow in the left: Apoll. Rh. 2. 34 kalau/ropa/ te trhxei=an | ...o)reitrefe/os koti/noio.—tina/sswn would suit lo/gxas ( Il.12. 298du/o dou=re tina/sswn) as well as r(o/palon, but not to/ca, for which a word such as e)/xwn or nwmw=n must be supplied: cp. n. on 353.—The picture is not distinct; his right hand must wield the club; his left may hold either bow or spears,—the other weapon being slung about him. As to the archer type of Heracles, here partly blended with the hoplite, cp. Ph.727 n.

a)ollei=s here simply=o(mou=: Hermann compares Mosch.2. 48doioi\ d' e(/stasan u(you= e)p' o)fru/os ai)gialoi=o | fw=tes a)ollh/dhn.—i)/san (epic=h)|e/san) e)s me/son: so Theocr. 22. 183 (of a fight) o( d' ei)s me/son h)/luqe *lugkeu/s.—lexe/wn: the plur., as Soph. Ant.630a)pa/tas lexe/wn, Soph. O. T.821le/xh...tou= qano/ntos.
mo/na d): whereas in an ordinary a)gw/n there were several r(abdou=xoi. ...eu)/lektros: in Ant.795 the epithet of a bride: here, of the goddess who gives fair brides to men.
e)n me/sw| here refers to the umpire as an impartial judge between two competitors.

r(abdono/mei ( = e)rrabdono/mei). The officials who maintained order in the contests at the great festivals were called r(abdou=xoi: Thuc.5. 50e)n tw=| a)gw=ni u(po\ tw=n r(abdou/xwn plhga\s e)/laben. The term included the notion of ‘umpire’: Plat. Prot. 338A pei/qesqe/ moi r(abdou=xon kai\ e)pista/thn kai\ pru/tanin e(le/sqai, o(\s u(mi=n fula/cei to\ me/trion mh=kos tw=n lo/gwn e(kate/rou. The verb r(abdonomei=n occurs only here, and r(abdono/mos itself is postclassical: but cp. Hesych. (s. v. r(a/bdoi), kai\ o( brabeuth\s r(abdono/mos.

Aphroditè is here the only person near the two combatants (cunou=sa): Deianeira views the fight from afar. But the scene was not always so conceived. Thus the Megarian qhsauro/s at Olympia contained a group of figures in gilt cedarwood, of which Paus. (6. 19. 12) says: *zeu\s de\ e)ntau=qa kai\ h( *dhia/neira kai\ *)axelw=|os kai\ *(hr<*>klh=s e)stin *)/arhs te tw=| *)axelw/|w| bohqw=n.

to/t' h)=n xero/s k.t.l. In this compressed description of the fight, the two combatants figure alternately. (1) Heracles deals blows with his fists (xero\s pa/tagos),—then retires a little, and sends a shaft from his twanging bow (to/cwn pa/tagos). (2) Acheloüs charges, and the hero's club rattles on his horns (kera/twn pa/tagos). (3) Then Heracles, <*>ning to the wrestler's arts, endeavours to grapple with Acheloüs, to spring upon his back (a)mfi/plektoi kli/makes). (4) The tauriform god butts at his adversary (metw/pwn plh/gmata). And the account fitly closes with the words, sto/nos a)mfoi=n.
For h)=n (me\n)...h)=n de\, cp. Ant.806 n.
a)na/migda=a)nami/c, suggesting the confusion of sounds. The form is a rare one: but Nicander has a)mmi/gdhn ( Alex.570, Ther.912). Cp. 839 a)/mmiga.

kera/twn. A prominent mention is given to the horns, since the story was that Heracles broke off one of them. Cp. Ovid M. 9. 85 rigidum fera dextera cornu | Dum tenet, infregit, truncaque a fronte revellit. Acheloüs ransomed it by giving his conqueror the horn of Amaltheia, or cornucopia ( Apollod.2. 7. 5). This gift, which Heracles transferred as the bride-price to Oeneus, was explained as a symbol of the increased fertility gained by works which altered the course of the Acheloüs (Strabo 10, p. 458).

h)=n with plur. subj.: the so-called schema Pindaricum: Theog. 825 h)=n e(kato\n kefalai/ (cp. ib. 321): Pind. fr. 75. 15 to/te ba/lletai to/t' e)p' a)mbro/tan xqo/n' e)ratai\ | i)/wn fo/bai: Eur. Ion1146e)nh=n d' u(fantai\ gra/mmasin toiai/d' u(fai/. In this constr., the sing. verb always precedes the plur. subject. ‘As the sing. is the general and the plur. the particular, we have not so much a want of concord as an afterthought’ (Gildersleeve, Introd. to Pindar, p. lxxxviii.). The genuine examples in Pindar are not numerous.

a)mfi/plektoi kli/makes. Ancient writers mention the kli=mac as a wrestling trick, but do not explain it (Hesych. s. v. kli/makes: Pollux 3. 155). The schol. here had evidently no clear notion of it: kli/makes: ai( e)panaba/seis (a literal paraphrase) para\ to\ a)/nw te kai\ ka/tw au)tou\s stre/fesqai e)n th=| ma/xh|. Hermann explains it thus;—the wrestler turns his adversary round, seizes him from behind, and springs on his back, so as to force him down. He relies on Ov. Met.9. 50—54, where Heracles shakes off the embrace of Acheloüs, and then, with a strong push from his hand, protinus avertit, tergoque onerosus inhaesit. For the view that this is the kli=mac see Appendix. The Acheloüs of Ovid, it should be remembered, is at that moment the horned man, not yet the bull (cp. n. on 507 f.).

At any rate klimaki/zw was a familiar term in Greek wrestling: cp. Plato comicus *pre/sbeis fr. 2 xai/reis, oi)=mai, metapetteu/sas au)to\n diaklimaki/sas te (explained by Hesych. as diapalai/sas). For a like use of wrestling terms, cp. Ar. Eq.262 f. —One of the subjects on the archaic throne of Apollo at Amyclae was h( pro\s *)axelw=|on *(hrakle/ous pa/lh ( Paus.3. 18. 5).

metw/pwn … plh/gmata, blows from the forehead; the bull is now butting (kuri/ttwn) at Heracles,—as shown on the gem mentioned above (507 f., n.). Schol.: oi( ga\r tau=roi toi=s ke/rasi kai\ metw/pois ma/xontai.—sto/nos, in the strenuous effort. Cp. Cic. Tusc.2. 23. 56(quoted by Billerbeck and others) pugiles etiam cum feriunt adversarium in iactandis cestibus ingemiscunt,—not from pain or fear, he adds, but because the very utterance helps to brace up the nerves (omne corpus intenditur).

thlaugei=, ‘seen afar,’ ‘distant’: Theog. 550 a)po\ thlauge/os faino/menos skopih=s: Nub. 281 thlefanei=s skopia/s: cp. thlwpo/s (n. on Ph.216).—Others take it actively, ‘seeing (=giving a view) from afar’ (cp. thlesko/pos). Diod.1. 50 has this use: th=s xw/ras au)toi=s sunergou/shs pro\s to\ thlauge/steron o(ra=n. But it seems less probable here.
o)/xqw|: Nonnus 43. 13 (quoted by Schneidewin) makes Deianeira watch the fight from the bank of a river. Did he, then, take o)/xqw| here as = o)/xqh|? (Cp. Ant.1132 n.)
to\n o(\n, emphatic (cp. 266): the husband who was to be hers.

†e)gw\ de\ ma/thr† me\n oi(=a fra/zw. The words e)gw\ de\ ma/thr (if no others) are unquestionably corrupt. They have been explained to mean:—‘I speak as a mother’ (or ‘her mother’) ‘might speak’: i.e., with all a mother's tender sympathy. If anything could increase the strangeness of such language, it would be the fact that the young maidens of Trachis are speaking of one who is old enough to be their mother. Or: (2) ‘I tell the story as her mother told it,’—a way of explaining how they can describe what they had not seen. This needs no refutation.

The true key to this passage depends on observing the sequence of topics. (1) In 517—522, to/t' h)=n xero/s...sto/nos a)mfoi=n, we have a brief picture of the fight. (2) Then vv. 523—525, a( d' eu)w=pis...a)koi/tan, mark Deianeira's suspense. (3) Next comes the obscure parenthesis, e)gw\ de\...fra/zw. (4) And then we return, at v. 527, to Deianeira's suspense,—not, however, in a form which adds anything new to vv. 523 —525, but in one which merely repeats their substance:—to\ d' a)mfinei/khton...a)mme/nei.

Now, to justify such a repetition, it is manifest that (2) and (4) should be separated, not by a mere parenthesis, such as (3) now is, but by some further allusion to the fight. This inference is strengthened by the phrase, to\ d' a)mfinei/khton o)/mma nu/mfas, which gains point if a reference to the nei=kos has immediately preceded.

I believe that e)gw\ has come from a)gw
, under the influence of fra/zw. The sense of the verse was, ‘And the strife goes on raging, as I describe’ (referring to vv. 517—522). *m*a*t*h*r may well be a corruption of *m*a*r*g*a*i, a loss of *r having been followed by a change of *g to *t. This may have happened after a)gw
 had become e)gw\, with help, perhaps, from a reminiscence of El.233a)ll' ou)=n eu)noi/a| g' au)dw=, | ma/thr w(sei/ tis pista/. Cp. Hesychius marga=|: margai/nei, u(bri/zei, e)nqousia=|, mai/netai. Eur. H. F.1005o(/s nin fo/nou margw=ntos e)/sxe. I would read, then, a)gw
 de\ marga=| me/n, oi(=a fra/zw. The next words, to\ d' a)mfinei/khton k.t.l., then fiftly turn from the stubborn fight to her continuing suspense.—For other views, see Appendix.

o)/mma, in periphrasis, is sometimes little more than ‘form,’ ( Eur. Ion1261w)= tauro/morfon o)/mma *khfisou= patro/s:) but here it refers specially to her anxious gaze: cp. Soph. Ai.139pefo/bhmai | pthnh=s w(s o)/mma pelei/as. Since the words o)/mma nu/mfas form one notion, the adj. is in the nom.: Soph. Ant.794.
e)leino\n a)mme/nei: awaits (the result) with a piteous look: cp. Ph.1130h)= pou e)leino\n o(ra=|s.

ka)po\ matro\s a)/far be/baken. Sophocles does not tell us whether Heracles took his bride away from her father's home immediately after the fight. According to the common account Heracles and Deianeira remained with Oeneus for a considerable time after their marriage, while the hero did various exploits. ( Apollod.2. 7. 6: Diod.4. 36, who speaks of three years.) Then, having accidentally slain a youth in the house of Oeneus, Heracles departed with his wife and infant son (Hyllus) to Trachis.
a)/far is not necessarily inconsistent with that version: it means merely that the result of the fight at once transferred Deianeira from the care of her mother to that of a husband.
w(/ste is preferable to w(/sper (cr. n.) in the first foot of the glyconic verse: for this use of it, cp. 112, 367, 537, 699, 703, 768, 1071.

po/rtis e)rh/ma: Schneidewin compares Anacreon fr. 52 oi(=a/ te nebro\n neoqhle/a | galaqhno/n, o(/st' e)n u(/lh| keroe/sshs | a)poleifqei\s a)po\ mhtro\s e)ptoh/qh. The image is especially suitable to one who was destined to have no secure or permanent home.

div2.p: Second e)peiso/dion. Deianeira confides to the Chorus her plan for regaining her husband's love: she will send him a robe, secretly anointed with a philtre.—Lichas enters (598); he receives the robe from her, and departs bearing it to Heracles.

div3.p: h)=mos (155 n.): this is the only Attic instance of the epic th=mos.
o( ce/nos, merely as a guest from a distance; Lichas was no stranger to her (cp. 232, 310).
qroei= seems to imply that their voices could be heard within, and that therefore she felt safe from sudden interruption.
tai=s ai)xm. paisi\n: who charge him with messages to their kinsfolk and friends among the Oechalian captives with Heracles: these maidens were e)cai/retoi (245).
w(s e)p' e)co/dw|: for w(s denoting the intention, cp. Ph.58 n.: and for e)p' e)co/dw|, cp. El.1322.
qurai=os fem., as El.313qurai=on oi)xnei=n: cp. 478 patrw=|os, and O. C.751.
ta\ me\n (adv.) refers to the recital which begins at v. 555: ta\ d), to vv. 536 ff.
xersi\n is slightly emphasised by its place (cp. O. T.139e)kei=non o( ktanw/n); her sense of wrong (oi(=a pa/sxw) has prompted action.

sugkatoiktioume/nh: some take the midd. as meaning, ‘to seek pity for myself from you.’ Rather it means simply, ‘to bewail (my woes) along with you’ (i.e., in your presence). So Her.2. 121a)poklau/santa h)\ katoiktisa/menon: 3. 156 katoikti/zeto, fa\s... peponqe/nai k.t.l. The midd. oi)kti/zomai is used by Aesch. ( Aesch. Suppl.1032), by Eur. (I. T. 486), and even in prose ( Thuc.2. 51).

ko/rhn, as Theocr. 27. 65 teke/wn trofo/s, ou)ke/ti kw/ra: but it is also said of a young wife ( Il.6. 247 etc.) where her father is mentioned: in loc. cit. koura/wn refers to *pria/moio in the preceding line.— e)zeugme/nhn: see 1226. Deianeira's first belief (309) has been changed by learning the vehemence of her lord's new passion (359 f.: 488 f.). Cp. O. T.825ga/mois... | ...zugh=nai.

pareisde/degmai k.t.l. Among the captives whom she has received into her house, there is one who is to be her rival. This suggests the comparison with the master of a trading vessel, who, along with the rest of his cargo, ships some merchandise which is destined to prove his ruin. The parallelism between fo/r- ton and lwbhto\n e)mpo/lhma marks that the fo/rtos, too, is disastrous: but the way in which it is so is left indefinite. There is no explicit reference to overloading.—For pareisde/degmai cp. De part. anim. 1 (p. 662 a 9) a)nagkai=on ...pareisde/xesqai to\ u(gro\n a(/ma th=| trofh=| (=‘to receive incidentally’). So, here, the para/ seems to mean strictly, ‘have received as an incident of receiving the others’ (Iolè having come in among them); cp. parapollu/nai etc. The objection to taking the prep. as=‘surreptitiously’ (=laqrai=on in 377) is that Deianeira was the victim, not agent, of the fraud.
lwbhto\n in active sense, as Ph.607lwbh/t' e)/ph, words of contumely.
e)mpo/lhma, a thing gained by traffic; here, an ‘acquisition’ (in an ironical sense).

th=s e)mh=s freno/s with lwbhto\n: cp. the gen. after lumanth/rios, o)le/qrios, etc. It might also depend on the phrase lwbhto\n e)mpo/lhma as=bla/bh. Others understand: ‘a disastrous merchandise, (bought by) my loyalty to Heracles’ (t<*> e)mh=s freno/s as gen. of price).
du/) ou)=sai, both of us: O. T.1505o)lw/lamen du/) o)/nte (n.).

mia=s u(po\ xlai/nhs: Eur. fr. 606 o(/tan d' u(p' a)ndro\s xlai=nan eu)genou=s pe/sh|s: Theocr. 18. 19 *zano/s toi quga/thr u(po\ ta\n mi/an w)/|xeto xlai=nan (shared the bed of Menelaus). For u(po/ with gen. in this sense, cp. Soph. Ant.65 n.
u(pagka/lisma: Ant.650 n.

Mr Murray S. has shown me a curious illustration of this passage. A vase of the 6th cent. B.C., now in the British Museum, depicts two women under the same xlai=na,—a symbolical representation, perhaps, of a common grief.
o( … h(mi=n kalou/menos=o(\n h(mei=s... e)kalou=men: though in O. T.8o( pa=si kleino\s...kalou/menos the dat. goes with the adj.
pisto/s k.t.l.: cp. O. T.385*kre/wn o( pisto/s, Ant.31to\n a)gaqo\n *kre/onta.

oi)kou/ria, sc. dw=ra: tou= makrou= xro/nou (gen. of price), for the long time during which she has been his true wife. Cp. Eur. H. F.1371(Heracles bewailing Megara) se/ t' ou)x o(moi/ws, w)= ta/lain), a)pw/lesa, | w(/sper su\ ta)ma\ le/ktr' e)/sw|zes a)sfalw=s, | makra\s diantlou=s' e)n do/mois oi)kouri/as.
ou)k e)pi/stamai, am incapable of it: cp. 582: Ant.686 n.

th=|de th=| no/sw|, a very rare substitute for the cogn. accus. It is justified by the fact that nosei=n is a word of such wide meaning; while th=|de th=| no/sw| here signifies, e)/rwti. So in Aesch. P. V.384, th=|de th=| no/sw| nosei=n, the dat. really means, ‘to be distempered in this special way’ (viz., by good sense).
to\ d' au)= cunoikei=n: the inf. with art., placed at the beginning, gives an indignant tone: ‘but as to living...’ etc. Cp. Ant.78to\ de\ | bi/a| politw=n dra=n e)/fun a)mh/xanos.

The text of this passage is, I believe, sound, though the diction is bold, and somewhat careless. The one h(/bh (Iolè's) is growing to the perfect flower, while the other (Deianeira's) is declining. (Cp. Ar. Lys.596th=s de\ gunaiko\s smikro\s o( kairo/s.) In what follows, these points may be noted.

(1) w(=n, fem., refers to the two phases of h(/bh just mentioned. The gen. is partitive: ‘of (out of) these h(=bai, the eye delights in the a)/nqos.’ Here a)/nqos is a shorter way of expressing th
 a)nqou=san,—the h(/bh which is in its early bloom. w(=n could not, surely, refer to th
 me
 e(/rpousan pro/sw only, as if it meant tw=n ne/wn gunaikw=n (schol.): it must refer to th
 de\ fqi/nousan also. Nor, again, could w)=n stand for w(=n th=s me/n.

(2) tw=n d' u(pektre/pei po/da. Here tw=n d) ought in strictness to have been th=s d), sc. th=s fqinou/shs h(/bhs. But, in the poet's thought, tw=n d) means, ‘the other kind,’— i.e., the women who represent the fqi/nousa h(/bh. The subject to u(pektre/pei is not o)fqalmo/s, but the man implied by it (o( o(rw=n). The eye, as being here the guide of the choice, might, indeed, be said to ‘turn the foot aside,’ in the sense of causing that movement; but this would be awkward. For the transition of thought from o)fqalmo/s to the person, cp. Eur. Med.1244(quoted by Wecklein), a)/g), w)= ta/laina xei\r e)mh/, labe\ ci/fos, | la/b), e(/rpe pro\s balbi=da luphra\n bi/ou.

(3) a)farpa/zein, said of the eye, means, to seize eagerly upon the beautiful sight (cp. Hor. Sat. 2. 5. 53 Sic tamen ut limis rapias etc.). So we can speak of ‘snatching’ a glance, or of the eyes ‘drinking in’ beauty. There is no allusion to the idea expressed by Aesch. Suppl. 663 h(/bas d' a)/nqos a)/drepton e)/stw.

(4) o)fqalmo\s: the swift and ardent glance of the lover is often mentioned in Greek poetry: see esp. fr. 431 toia/nd' e)n o)/yei li/gga qhrathri/an | e)/rwtos, a)straph/n tin' o)mma/twn, e)/xei. Aesch. Suppl.1003kai\ parqe/nwn xlidai=sin eu)mo/rfois e)/pi | pa=s tis parelqw\n <*>mmatos qelkth/rion | to/ceum' e)/pemyen i(me/rou nikw/menos.

tau=t' ou)=n, for this reason, then: the pron. is adverbial: cp. Aesch Pers.159tau=ta dh\ lipou=s' i(ka/nw xruseosto/lmous do/mous: Vesp. 1358 tau=t' ou)=n peri/ mou de/doike mh\ diafqarw=. This seems better than to govern tau=t) by fobou=mai. —po/sis was in Attic mainly a poetical word; but Arist. uses it, as Arist. Pol.7. 16. 18o(/tan h)=| kai\ prosagoreuqh=| po/sis: where, as here, it denotes the recognised or legal status.

kalh=tai is right here, because there is a real anxiety: kalei=tai (which would be fut., like kalei= in El.971) would imply too much certainty. The subjunctive is similarly preferable to the indic. in Ph.30(kurh=|) and ib. 494 (bebh/kh|). kalh=tai suits po/sis (‘bear the name of husband’); cp. 149: but a)nh/r, denoting here a clandestine relationship, requires h)=| to be supplied. Cp. 561.

a)nh/r: i.e., paramour. Cp. the sarcasm of the comic poet Pherecrates (fr. incert. 5) on Alcibiades:—ou)k w)\n a)nh\r ga\r [i.e., e)/ti ne/os w)/n] *)alkibia/dhs, w(s dokei=, | a)nh\r a(pasw=n tw=n gunaikw=n e)sti nu=n.
a)ll' ou) ga/r: elliptical: O. C.755 n.

553 f. The MSS. have h(=| d' e)/xw | luth/rion lu/phma. For the adj., cp. El.635luthri/ous | eu)xa\s...deima/twn: ib. 1490 to/d' a)\n kakw=n mo/non ge/noito tw=n pa/lai luth/rion: fr. 687 to\ mequ/ein phmonh=s luth/rion. Clearly, then, luth/rion is sound: and it must mean, as everywhere else, ‘giving deliverance.’ The corrupt word is lu/phma: it has displaced some word of which luth/rion could be the epithet. I believe that Sophocles wrote lw/fhma, ‘a means of relief.’ Hesychius shows that this noun was not only current, but tolerably familiar; for he has lw=far: lw/fhma,—using it to explain the rarer form. The corruption into lu/phma probably arose through a marginal gloss, lu/phs, on luth/rion.

Deianeira is here speaking of an expedient which gives her some hope, indeed, but no assured confidence (590 f.). This exactly suits the usage of lwfa=n and its derivatives, which denote the alleviation of evil,—not its complete removal. Cp. Ai.61e)peidh\ tou=d' e)lw/fhsen po/nou. Thuc.6. 12a)po\ no/sou mega/lhs kai\ pole/mou braxu/ ti lelwfh/ka<*>en. Plat. Legg. 854 C e)a\n me/n soi drw=nti tau=ta lwfa=| ti to\ no/shma. Thuc. uses lw/fhsis, ‘abatement’ (4. 81 tou= pole/mou). Deianeira, in bethinking her of the philtre, has found that which holds out a promise of deliverance, and assuages, though it does not cure, her pain,—a luth/rion lw/fhma.

The attempted versions of luth/rion lu/phma have been these:—(1) With a comma after th=|d): ‘a thing to grieve this girl, for my deliverance’:—a grammatically sound phrase, but wholly unsuited to Deianeira, whose aim is to be more loved than Iolè (584 ff.),—but not to pain her. (2) Taking luth/rion as=luto/n: ‘how I find that my pain is remediable.’ This is impossible. (3) Governing lu/phma by luth/rion: ‘how I have a thing to remedy my pain.’ Also impossible.

Paley, changing e)/xw to e)/xei, renders, ‘in what way my grief has a remedy’— making luth/rion a subst. This is clearly untenable. He cites Pind. P.5. 106to\ kalli/nikon luth/rion dapana=n | me/los xari/en: but there luth/rion is a second epithet of me/los. Nor is the case helped by Hesychius, luth/rion: fulakth/rion.— th=|d) u(mi=n fra/sw: the words mean strictly that the story will follow the course— i.e., will exhibit the line of thought—by which the remedy has been found.
h)=n moi: the imperf., because she has now used it.

pote\ belongs in sense to dw=ron, as though we had e)do/qh pote/. If the comma after qhro/s were omitted, and h)=n joined with kekrumme/non (as=e)ke/krupto), then pote\ would go with the verb: but kekrumme/non seems to be an afterthought.

palaio\n, because she has had it long; a)rxai/ou, because he lived long ago. This emphasis on the past is natural in one who is looking back sadly to the days of her youth, and speaking to young maidens for whom Nessus is only a legendary name.
qhro/s: so Il.1. 268fhrsi\n o)reskw/|oisi. They are called ke/ntauroi in Il.11. 832, as in the Odyssey (21. 295). Cp. below, 680.
le/bhti: properly a deep basin; also a kind of kettle used in cooking: but the poets can use the word to describe a cinerary urn (as El.1401). Here it means some kind of urn or jar.

dasuste/rnou: shagginess is a regular attribute of the Centaurs in Greek poetry and art: cp. 837: Il.2. 743fh=ras ...laxnh/entas: Hom. hymn 3. 224 ke/ntauron lasiau/xena. In Ov. Met.12. 284Cometes is the name of a Centaur.

para\ *ne/ssou, because it was his dw=ron (555): he invited her to take it, and told her how to use it: e)k fonw=n, gathered up from his wounds, as he lay dying. fonw=n, Bergk's correction of fo/nwn, seems right. The plur. fo/noi elsewhere (1) denotes separate acts of slaughter, O. C.1234: or (2) is a tragic expression for one such act (like qa/natoi): as El.11patro\s e)k fo/nwn: ib. 779 fo/nous patrw|ous. But here we expect rather a word which shall directly suggest the wounds: cp. 573 sfagw=n. And fonw=n can do so, since the phrase e)n fonai=s so often refers to carnage in battle. The schol. has fo/nwn in the lemma, but explains by ai(/matos, and quotes Il.10. 521(a)/ndras t' a)spai/rontas) e)n a)rgale/h|si fonh=|sin. Cp. Ant.696e)n fonai=s | peptw=t) (n.). If metre had allowed e)k fo/nou, there would then have been no reason for change.

The name *ne/ssos symbolises the roar of the angry torrent: the Sanskrit is nad, loud sound, whence nadá-s, ‘bellower’ (bull), or river: nad-i, flood: Curtius Etym. § 287 b. Hence the Thracian river *ne/stos (also *ne/ssos, Hes. Th.341), and the Arcadian *ne/da, described by Strabo as r(eu=ma labro
 e)k tou= *lukai/ou katio/n (8, p. 348). Among the Centaurs whom Heracles met at Mount Pholoè were *dou/pwn and *(/omados,—names likewise denoting noise; and it is noteworthy that Homados, like Nessus, was a ravisher: e)n *)arkadi/a| th
 *eu)rusqe/ws a)delfh
 *)alkuo/nhn biasa/menos a)nh|re/qh ( Diod.4. 12).

to\n baqu/rroun … *eu)/hnon. The Evenus (Fidhari) rises on the high western slopes of Oeta; in its lower course, it passes through Aetolia, and enters the Corinthian Gulf at a point about 12 miles w. of Antirrhion. Calydon was on its w. bank; Pleuron, some 10 or 12 miles to the w. It is ‘one of the fiercest and most treacherous torrents in Greece’ (Tozer, Geo. of Greece, p. 96). Cp. Ov. Met. 9. 104 Venerat Eveni rapidas Iove natus ad undas. The older name of the river, *luko/rmas (Strabo7. 327), expressed the ‘wolf-like’ rush of its waters.

The association of Nessus with the Evenus well illustrates the significance of the Centaur as a personification of a ravaging torrent. (Cp. Mr Sidney Colvin in Journ. of Hellen. Stud. vol. I. p. 160: also Mure, Tour in Greece, I. 170.) In Ov. Met.2. 638 a daughter of the Centaur Cheiron is called Ocyroe (*)wkuro/h), because born ‘Fluminis in rapidi ripis.’

potamo\n … brotou\s … )po/reue: for the double acc., cp. Eur. Alc.442gunai=k' a)ri/stan | li/mnan *)axeronti/an poreu/sas e)la/ta| dikw/pw|. Here the second acc. denotes the space traversed; it would more usually denote the place to which, as in Eur. Tro.1085e)me\...ska/fos | ...poreu/sei | ...*)/argos.—For the prodelision of the augment in )po/reue, cp. Soph. O. C.1602taxei= )po/reusan: Soph. Ph.360e)pei\ )da/krusa.—mis- qou=: acc. to Apollodorus (2. 7. 6) Nessus pretended divine authority for levying this toll,—le/gwn para\ qew=n th\n porqmei/an ei)lhfe/nai dia\ dikaiosu/nhn.—pompi/mois: cp. I. A. 1319 naw=n... | ...e)la/tan pompai/an.—ou)/te lai/fesin new/s might be an instrum. dat. construed directly with )po/reue: but it is perhaps truer to say that the notion of pe/mpwn is evolved from the preceding clause. Cp. 512 (tina/sswn).

to\n patrw=|on … sto/lon, ‘by my father's sending,’ cogn. acc. to e(spo/mhn: cp. 159 a)gw=nas e)ciw/n (n.). The peculiarity is that sto/los here=pe/myis, corresponding to the sense of the act. ste/llw: whereas it usu. means ‘expedition,’ ‘journey,’ from midd. ste/llomai. It may be noted, however, that the boldness is softened by the fact that sto/los sometimes meant a journey with ref. to its purpose, ‘a mission’: O. C.358 n. Certainly patrw=|os sto/los would ordinarily mean, ‘a journey of my father<*>s,’ or, ‘an expedition despatched by’ him; yet the sense required here seems possible for poetry. The phrase cannot well mean, (1) ‘the journey prescribed for me by my father’; nor (2) ‘under my father's escort,’—as if Oeneus had accompanied them for some distance.

The soundness of the words is confirmed by their dramatic fitness. There is a tacit contrast in her thoughts between herself and the new paramour; she thinks of the long-past day when her father gave her to her husband, and sent her forth with him. The words also accord with that tone of passivity in which she has already spoken of her marriage (6—27). She welcomed Heracles as a deliverer, and has learned to love him; but she had no voice in the bestowal of her hand.— Cp. fr. 521 (the young girl is happy at home, but the bride is sent forth by her parents to a doubtful fate): ai(\ ne/ai me\n e)n patro\s | h(/diston, oi)=mai, zw=men a)nqrw/pwn bi/on: | ... | o(/tan d' e)s h(/bhn e)cikw/meq' e)/mfrones, | w)qou/meq' e)/cw.—See Appendix.
eu)=nis=eu)ne/tis, as in Eur. Or.929 etc.

fe/rwn e)p' w)/mois. Nessus is here imagined as a Centaur of the older form known to Greek art,—viz., a complete man, with the barrel and hinder parts of a horse attached to the middle of his back. A Centaur on the la/rnac of Cypselus at Olympia is described by Paus. (5. 19. 7) as ou) tou\s pa/ntas i(/ppou po/das, tou\s de\ e)/mprosqen au)tw=n e)/xwn a)ndro/s. This form may be called the andro-centaur. The more familiar hippo-centaur—a complete horse, only with a human chest and head substituted for the equine neck and head—was of later origin. In Journ. Hellen. Stud. I. 130 Mr Sidney Colvin gives a wood-cut of an early gem (in the British Museum), representing an androcentaur carrying off a woman, who is grasped in his right arm. Similar subjects occur on coins of Eastern Macedonia. Violence of this kind was part of the u(/bris (1096) ascribed to the savage Centaurs, and appears in numerous legends (J. H. S., l.c., p. 140).
h)=: cp. O. T.1123 n. The third person, h)=n, would be less fitting: she speaks of her own helplessness at the moment.

me/sw| po/rw|: for the dat., cp. 172: El.313nu=n d' a)groi=si tugxa/nei.—matai/ais, implying rash folly ( Ant.1339 n.), here =‘wanton.’ The schol. wrongly took it to mean that the attempt was baffled by Heracles.

e)k d' h)/u+s' e)gw/: Sophocles has avoided the error of Archilochus, who had described Deianeira as making a prolix appeal to her husband (pro\s to\n *(hrakle/a r(ayw|dou=san: Dion Chrysost. or. 60).

e)pistre/yas, intrans., as in Her.2. 103e)pistre/yas o)pi/sw h)/ie: Vesp. 422 e)pi/strefe | deu=ro. The poet, though he has called the river baqu/rroun (559), seems to imagine Heracles as wading across it, in front of Nessus. If Heracles had been carried over first, he would naturally have been facing the river. Ovid makes him swim across, and shoot the Centaur from the bank ( Met.9. 110 ff.).

komh/thn: Ph.711 n. According to Dion (or. 60), Sophocles was criticised on the ground that the hero's act might have been fatal to Deianeira; Nessus might have dropped her in the river. It would be enough to suppose that Heracles could not pause to think; but the context also suggests, as we have seen, that he was near enough to rescue her at need.

pleu/monas=pneu/monas (rt pnu). Curtius (Etym. § 370) explains the change of n to l by ‘the rarity of the sound-group pn and the frequency of pl’; comparing the kindred words for ‘lungs,’ Lat. pulmo, Church-Slavonic plušta, Lithuanian plaúczei. The form with l is attested as Attic by schol. Ar. Pax1069, Eustath. p. 483. 8. In 1054, as here, L gives the l form, though with n written above by the first hand: but in 1054 pneumo/nwn.

e)kqnh/|skwn, as the faintness of approaching death began to come over him. The regular sense of e)kqnh/|skein is ‘to swoon away’: cp. Hist. Anim. 3. 19 (p. 521 a 11) a)fieme/nou (ai(/matos) e)/cw plei/onos me
 e)kqnh/|skousi, pollou= d' a)/gan a)poqnh/|skousin. So Legg. 959 A distinguishes a person in a swoon, to
 e)kteqnew=ta, from to
 o)/ntws teqnhko/ta.
569 ff. For tosou=ton, referring to what follows, and associated with toso/nde, cp. Ai.679 ff. e)s toso/nd)...tosau=q).—toso/nd) is explained by e)a\n ga\r etc.
tw=n e)mw=n … porqmw=n: porqmo/s usu. means (1) a ferry, or (2) the act of crossing water; here the second sense passes into that of porqmei/a, ‘my services as ferryman’: for the plur., cp. 628.

e)a\n ga\r … u(/dras. The gen. tw=n e)mw=n sfagw=n depends on the prep. in a)mfi/qrepton, ‘coagulated around the wound.’ e)ne/gkh| xersi/n: for the midd., cp. 558 a)neilo/mhn (n.). The phrase seems to imply a careful collecting of the blood with a cioth. h(=| melagxo/lous k.t.l.: ‘at the part (of the wound) where the monstrous hydra has tinged the arrow with black gall’: i.e., ‘where the hydra's gall, with which the arrow is tinged, can be traced,’—by a darker tint in that portion of the blood with which it has mixed. When the arrow was withdrawn from the wound, there would be a gush of blood, but some parts of the blood would have been more affected by the venom than others; and Nessus wishes her to take the most envenomed parts. The stress is on melagxo/lous, and the whole phrase is a compressed way of saying, h(=| me/las xo/los e)sti/n, <*> i)ou\s u(/dra e)/bayen (cp. O. T.1451 n.). For the proleptic adj., cp. Ant.475o)pto\n...periskelh=: for the plur. i)ou/s (referring to the single arrow of 567), Ai.231ci/fesin, El.196genu/wn. The double barb makes such a plur. intelligible. Heracles cannot have shot twice.

qre/mma … u(/dras: cp. 508 n.: so qre/mma refers to a monster in 1093 and 1099. For the periphrasis, cp. Legg. 790 D ta\ neogenh= pai/dwn qre/mmata.—*lernai/as: dwelling in the marsh of Lerna, on the Argolic coast, s. of Argos. Apollod.2. 5. 2to\ de\ sw=ma th=s u(/dras a)nasxi/sas th=| xolh=| tou\s o)i+stou\s e)/bayen.

Others explain thus:—‘If thou gather the blood from my wound, clotted around (the arrow), at the place where the hydra has tinged it,’ etc., i.e., at the arrow's head. This is quite possible, but is open to objections. (1) The language in 557 f. (para\ *ne/ssou...e)k fonw=n) implies that she obtained the blood directly from the body, not from the arrow-head. (2) The phrase e)ne/gkh| xersi/n here favours the same view.

If we adopted the conjecture mela/gxolos … i)o/s, the latter word would mean ‘venom,’ and qre/mma ‘issue’ (cp. 834 e)/trefe d' ai)o/los dra/kwn): the object of e)/bayen would be au)ta/s (the wound), The objection is that the wily monster does not wish to draw Deianeira's attention to the venom;—as he would then do very pointedly. He is content to speak of the dark colour (melagxo/lous).

Ovid describes the incident thus:—The arrow is withdrawn, and the blood flows from the wound, mixtus Lernaei tabe veneni: Nessus then presents Deianeira with a garment steeped in the blood (velamina tincta cruore): Met.9. 129 ff.

w(/ste mh/tin' ei)sidw\n ste/rcei. After w(/ste, the negative of the infin. is mh/, but of the indic., ou). Here the mh/ must be due to the final sense: i.e., the notion of result is merged in that of aim; as if it were o(/pws mh/. I have not found any real parallel. Dem. or. 19 § 218 writes, tosau/ths a)nandri/as...o(mologei=te ei)=nai mestoi/, w(/ste mh/t' e)n th=| xw/ra| polemi/wn o)/ntwn mh/t' e)k qala/tths poliourkou/menoi...e<*>ta th\n ei)rh/nhn e)poih/sasqe. But there the mh/ seems clearly ‘generic’: i.e., the sense is: ‘you are so weak as to have made peace at a time when there was no enemy in the country,’ etc. [Prof. Goodwin, Moods and Tenses, new ed., § 606, suggests that e)poih/sasqe virtually depends on an ei) further back, and that the force of w(/ste is lost. This would be conceivable if the mh/ came after e)poih/sasqe: but it immediately follows w(/ste.] —The opposite anomaly occurs in El.780 f. wst' ou)/te... | ...stega/zein.
a)nti\ sou=, instead of the gen. after the comparat.: Ant.182 n.
e)nnoh/sas): Sophocles prefers the act. voice of this compound: Ph.1440 n.
do/mois, simply ‘in the house’: e)gkeklh|me/non adds the notion expressed in 686 by e)n muxoi=s sw/|zein.
xitw=na to/nd): a handmaid carries the casket (622) containing the robe.
e)/baya. The notion of a fi/ltron in the form of an unguent was a familiar one: thus in Eur. Hipp.516Phaedra asks the Nurse, po/tera de\ xristo\n h)\ poto\n to\ fa/rmakon;

prosbalou=s), ‘with application of everything that he directed,’—i.e., applying the philtre to the robe with attention to all the prescribed details. From vv. 680—687 it appears that Nessus had said more than she repeats in 572—577. He gave qesmoi/ (682), precise instructions.—This is better than to understand, ‘with all the additions that he enjoined’ (schol. kai\ a)/lla tina\ summi/casa): though it may be supposed that the coagulated blood, before being applied to a large surface, was diluted with water. (Schneidewin explains the word by Apollod.2. 7. 6to/n te go/non o(\n a)fh=ke kata\ th=s gh=s kai\ to\...ai(=ma summi/cai.)— Not, ‘with observance of all that he said’<*> as if nw=| (or nou=n) were understood. See on 844 prose/bale.

pepei/rantai (3rd sing.), from the epic peirai/nw: Od.12. 37tau=ta me\n ou(/tw pa/nta pepei/rantai: Pind. I.7. 24di/kas e)pei/raine. The Attic form pepe/rantai occurs in Plat. Rep.502 The E. words have a tragic significance. Her remedial measures are now complete.

kaka\s de\ to/lmas. She wishes to assure them that she intends no harm to Heracles, and has no reason to fear evil. The results of so-called ‘lovecharms’ were often disastrous. Antiphon's first oration is against a woman charged with the wilful murder of her husband by causing a love-potion to be administered to him: she pleaded, ou)k e)pi\ qana/tw|...dido/nai, a)ll' e)pi\ fi/ltrois (§ 9). Magn. Mor. 1. 16 (p. 1188 b 31) notices a case in which a woman was tried under like circumstances by the Areiopagus, but acquitted, because there was no proof of pro/noia. Plut. Mor.139A compares lovers won by such means to fish captured by baits which spoil them; ai( fi/ltra tina\ kai\ gohtei/as e)pitexnw/menai toi=s a)ndra/si, kai\ xeirou/menai dia\ h(donh=s au)tou/s, e)mplh/ktois kai\ a)noh/tois kai\ diefqarme/nois sumbiou=si. Alciphron 1. 37 a)mfiba/llein (to have dubious effects) ei)/wqe ta\ fi/ltra, kai\ a)poskh/ptein ei)s o)/leqron.

mh/t' e)pistai/mhn …, mh/t' e)kma/qoimi: an emphatic way of protesting how utterly foreign such thoughts are to her nature: —‘may I never be capable of them (543 n.), or be led to learn anything about them.’
stugw=: for the indic. coordinated with the opt., cp. 143 n.

fi/ltrois d' e)a/n pws. The use of e)a/n pws is the same here as when it serves for the elliptical expression of a hope or aim ( O. C.1769*qh/bas d' h(ma=s | ...pe/myon, e)a/n pws | diakwlu/swmen i)o/nta fo/non. But memhxa/nhtai tou)/rgon, since it follows the clause with e)a/n pws, is not really analogous to the verb which usually precedes such a clause; as pe/myon in O. C.1770.The constr. is not, memhxa/nhtai tou)/rgon, e)a/n pws u(perbalw/meqa, ‘the deed has been devised, in the hope that,’ etc. Rather the sense is: ‘But as to the possibility of prevailing by love-charms,— the means for that attempt have been devised.’ memhxa/nhtai tou)/rgon is an abrupt substitute for tou=to peira=sqai bou/lomai or the like, and is prompted by her nervous sense that she has taken a bold step. The peculiar form of the sentence arises from the wish to emphasise fi/ltrois as opposed to kaka\s to/lmas.

u(perbalw/meqa: the midd., in this sense, is more freq. than the act.; but the dat. usu. denotes the point of excellence ( Ar. Eq.409ou)/ toi/ m' u(perbalei=sq' a)naidei/a|), and not, as here, the means.

th\n pai=da, —strong in the charms of youth (547).— qe/lktroisi, a reiteration that the means are to be gentle: cp. Eur. Hipp.509e)/stin kat' oi)/kous fi/ltra moi qelkth/ria | e)/rwtos. —toi=s e)f) *(hraklei=, aimed at him, as the person whose love was to be won: cp. Apollod.2. 7. 6ei) qe/loi fi/ltron pro\s *(hrakle/a e)/xein.
ei)/ ti mh\: ti (adv.)=‘perchance’: cp. 712: O. T.969: O. C.1450.
ma/taion, culpably rash (cp. n. on 565).

ei) de\ mh/: ‘otherwise,’ after a negative: cp. Vesp. 434 mh\ meqh=sqe mhdeni/: | ei) de\ mh/, )n pe/dais paxei/ais ou)de\n a)risth/sete. So Thuc.1. 28, Phaed.63D, etc. This rather clumsy formula was recommended by brevity: i.e., in Ar. l. c., the alternative was ei) de\ meqh/sesqe, as here ei) de\ dokw=.— pepau/somai: Soph. Ant.91 n.

pi/stis, in an objective sense, a ground of confidence, a warranty: cp. 623: El.887ti/n), w)= ta/lain) El., i)dou=sa pi/stin;—dokei=s par) h(mi=n: Eur. Med.762gennai=os a)nh/r, | *ai)geu=, par' e)moi\ dedo/khsai.

590 f. The whole phrase ou(/tws e)/xei is slightly emphasised by ge, and limits the affirmative implied by the art. before pi/stis: ‘The present state of the warranty (given by ta\ drw/mena) is this,’ etc. It seems needless to suppose that the literal sense of pi/stis here is different from that in 588.

w(s=w(/ste, answering to ou(/tws: cp. Her.2. 135ou)/tw dh/ ti kleinh\ e)ge/neto w(s kai\ oi( pa/ntes...to\ ou)/noma e)ce/maqon. (When w(s stands for w(/ste, it is more often with the infin.) It is possible, but less fitting, to take w(s as=‘since,’ introducing the explanation (like ga/r).
to\ me\n dokei=n is ‘the expecting’ to succeed (rather than ‘the seeming likely’ to do so).

pei/ra| d' ou) proswmi/lhsa, have not come to close quarters with an experiment, —have not actually essayed it: cp. Plat. Tim. 88C gumnastikh=| prosomilou=nta: Thuc.6. 70toi=s...e)la/xista pole/mw| w(milhko/si, opp. to toi=s...e)mpeirote/rois.

drw=san: the partic. expresses the leading idea (‘if thou wouldest know, thou must act’): cp. O. C.1038 n.— gnw=ma, a means of judging, a test: Her.7. 52*)/iwnas...tw=n e)/xomen gnw=ma me/giston. (In poetry the word sometimes means merely ‘judgment,’ ‘opinion’: Aesch. Ag.1352, Eur. Her.407.)—The Chorus do not say that she ought to make the experiment; but only that, until she does so, she can have no certainty.

a)ll' au)ti/k): for the repetition of a)lla/ (after 592), cp. Ph.645 Ph., 647.— e)leu/setai, will depart (to Heracles); and so the result will soon be known. For this sense of the verb, cp. Ph.48 n.: for the form, O. C.1206 n.
mo/non, modo: cp. 1109: Ph.528.

par' u(mw=n, from your side, on your part: the gen. is probably right, though the v. l. par' u(mi=n is specious. Silence is their contribution to her plan. Cp. El.469sigh\ par' u(mw=n pro\s qew=n e)/stw, fi/lai. —stegoi/meq), have my action kept secret. Cp. fr. 614 su/ggnwte ka)na/sxesqe sigw=sai: to\ ga | gunaici
 ai)sxro
 su
 gunai=ka dei= ste/gein (so I amend su
 gunaiki\: cp. Ant.85krufh=| de\ keu=qe, su
 d' au)/tws e)gw/).— Blaydes may be right in reading stegw/meq) (cp. O. T.49 n.). But the opt. is defensible, as expressing an ardent hope, rather than a mere injunction (‘Heaven grant that ye keep my secret!’).

ai)sxu/nh| pesei=: the dat. is one of manner (cp. O. T.51a)sfalei/a|...a)no/rqwson, n.), not of cause, as El.429a)bouli/a| pesei=n. Thus the phrase=pesei= ai)sxro\n ptw=ma ( Ant.1045). The simple pesei= could not stand for peripesei= (‘fall into shame’).
tw=| makrw=| xro/nw|, by reason of the long time (spent at Trachis). He was ready to depart when he entered at v. 393: but Deianeira, after learning all, brought him back into the house (492).

au)ta\ … tau=ta: the commands for which he asks (598). Instead of saying, ‘I have been preparing this robe, in order that you may take it,’ she says: ‘I have been busied about the charge to be given to you,—so that you may take this robe.’—For kai\ before pra/ssw, cp. 314.— h)gorw=: the only part of the epic a)gora/omai found in Trag.: Her.6. 11 has h)goro/wnto.

tanau+fh=, woven long, podh/rh. Wunder's restoration of this word, in place of to/nde g' eu)u+fh=, is confirmed by two facts: (1) there was a mysterious variant a)u+fh=, explained by leptou+fh=: (2) tanau+fh=, explained by leptou+fh=, occurs in Hesychius, Suidas, and Photius. It may be added that the ge of the vulgate, if not impossible, is at least suspicious.

pe/plon: Eustath. p. 599.44 refers to this passage as one in which pe/plos is part of a man's dress, alluding also to I. A. 1550, where a pe/plos is worn by Agamemnon. The Homeric pe/plos belongs to women only; hence the schol. here objects to the word. xitw/n is, in fact, the proper term for the long robe sent to Heracles: pe/plos, when used with ref. to it (674, 758, 774), is rather a general word for a stately garment.—She now hands to Lichas the casket (622) containing the robe. Hence the repeated to/nde (instead of au)to/n) in 604 is natural.

fra/z) o(/pws mhdei\s … a)mfidu/setai: cp. Ai.567kei/nw| t' e)mh\n a)ggei/lat' e)ntolh/n, o(/pws (dei/cei). The more usual infin. is often thus replaced after verbs of asking or commanding; but it is specially suitable, as here, after a verb of warning.

e(/rkos i(ero\n, a sacred temenos, where there might chance to be a blazing altar (she is thinking of vv. 237 f.): e)fe/stion se/las, any fire kindled in the warrior's quarters at Cenaeum. She is repeating the substance of the Centaur's precepts: see 685 f.

fanero\s, ‘conspicuous,’ e)mfanw=s, ‘publicly,’ ‘before all eyes’: both words go with staqei\s, picturing the moment when Heracles shall stand forth in front of the altar. The order of words and the rhythm are against taking e)mfanw=s with dei/ch|.—taurosfa/gw|: a day of solemn rejoicing, when the greater victims are slain: Aesch. Cho.261bouqu/tois e)n h)/masi. Cp. 760.
hu)/gmhn, the only instance of this plpf. (for eu)=kto in Hom. fr. 2. 15 is rather an a<*>.): but Phaedr. 279 C has the pf. hu)=ktai as pass. impers. Cp. O. T.1512 cr. n.

pandi/kws (with stelei=n) ‘as in duty bound,’—by the vow, and by a wife's natural sympathy. Cp. 294 pandi/kw| freni/ (n.).—Others join the adv. with swqe/nt), as=‘completely’ (schol. a)nendoia/stws, ‘indubitably’). But there is no evidence for pandi/kws as merely= pantelw=s: cp. 1247: O. C.1306: [Eur. ] Rhes. 720 o)/loito pandi/kws (‘as he deserves’).

kainw=| kaino
: the epithet, strictly applicable to the pe/plwma only, is given to the quth/r also, expressing the new radiance with which the robe shall invest its wearer. This common idiom ( Her.2. 173e)n qro/nw| semnw=| semno
 qwke/onta) occurs elsewhere also under a similar condition,— viz., where the repeated adj. serves for collective emphasis rather than for separate characterisation: Soph. El.742o)rqo\s e)c o)rqw=n di/frwn: Soph. Ai.267koino\s e)n koinoi=si lupei=sqai: ib. 467 cumpesw
 mo/nos mo/nois. But it should be observed that, in this passage, the repetition has a further motive. It is a touch of tragic irony, like the unconscious ambiguity of prosarmo/sai in 494. For quth kaino/s could mean, ‘a sacrificer of a novel kind’: cp. Soph. O. C.1542e)gw\ ga h(gemw
 | sfw=|n au)= pe/fasmai kaino/s. For the sinister sense of kaino/s, cp. 867.
As to the wearing of new, or freshly washed, garments on such occasions, cp. Od.4. 750(Penelope is to pray to Athena) kaqara\ xroi+\ ei(/maq' e(lou=sa.

kai\ tw=nd' a)poi/seis. Deianeira has sealed the casket (622) with her own signet. sfragi/s here is not the signetring itself, but the impression in wax, the seal: cp. I. A. 155 sfragi=da fu/lass), <*>n e)pi\ de/ltw| | th=|de komi/zeis. The word e(/rkos, ‘enclosure,’ means the part of the ring which bears the device, sh=ma. This part was called sfendo/nh ( Eur. Hipp.862tu/poi...sfendo/nhs), Lat. funda, be cause the gem in its setting was like a stone in a sling: the English term is bezel; the French, chaton. That e(/rkos here denotes the whole bezel, and not merely the rim, is shown by e)po/n, which would otherwise be e)no/n. The use of the word sh=ma in this context is illustrated by an inscription on a scarab of the 6th cent. B.C., published by Rossbach, Archäol. Zeit. (1883, pp. 311 ff., pl. 16, No. 19): *qe/rsiw/s ei)mi sa=ma: mh/ me a)/noige. Cp. Prof. H. MiddletonJ. , Engraved Gems of Classical Times (1891), p. 67.

e)po\n maqh/setai is Billerbeck's certain correction of e)p' o)/mma qh/setai, a corruption caused by the easy change of n (before maqh/setai) into m; just as in Ant.1266, cu\n mo/rw|, L has cummo/rwi. As to eu)maqe\s … maqh/setai, cp. n. on Ant.502kle/os... eu)klee/steron. Those who keep the vulgate govern o(\ by e)piqh/setai o)/mma as= o)/yetai.
no/mon, ‘rule’; cp. 1177.

to\ mh\ )piqumei=n pompo\s w)
: not pompo
 o)/nta. Even when the inf. has the art., and represents an oblique case, its subject stands in the nom., if identical with the subject of the principal verb; Plat. Rep. 598D e)chpath/qh dia\ to\ au)to\s mh\ oi(=o/s t' e<*>nai e)pisth/mhn...e)ceta/sai: cp. ib. 526 B: Thuc.4. 18e)la/xist' a)
...dia\ to\ mh\ tw=| o)rqoume/nw| au)tou= pisteu/ontes e)pai/resqai...katalu/ointo: Andoc. or. 3. § 30 ei(lo/meqa...strateu/esqai..., a)nti\ tou= me/nontes oi)/koi cumma/xous e)/xein *surakosi/ous.—perissa\ dra=n ( Soph. Ant.88) glances at the instance in which he had exceeded his master's orders (481 ff.); it is more particularly a hint, as the schol. remarks, that he is to respect the sfragi/s on the casket: verse 622 indicates this.

o(/pws a)\n depends on the notion of e)pimelou= contained in fu/lasse no/mon.— If Lichas acts in the interest of his master only (cp. 286 pisto\s w)\n kei/nw|), the xa/ris won by him will be a(plh=: if he regards the welfare of his mistress also, it will become diplh=. The genitives kei/nou te ka)mou= (of which the second has the chief stress)=‘from him and me’: hence cunelqou=s).
ei)/per *(ermou= k.t.l.: for *(ermh=s o( pe/mpwn, the patron of kh/rukes, cp. Ph.133 n.
pompeu/w, absol., act as pompo/s: te/xnhn, cogn. acc., like pomph/n, which ‘the art of Hermes’ implies. be/baion, predicate, with the sureness of experience and good faith.

ou)/ ti mh\ is more usual than ou)/ toi mh\ (L's re<*>ding), and seems slightly more suitable here. Yet note Ai.560ou)/ toi s' *)axaiw=n, o<*>da, mh/ tis u(bri/sh|: O. C.176ou)/ toi mh/pote/ s)...a)/konta/ tis a)/cei.—e)/n soi, in thy case, in what concerns thee: Ai.1092e)n qanou=sin u(bristh/s.—sfalw= g), trip, commit a fault: cp. 727.
to\ mh\ ou): O. T.1232.

a)/ggos, a word applicable to ‘vessels’ of various kinds, here means a coffer or casket, the zu/gastron of 692. Similarly in Eur. Ion32a)/ggos is the general term, defined by a)nti/phc, ‘cradle’ (19Eur. Ion, 1337 f.).
w(s e)/xei: with the seal unbroken (614).
lo/gwn … pi/stin: the pledge (588) of thy words,—referring esp. to the mention of the vow (610 ff.), which explains the gift.
e)farmo/sai=‘fitly (or ‘duly’) add,)—i.e. ‘add in attestation of the gift.’

le/geis is the best correction of e)/xeis, which doubtless arose from e)/xei in the line above. (In El.934 f., su\n xara=| lo/gous | toiou/sd' e)/xous' e)/speudon, the sense is ‘bearing news,’ not ‘speaking words.’) Otto's e)fei=s) (cp. 286 e)fei=t)) is ingenious, though the 2nd pers. of this aor. does not seem to occur elsewhere: but, before e)farmo/sai, the sound would be unpleasing.
stei/xois a)\n h)/dh: a courteous form: Ph.674xwroi=s a)\n ei)/sw.
seswsme/na: all has been kept safe during the master's long absence: cp. 542 oi)kou/ria (n.).

627 f. For a)lla\ … me
 dh\, cp. O. T.523,—I read au)th
 (with A), not au)th/n q) (with I), for these reasons. (1) It is clear that au)th
 means merely eam, not ipsam. We cannot distinguish ta\ th=s ce/nhs prosde/gmata, as meaning the welcome of Iolè along with the other captives, from a special welcome given to Iolè personally. (2) au)th
, although unemphatic, has a position which would usually give emphasis. But this is excused by the fact that the whole clause, au)th
 w(s e)deca/mhn fi/lws, depends on oi)=sqa, being merely epexegetic of ta\ th=s ce/nhs prosde/gmata (instead of oi(=a e)ge/neto or the like). The chief stress falls on fi/lws. (3) If, however, we had au)th/n q), then the sentence would lose that compact unity which justifies the place of the pronoun. And so au)th/n q) would naturally seem to mean ipsam,—raising the objection noticed above (1). The insertion of q) may easily have arisen from a notion that the second clause required a link with the first.
