e)kplagh=nai, of joy (cp. 24), as in Aesch. Ch.233xara=| de\ mh\ )kplagh=|s fre/nas.—Cp. Aesch. Ag.541KH. w(/st' e)ndakru/ein g' o)/mmasin xara=s u(/po. For the absence of ge here, cp. Soph. Ph.105Soph. Ph., 985.
prw\|, ‘early,’ i.e., ‘too soon<*> ( Aesch. P. V.696prw/| ge stena/zeis). prw-i/ is prob. for prov-i (Brugman, Stud. IV. 154).

mh\ … le/gois a)
. After a verb of fearing (whether the tense be primary or secondary) the potential opt. with a)/n retains its ordinary sense. As ge/noito <*>=‘it might possibly happen,’ so de/doika mh\ ge/noito a)/n=‘I fear that it might possibly happen.’ This is the mildest mode of expressing a fear, as mh/ with the fut. indic. is the most vivid. Hence it suits the misgiving, and the reserve, of Deianeira:—‘I fear that you might happen to be premature in speaking on that subject.’ Cp. Xen. An.6. 1. 28e)kei=no e)nnow= mh\ li/an a)
 taxu\ swfronisqei/hn: id. De Vect. 4. 41 ei) de/ tines au)= fobou=ntai mh\ matai/a <*>n ge/noito au(/th h( kataskeuh/. In Lys. or. 13 § 51, where the MSS. give dedio/tes mh\ kataluqei/hsan o( dh=mos, Markland conjectured kataluqei/h a)
: and the mild phrase suits the irony of the passage. (Bekker reads kataluqei/h without a)/n.)
to\n e)c e)mou=: cp. Ant.95th\n e)c e)mo<*> dusbouli/an (n.).

ta)kei=qen, acc. with ei)de/nai, explained by ei) poqou/meqa. Here <*>a\ e)kei=qen is not merely t<*> e)kei= (315 n.): rather it means, ‘the feeling from (or <*>) his side,’ as opp. to po/qon to\n e)c e)mou=.—<*>qou/meqa: for the plur., following de/doika and e)mou=, cp. n. on Ant.734.

div2.p: Second st<*>on. 1st strophe, 633—639,=1st an<*> 640— 646, 2nd strophe, 647—654,=2nd antistr., 655—662. For the <*>res see Metrical Analysis.
A joyous music will presen<*> be heard by the dwellers around Tr<*>s. The victorious Heracles will soon <*>rn, filled with new love for Deianeira, inder the spell of the robe.

div3.p: <*> nau/loxa k.t.l. Wishing to call up a general picture of the whole region, the poet takes Thermopylae as his central point. From the cliffs of Oeta, which overhang that pass, his thought passes to the highlands (<*>ous *oi)/tas) of Malis, and thence descends to the seaboard,—bringing us back to Thermopylae by the mention of the Amphictyons.

qerma\ loutra\: the wa<*>m springs at Thermopylae are situated between the Malian gulf on the N. (na<*>loxa), and the cliffs of Oeta on the south (petrai=a). They gush from the foot of the mountain,—that spur of Oeta which Livy and Strabo call Callidromus,—a little west of the point where the pass is narrowest. They were locally called x<*>roi, from the natural basins of rock; and near them was an altar of Heracles, for whose use Athena was said to have called them forth ( Her.7. 176: Peisander ap. schol. Nub. 1050).
nau/loxa: Strabo 9. 428 speaks of a limh\n me/gas near Thermopylae. Here the word suggests the expected landing of Heracles.
pa/gous *oi)/tas: the *trhxiniai pe/trai of Her.7. 198, spurs from the main range of Oeta, which enclose the plain of Malis on s. and w.: see Introd. to the Philoctetes, pp. ix. f.
paranaieta/ontes with acc.: cp. Isocr. or. 4 § 162 *(/ellhnes th\n *)asi/an paroikou=sin, dwell along its coasts.

oi(/ (art.) te, sc. naieta/onres, following the direct vocative (633): cp. Xen. Cyr.3. 3. 20w)= *ku=re kai\ oi( a)/lloi <*>rsai.—me/ssan *mhli/da … li/<*>nan, the part of the gulf between the two extremities, i.e., the innermost part of the deep <*> which it forms. It is in this part that the shores of the gulf belonged to Malis,—viz., from the neighbourhood of Thermopylae to that of Anticyra.

xrusalaka/tou t' a)kta\n ko/ras: merely another way of describing the same seaboard: they live by the li/mnh, and on the a)kth/. Artemis, one of whose attributes was limenosko/pos, was worshipped all along these eastern coasts, since the whole maritime life of Greece Proper looked mainly towards the Aegaean. Apoll. Rhod. 1. 571 (referring to the coasts about Pagasae and Iolcus in Magnesia), *)/artemin, h(\ kei/nas skopia\s a(lo\s a)mfie/pesken. Cp. 212 f.—The schol. wrongly takes a)kta\n here as meaning that ai)gialo/s in the N.W. of Euboea which was called *)artemi/sion ( Her.7. 176).

xrusalaka/tou: this Homeric epithet of the goddess ( Il.16. 183) is rightly explained by Hesych. as=kalli/tocos: h)laka/th ga\r o( tociko\s ka/lamos. Cp. a)/traktos=oi)sto/s. Artemis had nothing to do with a distaff.

e)/nq' *(ella/nwn k.t.l. Meetings of the Amphictyonic Council were held at the town of Anthela, close to Thermopylae on the west,—where was the sacred precinct of *dhmh/thr *)amfiktuoni/s, containing seats (e(/drai) for the Council, and also a shrine of its legendary founder, Amphictyon ( Her.7. 200). Anachronisms were tolerated by Attic Tragedy, but this is hardly one, from the Greek point of view. The Thessalian and Dorian nucleus of what became the ‘Delphic’ Amphictyony was of immemorial age; Amphictyon was called the son of Deucalion; Acrisius of Argos figured in tradition as an early organiser of the league ( Strabo 9.420).

*(ella/nwn, implying a Panhellenic character, reflects the regular phraseology of the poet's day. The Delphic Amphictyony never actually represented the whole even of Greece Proper; thus it never included the Acarnanians, Arcadians, or Eleans. Yet Her.7. 214 speaks of oi( tw=n *(ella/nwn *pulago/roi: an Argive inscr., older than 416 B.C., calls the Council to\ sune/drion tw=n *(ella/nwn (Lebas, Revue Archéol. XI. 577): and Hypereides Epitaph. c. 8. 25 describes those attending it as oi( *(/ellhnes a(/pantes.

a)gorai\ *pula/tides: a)gora\ pula=tis= pulai/a (sc. su/nodos), the name for a meeting of the Amphictyons, whether at Pylae or at Delphi,—one of several proofs that the former place was the League's older centre.
kle/ontai, not ‘are called together,’ but, ‘are famous’: cp. O.T. 1451 e)/nqa klh/|zetai | ou(mo\s *kiqairw/n (n.).—See Appendix.

a)narsi/an, ‘unkindly’ (cp. 853), ‘harsh,’—referring to the use of the flute in wild or mournful music. Cp. Sextus Empiricus Adv. Math. 6. 22 dio\ kai\ toi=s penqou=sin au)loi\ melw|dou=sin oi( th
 lu/phn au)tw=n e)pikoufi/zontes. Lucian De Luct. § 19 h( pro\s to
 au)lo
 au(/th sternotupi/a. Plato Legg. 800 E, *karikh=| tini mou/sh| prope/mpousi tou\s teleuth/santas, alludes to au)lw|doi/ (cp. Pollux 4. 75).
e)pa/neisin, ‘return,’ but also with the notion of sound rising.

qei/as … mou/sas, sc. kanaxa/n, a sound of music made to the gods (in thanksgiving): a)nti/luron, like that of the lyre: schol. i)so/luron. This is simpler than to understand, ‘responsive’ to it (as if both instruments were used). The lyre, ‘common treasure of Apollo and the Muses’ ( Pind. P.1. 1), was peculiarly associated with joyous worship. Cp. O.C. 1222 n.
a)xw=n, as a correction of i)a/xwn, is hardly doubtful, since a resolution of the long syllable would impair the rhythm (cp. 635 *oi)/tas).

o( *dio\s … *)alkmh/nas ko/ros: objection has been taken to the double gen., but needlessly: the second gen. practically forms a single notion with ko/ros,—‘Zeus's Alcmena-son,’=the son of Zeus by Alcmena. To a Greek ear the effect would be nearly the same as when the first gen. is replaced by an adj.; e.g., Aesch. Suppl.313o( *di=os po/rtis...boo/s, Pind. O.2. 13<*> *kro/nie pai= *(re/as.

sou=tai, instead of the MS. seu=tai, is now generally read here. Cp. Ai.1414sou/sqw: Aesch. Pers.25sou=n<*> tai: Vesp. 209 sou=. On the other hand, seu=tai has no nearer <*>arallel than the Homeric steu=tai: which some, indeed, regard as syncopated (Curtius, Gk. Verb, ch. iv. I. C), but others as a genuine non-thematic form (Leaf, Il.18. 191).
pa/sas, complete: cp. Ai.436pa=san eu)/kleian.—a)reta=s la/fura (like <*>qla), ‘things won by’ a)reth/ (root lab).

o(\n a)po/ptolin ei)/xomen: ‘whom we had absent’=‘whose absence we had to endure’: schol. o(\n e)kto\s ei)/xomen th=s po/lews. (Paley would join ei)/xomen a)mme/nousai, ‘whom we had been waiting for’: this seems inadmissible.)

panta=|, ‘utterly,’ goes with a)po/ptolin: it implies a contrast between this long unbroken absence and his former expeditions. Cp. Eur. fr. 966 a)ko/lasta pa/nth|. (The Doric form was written panta=|.) The adv. could mean also, ‘in all directions,’ but that sense is less fitting.
duokaideka/mhnon … xro/non: more exactly, fifteen months (44 f.).
pela/gion: they imagined him as wandering on the sea, before or after his Lydian bondage: cp. 100 ff., Ant.785foita=|s d' u(perpo/ntios (n.).

a( de/ oi( … da/mar. The art. is here a pron., in apposition with da/mar, and serves to contrast the wife with the husband: the dat. oi( is equiv. to a possessive pron.: cp. Il.13. 616la/ke d' o)ste/a, tw\ de/ oi( o)/sse k.t.l. Note also the epic hiatus before oi( (voi(): cp. El.196o(/te oi( (Herm. , for o(/te soi): where Dindorf cp. Aesch. Ag.1147perieba/lonto/ oi(, and Cratinus ap. Plut. Per.24*(/hran te oi(. In Eur. Phoen.637, however, e)/qeto/ soi (not oi() is clearly right.
ta/lainan (for the MS. ta/laina) is required by the metre (cp. 659 a)mei/yas).
w)/lluto=e)th/keto: cp. El.140a)ll' a)po\ tw=n metri/wn e)p' a)mh/xanon | a)/lgos a)ei\ stena/xousa dio/llusai.

*)/arhs. The first syll. might be long (as it is in some other lyric passages, Ant.139, El.96, Ai.254 Ai., 614): but more probably it is short, and the first syll. of peiqou=s in 661 is ‘irrational’ (see Anal.).

oi)strhqei\s: the sudden rage of Ares symbolises the furious impulse which sent Heracles against Oechalia. Cp. Eur. Bacch.119oi)strhqe<*>s *dionu/sw|. The conject. au)= (or oi() strwqei\s would suggest the subsidence of a storm ( Her.7. 193to\ ku=ma e)/strwto). This is less suitable, when, as here, Ares is a personified deliverer.

e)ce/lus' e)pi/ponona(me/ran, has ‘resolved,’ ‘cleared away,’ the day of sorrow. The notion of untying a knot passes into that of dissipating a trouble. Cp. O. T.35e)ce/lusas...dasmo
 (n.). The image is more clearly developed in Ai.706e)/lusen ai)no
 a)/xos a)p' o)mma/twn *)/arhs.—For e)pi/ponon a(me/ran, cp. Eur. Phoen.540e)xqra=s... h(me/ras, Eur. Hec.364lupra
...h(me/ran. In the Athamas Sophocles had leukh
 h(me/ran as=th
 a)gaqh/n (Bekk. Anecd. p. 106. 33).

o)/xhma nao\s: it may be doubted whether this means more than ‘the ship which conveys him.’ I. T. 410 na/i+on o)/xhma is similar. Cp. Hipp. ma. 295 D ta\ o)xh/mata, ta/ t<*> peza\ kai\ ta\ e)n th=| qala/tth| ploi=a. But in nauti/lwn o)xh/mata ( P.V. 468) the metaphor of the chariot is distinct, as in Eur. Med.1122nai+/an | ... a)ph/nhn.—polu/kwpon agrees with the compound phrase: cp. Soph. Ant.794 n.
pri\n … a)nu/seie: the opt. is due to the preceding opt., stai/h: cp. Ph.961o)/loio mh/pw, pri\n ma/qoim).
e(sti/an, altar: O. C.1495bou/quton e(sti/an (n.).
a)mei/yas, having quitted: Ph.1262 n.
klh/|zetai quth/r, is said by rumour to be sacrificing: cp. 237, 287: and for the verb, 1268.

pani/meros: Anthol. 2. 169 xalkw=| ko/smon e)/dwke pani/meron. Here, however, the act. sense, ‘full of love’ (for Deianeira), is fitter than the pass., ‘alldesired.’ This is Mudge's correction of the MS. pana/meros, which admits of no satisfactory explanation. It has been interpreted: (1) ‘travelling all day’: ‘Thence may he come, | A long day's journey without pause’ (Whitelaw). (2) ‘Today.’ One schol. paraphrases it, th\n sh/meron h(me/ran: another, e)n th=| au)th=| h(me/ra|. How this sense was extorted from the word, I do not know. (3) Taking it with what follows: ‘re-united to Deianeira for all his days to come.’

ta=s peiqou=s pagxri/stw| k.t.l. The corresponding verses of the strophe (653 f.) appear sound: nu=n d' *)/arhs oi)strhqei\s | e)ce/lus' e)pi/ponon a(me/ran. The traditional text here, ta=s peiqou=s pagxri/stw| | sugkraqei\s e)pi\ profa/sei qhro/s, makes a long syllable answer to the second of e)ce/lus), and to the second of a(me/ran.
Let us now examine the text in detail.

(1) pagxri/stw| does not look like a gloss. Dindorf, who thinks it one, can only suggest that it arose from pa/gxristos, a gloss upon sugkraqei/s. This is hardly probable. Sophocles is fond of intensive compounds with pa=s: cp. 505, 652: El.851pansu/rtw|, pammh/nw|: Ant.1282pammh/twr: fr. 347 pa/gcenos, etc. As an epithet for the robe, pagxri/stw|, ‘thoroughly anointed,’ is suitable. (Cp. Deianeira's words in 580.) But it cannot be a subst., as the schol. on 663 would make it (lei/pei tw=| pe/plw|).

(2) The words e)pi\ profa/sei qhro/s= e)pi/ponon a(me/ran in 654. Besides being unmetrical, qhro/s requires an unexampled sense for profa/sei, viz., ‘precept.’ Hence Dindorf reads profa/nsei (a word which is not extant), and in 654 e)pipo/nwn a(mera=n. For qhro/s, M. Haupt conjectured fa/rous (*q*h*r*o*s, *f*a*r*o*s): for the a^, cp. 916. The words e)pi\ profa/sei fa/rous then mean, ‘on the pretext of the robe.’ The robe was the pro/fasis for using the love-charm. pagxri/stw| can be retained in the dat., agreeing with profa/sei (cp. Ant.794 n.).

(3) For sugkraqei\s, cp. Ant.1311deilai/a| de\ sugke/kramai du/a| (‘steeped in’ it): Ai.895oi)/ktw| tw=|de sugkekrame/nhn (‘steeped in this lament,’—i.e., in the anguish of it). Plut. 853 ou(/tw polufo/rw| sugke/kramai dai/moni. Thus the primary sense of mixture, or fusion, led to that of intimate union. If we accept fa/rous, then sugkraqei\s would be most naturally taken in the sense which pani/meros, just before it, could suggest,— ‘made one in heart’ with Deianeira.

There remains, however, the metrical discrepancy between sugkraqei\s and e)ce/lus) in 654. Hermann read e)cei/lus) (‘unrolled,’ meaning, ‘disentangled,’ ‘brought to a smooth close’). But e)ce/lus) seems genuine. It is possible, however, that sugkraqei\s was an explanation of suntakei\s (suggested by Paley), which would give the same sense. Cp. Aesch. Suppl.1029game/tas | sunthxqei\s au)/rais a)do/lois | gennai/as a)lo/xw| yuxa=s, ‘husband made one with wife in the sincere spirit of a loyal soul.’ So suntakei/s tini, of close attachment, Plat. Symp. 183EPlat. Symp., 192

Either sugkraqei/s or suntakei/s would here admit a secondary sense, unconsciously prophetic of the dire event (833 prostake/ntos i)ou=: 836 prostetakw/s),— like prosarmo/sai in 494.—For other views, see Appendix.

div2.p: Third e)peiso/dion. Deianeira confides to the Chorus her fear that a danger may lurk in the gift which she has just sent to Heracles. Hyllus enters (734). He describes the sufferings of his father, who is being carried home; and ends by invoking curses upon his mother. She goes silently into the house.

div3.p: peraite/rw, absol., implying peraite/rw tou= de/ontos ( Plat. Gorg. 484C).
*dh|a/neira, te/knon *oi)ne/ws: the form of address implies earnest sympathy with the terror which they perceive in her: cp. the pai= *menoike/ws of the Chorus in Ant.1098.

a)qumw= d), ei) fanh/somai: cp. 176 n.: Eur. Andr.61fo/bw| me/n, ei)/ tis despotw=n ai)sqh/setai.—a)p) e)lpi/dos kalh=s, as the outcome of it: cp. Soph. Ant.695ka/kist' a)p' e)/rgwn eu)kleesta/twn fqi/nei. (Not, ‘contrary to it.’)

ou) dh/ in a question, as Ph.900: more often, ou) dh/ pou ( O. T.1472, Ant.381), or ou) dh/ pote ( Tr.876, El.1108).— ti is acc. of respect, and the gen. depends on it: ‘Surely thou art not anxious as to aught belonging to, concerning thy gift?’ This is simpler than to take the gen. as depending on e)lpi/dos, and ti as adv.: ‘Not, perchance, (the hope concerning) thy gift?’—For the plur. dwrhma/twn, cp. 494: for the dat. *(hraklei=, depending on the verbal notion, Plat. Euthyph. 15A ta\ par' h(mw=n dw=ra toi=s qeoi=s: and Soph. O. C.1026 n.

w(/ste mh/pot' a)\n paraine/sai, i.e., w(/ste ou)/pot' a)\n paraine/saimi. The words proqumi/an … e)/rgou form a single notion, the sense being the same as if a)/dhlon were a)dh/lou. Cp. Ant.794 n. a)/dhlon here means, ‘untried by previous test’: cp. her own words in 590 f. So in Thuc.5. 103a)fanei=s e)lpi/des (as opp. to fanerai/) are those which rest on no solid ground. Cp. id. 1. 78 e)n a)dh/lw| kinduneu/etai.—For labei=n, ‘conceive,’ cp. Soph. Ph.1078fro/nhsin...la/boi: Soph. Ai.345ai)dw=...la/boi.
ei) didakto/n: cp. 64.
oi(=on, h)\n fra/sw k.t.l. The choice here seems to lie between two courses.

(1) To retain u(mi=n, but with a comma after it, and to supply from it u(ma=s as subject to maqei=n: ‘such that, if I tell it to you, ye will learn an unexpected marvel.’ Cp. Plut. 349 poi=o/s tis (sc. xrhsmo/s);—oi(=os... | h)\n me\n katorqw/swmen, eu)= pra/ttein a)ei/: where the subject to the inf. is h(ma=s, supplied from the preceding verb.

(2) To read u(ma=s (subject to maqei=n) instead of u(mi=n, which may well have arisen from fra/sw. This course is recommended by the lucid construction, and by the better rhythm. Cp. O. T.1295 f. qe/ama d' ei)so/yei ta/xa | toiou=ton oi(=on kai\ stugou=nt' e)poikti/sai.

Others, taking maqei=n with qau=m' a)ne/lpiston only, suppose an ellipse of e)/stai (or an equiv. word): ‘Such that, if I tell it, (it will be) an unexpected marvel for you to hear.’ But such an ellipse is extremely harsh. Wunder's a)\n fra/sai (with e)me/ understood as subject) is possible, but loses the emphasis prepared by h)\n fra/sw, and gives an unpleasing rhythm.

to\n e)nduth=ra pe/plon. The word e)nduth/r (found only here) expresses that the pe/plos was not for ordinary use, but was one which Heracles was to assume for the solemn rite. Thus it is equivalent to ‘stately,’ or ‘festal.’ Cp. Eur. Tro.258e)ndutw=n stefe/wn i(erou\s stolmou/s, ‘the sacred apparel of wreaths with which thou hast been invested’ (because they mark Cassandra's prophetic character).—The xitw/n belonged to the class of e)ndu/mata, garments ‘put on’ (and not merely wrapped round the body); while the Homeric pe/plos must be classed with e)piblh/mata (cp. Il.5. 734 ff.). But we cannot well regard e)nduth/r here as a qualifying epithet, meaning that this pe/plos was of the xitw/n class (cp. 602 n.).

a)rgh\s … po/kos: I follow Wunder and Lobeck in thus amending a)rgh=t' … po/kw|. The latter reading, if sound, presents a dilemma. (1) a)rgh=t)=a)rgh=ti. But it is now generally recognised that the epic license of eliding datival i was foreign to Attic Tragedy: the supposed examples all admit of easy remedy: see O. C., Appendix on v. 1436. (2) a)rgh=ta, agreeing with pe/plon: ‘white, glistering.’ This is possible; for, though to\n e)nduth=ra pe/plon precedes, a second epithet might follow: cp. n. on O. T.1199.But the effect of such an epithet, added at the end of the clause, would here be very weak. And if a)rgh=ta is taken as the proleptic predicate (‘anointed so as to make it shine,’ Wecklein), this does not suit the sense. On the other hand, the connection of a)rgh/s with po/kos is confirmed by Aesch. Eum.45a)rgh=ta mallo/n.

Blaydes suggests a)rgh=s oi)o\s eu)e/rou po/kw|: but the usage of a)rgo/s precludes this. A change of a)rgh\s … po/kos into a)rgh=t) (meant for a)rgh=ti)...po/kw| would easily have been induced by the preceding w(=|.— eu)e/rou, the Attic form, acc. to the schol. on Ar. Av.121(where metre requires eu)/eron).

pro\s ou)deno\s (neut.) tw=n e)/ndon, by nothing in the house (such as fire, or a corrosive substance). The conj. tw=n e)kto/s is ingenious, but seems unnecessary.— fqi/nei, instead of fqi/non: see n. on O. T.1134.

yh=| is not elsewhere intrans. (cp. 698), and hence has been suspected here: but cp. 128, n. on e)pi\...kuklou=sin.—kat) a)/kras spila/dos, down from the top of a flat stone, or slab, in the au)lh/ of the house. Schol.: w(s ou)=n e)pi\ li/qou qeme/nh au)to\ tou=to/ fhsi. On coming into the court-yard from the room in which she had secretly anointed the robe, she had carelessly thrown the tuft of wool down upon this stone.

Such is the only sense which the words will bear. They are perhaps corrupt. Sophocles has the dat. plur. spila/dessi, in the ordinary sense, ‘sea-rocks,’ in fr. 341; but the sense of the sing. here is peculiar. And vv. 695—698 would naturally suggest that she had thrown the tuft at once on the ground, rather than on a stone from which it afterwards crumbled down.

Possibly the true reading is kat' a)/kras spo/dion, ‘utterly pulverised,’ and spila/dos arose, when the letters after sp had been partly effaced, through the wish to find a subst. which could agree with a)/kras. Cp. Suid. kat' a)/kras: di) o(/lou, pantelw=s: and Soph. O. C.1242.
e)ktenw=: Ai.1040mh\ tei=ne makra/n: Aesch. Eum.201tosou=to mh=kos e)/kteinon lo/goun.
ga\r, prefatory.
w(=n, for ou)\s, by attract. to the subsequent qesmw=n: cp. Dem. or. 20 § 87 w(=n e)/rgw| pepoi/hken e(/kastos..., tou/twn e)k lo/gou kri/sis gi/gnetai.
o( qh\r *ke/ntauros, as in 1162: qh/r may here be rendered by an adj., but is strictly a subst., the general term in apposition with the special.
ponw=n pleura\n: Hense quotes Ennius Ann.601tum laterali' dolor, certissimu' nuntiu' mortis.

pikra=|, cp. Ai.1024pikrou= | ...knw/dontos: Il.5. 278pikro\s o)i+sto/s.—glwxi=ni. This sense of glwxi/n (which means ‘the end of a strap’ in Il.24. 274) does not occur elsewhere in poetry of the classical age, but is attested by Il.5. 393o)i+stw=| triglw/xini (cp. 11. 507), a three-barbed arrow: which shows that the schol. here is right in identifying glwxi/n with the Homeric o)/gkos (uncus), ‘barb’ of an arrow ( Il.4. 151).

prou)dida/cato, ‘had taught me beforehand’: distinguish the other sense of this compound, ‘to teach gradually’ ( Ai.163, Ph.1015). The midd. voice here suits the fact of the Centaur's hidden design. In Plut. 687, o( ga\r i(ereu\s au)tou= me prou)dida/cato, the verb might be causal (‘had me instructed beforehand’). Sometimes, however, the midd. dida/skomai hardly differs from dida/skw, unless by emphasising the te cher's effort (cp. Pind. O.8. 59: Nub. 783).

qesmw=n ou)de/n. The regular plur. was qesmoi/, though in fr. 90 we find ou) ga/r ti qesma\ toi=sin a)sti/tais pre/pei. Cp. Ph.24ta)pi/loipa tw=n lo/gwn (n.).— e)sw|zo/mhn, remembered: Plat. Rep. 455B a)\ e)/maqe, sw/|zetai: cp. Soph. O. T.318 n.

xalkh=s … de/ltou. This image is peculiarly forcible in connection with qesmw=n,—the word which expresses her religious reverence for the Centaur's precepts. Laws, rituals, oracles, etc., were often engraved upon bronze tables. An example is afforded by the ‘Eugubinae Tabulae’ preserved at Gubbio, which concern sacred rites. Diod. Sic. 12. 26 (referring to the Lawsof the XII. Tables) ei)s dw/deka xalkou=s pi/nakas xara/cantes oi( u(/patoi. Plut. Alex.17de/lton...xalkh=n, tu/pous e)/xousan a)rxai/wn gramma/twn (an oracle): where, for tu/pous (graven characters), cp. Pollux 8. 128 de/ltois xalkai=s h)=san pa/lai e)ntetupwme/noi oi( no/moi oi( peri\ tw=n i(erw=n kai\ tw=n patri/wn. Cic. Phil. 1. § 26 Quod ita erit gestum, id lex erit? et in aes incidi iubebitis...?

kai/moi k.t.l. Those who agree with Wunder in rejecting this verse hold that sw/|zein depends on prou)dida/cato (681), and urge that ka)/drwn toiau=ta in 688 condemns toiau=t' e)/drwn here. The question must be considered in the light of the whole context. She begins by saying that the Centaur's dying precepts remained in her memory as if graven on bronze (680—683). That passage is much more impressive if a full stop follows 683. She then says, ‘Now these were his precepts,’— verse 684 marking her anxiety to explain that she had simply obeyed him to the letter. The reiteration, ka)/drwn toiau=ta, in 688, is unnecessary; but, in her actual state of mind, it is full of dramatic truth. The scholiast read this verse.
a)/puron k.t.l.: cp. 606 f.—For a)/qikton with gen., cp. 23 n.

e(/ws nin. The solecism in the MSS., e(/ws a)
, is like their pri
 a)
 qa/noi in 2 f., and h(ni/k' a(
...a)pei/h in 164 f.

pou: neither Nessus (575) nor she herself had ever thought of the charm being used on any one except Heracles. But, as she shrank from naming Eurystheus (35), so, at this moment, she shrinks from naming the man whom she loves.

e)/xrisa me\n corresponds with ka)/qhka in 691, not with ei)/sw d) in 693. Cp. Ai.1a)ei\ me/n,...3 kai\ nu=n: Thuc.2. 65§ 12 de/ka me\n e)/th a)ntei=xon...kai\ ou) pro/teron e)ne/dosan. So me/n...te, belowThuc., 1012.— kat' oi)=kon, in the house (and not outside the gates): e)n do/mois, in the gunaikwni=tis, and not in the open au)lh/. For this limited sense of do/moi, cp. Hom. Od.6. 303a)ll' o(po/t' a)/n se do/moi keku/qwsi kai\ au)lh/.

kthsi/ou, ‘belonging to the household,’—i.e., to a flock kept near the house, to supply food, and victims for sacrifice. *zeu\s *kth/sios was more especially the tutelar god of household property; hence domestic slaves stand kthsi/ou bwmou= pe/las ( Aesch. Ag.1038). The epithet here does not, however, directly allude to him, as if meaning, ‘devoted to the *kth/sios.’
a)lampe\s h(li/ou: cp. O. C.677a)nh/nemon... | xeimw/nwn (n.).
zuga/strw|: for the dat., cp. 564. Xen. Cyr.7. 3. 1 uses zu/gastra of boxes in which treasure is packed up for removal. The word meant simply, ‘something fitted together,’ ‘compacted’ (zug-).

koi/lw|: the addition of this adj. is sometimes, esp. in poetry, merely picturesque: cp. O. C.1593, Ai.1165: Eur. Ion19koi/lhs...a)nti/phgos: Her.4. 2a)ggh/i+a koi=la.—w(/sper ei)/dete. They saw the zu/gastron, but not the act of placing the robe in it: this (as a)lampe\s h(li/ou shows) had been done in the house.
ei)/sw d' a)postei/xousa, returning into the house (632). The words w(/sper ei)/dete indicate the previous dialogue in front of it (531—632).

fa/tin is boldly used here, but appears sound. The harshness is modified by the context: i.e., the antithesis between uttering and comprehending has led the poet to strengthen a)/fraston by a noun specially suited to it, as he strengthens a)cu/mblhton by the addition of a)nqrw/pw| maqei=n. In El.1466, on the other hand, de/dorka fa/sma... | peptwko/s (the corpse), the subst. is accommodated to the verb.—For a)cu/mblhton cp. Aelian Nat. An. 6. 60 tw=n a)tekma/rtwn te kai\ a)sumblh/twn. Eur. Med.675sofw/ter' h)\ kat' a)/ndra sumbalei=n e)/ph.

ka/tagma properly meant the ball of wool on the distaff, from which the thread is drawn down (kata/getai, deducitur) by the spinner. ( Polit. 282 E: Soph.226B. ) Here it is merely a synonym for mallo/s (690). In Ar. Lys.583 ff. ka/tagma is the thread itself.

prou)/xrion, before putting it into the casket (692). Lucian Alex.21sia/lw| th\n sfragi=da proxri/sas.—flo/ga comes first, since heat is the main point; then, to avoid ambiguity, a)kti=n' e)s h(liw=tin is added. Seneca Herc. Oet. 725 translates these words: medios in ignes solis et claram facem.

Wunder rashly rejects the verse. Dobree's objection to it seems to have been the repeated e)s. His words are merely: ‘Suspectus ob constructionem; nisi legas flo/ga a)kti=nos h(liw=tin’: II. Adv.38. But the prep. is often thus repeated when a second noun stands in apposition with the first, serving to explain it: e.g., Lysias or. 6 § 14 kai\ e)n *)arei/w| pa/gw|, e)n tw=| semnota/tw|...dikasthri/w|: Laches 183 C e)k tou/twn oi( o)nomastoi\ gi/gnontai, e)k tw=n e)pithdeusa/ntwn e(/kasta: Prot.358B ai( e)pi\ tou/tou pra/ceis a(/pasai, e)pi\ tou= a)lu/pws zh=n.
r(ei= is equiv. to yh=| in 678. The wool shrivels away; and presently there is nothing to be seen but a powder, like saw-dust, on the ground. For r(ei=n, cp. O. C.259 n.
kate/yhktai: the perf. of instant result: cp. Ph.76o)/lwla (n.). Seneca Herc. Oet. 736 Dumque ipsa miror, causa mirandi perit.

morfh=|, dat. of respect: ma/list' ei)kasto\n, lit., ‘most nearly comparable’; but, instead of a simple dat., e)kbrw/masi, we have a clause with w(/ste (=w(s), as if (e.g.) ou(/tws e)/xon had preceded.

pri/onos e)kbrw/mat) = pri/smata (or parapri/smata): Schneidewin cp. Nicander Ther.52kai\ h( pri/onessi tomai/h | ke/dros, pouluo/dousi katayhxqei=sa genei/ois.—e)n tomh=| cu/lou=o(/te cu/lon te/mnetai: for the form of the phrase, cp. Ant.24 n.

propete/s, where it was thrown down: schol. e)rrimme/non (cp. 695) kai\ propeso\n xamai/.—o(/qen, by attract. to e)k gh=s, instead of o(/pou: cp. Thuc.1. 89§ 3 diekomi/zonto eu)qu\s o(/qen (=e)nteu=qen o(/poi) u(pece/qento pai=das kai\ gunai=kas. In Soph. O. C.1226 the doubtful kei=qen is not similar.— prou)/keit), a)naze/ousi: past tense combined with historic pres. ( Soph. Ant.254 n.).— qrombw/deis a)froi/, foam, thickened into clots (qro/mboi, tre/fw): hence the plur., which Seneca imitates, Herc. Oet. 737 Quin ipsa tellus spumeos motus agit.

pi/onos potou= gl. o)pw/ras a)po\ *b. a)mpe/lou: the rich juice of the blue fruit (obtained) from the vine: i.e., the gleu=kos, or ‘must,’ newly pressed from the ripe grapes; which foams when poured on the ground, since it has not yet passed through the stage of fermentation. Schol.: ma/lista de\ o( ne/os oi)=nos, qermo\s w)/n, ei) pe/soi xamai/, a)fri/zei. The simile is suggested chiefly by the foam, but partly also by the purple tinge which the poison gives to the blood.
xuqe/ntos should not be taken with *b. a)p' a)mpe/lou, since the grapes have already been gathered.

For o)pw/ras as=‘fruit,’ cp. fr. 234. 7 pa=sa te/mnetai blastoume/nh | kalw=s o)pw/ra, ka)naki/rnatai poto/n.—For *bakxi/as, ib. 2 *ba/kxeios bo/trus: Geo. 2. 5 tibi pampineo gravidus autumno | Floret ager, spumat plenis vindemia labris. For pi/onos cp. Tibull. 1. 1. 10 pleno pinguia musta lacu.
poi= gnw/mhs pe/sw: she knows not to what counsels she can have recourse: i.e., she can think of no remedy. Cp. O. C.170poi= tis fronti/dos e)/lqh|; (n.).

o(rw= de/ m' … e)ceirgasme/nhn. The constr. with the acc. can be used whenever the speaker looks at his own case from without. But the examples are of two kinds. (1) Most often there is a contrast of persons; El.65: Andoc. or. 1 § 30 fhmi\ dei=n e)kei/nous me
 a)pole/sqai..., e)me\ de\ sw/|zesqai. (2) Sometimes, as here, there is no such contrast, and the effect is merely to give a certain objectivity: Soph. El.470pikra
 | dokw= me pei=ran th/nde tolmh/sei
 e)/ti: so Soph. Ai.606 f.: Plat. Rep. 400B oi)=mai de/ me a)khkoe/nai. This is esp. fitting when the speaker is in an evil plight, and means that he can see himself as others see him: so Xen. An.5. 6§ 20 nu=n me
 o(rw=men h(ma=s a)po/rous o)/ntas k.t.l.
po/qen, ‘from what motive?’: a)nti\ tou=, ‘in gratitude for what?’
a)\n … pare/sx): (if he had shown kindness,— as he did not), why would he have done so?
h(=s … u(/per, on account of whom,=h(=s e(/neka, or di) h(/n: cp. Ant.932braduth=tos u(/per.
a)pofqi/sai: fqi/sw and e)/fqisa have i_ in epic poetry, but i^ in Attic: cp. 1043: O. T.202: Ai.1027.
a)rkei=, ‘anails’: not, ‘suffices.’ In the latter sense, a)rkei= is usu. impers., but in the former, personal, as it is here (sc. h( ma/qhsis).
a)/rnumai: Ant.903: Ph.838.
ei)/ ti mh\: 586 n.
yeusqh/somai gnw/mhs: Ai.1382kai/ m' e)/yeusas e)lpi/dos polu/.
a)/trakton: cp. Ph.290 n.—

qeo\n *xei/rwna. Cheiron, as the son of the god Cronus by the nymph Philyra, was of a different origin from the other Centaurs, the descendants of Ixion and Nephelè. So Pindar distinguishes him as *kroni/dan | *ke/ntauron (N. 3. 47), ou)rani/da go/non eu)rume/donta *kro/nou (P. 3. 4): and Apollonius Rhodius as a)/lla me\n i(/ppw|, | a)/lla qew=| a)ta/lanton (2. 1240). He was still more separated from the rest of the Centaur tribe by his just and gentle character ( Il.11. 832dikaio/tatos *kentau/rwn). Hence Greek art, after the in vention of the hippo-centaur (564 n.), continued to portray Cheiron under the more humane type of the andro-centaur. This is his form on Greek vases, down at least to 400 B.C. Later art neglected this distinction. (See Colvin S. in Journ. Hellen. Stud., vol. 1. pp. 133— 137.)

phmh/nanta. Other Centaurs, routed by Heracles in Arcadia, fled to Cheiron near Cape Malea; and the hero, in shooting at them, accidentally wounded his friend. Cheiron could not be healed; and, being a god, could not die. At last Zeus allowed him to exchange fates, the immortal for the mortal, with Prometheus; and so he found rest ( Apollod.2. 5. 4).

Ovid varies the story. Heracles visited Cheiron on Mount Pelion; a poisoned arrow chanced to fall from the hero's quiver on the left foot of the Centaur. Virus edax superabat opem...Nona dies aderat, cum tu, iustissime Chiron, | Bis septem stellis corpore cinctus eras. (Fast. 5. 387—414.)

xw(=nper seems a certain correction of xw(/sper. The latter has been explained thus:—(1) ‘Even as it may touch, (so surely) does it destroy.’ This is possible, but somewhat forced; certainly less probable than xw(=nper. (2) ‘If only it touch them.’ This view—that w(/sper <*>n=dummodo—rests on passages in which w(s should be corrected to e(/ws ( O. C.1361, Ph.1330, Ai.1117).—Few will defend xw(/sper as=kai\ o(/sper (‘whoever touches the arrow’); or accept, with Wunder, xw(/saper.
e)k … sfagw=n tou=de dielqw\n, having passed out from the wounds of Nessus.

i)o\s ai(/matos, a poison consisting (or contained) in blood, because the poison from the arrow had become mixed with the blood; and it was in the form of blood (572 a)mfi/qrepton a<*>ma) that the poison had been applied. For the ‘defining’ gen., cp. El.682pro/sxhm' a)gw=nos,=pro/sx. a)gwnistiko/n.

to/nde, Heracles. tou=de—o(/de—to/nde: this repetition of the pron., in different relations, has been thought strange. Yet cp. O. T.948kai\ nu=n o(/de | pro\s th=s tu/xhs o)/lwlen, ou)de\ tou=d' u(/po: where o(/de is Polybus, and tou=d), Oedipus. She reasons from past to present:—‘the same poison, coming from this source, will kill this man.’ The reiterated pronoun really marks the stress of the inductive argument.

Others take e)k … tou=de as=‘from this arrow’: then sfagw=n must go either with dielqw/n, ‘having come through (from) the wounds’; or with ai(/matos, ‘poison contained in the blood of the wounds.’ But the point is that the poison, though it comes to Heracles from the wound of Nessus, and not (as to its former victims) directly from the arrow, is still the same. And, since o(/de expresses this, tou=d), if it referred to the arrow, would be superfluous.
do/ch| gou=n e)mh=|: cp. Phaed.68B ou)k a)/smenos ei)=sin au)to/se; oi)/esqai/ ge xrh/. For gou=n, cp. n. on Ant.45to\n gou=n e)mo/n.

sfalh/setai: cp. 297, sfalh=|. —tau)th=| su\n o(rmh=|, lit., ‘borne along by the same impetus.’ The o(rmh/, impetus, is that of the fate which brings Heracles low: she means, ‘at the same moment I, too, shall be swept out of life.’ Cp. Xen. Ages.2. 29e)no/mize ga\r th=| au)th=| o(rmh=| tw=| me\n *ai)gupti/w| xa/rin a)podw/sein..., tou\s d' e)n th=| *)asi/a| *(/ellhnas pa/lin e)leuqerw/sein, tw=| de\ *pe/rsh| di/khn e)piqh/sein: i.e., ‘by the same effort.’ The phrase was perhaps a familiar one, to which the poet has here given a new turn.
For su\n, cp. Theocr. 25. 251 thlou= de\ mih=| ph/dhse su\n o(rmh=| (‘at one bound’: though mia=| o(rmh=| usu.=‘by a common impulse,’ Xen. An.3. 2. 9).

protima=| with inf.; cp. Her.3. 21protimw=n pollou= e)moi\ cei=nos gene/sqai. —mh\ (‘generic’) with kakh\, rather than with the inf.: cp. 725: fr. 154. 2 e)/xoim' a)n au)to\ mh\ kakw=s a)peika/sai. The adj. is not here a mere synonym for dusgenh/s (as in O. T.1063), but rather blends the ideas of birth and character. For the sentiment, cp. El.989zh=n ai)sxro\n ai)sxrw=s toi=s kalw=s pefuko/sin: Ai.479.
e)/rga dei/n): the ‘deeds’ are the dire results which Deianeira has so frankly presaged (718 pw=s ou)k o)lei= kai\ to/nde;). Hence deina/ is not too strong.

e)lpi/d) has properly a neutral sense (cp. 125 n.): ‘we must not decide our foreboding before the issue,’—i.e., assume that the worst will certainly happen: hence we may more freely render, ‘doom our hope.’

toi=s mh\ kaloi=s b.: for the generic mh/, cp. Ant.494tw=n mhde\n o)rqw=s e)n sko/tw| texnwme/nwn.—e)lpi/s, h(/tis kai\ qr. ti procenei=, a foreboding which so much as lends courage. The measures which she has taken do not allow her to think of a good result as even possible. For procenei= cp. O. T.1483 n.
a)mfi\ with dat., ‘in the case of,’ Ph.1354 n.
mh\ )c e(kousi/as: cp. 395: Ph.467mh\ )c a)po/ptou. The adverbial phrase would properly precede sfalei=si: but cp. Ant.659 n.

pe/peira (related to pe/pwn as pi/eira to pi/wn) is attested by the grammarians, but extant only in Anacreon fr. 87. Hippocrates Acut.390 has pe/peiros no/sos, and Ar. Eccl.896e)n tai=s pepei/rois (Rav. pepei/rais).—For the sentiment, cp. fr. 599 a)/kwn d' a(martw\n ou)/tis a)nqrw/pwn kako/s.
toiau=ta d): de/ introduces an objection, as in O. T.379(n.).

oi)/koi, fig.: cp. Eur. Tro.647to\n de\ nou=n dida/skalon | oi)/koqen e)/xousa xrhsto/n. So Lat. domi (Plaut. Miles 194, with Tyrrell's note). In Her.7. 152ta\ oi)kh/ia kaka/ (‘the troubles that they have at home’) is similarly figurative.
a)\n a(rmo/zoi: cp. Dem. or. 18 § 42 lo/gous ou(\s...a(rmo/sei le/gein.

to\n plei/w lo/gon: the further discourse which might be expected: cp. n. on O. C.36ta\ plei/on' i(storei=n.—ei) mh/ ti: the schol. seems right in taking ti as object to le/ceis, rather than as an adv. (‘perchance,’ 712).
masth\r patro\s: cp. O. C.455e)mou= | masth=ra. The Chorus may be supposed to know of this mission through having heard the last words of the pro/logos as they were entering (95).
a)\n … ei(lo/mhn: cp. Ph.1239a)\n...e)boulo/mhn (n.).

se is subject to each of the three infinitives which follow. It is placed as if the speaker mentally supplied a word such as paqei=n. But e(\n is really an accus. in apposition with the whole sentence, se h)\ mhke/t' ei)=nai, etc. The peculiar order has been due to the metrical difficulty of inserting se anywhere in vv. 735—737.

e)k triw=n e(
. Photius and Suidas quote the proverb, tw=n triw=n kakw=n e(/n, illustrating it from Polyzelus (a poet of the later Old Comedy), triw=n kakw=n e(/n g' ou)=n e(le/sq' au)tw=| ti pa=s' a)na/gkh, and Menander, e(
 ga/r ti tou/twn tw=n triw=n e)/xoi kakw=n. Cp. schol. Pind. O.1. 97tri/a le/getai koinw=s kai\ ta\ pro\s to
 qa/naton sunergou=nta, ci/fos, a)gxo/nh, krhmno/s: *sofoklh=s (fr. 822)<*> lu/sw ga/r, ei) kai\ tw=n triw=n e(
 oi)/somai. A like prov. was tri/a *qhrame/nous, alluding to three alternative penalties proposed by him.

keklh=sqai: cp. 149: El.366pa/ntwn a)ri/stou pai=da keklh=sqai.—a)mei/yasqai, get in exchange: Aesch. Theb.304poi=on d' a)mei/yesqe gai/as pe/don | ta=sd' a)/reion; poqen is wholly vague: the schol.'s e)k qeou= tinos is too definite.

ti/ d' e)/stin … pro/s g' e)mou= stugou/- menon; ‘What is there, on my part, that excites hatred?’ The phrase is peculiar (since the words could mean, ‘what is hated by me?’); but, in speaking, the sense would be made clear by a very slight pause after the words pro/s g' e)mou=, which are naturally emphatic (cp. O. T.516).

to\n d' e)mo\n: for this use of de/ to mark a second relationship, see on O. C.1275w)= spe/rmat' a)ndro\s tou=d), e)mai\ d' o(mai/mones. Two modes of expression are blended here, since either de/, or le/gw, should properly be absent: but the redundancy suits the speaker's vehemence. —For le/gw, cp. 9.
e)ch/negkas here denotes a startling utterance (like poi=o/n se e)/pos fu/gen e(/rkos o)do/ntwn;). e)kfe/rw, with ref. to speech, usu. = ‘to disclose’ a secret ( Her.3. 71).

dn ou)x o<*>o/n te k.t.l. This lo/gos is one which must needs ‘be fulfilled,’ —i.e., ‘befound to correspond with a fact,’ ‘prove true,’—since the thing has already happened. Cp. Il.1. 388h)pei/lhsen mu=qon, o(\ dh\ tetelesme/nos e)sti/n.—Most edd. read mh\ ou), instead of the MS. mh\, here: but see 90 n.

to\ … fanqe\n, that which has come before men's eyes,—come to pass: cp. Ai.647(xro/nos) fu/ei t' a)/dhla kai\ fane/nta kru/ptetai: Ant.457kou)dei\s oi)=den e)c o(/tou )fa/nh. The word is fitting at a moment when his mind is full of the terrible sight which he has just seen (746 f.). For to\ ga\r at the end of the v., cp. 92.
ti/s a)\n du/nait' a)\n: cp. 21.

a)ge/nhton, ‘not brought to pass’ (st. gen-, gi/gnomai): cp. Horace's infectum (C. 3. 29. 47). But a)ge/nnhtos (genna-)=‘not begotten’ (61). Agathon fr. 5 (ap. Eth. N. 6. 2) mo/nou ga au)tou= kai\ qeo\s steri/sketai, | a)ge/nhta poiei=n a(/ss' a)
 h)=| pepragme/na. Pind. O.2. 17tw=n de\ pepragme/nwn | ...a)poi/hton ou)d' a)
 | xro/nos o( pa/ntwn path du/naito qe/men e)/rgwn te/los. Simonides fr. 69 to\ ga gegenhme/non ou)ke/t' a)/rekton e)/stai. Theognis 583 a)lla\ ta\ me
 probe/bhken a)mh/xano/n e)sti gene/sqai | a)rga/. H. N. 2. 7 Deus nullum habet in praeterita ius praeterquam oblivionis.
744 f. For a)nqrw/pwn added to the interrog. ti/s, cp. El.238 El., 930.

a)/zhlon: cp. 284.—Nauck rejects v. 745, because Deianeira ought to have one verse only (cp. 738, 741, 748). But it is unsafe to assume such a rigorous ‘symmetry’: and the larger utterance is natural here.
e)n o)/mmasin: 241 n.

kata\ glw=ssan, ‘as a matter of report,’ i.e. par' a)/llwn. (The similar phrase a)po\ glw/sshs usu. means ‘orally,’ i.e., not in writing: Her.1. 123, Thuc.7. 10.) Cp. I. T. 901 ta/d' ei)=don au)th/, kou) klu/ous' a)paggelw=.

e)mpela/zeis … kai\ pari/stasai, i.e., find him, and then stand near to him in his sufferings. The vivid historic pres. suits the tension of mind with which the question is asked: cp. O. T.113sumpi/ptei, and ib. 1025 di/dws.—These are Deianeira's last words on the scene.

ei) xrh\ maqei=n se. Hyllus abhors her, as the murderess of his father; there is no touch of pity in his mood. His words mean that the recital will be painful to him, and also that he shrinks from speaking to her at such length. (Cp. 815 f.) According to Greek usage, it was not o(/sion for the relatives of a slain person to hold any avoidable intercourse with the slayer. (Cp. Lys. or. 12 § 24: Isae. or. 9 § 20.) This feeling appears in 815 f.

o(/q' ei(=rpe: see on 237 f. For the absence of a prefatory ga/r, cp. 555, 900. e)pei/ is more usual than o(/te in opening such a r(h=sis. The schol.'s remark here, kainopreph\s h( fra/sis, may refer partly to that, and partly to the abruptness of ei(=rpe.

tropai=a, the arms taken from the enemy (cp. Ant.143 n.), sku=la: a)kroqi/nia, the booty, lei/a.—This accent for the subst. tropai=on is attested by the grammarians, and preserved by L in 1102: though, acc. to rule, the subst. would be tro/paion, and the adj. tropai=os ( Ph.1459 n.).

a)kth/ … e)/stin, instead of h)=lqen ei)s a)kth/n k.t.l.: cp. Eur. Hipp.1198e)pei\ d' e)/rhmon xw=ron ei)seba/llomen, | a)kth/ tis e)/sti k.t.l. (instead of ei)/domen a)kth/n tina): I.T. 260 e)pei\ to\n e)sre/onta dia\ *sumplhga/dwn | bou=s u(loforbou\s po/nton ei)seba/llomen, | h)=n tis diarrw\c kuma/twn pollw=| sa/lw| | koilwpo\s a)gmo/s: ib. 1449 o(/tan d' *)aqh/nas ta\s qeodmh/tous mo/lh|s, | xw=ro/s tis e)/stin. The epic fashion is to begin with a description of the place ( Il.2. 811e)/sti de/ tis...kolw/nh, Od.3. 293e)/sti de/ tis pe/trh)—as above Od., 237.The mixed construction here comes from a wish to make the narrative at once consecutive and graphic.
*kh/naion: 237 n.
patrw/|w|: 288 n.— bwmou\s o(ri/zei k.t.l.: 238 n.
temeni/an … fulla/da=te/menos polu/fullon (schol.).— a)/smenos po/qw|, glad, through my longing (causal dat.).
poluqu/tous … sfaga\s: the second part of the compound adj. is akin in sense to the subst.; cp. xoai=si trispo/ndoisi ( Ant.431), neoto/moisi plh/gmasin (ib. 1283).

kh=ruc a)p' oi)/kwn … oi)kei=os: ‘his own’ herald, returning from Trachis, was not one at whose hand he could have expected such a gift. It is needless to give oi)kei=os a special sense, as (a) ‘bred up in his household,’ or (b) ‘sent on a private mission,’ as Paley takes it.
prou)cefi/eso: for the imperf., cp. O. T.1055e)fie/mesqa: O. C.1605e)fi/eto: so often e)ke/leuon. This compound does not occur elsewhere, but is paralleled by proecani/stamai, proecaposte/llw.

tauroktonei= k.t.l. The offering consisted of a hundred victims altogether, including bulls, sheep, and goats (summigh= boskh/mata),—a ‘hecatomb’ in the general sense ( Il.1. 315e(kato/mbas | tau/rwn h)d' ai)gw=n). The sacrifice was to begin with the slaughter of twelve oxen, animals specially selected from the spoil. Such a qusi/a dw/deka i(erei/wn was called dwdekh=|s (Eustath. p. 1386. 48, etc.). In Il.6. 93Helenus directs that an offering of twelve cows shall be promised to Athena.

e)ntelei=s=telei/ous, with no physical blemish or taint: Lucian Sacrif. 12 stefanw/santes to\ zw=|on, kai\ polu/ ge pro/teron e)ceta/santes ei) e)ntele\s ei)/h, i(/na mhde\ tw=n a)xrh/stwn ti katasfa/ttwsi, prosa/gousi tw=| bwmw=|.

bou=s is probably masc. here (as in Ai.62), though in Homer it is usu. fem., unless the contrary is specified. The word tauroktonei= is not decisive, since it might express merely the antithesis between oxen and other victims (cp. such phrases as oi)noxoei=n ne/ktar). Seneca Herc. Oet. 784 Ut stetit ad aras omne votivum pecus, | Totumque tauris gemuit auratis nemus.

prosh=ge, sc. tw=| bwmw=|: cp. Pollux 1. 29 ta\ de\ prosakte/a fu/mata, i(erei=a a)/rtia a)/toma o(lo/klhra u(gih= a)/phra. The imperf. means strictly, ‘proceeded to bring’ (after donning the robe). The hist. pres. tauroktonei=, too, represents an imperf., not an aor.

i(/lew|. While i(laro/s (i^) properly refers to aspect (‘beaming,’ ‘cheerful,’ as opp. to skuqrwpo/s), i(/lews denotes a placid or gracious mood of the mind: cp. Ephippus (a poet of the Middle Comedy), *)empolh/ fr. 1 e)poi/hse/ q' i(laro/n, eu)qe/ws d' a)fei=le pa=n | au)tou= to\ lupou=n, ka)pe/deicen i(/lewn (where Meineke rashly changes q' i(laro/n to qalero/n).

ko/smw| te … kai\ stolh=|=kosmi/a| stolh=|. So in Eur. Med.1165Glauce puts on the deadly gifts of Medea, dw/rois u(perxai/rousa.—kathu/xeto: as Chryses mega/l' eu)/xeto xei=ras a)nasxw/n, at the sacrifice described in Il.1. 447—466; and as Nestor polla\...*)aqh/nh| | eu)/xet) on the like occasion in Od.3. 430—463. Those two passages explain the ritual imagined here (vv. 756—766). (1) Heracles, having put on the robe, brings his victims to the altar. (2) The next act would be to sprinkle the xe/rniy on the sacrificers; who would then take barleymeal (ou)loxu/tai) in the hands from the basket, kanou=n. (3) Then Heracles offers his prayer to Zeus. (4) The actual immolation follows; the barley-meal is sprinkled on the heads of victims; hair, cut from one or more of them, is thrown on the altar-fire; and they are slain. (5) The mhri/a ( Ant.1011), doubly wrapped in fat, are burnt on the altar. This act was in progress, when the agonies of Heracles began.

Several critics alter kathu/xeto to kath/rxeto. The latter, if used in its larger sense, would refer to no. 2 of the stages described above (cp. Od.3. 445xe/rniba/ t' ou)loxu/tas te kath/rxeto); if in its narrower sense, to no. 4 (cp. Ar. Av.959, Her.2. 45). The larger sense would be best here.

But kathu/xeto is an immeasurably finer reading. Heracles, standing before the altar as he prays with uplifted hands to Zeus, is thrown into stronger relief than if imagined merely in the brief act denoted by kath/rxeto. The i(/lews frh/n, too, would be more apparent in the eu)xh/ than in the rite.

semnw=n o)rgi/wn … flo\c, ‘the flame of the solemn rites,’ i.e., the flame from the sacrifice on the altar. o)/rgia could not literally mean qu/mata (the word by which the schol. explains it); but the sense is the same. In Ant.1013, too, o)rgi/wn are ‘rites,’ not ‘victims.’ The flame is called ai(mathra/, because the burning flesh was so. It is needless to take a)po/ with o)rgi/wn.

piei/ras druo/s: the wood of the pine (peu/kh) is resinous (r(htinw/dhs),—a quality conducive to the bright flame which was prized as an omen ( Ant.1007 n.). The original meaning of dru=s was simply ‘tree’ (schol. Il.11. 86; Curt. Etym. § 275). In 1168 and 1195 it means ‘oak.’

i(drw\s, showing that the irritant action of the poison has begun.— a)rti/kollos, w(/ste te/ktonos, closely glued to his flesh as if by a craftsman: schol. w(s u(po\ te/ktonos kalw=s sugkekollhme/nos. The gen. here is not so definitely equivalent to a gen. with u(po/ as it is in Ai.807fwto\s h)pathme/nh, or Eur. Or.497plhgei\s qugatro/s. Eur. Itexpresses a similar notion, but in a vaguer form: ‘like something from (the hand of) a te/ktwn’: ‘like (a work) of his.’ Some supply kollh/santos: but this seems difficult, and is not warranted by such examples as w(s e)mou= mo/nhs pe/las (sc. ou)/shs, Soph. O. C.83).

Some have supposed that the xitw/n is compared to (stone or bronze) drapery on a statue. te/ktwn could certainly mean a sculptor: Eur. Alc.348sofh=| de\ xeiri\ tekto/nwn to\ so\n de/mas | ei)kasqe/n. But: (1) There would be little point in comparing a real robe to an imitation in art. (2) Cp. fr. 430. 4, where Pelops is responding, with his eyes, to the glance of Hippodameia, and the discreet limit which the lover's instinct observes is compared to the line traced by a craftsman's rule;—i)/son metrw=n o)fqalmo/n, w(/ste te/ktonos | para\ sta/qmhn i)o/ntos o)rqou=tai kanw/n. There, then, as here, the simile is from a mechanical process: the te/ktwn is suggested there by i)/son metrw=n, as here by a)rti/kollos.

a(/pan kat' a)/rqron: the robe clings so tight as to show the contour of the body: cp. the Homeric phrase, e)ntupa\s e)n xlai/nh| kekalumme/nos, explained to mean, w(/ste dia\ tou= i(mati/ou tou= sw/matos to\n tu/pon fai/nesqai ( Il.24. 163, with Leaf's n.).

o)ste/wn might be joined with a)nti/spastos (=a)ntispw=n ta\ o)sta=), but is more simply taken with a)dagmo/s. The latter word means ‘a biting pain’ (rt dak), esp. an ‘itching.’ Photius p. 7 21: a)dagmo\s o( o)dachsmo/s, o(/per e)sti\ knhsmo/s: ou(/tw *sofoklh=s. The forms o)da/cw (act. and midd.) and a)dace/w (do.) seem both to have been in use; the former was perhaps chiefly Ionic.
e)xi/dnhs … w(\s: Hyllus does not know what Deianeira had applied to the robe; but, as the venom was that of the hydra, his conjecture comes near the truth.
e)dai/nuto: cp. 1088: Eur. fr. 790 fage/dain' a)ei/ mou sa/rka qoina=tai podo/s.

)bo/hse: boa=n tina usu.=‘to shout to (or for) one’: Pind. P.6. 36bo/ase pai=da o(/n (called his son to his aid): Xen. Cyr.7. 2. 5*ku=ron e)bo/a. Here it means, ‘shouted for him, (asking),’=bow=n h)rw/thse.—e)ne/gkoi: for h)/negkon and h)/negka, cp. Soph. O. C.522.
mhxanai=s in a bad sense, as Ai.181.

e)/lecen, sc. e)negkei=n.—w(/sper h)=n e)stalme/non, as it had been sent; i.e., without tampering with it by the way. Cp. 622 to/d' a)/ggos w(s e)/xei dei=cai fe/rwn. —Not, ‘as had been prescribed’ (e)pestalme/non).
pleumo/nwn: cp. 1054: for the form, 567 n.

a)/rqron h(=| lugi/zetai, ‘where the joint is supple,’ i.e., at the ankle (sfuro/n), where the ball of the joint (a)stra/galos) plays in its socket. This mode of definition is Homeric: cp. Il.5. 305e)/nqa te mhro\s | i)sxi/w| e)nstre/fetai (turns in the hip-joint).

e)k po/ntou, ‘in’ (‘rising from’) the sea; i.e., an isolated rock, not part of a promontory. This is better than to take the words with a)mfi/kluston, ‘washed on all sides by the sea’: e)k po/ntou would then be too weak.

The name ‘Lichades’ was given to some rocky islets just S. of C. Cenaeum, in the narrow strait dividing it from the promontory of Cnemīdes on the Locrian coast. Strabo 9. p. 426 e)ntau=qa kai\ ai( *lixa/des kalou/menai trei=s nh=soi pro/keintai, a)po\ *li/xa tou)/noma e)/xousai. Cp. Aesch. fr. 29, quoted on 237 f. Ovid Met. 9. 226 Nunc quoque in Euboico scopulus brevis emicat alte | Gurgite, et humanae servat vestigia formae; | Quem quasi sensurum nautae calcare verentur, | Appellantque Lichan.—*li/xas perh.=li/qos: cp. o)/rnixos, o)/rniqos (Preller 2. 255 n. 2).

ko/mhs … muelo
 e)krai/nei, he causes the brain to ooze out through his victim's hair,—at the moment when the skull is cloven. Cp. Eur. fr. 388 ka/ra te ga/r sou sugxew= ko/mais o(mou=, | r(anw= de\ pedo/s' e)gke/falon: id. Eur. Cycl.402to
 d' au)=, te/nontos a(rpa/sas a)/krou podo/s, | pai/wn pro\s o)cu
 sto/nuxa petrai/ou li/qou | e)gke/falon e)ce/rrane (where the verbal resemblance to this passage is remarkable).

muelo\n: e)gke/falos, the proper word for ‘brain,’ is merely an adj. with which muelo/s is understood. In Plat. Tim. 73C, D the e)gke/falos is described as that part of the muelo/s which is to receive to\ qei=on spe/rma.

diaspare/ntos: the skull, cleft from its centre (me/sou), is scattered in fragments. Other views are:—(1) The word means merely ‘cloven,’ and has been substituted for a word like diarrage/ntos on account of the following ai(/matos. This seems impossible. (2) diarrage/ntos, or the like (see cr. n.), should be read. But diaspare/ntos, rightly understood, suits both nouns. Athenaeus (66 A) quotes vv. 781 f., as cited by Apollodorus (c. 140 B.C.), without variation from our text. The reading, then, is at least a very old one.

a)nhufh/mhsen oi)mwgh=|: the verb can bear this sense even without a defining addition: Eur. Or.1335a)neufhmei= do/mos (of wailing): Plat. Phaedo60 A a)nhufh/mhse (Xanthippè). The notion is that of a cry which expresses religious awe. Cp. Matthew Arnold, Mycerinus: ‘And one loud cry of grief and of amaze | Broke from his sorrowing people.’
i)u/zwn: i)u/, a shrill sound, expressed astonishment or anguish: Aeëtes uses it in his ‘inarticulate’ vexation (i)/ucen d' a)fwnh/tw| per e)/mpas a)/xei: Pind. P.4. 237).

*lokrw=n t' o)/reioi prw=nes: the heights of the Cnemis range, on the Locrian coast, just s. of Cape Cenaeum in Euboea. At this point the strait is less than three miles in breadth. The t) after *lokrw=n (cr. n.) seems genuine.— a)/krai, the cliffs which jut into the sea at or near Cenaeum. This fem. form is usual when, as here, the ref. is to promontories. a)/kra, the reading of Diogenes Laertius (cr. n.),—meant doubtless as neut. pl.,—would be rather ‘mountain heights.’ The neut. a)/kron is rarely said of a foreland (as in Od.3. 278).

Seneca's equivalent for this passage is curious: he describes the hero's cries as re-echoed from Chalcis (50 miles off), from Cape Caphareus (upwards of 100), and from ‘all the Cyclades’! (Herc. Oet. 803 ff.)
a)pei=pe … r(i/ptwn: the cause of weariness is regularly expressed by a pres. part.: Ar. Lys.778mh/ nun a)pei/pwmen talaipwrou/menai: Plat. Legg. 769 E ou)k a)/n pote le/gwn a)pei/poi.
duspa/reunon: for the adj., compounded with a subst. akin in sense to le/ktron, cp. O. T.518bi/ou ... makrai/wnos, and above O. T., 756 n.
e)ndatou/menos: cp. O. T.205 n.

to\n *oi)ne/ws ga/mon: the gen. is most simply explained by the fact that ga/mos implies alliance: cp. Soph. Ph.77kh=dos *)adra/stou labw/n. Others understand, ‘the marriage granted to him by Oeneus,’ so that the constr, would be as with dw=ron.
prose/drou, perikexume/nhs: the cloud hung around him.
lignu/os, the smoky flame from the resinous peu/kh (766),—just as in Ant.1126ste/roy lignu/s refers to pine-torches.

dia/strofon, with the frenzy of pain: cp. Eur. H. F.932e)n strofai=sin o)mma/twn e)fqarme/nos.—stratw=|: though the crowd must have been partly composed of warriors (259), strato/s has here the general sense of lew/s (783): cp. Soph. Ant.8 n.: Soph. El.749.
sunqanei=n: cp. Aesch. Suppl.1006a(/distos ga/r toi qa/natos | sunqnh/|skein qnh/|skousi fi/lois.

e)/cw, as the context shows, means ‘out of Euboea’: for a)=ron, cp. Ai.545ai)=r' au)to/n, ai)=re deu=ro.—ma/lista me/n: cp. Ant.327 n. His thought is: ‘Take me at once to the wilds of Mount Oeta, and leave me to perish alone; or, if you shrink from that, at least take me out of the island.’

The reasons for preferring Wakefield's me qe\s to the MS. me/qes turn on these points. (1) The act. meqie/nai, when said of persons, usu.=‘allow to escape’ ( O. C.906a)/trwton ou) meqh=k' a)/n: Ai.372meqh=ka tou\s a)la/storas): or ‘leave’ to some course; as Ant.653me/qes | th\n pai=d' e)n *(/aidou th/nde numfeu/ein tini/. But this use of the verb has no place here. The sense is not, ‘allow me to escape’ to some solitude. (2) As said of things, meqie/nai can mean, ‘to let go,’ ‘release from one's grasp’; El.448tau=ta me\n me/qes: ib. 1205 me/qes to/d' a)/ggos. Hermann, who retains me/qes, renders it by ‘depone.’ But that is too gentle a word: me/qes here would differ from kata/qes as ‘drop’ from ‘lay down.’ Cp. 1254 e)s pura/n me qh=|s.
o(/pou … mh/ tis o)/yetai: cp. O. T.1410e)/cw me/ pou | kalu/yat), h)\ foneu/sat), h)\ qala/ssion | e)kri/yat), e)/nqa mh/pot' ei)so/yesq' e)/ti (n.).
ei) d' oi)=kton i)/sxeis, if thou hast no heart to do that. It would be easy, but it is needless, to read ei) d' oi)=ktos i)/sxei s).
a)lla/, ‘at least’: 201 n.— au)tou= ‘just here’ ( O. C.78e)nqa/d' au)tou=).
qa/nw: the prohibitive subj. is rare in the 1st pers.; but cp. O. C.174(n.): Eur. Tro.172(mh\) a)lgunqw=.
tosau=t), implying brevity.
e)piskh/yantos, sc. au)tou=: cp. Ph.1033pleu/- santos (sc. e)mou=): Xen. An.4. 8. 5oi( d' ei)=pon, e)rwth/santos, o(/ti k.t.l.—e)n me/sw| ska/fei, recumbent in the middle of the vessel.

sfe is prob. governed by e)ke/lsamen as well as by qe/ntes. The acc. after ke/llw usu. denotes either the ship or the place; but cp. Ph.236ti/s s), w)= te/knon, prose/sxe k.t.l. (n.).—The boat would be rowed from Cape Cenaeum to the harbour near Thermopylae (633 n.), a distance of about eighteen miles; thence Heracles would be carried some six miles to Trachis. The shortest sea-passage would be across to the Locrian coast (788 n.); but the longer land-journey would be more trying for the sufferer.
h)\ zw=nt' … h)\ teqnhko/t): a way of saying, ‘I cannot tell whether his life will last so long.’ The change to zw=nt' e)/t' o)/yesq) would weaken the verse.—Cp. 235.

bouleu/sas): not only in poetry (as Ant.267), but in prose also, bouleu/ein is said of ‘planning’ (as dist. from ‘executing’) a crime ( Dem. or. 19 § 21); and bou/leusis was a legal term in this sense. The boulh/ was really that of Nessus (844 f.).

drw=s), not dra/sasa, since his torments continue. The dat. patri\ e)mw=| can be taken with drw=s), no less than with bouleu/sas). For the construction drw= tau=ta/ soi (instead of se), cp. O. T.1373 n.
poi/nimos, of avenging deities, as Ai.843.

*di/kh is associated with *)erinu/s, since the latter especially punishes sins against kinsfolk: cp. Aesch. Ag.1432ma\ th\n te/leion th=s e)mh=s paido\s *di/khn, | *)/athn t), *)erinu/n q), ai(=si to/nd' e)/sfac' e)gw/.—w(=n … tei/sait): for the causal gen., cp. Soph. O. C.229w(=n propa/qh| to\ ti/nein: Her.4. 118tei/sasqai th=s pro/sqe doulosu/nhs boulo/memos. For the spelling, cp. O.T. 810 n.
e)peu/xomai: he deliberately gives his wish (tei/sait)) the solemn form of an imprecation.
ei) qe/mis … qe/mis d): cp. Ph.1035: fr. 856 ei)/ moi qe/mis: qe/mis de\ ta)lhqh= le/gein: Eur. H. F.141ei) xrh/ m), e)rwtw=: xrh\ d), e)pei/ ge despo/ths k.t.l.

prou)/bales, hast cast from thee, spurned: schol. e)pei\ su\ pro/tera [read prote/ra] th\n qe/min a)pe/rriyas kai\ parei=des. Cp. Ai.830r(ifqw= kusi\n pro/blhtos. Aesch. Eum.215*ku/pris d' a)/timos tw=|d' a)pe/rriptai lo/gw|. Tac. Ann. 1. 42 cives, quibus tam senatus proiecta auctoritas.
moi, ethic dat. (=‘I have seen thee’ do so): cp. O. C.81h)= be/bhken h(mi\n o( ce/nos;

Others understand: (1) ‘you have thrown this very justice as a shield (pro/blhma) over my action’ (Paley); i.e., ‘have made it right for me to do so.’ (2) ‘You have given me the right to do so’ (lit., ‘placed’ that right ‘at my disposal’).—Wunder, changing qe/min to e)/rin, explains, ‘you have challenged me to this strife.’
si=g): cp. Eurydicè's silent exit, Ant.1244: and for the sentiment, cp. fr. 842 ai)dw\s ga\r e)n kakoi=sin o<*>de\n w)felei=: | h( ga\r siwph\ tw=| lalou=nti su/mmaxos.

815 f. The place of o)fqalmw=n e)mw=n in the sentence is due to the implied thought, ‘So long as I see her no more, she may go where she will.’ The poet cares not that the gen. might seem to depend on ou)=ros: for like cases, cp. Ant.944(*dana/as), Ph.598(ti/nos d)).
au)th=| is not emphatic (‘of her own accord’), any more than au)to\n in 262.

kalo/s seems a true correction of kalw=s, and was probably read by the schol. (cr. n.). Cp. Od.11. 640ka/llimos ou)=ros. The adv. would have a weak effect at the end of the v., and would belong to e(rpou/sh| rather than to ge/noit).—Cp. Aesch. Th.690i)/tw kat' ou)=ron, ku=ma *kwkutou= laxo/n, | *foi/bw| stughqe\n pa=n to\ *lai+/ou ge/nos.
ga\r justifies his unfilial language.

o)/gkon, ‘importance’ ( O. C.1162 n.), ‘pomp’ ( Ai.129mhd' o)/gkon a)/rh| mhde/n)): here, the ‘dignity’ belonging to the name of mother. The adj. agrees with o)/gkon, since o)/gk. o)no/matos=‘namedignity’: cp. Aesch. Eum.325matrw=|on a(/gnisma...fo/nou.—a)/llws, ‘vainly’ ( Soph. Ph.947 n.), i.e., when she is a mother in name only.
tre/fein, ‘keep,’ continue to enjoy.
mhde\n, generic, helping the causal force of h(/tis. Cp. El.1194mh/thr kalei=tai, mhtri\ d' ou)de\n e)cisoi=.
a)ll' e(rp. xai/rousa: cp. Eur. Phoen.921xai/rwn i)/q): ou) ga\r sw=n me dei= manteuma/twn.—h(\n at the end of the verse: cp. Soph. O. T.298, Soph. O. C.14, Soph. El.873.
th/nd): th\n d) would be too emphatic: cp. 23 n.

div2.p: Third sta/simon. 1st strophe (821—830)=1st antistrophe (831 —840): 2nd str. (841—851)=2nd antistr. (852—862). For the metres see Metrical Analysis.
The oracle given twelve years ago is being fulfilled; Heracles is doomed. Deianeira has been the unconscious instrument of fate. And in all this can be seen the work of Aphroditè.

div3.p: i)/d): though several persons are addressed, the sing. is used (as in O.C. 1463), since i)de/ could be a mere interjec tion; cp. Od.3. 332a)/ge ta/mnete: Ar. Th.788fe/re dh/ nun, | ...ti/ gamei=q' h(ma=s; id. Ar. Pax383ei)pe/ moi, ti/ pa/sxet), w)=ndres;

prose/meicen, intrans., as in Ph.106(where see n. on the spelling), ‘has come to close quarters with us,’ instead of merely threatening from a distance. As palaifa/tou indicates, the poet was thinking of Od.9. 507 h)= ma/la dh/ me palai/fata qe/sfaq' i(ka/nei.

qeopro/pon, ‘oracular’: usu. connected with pre/pw (intrans.), as=‘appearing from a god’; though Buttmann explains it by qeo\s pre/pei (trans.), ‘a god sends a sign.’ Acc. to another view, qeopro/pos is ‘one who prays to a god’ (as though the rt prop- were akin to Lat. prec: Leaf, Il.1. 85).

ta=s palaifa/tou pronoi/as, the (divine) prescience which was declared (which found utterance) long ago: viz., twelve years ago, at Dodona: see 44 n. Cp. Soph. Ph.637qei/a| pronoi/a|, ‘with inspired foresight.’ Soph. O. C.454(mantei=a) palai/faq).

o(/ t), neut. of the epic relat. o(/s te: cp. El.151a(/ t) (h(/ t)). There is no metrical ground for reading a(/ t) (fem.) here, since the syllable, forming the anacrusis of the verse, is properly short: in the antistrophic v. El., 834, o(\n before te/keto is a long substituted for a short.
e)/laken, of oracular utterance, Ant.1094.

e)kfe/roi, intrans., ‘come to an end’: schol. pare/lqoi. Anintrans. e)kfe/rein occurs elsewhere only as meaning ‘to shoot ahead’ in a race: see on O. C.1424(where e)kfe/rei is best taken as 2nd pers. pres. midd., ‘fulfil for thyself’). But the sense found here is parallel with that of the intrans. e)kdido/nai and e)cie/nai, as said of rivers, ‘to issue.’

dwde/katos a)/rotos: the twelfth year from the time when the oracle was given at Dodona: see n. on 44. Apollodorus names the same term, though, acc. to his version, the oracle was given at Delphi (2. 4. 12).

This is the only passage of the play which mentions the period of twelve years. In 44 f. and 164 f., the reference is merely to the fifteen months which, when Heracles left home, were still wanting to those twelve years. It may be asked, then, whence the Chorus derive their knowledge of the twelve years; for Deianeira, in 155 ff., speaks as if they had not then heard of the oracle. The answer is simply that this inconsistency of detail was overlooked by the poet; the term of twelve years was in his mind, as a familiar part of the story; and he forgot that, if the Chorus were to know it, Deianeira ought to have mentioned it.

Needless difficulties have been made by assuming that the allusion here must be to the fifteen months of 44 f. and 164 f. Even then, however, it has to be supposed that ‘twelve months’ are put loosely for ‘fifteen.’
a)/rotos, ‘year’: 69 n.

a)nadoxa\n telei=n (fut.) po/nwn: the subject to the inf. is au)to/n supplied from a)/rotos: ‘that it (the twelfth year) should end the succession of toils.’ telei=n could not be intrans., with a)nadoxa/n for subject. The apparently intrans. use of the verb is limited to such phrases as the following: El.1419telou=s' a)rai/ (are doing their work): Aesch. Th.659ei)so/mesq' o(/ph| telei= (‘how the god will ordain’): cp. Aesch. Ch.1021, Aesch. Pers.225.
au)to/paidi: schol. gnhsi/w| paidi/: cp. au)tane/yios.—o)rqw=s, i.e., at the due moment (cp. 173): o)rqo/s is oft. thus said of oracles coming true: O. T.853: O. C.1424: Ant.1178.
e)/mpeda, without fail: cp. 487.

katouri/zei, intrans., are coming into haven before a fair wind: schol. w(/sper ou)ri/w| pneu/mati prosormei= h(mi=n kat' o)rqo\n a)nuo/mena. This compound does not occur elsewhere: but cp. Ar. Th.1226tre/xe nun kata\ tou\s ko/rakas e)pouri/sas.
o( mh\ leu/sswn=o( mh\ ble/pwn, the dead. Though this absol. use of leu/ssein is found only here, it does not warrant suspicion.

e)pi/ponon … latrei/an. The insertion of po/nwn, due to Gleditsch, is made probable by the text of the antistrophe: see on 839 f. For the phrase, cp. 356 po/nwn | latreu/mat). And for e)pi/ponon along with po/nwn, cp. Ant.502 n. Other views of this verse are given in the Appendix on 839 f.

foni/a| nefe/la|, dat. of circumstance, ‘with a cloud of death around him’: cp. Il.16. 350qana/tou de\ me/lan ne/fos a)mfeka/luyen. There is perhaps a reminiscence of Pindar N. 9. 37 fo/nou | parpodi/ou nefe/lan (referring to battle). The image might be partly suggested by the vivid description, which the Chorus have just heard, of Heracles in his agony, with the altar-smoke hanging around him: the pro/sedros lignu/s (794) was indeed, for him, a foni/a nefe/lh.

Others understand: (1) ‘in the Centaur's deadly net.’ nefe/lh was a kind of bird-net used by fowlers: in Anthol. 6. 11. 2 it is called lepto/mitos, ‘of fine texture,’ and distinguished from the hunter's dolixo\n di/ktuon. Cp. 1052 u(fanto\n a)mfi/blhstron, and 1057 pe/dh|. But it seems doubtful whether this use of nefe/lh would have been suitable to Tragedy. (2) ‘The deadly envelopment,’—i.e., the robe, compared to a cloud which obscures the sun.

*kentau/rou … dolopoio\s a)na/gka, the Centaur's insidious constraint; i.e., the inevitable doom, brought upon him by the Centaur's guile. The adj. is properly active in sense, ‘contriving fraud’; cp. paidopoio/s, sitopoio/s. In O. C.698 the passive sense of au)topoio/n (‘selfproduced’) is exceptional.
xri/ei, irritates, torments: Aesch. P. V.567xri/ei tis au)= me ta\n ta/lainan oi)=stros. This sense, like that of ‘anointing,’ comes from the primary sense, to ‘graze,’ or ‘rub.’
pleura/ from pleuro/n: for the second acc., cp. Ph.1301me/qes me... xei=ra.

834 The MSS. have o(\n te/keto qa/natos, e)/teke d) ai)o/los dra/kwn. This has been explained as if qa/natos were the father and the dra/kwn (hydra) the mother. But usage does not warrant such a pointed antithesis between ti/ktomai (midd.) and ti/ktw. The poets apply either voice to either parent: see, e.g., Il.6. 154o( d' a)/ra *glau=kon te/keq' ui(o/n, | au)ta\r *glau=kos e)/tikten a)mu/mona *bellerofo/nthn: ib. 2. 728 e)/teken *(rh/nh, and 742 te/keto kluto\s *(ippoda/meia. Lobeck's correction of e)/teke to e)/trefe is a certain one.— ai)o/los: cp. 11.
a)e/lion, with a^, the rarer quantity: cp. Ant.100 n.

u(/dras … fa/smati, monstrous hydra: cp. 508 fa/sma tau/rou. prostetakw\s, ‘close-locked’ in the <*>eadly grip of the monster. The word came to the poet's mind through a consciousness of the literal meaning,—viz., that the hero's flesh is ‘glued’ to the robe. Thi<*> very trait, so thoroughly Sophoclean, confirms the soundness of the text. (Cp. Ant.117 n.) The context (melagxai/ta d) etc.) further confirms it. As the Chorus picture the turments of Heracles, two dread shapes rise before their thought,—the hydra, who nursed the venom, and the Centaur, through whose blood it works.—For the proposed emendations of fa/smati, see Appendix.
melagxai/ta (gen.): Scut. 186 melagxai/thn te *mi/manta. Cp. above, 557 n.

a)/mmiga=a)na/miga (cp. 519): Dem. or. 21 § 52 (in a mantei/a), i(sta/nai w(rai/wn *bromi/w| xa/rin a)/mmiga pa/ntas (‘promiscuously,’ i.e. of mixed fruits). Here the sense seems to be, ‘confusedly’; there is a tumult of pangs: cp. 1053 ff. The objection of taking it as merely ‘therewith,’ or ‘at the same time,’ is that the ke/ntra are only the workings of the hydra's venom.

It has long been the general belief that the words ne/sou (or ne/ssou) q' u(/po, found in the MSS., have arisen from a gloss,—the name of Nessus having been introduced to explain melagxai/ta. But otherwise there has been little agreement. The views of various critics are given in the Appendix.

Here I may briefly state my own conclusions. (1) melagxai/ta, ‘the blackhaired one,’ could probably stand without a substantive, or proper name,—esp. as *kentau/rou has occurred not far back; though it would be somewhat harsh.

(2) Comparing v. 830 with v. 840, we see that the words e)/xoi qanw\n latrei/an in 830 correspond metrically with -a^ ke/ntr' e)pize/santa. The words e)/ti pot' e)/t' e)pi/ponon in 830 ought therefore to correspond with what stands between ai)ki/zei in 839 and the a^ before ke/ntr) in 840: viz., acc. to the MSS., ne/sou (or ne/ssou) q' u(/po foi/nia dolo/muq-.

(3) Now, if ne/sou q' u(/po were ejected, this correspondence would be obtained by reading u(po/fona (instead of foi/nia) dolo/muqa. The form u(po/fonos, though not extant, is correct (cp. a)po/fonos in Eur. Or.163Eur. Or., 192). The ke/ntra would be u(po/fona as being ‘secretly fraught with death.’ The hiatus in ai)ki/zei | u(po/fona is not unexampled, though it has not the usual excuse of a slight pause: cp. 833 f., 846 f.; Ph.832 n. Such a hiatus has been assumed here by Hermann and others. It might be avoided, however, by reading fo/nia dolio/muqa. The forms dolo/muqos and dolio/muqos are equally correct: cp. dolo/mhtis and dolio/mhtis, dolo/frwn and dolio/frwn. In this case, the origin of u(/po would remain obscure.

(4) But a closer adherence to the MS. text becomes possible, if, with Gleditsch, we read *ne/ssou u(pofo/nia dolio/muqa ke/ntr' e)pize/santa, and in 830 e)/ti pot' e)/t' e)pi/ponon <po/nwn> e)/xoi qanw\n latrei/an. The form u(pofo/nios occurs in the neut. pl. u(pofo/nia, as a subst., meaning the poinh/ paid to the kinsfolk of a slain man (Harpocr.). The great recommendation of this reading is that it fully accounts for the traditional text here,— the insertion in the MSS. of q) before u(/po being a trivial error of a common type; while in 830 po/nwn might easily have dropped out after e)pi/ponon.

w(=n … a)/oknos, quorum secura (cp. 23): she had no apprehension of such results. The MS. a)/oknon, an epithet of bla/ban, is explained as ‘not shrinking,’ i.e., ‘not delaying,’ ‘hastening on.’ But (a) such a personification is strange; and (b) w(=n has then to be taken, somewhat awkwardly, with ta\ me\n in 843.
prosorw=sa is confirmed, as against the plausible proorw=sa (Blaydes), by the fact that Deianeira had seen Iolè's arrival. She did not merely ‘foresee’ evil; she had ‘beheld’ it coming.

a)i+/ssousan, Nauck's correction of a)i+sso/ntwn, is acceptable, because ‘swift coming’ should be that of the bla/bh, rather than of the ga/moi: since ga/mwn here means simply the new tie,—not a formal marriage which was in prospect: cp. 460 e)/ghme (n.), Ant.185th\n a)/thn o(rw=n | stei/xousan a)stoi=s. ne/wn a)i+sso/ntwn ga/mwn would be a gen. absol., ‘as a new marriage was hastening on.’

ta\ me\n au)ta\ prose/bale: the remedial measures were her own; their results, due to Nessus, were not foreseen by her. prose/bale=‘applied,’ as a remedy to a disease: cp. 580. Others explain, ‘brought upon herself’ (sc. e(auth=|): but this would rèquire au(ta=| in place of au)ta/.

The MS. reading, ta\ me\n ou)/ ti prose/bale, is explained to mean, ‘part she did not comprehend’ (schol. ou)k e)/gnw, ou) sunh=ken): i.e., she had, indeed, a secret purpose, but she did not know the deadly nature of the unguent. To this there are two objections. (1) The supposed sense of prose/bale is unexampled: cp. 580 n. (2) The proper antithesis is lost; for ta\ a)p' a)llo/qrou gnw/mas molo/n<*>) <*>ought to be opposed to her own designs or acts; but those things which she ‘did not comprehend’ were just those which ‘came from the alien will.’
a)llo/qrou here merely=a)llotri/as: cp. Ph.540 n.

o)leqri/aisi sunallagai=s, causal dat., ‘through her fatal meeting, converse,’ with Nessus at the Evenus (562 ff.).—Others explain: (1) ‘by a fatal reconciliation’; either (a) between Deianeira and Nessus, or (b) between Deianeira and Heracles,—in so far as she resolved to pardon him. (2) ‘By fatal conjunctures, issues’: cp. O. C.410 n.
o)leqri/aisi is the simplest correction of the unmetrical o)leqri/ais: see Analysis.
h)= pou: Ph.1130 n.
o)loa\ is best taken here as adverbial neut. plur., ‘desperately’: though in El.844o)loa\ is nom. fem.

ste/nei is metrically suspicious: the corresponding word in the antistr. is nu/mfan (857). But no correction is probable. Hermann, writing h)= pou a)/r' a)lastai/nei, cites Hesychius: a)lastai/nei: duspaqei=. Arndt proposes h)= pou o)lo/) a)stai/nei,—another word which the grammarians explain by duspaqei=, but which is wholly obscure. The conject. of Blaydes, ai)a/zei, would serve; but then ste/nei must be viewed as a gloss.
xlwra\n … a)/xnan, a fresh, delicate dew; the tears fall in pearly drops. Eur. Med.906a)p' o)/sswn xlwro\n w(rmh/qh da/kru. Pind. N.8. 40xlwrai=s e)e/rsais.
te/ggei … a)/xnan: cp. Ai.376e)remno\n ai(=m' e)/deusa: I. T. 159 xoa\s | ...u(drai/nein: Pind. N.10. 75qerma\ dh\ te/ggwn da/krua.
850 f. The moi=ra is still e)rxome/na, since Heracles is not yet dead. The a)/tan is his death,
doli/an, as wrought by the guile of Nessus.
profai/nei, ‘foreshows,’—enables us to forebode.—Hermann understood, ‘reveals the secre<*> villainy (of Nessus).’

e)/rrwgen paga\ dakru/wn: cp. 919: Ant.802i)/sxein d) | ou)ke/ti phga\s du/namai dakru/wn. The natural sense is, ‘The stream of tears has burst forth’; i.e., ‘we all weep for this calamity.’ The words could not well mean merely, ‘a source of tears has been opened’; i.e., a woe has befallen, which will claim tears.
ke/xutai no/sos, the plague has been diffused through his whole frame: cp. Ph.293pa/gou xuqe/ntos, ‘spread abroad.’
w)= po/poi: O. T.167 n.
a)narsi/wn, foes: Il.24. 365dusmene/es kai\ a)na/rsioi. This worst of woes has come to him from his own home: cp. 1058—1063.

The doubt as to the reading here is confined to the words between po/poi and e)pe/mole. The traditional text is, oi(=on a)narsi/wn | ou)/pw a)gakleito\n *(hrakle/ous. The v. l. *(hrakle/a, found in a few of the later MSS., was apparently prompted by a)gakleito/n. In the corresponding vv. of the strophe (841 ff.), the MS. text is, mega/lan prosorw=sa do/mois bla/ban | ne/wn a)i+sso/ntwn ga/mwn, ta\ me\n ou)/ ti: where the only doubt affecting metre is between do/mois and do/moisi.

It seems almost certain that *(hrakle/ous was a gloss, and that ta\ me\n ou)/ ti in the strophe answered metrically to a)gakleito/n here. The proposed emendations of this passage are classified in the Appendix. Those which eject *(hrakle/ous follow one of two methods. (1) To read do/mois, not do/moisi, in 842: to insert a long syllable, beginning with a vowel (as e)c), before a)narsi/wn: and to supply something, equal to ˘¯ (as pot' a)/ndr)), between ou)/pw and a)gakleito/n. (2) To read do/moisi in 842: and to make such an addition to ou)/pw as shall metrically balance a)i+sso/ntwn ga/mwn. On this plan, I suggest <u(/p)> ou)/pw <tou=de sw=m)> a)gakleito/n. The prep. goes with a)narsi/wn, which, without a prep., would here be somewhat harsh (as=‘from his foes’). *(hrakle/ous would have been a gloss on to<*>e. Sophocles is fond of the periphrasis with sw=ma, which would be fitting here: cp. 1194, 1210: O. C.355: El.1233.
oi)kti/sai, epexegetic, ‘for us to pity’ (rather than, ‘for him to lament’): cp. O. C.144ou) pa/nu moi/ras eu)daimoni/sai prw/ths (sc. ei)mi/).

kelaina\, ‘dark,’ referring at once to the colour of the metal, and to old stains. This general character of the epithet is seen in Eur. Bacch.628, i(/etai ci/fos kelaino\n a(rpa/sas: where no blood has yet been shed.

proma/xou, ‘fighting in the front of battle.’ Others understand, ‘fighting on behalf of men,’ ‘champion of the oppressed’ (cp. 1011); the sense, probably, in which Heracles was styled *pro/maxos at Thebes ( Paus.9. 11. 4). But the war upon Oechalia hardly illustrated that character.
ai)xma=|, in the sense of ‘prowess,’ ‘warlike might,’ can follow lo/gxa proma/xou doro/s, since the latter is really an image for the warrior himself. Cp. 355 ai)xma/sai (n.).

qoa
 here is merely abverbial,=taxe/ws. So Od.2. 257lu=sen d' a)gorh
 ai)yhrh/n= Il.2. 808ai)=ya d' e)/lus' a)gorh/n. Od.8. 38qoh
 a)legu/nete dai=ta, ‘quickly fall to feasting.’
ai)peina=s: cp. 327 n.

a)mfi/polos and a)/naudos, both epithets of *ku/pris, are to be taken closely together,—‘ministering in silence,’—viz., to the purposes of the gods,—not to the desire of Heracles. Some regard a as a pron., with which *ku/pris is in apposition, (‘but she,’ etc.,) like Ph.371o( d' ei)=p' *)odusseu/s (n.): but it is simpler to take it as an ordinary article. For the order of words, cp. O. T.1199ta\n gamyw/nuxa parqe/non xrhsmw|do/n (n.).

The ‘silence’ of Aphroditè means that the passion of Heracles had not been avowed as his motive for the war (cp. 358). She has been revealed as the fanera\ pra/ktwr, because that motive has now been disclosed as supreme. For pra/ktwr fem., cp. O. T.81 n.

div2.p: Fourth e)peiso/dion. The death of Deianeira.

div3.p: These eight verses form an epode to the stasimon; three persons take part in the delivery, viz., the two parasta/tai, or leaders of h(mixo/ria (HM. A, HM. B), and the coryphaeus (XO.). The third part (868—870) is best assigned to the coryphaeus, who usually announces a new comer, and who would naturally conduct the dialogue with the trofo/s. Similar epodes to stasima are Eur. H. F.815—821, and Eur. Hipp.1143— 1152, in each of which three parts can be distinguished. (See W. Christ, Metrik, § 723, p. 653 2nd ed.)

The motive of the whole passage from 863 to 898 is the dramatic necessity of making an impressive preparation for the Nurse's r(h=sis. It rests with the Chorus alone to do this, since no actor is present.
Hermann supposed that, after the three leading choreutae had spoken (863 —870), each of the other twelve in turn took part in the dialogue. But this seems improbable.
ma/taios, foolish, deluded: cp. 407 n. For this fem., cp. 207 koino\s (n.). In 565 we have matai/ais and in 887 matai/a, but in O. C.780matai/ou...h(donh=s.

ti/ fhmi/; ‘what do I say?’ i.e., ‘what am I to say?’ Cp. O. T.1471ti/ fhmi/; | ou) dh\ klu/w pou...;—where, as here, it expresses perplexity at a sound suddenly heard. It is only a more vivid form of ti/ fw=; ( O. C.315). Hermann wrote ti\ fhmi/; i.e. ‘do I say anything (true)?’—like le/gw ti; ( O. T.1475). But the pron. could not then stand first.
ou)k a)/shmon, not doubtful (between joy and woe), a)lla\ dustuxh=, but (clearly) woful. Cp. Ph.209dia/shma ga\r qroei=.—ei)/sw: cp. 202 n.

kaini/zei: schol. e)/oike/ ti new/teron e)/xein o( oi)=kos: the house is experiencing something for the first time,—i.e., is suffering some new calamity. So Aesch. Ag.1071kai/nison zugo/n. In Lycophron 530, kaini/sei do/ru, a v. l. is kinh/sei.

869 The MS. reading, a)h/qhs, cannot be right. The word means either (1) ‘unusual,’ or (2) ‘unaccustomed’ to a thing. Here it has been taken in the first sense, as meaning, ‘with strange aspect,’ ‘unlike herself,’—i.e., gloomy, instead of cheerful. It seems inconceivable that a classical writer should have so used a)h/qhs.
