The conjecture a)hdh\s has been generally received; but this presents almost equal difficulties. As applied to persons, it regularly means, ‘disagreeable’; Eth. N. 2. 7 (p. 1108 a 29) o(...e)n pa=sin a)hdh\s du/seri/s tis kai\ du/skolos: Magn. Mor. 2. 3 (p. 1200 a 15) u(pero/ptas kai\ a)hdei=s. Here it ought to mean, ‘of sad aspect’; it never occurs, however, in that sense. Hesychius has, indeed, a)hde/s: stugno\n, luphro/n: but this paraphrase of the neuter proves nothing. In O. T.82h(du/s is not ‘joyous-looking,’ but ‘welcome.’
Surely a)h/qhs was merely a corruption of a)(g)hqh/s, which does not seem to occur, but which is as correct as eu)ghqh/s or polughqh/s.—Cp. Eur. Alc.777stugnw=| prosw/pw| kai\ sunwfruwme/nw|.
shmanou=sa, as a correction of shmai/nousa, is not merely recommended by usage, but is necessary, unless the trofo/s be supposed to make signs before she speaks.

*(hraklei= to\ po/mpimon=to\ *(hr. po/mp.: cp. O. C.714i(/ppoisin to\n a)kesth=ra xalino/n: Ai.1166brotoi=s to\n a)ei/mnhston | ta/fon. po/mpimon here=pempto/n, as in Eur. Hipp.579pompi/ma fa/tis dwma/twn=h( e)k dwm. pemfqei=sa.
kainopoihqe\n: a verb not elsewhere found in writers of this age, but frequent later; cp. Polyb. 1. 4. 5 polla\ ga\r au(/th (sc. h( tu/xh) kainopoiou=sa k.t.l.
e)c a)kinh/tou podo/s: e)k expresses the condition; cp. El.455e)c u(perte/ras xero/s: Ph.91 n. This is one of those proverb-like turns which a homely speaker would use in the desire to be impressive.
ou) dh/ poq): cp. 668 n.
pa/nt' a)kh/koas: cp. Ant.402pa/nt' e)pi/stasai, —in a similar answer.
te/qnhken...; They are so bewildered that they repeat the question which has been answered: cp. 184 n.
878 For the metres of this kommo/s (878—895), see Analysis.
o)leqri/a, ‘undone,’ ‘lost’: a rare sense; but cp. O. T.1341to\n me/g' o)le/qrion. The second syll. is short, as in 845.

879 The MS. reading, sxetliw/tata pro/s ge pra=cin, has been variously altered (cr. n.), in order to avoid an anapaest in the 2nd foot, on the assumption that the verse is an iambic trimeter. The neatest of such corrections is Hermann's, sxetli/w| ta\ pro/s ge pra=cin.

Heinrich Schmidt, whose view of the metre will be seen in the Metrical Analysis, merely transposes pro/s and ge, writing sxetliw/tata/ ge pro\s pra=cin. Simplicity is not the only recommendation of this course; it transfers the stress of ge from pra=cin to the adverb. For this sense of sxe/tlios, cp. Ai.887, and n. on Ant.47.

By pra=cin must be meant here the mode of ‘doing’ the deed, rather than the victim's ‘fortune’; though the latter is the usual sense of the singular ( Ant.1305 n.). After the question, ti/ni tro/pw|, a strong emphasis on pra=cin would be, however, less natural. It might, indeed, be explained thus;—‘the tro/pos of her death was the sword; but the mode of infliction (pra=cis) rendered it peculiarly pitiable,’— since it was inflicted by her own hand.

cuntre/xei: schol. ti/ni qana/tw| sune/pesen (cp. O. T.113tw=|de sumpi/ptei fo/nw|). The verb is, in fact, a bold poetical substitute for sumpi/ptei, expressing the notion of ‘suddenly encountering’ a violent death. Cp. the Homeric sune/dramon, said of combatants ( Il.16. 337).
dihi+/stwse: the compound occurs only here. For this sense, cp. Her.3. 127du/o h(me/wn h)i+/stwse.
ti/s qumo/s, what impulse of passion,

ti/nes no/soi, what pangs of frenzy ( Ai.59foitw=nt' a)/ndra mania/sin no/sois). The words h)\ ti/nes no/soi are really parenthetical,—suggesting that the excited mind (qumo/s) may have been also deranged; hence the verb can agree with qumo/s, on which the chief stress falls.— cunei=le, corripuit, seized and carried off; cp. Thuc.2. 51(o( loimo\s) pa/nta cunh/|rei. Not, ‘destroyed her along with Heracles.’
mo/na means merely that she alone is responsible for the death of Heracles as well as for her own. It does not anticipate the statement that she was unaided in her suicide (891).
stono/entos: cp. Il.8. 159be/lea stono/enta xe/onto (‘dolorous darts’).
e)n toma=|: the instrumental e)n: Ant.1003spw=ntas e)n xhlai=sin.

w)= matai/a is said with a mixture of pity and impatience; the aged trofo/s, in her terror and anguish, has failed to grasp the scope of the question, pw=s e)mh/sato (884), and has replied merely, ‘with a sword.’ The leader of the Chorus now asks her if she was an eye-witness of the deed,—feeling that she will satisfy their anxiety only if she can be led on to describe what she has seen. Thus the bewilderment of the messenger becomes a preparation for the r(h=sis.
ta/nd' u(/brin, this deed of violence (done to herself). So in El.864lw/ba is merely a fatal accident.
w(s dh\ … parasta/tis, sc. ou)=sa (cp. O. C.83 n.); here dh/=‘in fact.’ Elsewhere, when w(s dh/ is not ironical (as it is in O. C.809), dh/ sometimes=h)/dh ( Ph.1065). Cp. 1192.
ti/s h)=n, sc. h( u(/bris: what was its nature? pw=s (e)ge/neto), how was it executed?

au)th\ pro\s au(th=s k.t.l. The verb xeiropoiei=n occurs elsewhere only in later Greek.—The exclamation which follows implies that these words add something to the disclosure made in 881, au(th\n dihi+/stwse. They certainly state more precisely that the blow was dealt by her own hand (and not by a slave's); also that the deed had its origin from her own mind (pro\s au(th=s), and not from any external influence. But it should also be recognised that, throughout this passage (871—898), the dramatic aim is to express profound horror and amazement. The messenger can hardly seize the full meaning of the questions; the hearers, on their part, find it hard to realise the answers.

e)/teken e)/teke dh\. I read with H. H. Schmidt J. (cr. n.), thinking with him that the metre is probably ˘˘˘|˘˘˘| ¯˘˘| ¯ *l ||. In such a passage the text might easily have lost dh/.—The firstborn of Iolè, that phmonh\ u(po/stegos (376), is a dire spirit which avenges the house of Eurytus on the house of Heracles. Cp. Tennyson, Guinevere: ‘Well is it that no child is born of thee. | The children born of thee are sword and fire’...
ne/ortos, simply, ‘that has newly arisen’: not, ‘that has lately sped hither’ (schol. h( newsti\ e)ntau=qa o(rmh/sasa).
a)/gan ge, sc. mega/lan: cp. Ai.982*t*e. w)= perisperxe\s pa/qos. | *x*o. a)/gan ge, *teu=kre.
ka/rta ma=llon a)\n w)/|ktisas, assuredly thou wouldst have felt greater pity.
kai\ tau=t' e)/tlh tis k.t.l. For the place of tis, cp. Ph.104ou(/tws e)/xei ti deino\n i)sxu/os qra/sos; (n.).

kti/sai implies that the deed was momentous: schol. kataskeua/sai kai\ poih=sai: kalw=s de\ w(s e)pi\ mega/lw| tolmh/mati ei)=pen th\n le/cin. When kti/zein is thus a tragic synonym for poiei=n, there is usu. a predicative adj., as Aesch. Eum.17te/xnhs de/ nin *zeu\s e)/nqeon kti/sas fre/na: cp. Aesch. Suppl.138: Aesch. Ch.441.

Hermann rejects this v. and the next, because the Chorus, not knowing the nature of the deeds (oi(=) e)/drase), ought not yet to marvel at them. The verses were inserted, he thinks, to soften the abruptness of e)pei\ parh=lqe (900) after ka/rt' a)\n w)/|ktisas (897). It may be granted that they are not very forcible; but they seem genuine. The Nurse has hitherto been led from point to point by questions. A direct question (898) is needed to prompt her narrative. It would be less like her to begin it spontaneously.

parh=lqe is confirmed by the usage of this compound with ref. to entering a house: O. T.1241, El.1337, Eur. Med.1137, Eur. Hipp.108, etc. And the asyndeton is of a kind which the poet often admits; cp. 555, 750. The conjecture ga\r h)=lqe, which has been generally received, seems, then, unnecessary.
au)lai=s, the au)lh/ of the house; a poet. plur. like numfei=a (920), parqenw=nes ( Aesch. P. V.646), etc.

koi=la is not merely a general epithet (as koi/lhn of ka/peton in Ai.1165), but means that the litter (forei=on) was arranged so that the sufferer could lie in it as in a hammock,—with soft bedding on each side of him as well as beneath him. His agonies made this indispensable.
stornu/nq): Attic prose rarely uses this form, except in the aor. e)sto/resa.—a)/yorron a)ntw/|h, go back to meet him on his way from the harbour (804): cp. El.53a)/yorron h(/comen pa/lin.
Hyllus had entered the house immediately after his mother (820). His occupation reminded her that Heracles would soon arrive, and decided her to act at once.
kru/yas' e(auth\n, in the women's apartments (cp. 686 e)n muxoi=s).

e)/nqa mh/ tis ei)si/doi would usu. mean, ‘in any place where no one beheld,’— oblique of e)/nq' a)\n mh/ tis ei)si/dh|. But here the sense is final; ‘where no one should behold.’ The normal Attic for this would be, e)/nqa mh/ tis o)/yetai (cp. 800),—not o)/yoito, since, in a final relat. clause, the fut. indic. was usu. kept even after a secondary tense.

In Homeric Greek, a final relat. clause can take the subjunct. (usu. with ke) after a primary tense, and the optat. (without ke) after a secondary tense. But this is not an Attic construction. Thus the Homeric a)/ggelon h(=kan o(\s a)ggei/leie ( Od.15. 458) would in Attic be a)/ggelon e)/pemyan o(\s a)ggelei=: it could not be, o(\s a)ggei/leie. The constr. e)/nqa mh/ tis ei)si/doi —a very rare one in Attic—has grown out of the ‘deliberative’ constr. ou)k oi)=den e)/nqa mh/ tis ei)si/dh|, by steps which have changed the interrogative clause into a final relative clause. A like instance is Ph.281ou)x o(/stis a)rke/seien, (seeing no one) to aid. See Appendix.
bruxa=to: for the omission of the augment, cp. O. T.1249 n.

bwmoi=si: besides the altar of Zeus e(rkei=os in the au)lh/, there would be other altars of domestic gods in a large house; cp. Eur. Alc.170pa/ntas de\ bwmou/s, oi(\ kat' *)admh/tou do/mous, | prosh=lqe ka)ce/steye kai\ proshu/cato.

ge/noint' e)/rhmoi: she said, e)/rhmoi e)ge/nonto (or e)ge/nesqe). After her death, and that of Heracles, these altars were doomed to desolation. Nauck seems right in thus amending ge/noit' e)rh/mh, though not for the reasons which he assigns. Those words could certainly mean, ‘that she had become desolate,’— nor is the plaint less natural because death is so near. But the other reading is in truer harmony with the context, because she is saying farewell to the surroundings of happier days. Even inanimate objects move her tears at the thought of parting. Naturally the altars come first; when they were forsaken, the family life would have ceased.

o)rga/nwn o(/tou yau/seien: for the optat., cp. Ph.289o(/ moi ba/loi (n.). o(/tou here =ei)/ tinos. Among the o)/rgana would be sacrificial vessels, and, as the schol. remarks, the implements which she had used in weaving the robe.
a)/llh| … dwma/twn: for the gen., cp. 375.

fi/lwn … oi)ketw=n. The opening scene with the trofo/s illustrates these kindly relations. Cp. Eur. Alc.194 f., when Alcestis takes leave of her attached oi)ke/tai:—kou)/tis h)=n ou(/tw kako\s | o(\n ou) prosei=pe kai\ proserrh/qh pa/lin.—ei)sorwme/nh: the midd., as Soph. El.1060e)sorw/menoi.
a)nakaloume/nh: cp. O. C.1376 n.
911 The MS. text, kai\ ta\s a)/paidas e)s to\ loipo\n ou)si/as, is undoubtedly corrupt. Various attempts to explain or to amend it are recorded in the Appendix.

The genuine verse must have had some direct reference to the context. She is weeping at the sight of attached servants whom she is about to leave. The general sense ought to be, ‘bewailing her own fate, and that of the household over which a change was impending’; since, when master and mistress were dead, the household would be dissolved, and the faithful slaves would pass into other hands. After the death of Heracles, Ceÿx, the king of Trachis (40 n.), was deterred by Eurystheus from continuing to protect the Heracleidae; who sought refuge at Athens. ( Apollod.2. 8. 1.)

I believe that *a*p*a*i*d*a*s arose from *e*p*a*l*l*o*i*s when the E had been accidentally lost or obscured. A similar interchange of initial a and e, combined with fusion of two words into one, occurs in O. C.550, where e)f' a(sta/lh was corrupted into a)pesta/lh. I would read, kai\ th=s e)p' a)/llois e)s to\ loipo\n ou)si/as: ‘and the fate of the property which would thenceforth be in the power of others.’ For e)pi/ with dat. as=penes, cp. O. C.66, Ph.1003.The slaves are part of the ou)si/a. Euripides has ou)si/a, as=‘property,’ at least twice: H. F.337patrw=|on e)s me/laqron, ou(= th=s ou)si/as | a)/lloi kratou=si: Helen. 1253 w(s a)\n parou/shs ou)si/as e(/kastos h)=|. (See Appendix.) e(sti/as would be an easy correction of ou)si/as: but, on my view of the passage, the change is not required.
to\n *(hra/kl.: for the adj., cp. 51, 576.
qa/lamon, the nuptial chamber: Ant.804 n.

laqrai=on o)/mm), acc. of respect: e)peskiasme/nh, ‘overshadowed,’ i.e., ‘shrouded from view.’ Thus the phrase means strictly, ‘shrouded as to (or in) my secret observation’: for o)/mma here implies the act of observing. laqrai=on expresses the result of e)peskiasme/nh. She may have watched from behind a curtain, or at a partly open door.—Not, ‘with eyes shaded by my hand’ ( O. C.1650o)mma/twn e)pi/skion | xei=r)).

ba/llousan with dat., in the sense of e)m- or e)piba/llousan ( Ph.67 n.).— strwta\ goes closely with the partic.,— spreading them as coverings, stw/mata.— fa/rh: the Homeric fa=ros is not thus used; but cp. Od.4. 297 ff., where the bed (de/mnia) is spread with r(h/gea (‘blankets’), ta/phtes (‘rugs’), and woollen xlai=nai as coverlets.
eu)nathri/ois: the form eu)nasthri/ois appears to be a later one (Dind. on Aesch. Pers.160).—Cp. Verg. Aen.4. 650(Dido, about to die) Incubuitque toro dixitque novissima verba.
r(h/casa: so Plut. Per.36klauqmo/n te r(h=cai kai\ plh=qos e)gxe/ai dakru/wn. Soph. O. T.1075 n.
numfei=a, bridalchamber ( Ant.891): for the plur., cp. 901 n.
eu)na/trian: this form is rightly preferred to eu)nh/trian by Nauck, Eur. Stud. II. p. 175.
sunto/nw|, intense, vehement: Eur. Bacch.1091sunto/nois dromh/masi.
h(=|, at the place where. The MS. w(=| doubtless arose from pe/plon: it would mean, o(\s peroni/da ei(=xe mastw=n prokeime/nhn: but this is less natural.

prou)/keito mastw=n: the pe/plos was fastened near the left shoulder by the peroni/s, which is described as lying ‘in front of,’ i.e. ‘above,’ the (left) breast. It would not accord with Greek usage to imagine the brooch as placed at the centre of the bosom. Cp. Il.14. 180(of Hera's e(ano\s) xrusei/h|s d' e)neth=|si kata\ sth=qos perona=to. O. T.1269 n.

e)k d' e)lw/pisen: for the tmesis, cp. Ant.1233e)k d' o(rmwme/nou: and ib. 427. e)klwpi/zw (from lw/ph, lw=pos, a covering) occurs only here. e)klwpi/sai has been conjectured in Pollux 7. 44 a)podu=sai kai\ a)polwpi/sai, w(s *sofoklh=s.

dromai/a: Eur. Or.45phda=| dromai=os. Thuc.3. 29sxolai=oi komisqe/ntes.—We may render, ‘warned her son of her intent’; but the literal sense is, ‘warned the son of her who was devising these things’: the gen. depends on tw=| paidi/. Others take the gen. with fra/zw (‘tell him about her’). It would then be best to govern ta/de by fra/zw: for in this constr. of the gen. with verbs of saying or asking, the object is usually expressed, either by an acc. ( Soph. El.317, Soph. Ai.1236), or by a relat. clause (belowSoph. Ai., 1122, Soph. Ph.439). ta/de, however, belongs rather to texnwme/nhs.
to\ kei=se deu=ro/ t): cp. Soph. Ph.315e)kei=se kai\ to\ deu=ro. For the art. with the first word only, Soph. O. C.606ta)ma\ ka)kei/nwn (n.).
e)cormw/meqa might refer to the Nurse only, but rather includes Hyllus (as o(rw=men certainly does). It suits deu=ro, therefore, but not kei=se. The thought is, ‘before I could return with him.’

o(rw=men au)th\n … peplhgme/nhn, instead of pe/plhktai, w(s o(rw=men.—a)mfiplh=gi fasga/nw|: adjecti<*> which are properly only masc. or fem. are sometimes used in oblique cases with neuter nouns: cp. Ph.19a)mfitrh=tos au)li/ou: Ai.324botoi=s | sidhrokmh=sin.

u(f' h(=par kai\ fre/nas, lit., ‘to the liver and midriff.’ But it was her left side that she bared (926), and the fatal blow must have been nearer to the heart than to the liver. The phrase should therefore be understood in a general sense, as a poetical way of saying, ‘home to the very centre of life.’ It may have been suggested by Od.9. 301 ou)ta/menai pro\s sth=qos, o(/qi fre/nes h(=par e)/xousin, ‘stab him in the breast, where the midriff holds the liver.’ Cp. Ant.1315pai/sas' u(f' h(=par au)to/xeir au(th/n.

tou)/rgon … w(s e)fa/yeien, that he had ‘fastened,’ ‘bound’ the deed ‘upon her,’ as a burden or doom. Cp. Pind. O.9. 64mh\ kaqe/loi nin a<*>n po/tmon e)fa/yais|o)rfano\n genea=s, ‘having laid on him the doom of childlessness.’ Il.2. 15*trw/essi de\ kh/de) e)fh=ptai, ‘have been imposed’ on them.

Others explain: (1) ‘that he had kindled the deed.’ But e)fa/ptein never has the sense of u(fa/ptein. In Eur. Bacch.778 our only MS. for that part of the play has, indeed, h)/dh to/d' e)ggu\s w(/ste pu=r e)fa/ptetai | u(/brisma: but the true u(fa/ptetai is attested by the Christus Patiens 2227. (2) ‘That she had made fast the deed,’—i.e. done the irrevocable deed. But kat' o)rgh\n must refer to the anger of Hyllus (734 ff.).

tw=n kat' oi)=kon: for the simple gen. with e)kd., cp. O. T.117o(/tou...e)kma- qw/n.—pro\s tou= qhro\s, at his instigation. This pregnant sense of the prep. is somewhat rare: but cp. Il.1. 238qe/mistas | pro\s *dio\s ei)ru/atai (by his ordinance): 6. 456 pro\s a)/llhs i(sto\n u(fai/nois (at her bidding).

du/sthnos=du/sthnos w)/n, ‘miserable as he was.’ This is better than to make it an interjection, ‘poor youth!’— e)lei/pet' ou)de/n (adv.), ‘in no wise fell short.’ The verb has here a twofold constr., viz., (1) with gen. o)durma/twn, as El.474gnw/mas leipome/na sofa=s: (2) with partic. a)mfipi/ptwn: cp. Xen. Oecon.18§ 5 tau=ta me\n toi/nun, e)/fh, ou)de\n e)mou= lei/pei gignw/skwn (‘you understand these things just as well as I do’),—where e)mou= is parallel, not with o)durma/twn here, but with tw=n w)=n te/knwn in 266.
a)mfi/ nin: the acc. with a)mfi/, as=‘concerning,’ is somewhat rare: but cp. Pind. P.2. 15kelade/onti me\n a)mfi\ *kinu/ran. (In Il.18. 339a)mfi\ de/ se...klau/sontai, the sense is ‘around.’)
a)mfipi/ptwn sto/masin: Eur. Alc.404poti\ soi=si pi/tnwn sto/masin (=xei/lesi).

pleuro/qen, ‘at’ (or ‘near’) ‘her side.’ The ending qen properly denotes the point from which motion sets out. Hence a form in qen is equivalent to a genitive expressing source or starting-point. By a stretch of that analogy, pleuro/qen does duty here for the genitive of place, which is only a special kind of possessive genitive,—‘belonging to,’ and so, ‘in the region of’: El.900e)sxa/ths d' o(rw= | pura=s...bo/struxon: Il.9. 219i(=zen... | toi/xou tou= e(te/roio. A somewhat similar example is Il.15. 716pru/mnhqen e)pei\ la/ben, ou)xi\ meqi/ei, where the form in qen=the gen. after a verb of seizing (‘took hold by the stern’).—Cp. Eur. Alc.366pleura/ t' e)ktei=nai pe/las | pleuroi=si toi=s soi=s.—For parei/s, cp. Soph. El.819.
ai)ti/a| ba/loi, as with a missile: Ai.1244h(ma=s...kakoi=s balei=te: Soph. El.902mh/ me/ tis fqo/nw| ba/lh|: Ar. Th.895tou)mo\n sw=ma ba/llousa yo/gw|.

e)k duoi=n … w)rfanisme/nos bi/on (acc. of respect), ‘orphaned as to his life,’ having his life made o)rfano/s, ‘on the part of both parents at once’: cp. the lament of Eumelus for his mother Alcestis ( Eur. Alc.397), prolipou=sa d' a)mo\n bi/on | w)rfa/nisen tla/mwn. bi/on (Wakefield) is a necessary correction of bi/ou, with which the sense would be either (a) ‘deprived of life,’ as in Anth. 7. 483 zwa=s nh/pion w)rfa/nisas: or (b) ‘deprived of subsistence.’ Nauck, keeping bi/ou, changes e)k to ei(=s, understanding, ‘bereaved of the life of both parents.’ But ei(=s is clearly unsuitable here; and the phrase w)rf. duoi=n bi/ou would be strange as well as weak.
du/o, i.e. to-day and to-morrow.

h)\ kai/ ti plei/ous (Dindorf) is the best correction of h)\ kai\ plei/ous tis (L), which may have arisen from ti being accidentally omitted or transposed. The v. l. h)\ kai\ ple/ous tis was an attempt to reconcile that reading with metre. In lyrics we find the gen. ple/onos ( O. C.1211; Ph.1100, if the reading of the schol. be accepted): but in the iambics of Tragedy there is no certain instance (apart from ple/on) of the shorter form. (In Aesch. Ag.1299, ou)k e)/st' a)/lucis, w(= ce/noi, xro/nw| ple/w, the text is doubtful.) A further objection to ple/ous is the repeated tis.

The sense is:—‘Men often reckon on the morrow, or even, perchance (ti), on more days to come; but this is rash. A man can never be sure that his good fortune (i.e. immunity from disaster) will last even to the end of to-day.’ Cp. O. C.567e)/coid' a)nh\r w)/n, xw)/ti th=s e)s au)/rion | ou)de\n ple/on moi sou= me/testin h(me/ras. For h( au)/rion (without h(me/ra), cp. Alexis *(/upnos fr. 3 ei)s th\n au)/rion.—logi/zetai, ‘computes,’ i.e., ‘sets down in his calculations,’ as something upon which he can count.

div2.p: Fourth sta/simon. 1st strophe, 947—949,=1st antistr., 950— 952: 2nd str., 953—961,=2nd antistr., 962—970. For the metres see Metrical Analysis.
One blow has fallen, and another is impending. Heracles, in his dying agonies, is borne silently towards the house.

div3.p: po/tera pro/teron: these words, as Schneidewin remarks, are often found in juxtaposition; e.g., Ar. Eccl.1082pote/ras prote/ras...a)pallagw=; —du/skrita/ (e)sti), po/terapro/teron e)piste/nw (delib. subjunct.), pote/ra me/lea peraite/rw (e)sti/). For du/skrita, instead of du/skriton, cp. 64 n. This is better than to place a note of interrogation after e)piste/nw, and another after peraite/rw.

me/lea: the MS. te/lea would mean, ‘which woe is the more complete’; but this is less fitting here, since the second calamity is still prospective (951): nor is te/lea) peraite/rw a natural phrase. We cannot well take it adverbially (‘which woe I should mourn more completely’).

ta/de is governed by me/nomen: e)p' e)lpi/sin=‘with forebodings’: cp. Xen. Mem.2. 1. 18o( me\n e(kousi/ws talaip<*>rw=n e)p) a)gaqh=| e)lpi/di ponw=n eu)frai/netai.—Hermann's melo/men) (sc. e)sti/)= ‘are cares to us’: Soph. El.1436ta)nqa/d' a)\n me/loit' e)moi/.

e)/xein, to have (troubles), me/llein, sc. e(/cein (cp. 75), to be in expectation of them. koina\, sc. e)sti/n, are kindred things. For this sense of koino/s, cp. O. T.261 n.: similarly ‘cognate’ things can be called suggenh=.—Others explain: (1) ‘It is all one’ whether sorrow is present or prospective. (2) ‘There are woes on both parts’ (that of Deianeira and that of Heracles), ‘for us to suffer or apprehend.’

a)nemo/essa (Doric for h)n-) au)/ra, a strong breeze: cp. Aesch. Ch.591a)nemo/ent' a)
 | ai)gi/dwn fra/sai ko/ton (‘the stormy wrath of whirlwinds’). For e)/pouros, ‘wafting,’ cp. Soph. O. T.194 n.: e(stiw=tis, ‘of the hearth,’ i.e., ‘coming to our home’ at Trachis. The word occurs only here. Schol. ei)/qe w(s e(/sthka pneu/seien a)/nemos ou)/rios e)pi\ th=s oi)ki/asSoph. O. T., i(/na me labw
 tau/ths a)paga/goi th=s e(sti/as.—a)poiki/seien: Soph. O. C.1389kalw= to\ *tarta/rou | stugno
 patrw=|on e)/rebos w(/s s' a)poiki/sh|. The optat. in the relative clause is due to the optat. of wish in the principal clause: cp. Soph. O. T.506 n.—Cp. the wish of the anxious Chorus in Soph. O. C.1081ei)/q' a)ellai/a taxu/rrwstos peleia\s | ai)qeri/as nefe/las ku/rsaim). Eur. Hipp.732a)liba/tois u(po\ keuqmw=si genoi/man k.t.l.

956 ff. It is doubtful whether the MS. *dio\s, instead of which we require ¯˘, should be corrected to (1) *zhno\s, or (2) *di=on. Cp. El.1097.I incline to (1), because it seems unlikely that the poet should have preferred to make four consecutive words end in on. It is also worth noticing that *di=os, ‘belonging to Zeus,’ though used by Aesch. and Eur. , is not extant in Soph. , who has only di=os, ‘divine’ or ‘godlike.’

mou=non (adv.) ei)sidou=s' a)/far, ‘at the mere sight of him anon.’ a)/far might be ‘suddenly,’ as in 821: but is rather ‘anon,’ ‘forthwith’ (cp. 135): his arrival is close at hand. The schol.'s words, mh\ paraxrh=ma a)poqa/nw qeasame/nh to
 *(hrakle/a kakw=s diakei/menon, have caused a surmise that mou=non has arisen from some word meaning ‘weak’ (see cr. n.). But there is little probability in mw=lun (Hippônax fr. 60, perh. akin to malako/s), kau=ron (a word which, acc. to Photius Lex.p. 181. 14, Sophocles used in the sense of kako/s), mano
 (properly opposed to pukno/n), or mau=ron (found only in grammarians). We might rather suggest qa/noim), a)-|mauro
, were change needful. The schol.'s kakw=s diakei/menon may, however, be a mere comment; and mou=non seems well fitted to emphasise the terror of the sight. Cp. Ph.536oi)=mai ga ou)d' a)
 o)/mmasin mo/nhn qe/an | a)/llon labo/nta plh
 e)mou= tlh=nai ta/de.
e)pei\, ˘˘, with epic hiatus (cp. 650 a( de/ oi().

xwrei=n pro\ do/mwn, advancing (so as to come) in front of the house. The phrase is correct, though it would more naturally suggest a movement from within the house, as in Eur. Hec.59a)/get), w)= pai=des, th\n grau=n pro\ do/mwn.— le/gousin: the Chorus may be supposed to overhear murmurs of astonishment and anguish from servants of the house, who are watching the approach of the litter.—As to the proposed changes in this v. (cr. n.), see on 969.
qau=ma has been needlessly suspected: it is often said of persons (cp. 1004, and Od.9. 190 qau=m' e)te/tukto pelw/rion, of the Cyclops), and is here far more forcible than qe/ama.

a)gxou= d' a)/ra k.t.l. At this moment the bearers of the litter,—first descried by the servants of the house (960),—become visible to the Trachinian Maidens; who say, in effect, ‘It seems that the woe presaged by our voice is (even) closer at hand than we knew.’ a)gxou= kou) makra)n prou)/klaion is a short way of saying, ‘the subject of our boding lament is near and not distant.’ We might supply ou)=sa with the verb: but it seems better to supply o)/n with the adverbs. Similar, though less bold, is Ph.26tou)/rgon ou) makra\n le/geis, ‘the task of which thou speakest is not distant.’

o)cu/fwnos w(s a)hdw/n refers to prou)/klaion only: i.e. the point of comparison is merely the clear, sad note. Cp. 105 n.: Theocr. 12. 6 a)hdw
 | ...ligu/fwnos. Here o)cu/fwnos well suits the context, since o)cu/s and its compounds so often refer to tones of grief: Ant.424o)/rniqos o)cu
 fqo/ggon: ib. 1316 o)cukw/kuton: El.244o)cuto/nwn go/wn.—It would be forced to explain the simile by a)gxou= (because the nightingale often sings close to dwellings), or by makra
 (because its note is far-reaching).

ce/nw|n k.t.l. It should be observed how the poet has marked successive stages in the approach of the litter. When it first comes into view, the Chorus note the foreign aspect of the bearers. In another moment, they are listening for a sound (pa=| d' au)= forei= nin); and the silence dismays them.

ce/nwn … ba/sis=ce/noi badi/zontes: cp. Ph.868oi)kou/rhma...ce/nwn (n.). The conject. sta/sis (‘company’), though specious, seems less fitting here. It would be unsafe to argue against ba/sis from the fact that ba/sin closes v. 967. Cp. Ant.76, where kei/somai stands at the end of a clause, though it occurs also in 73.

e)co/milos, living out of our o(/milos, i.e., ‘foreign.’ Cp. I. A. 735 ou) kalo\n e)n o)/xlw| s' e)comilei=sqai (midd.) stratou= (said by Agam. to his wife), ‘to live abroad’ (out of thy proper o(mili/a).
pa=| d' au)=, ‘and then in what manner...?’
barei=an, heavy with sorrow, slow; as kou/fh ba/sis would be a joyously light step.

fe/rei ba/sin, lit., ‘carries the step forward,’ ‘moves on its way.’ ba/sis (964) is subject to fe/rei, but there is little real harshness in this, since ce/nwn ba/sis is a mere periphrasis. Schneidewin well compares Ai.14w)= fqe/gm' *)aqa/nas, followed by w(s eu)maqe/s sou... | fw/nhm' a)kou/w.
a)nau/datos, ‘without speech,’— either from his own lips, or from those of his bearers. Cp. the comprehensive sense of ou) stenakto/s in O. C.1663.In Ai.713a)nau/datos has its pass. sense.

ti/ xrh/, k.t.l. In order to obtain an exact metrical agreement with 960, xwrei=n pro\ do/mwn le/gousin, qano/nta has been changed (1) by Hermann, to fqi/menon: (2) by Bothe, to qa/naton. The latter seems preferable; for, though kata\ suits u(/pnon better than qa/naton, that turn of phrase may be regarded as an afterthought. ‘Death, is it,—or sleep?’ But I refrain from altering qano/nta, because it is doubtful whether metre requires that the dactyl should hold the same place here as in 960: see Metrical Analysis.
A comma should follow xrh/, since the constr. is, ti/ xrh/ (kri=nai); (po/teron) qano/nta nin etc., as in El.766ti/ tau=ta, po/teron eu)tuxh= le/gw etc.

div2.p: Exodos. Heracles bewails his doom, and gives his last commands to his son.—Anapaests, which mark the entrance of the mournful procession, are succeeded by lyrics a)po\ skhnh=s, in the nature of a kommo/s (1004—1043). Iambic dialogue follows, down to 1258; and anapaests then close the play.

Hyllus, detained by the events within (928), cannot have been far on his way towards the harbour (902) when he met the sufferer. At the side of the litter walks the pre/sbus, whose experience in the symptoms of the malady indicates that he has accompanied Heracles from Cenaeum.

971 f. The traditional text, oi)/moi e)gw\ sou=, | pa/ter, oi)/moi e)gw\ sou= me/leos, gives an anapaestic monometer, followed by an anapaestic dimeter in which the third foot lacks a syllable. The first four words, oi)/moi e)gw\ sou=, pa/ter, are clearly sound. As regards the rest, the choice is between two remedies. (1) To omit the second oi)/moi e)gw\ sou=, and substitute w)=, as Dindorf does. Verses 971 f. then shrink into one anapaestic dimeter. (2) To supply the defect in 972 by substituting an anapaest, or its equivalent, for the second sou=. Thus we might write pa/ter, oi)/moi e)gw/, <pa/ter, w)\> me/leos. I incline to this second course, because the monometer in 971 oi)/moi e)gw\ sou= seems right as a prelude.

div3.p: ti/ pa/qw; ti/ de\ mh/somai; the delib. subjunct. is combined with a fut. ind., as in Eur. Ion758ei)/pwmen h)\ sigw=men h)\ ti/ dra/somen; For mh/somai (devise as a remedy), cp. Aesch. Th.1057ti/ pa/qw; ti/ de\ drw=; ti/ de\ mh/swmai;
w)mo/fronos does not refer to his general character, but means that he is exasperated by these torments: cp. 1035 a)/xos, w(=| m' e)xo/lwsen.

propeth/s, lying prostrate in the litter,—in a deathlike swoon. (It may be doubted whether the word here implies, ‘lying on his face,’ as the schol. explains it.) Others understand, ‘verging on death.’ But, when propeth/s=‘on the brink of,’ e)pi/ (or ei)/s ti) is usu. added, as in Eur. Alc.908polia\s e)pi\ xai/tas | h)/dh propeth/s. Eur. Itseems impossible that, without such help, propeth/s should express ‘moribund.’ In Eur. Alc.143h)/dh pronwph/s e)sti kai\ yuxorragei=, which Paley compares, the adj.=‘drooping.’

dakw
, as by biting the lips,—a proverbial phrase: fr. 811 o)do/nti pri=e to\ sto/ma: Od.1. 381o)da\c e)n xei/lesi fu/ntes: Nub. 1369 to
 qumo
 dakw/n.
ou) mh\ )cegerei=s, a sharp prohibition: Ar. Ran.462ou) mh\ diatri/yeis: cp. n. on Soph. O. C.177.
ka/toxon with dat., as Eur. Hec.1090*)/arei ka/toxon ge/nos.

foita/da, coming at intervals: foita=n was said in this sense of intermittent diseases: see n. on Ph.758h(/kei ga\r au(/th dia\ xro/nou, pla/nois i)/sws | w(s e)ceplh/sqh. Not merely maniw/dh, as the schol. explains it.
a)ll' e)pi/ moi, sc. e)sti/. Cp. Ph.806ta)pi\ soi\ ste/nwn kaka/ (the ills which lie upon thee).

a)/pleton=a)/peiron, ‘immense’; a word of doubtful origin, sometimes connected with the root of ple/ws, as meaning (1) ‘which cannot be filled’; or (2) ‘what exceeds measure,’ a sense which Lobeck sought through ple/qron. The word occurs in Attic prose.—If no stop is placed after a)/pleton, then ba/ros a)/pleton becomes an acc. of the ‘inner object’ with e)mme/mone: ‘is wild with an infinite weight of woe.’ But e)pi/ is then very awkward, whether we assume tmesis, or still join it with moi.
w)= *zeu=: the hero's utterance begins,—as the play ends,—with his father's name.
toi=si=ti/si, contracted from the Ionic te/oisi ( Her.1. 37).
peponhme/nos: cp. Aeschin. or. 2 § 36 to\n dh=mon katapeponhme/non (‘exhausted’).
a)llh/ktois, the regular form of this epic word: a)/lhktos is very rare (C. I. G. 6303). For the ll, cp. Od.12. 224a)pollh/ceian.
oi)/moi <moi>. The addition of moi, Brunck's remedy for the metrical defect, is better than Bergk's insertion, after o)du/nais, of w(=d), which would have a weak effect there.

h( d), the personified no/sos: cp. 1084: so Ph.807h(/de, and ib. 758 au(/th. Blaydes writes a(/d) (Doric), which accords with ga=s and tla/mwn, but not with peponhme/nos or a)llh/ktois: the Doricism of tragic anapaests is not always consistent; see Appendix to Ant.110.
bru/kei: so Ph.745bru/komai.

a)=r' e)ch/|dh o(/son ke/rdos h)=n se tigh=| keu/qein; ‘Did I not well know,’ etc., —referring to 974 si/ga, te/knon, k.t.l. Cp. Ar. Av.1019*m*e. oi)/moi kakodai/mwn. *p*e. ou)k e)/legon e)gw\ pa/lai; keu/qein is really trans. in sense, ‘to hide (thy grief),’ though the object is not expressed: cp. Soph. Ant.85krufh=| de\ keu=qe (tou)/rgon). The rare intrans. keu/qw=‘to be hidd n’ ( Soph. O. T.968 n.).

e)ch/|dh s) is Wecklein's correction of the MS. e)ch/|dhs, instead of which we must at least write e)ch/|dhsq) ( Ant.447). Two explanations of e)ch/|dhsq) have been given. (1) ‘Did you well know’ (as soon as Heracles began to speak Ant., 983),— i.e., ‘have you now learned?’ Such is the schol.'s view: a)=ra...o(/son h)=n ke/rdos to\ siwpa=n e)/gnws; He classed the pluperf., then, with those aorists, referring to a moment just past, which we render by a present tense ( Ph.1289a)pw/mos), n.). This is possible, but awkward. (2) ‘Did you not well know (beforehand),— i.e., ‘had not I clearly told you?’ (Paley). The tense has then its usual force; but the words lose their special point,— which is that the result must have shown him the value of the neglected advice.
keu/qein — skeda/sai: for the pres. inf. (of a continued act), combined with the aor. inf. (of a momentary act), cp. Ph.95 Ph., 1397.

krato\s blefa/rwn q): the phrase suggests a movement of the head at the moment when the sleeper opens his eyes: cp. Ph.866kinei= ga\r a(nh\r <*> ka)na/gei ka/ra.—Wecklein, omitting <*> takes blefa/rwn u(/pnon as ‘sleep of the eyelids.’
ste/rcaimi: cp. 486: Ph.538ste/rgein kaka/.
*khnai/a, instead of *khnai/wn: cp. 818 mhtrw=|on (n.).

krhpi\s, the substructure, basis, of the altar; Eur. H. F.984a)mfi\ bwmi/an | e)/pthce krhpi=d), ‘at the altarsteps.’ The word has a picturesque force here, as recalling the moment when the altars were founded by him (237).

i(erw=n oi(/wn, gen. of price.— e)pi/ moi, lit., ‘in my case’: Ph.1384le/geis d' *)atrei/dais o)/felos h)\ )p' e)moi\ to/de; Others explain, ‘against me,’ ‘to my hurt’; but this suits the irony less well.— The MS. h)nu/sw has been altered by many recent edd. to h)/nusas: but the proper force of the midd., ‘to obtain,’ ‘win’ ( Plut. 196 etc.), seems fitting here, since the sacrificial altars may be said to have earned the recompense given by Zeus. h)/nusas would be simply, ‘hast effected.’
w)= *zeu= at the end of the sentence: Ph.1139 n
e)/qou me lw/ban=e)lwbh/sw me: cp. O. C.223 n.
h(\n, referring back to krhpi/s (993); cp. 358 (n.). Wunder needlessly placed h(\n … o)/ssois immediately after 993.
mh/ pot) belongs to prosidei=n, not to w)/felon, though the latter might have come between them; cp. Ph.969mh/ pot' w)/felon lipei=n (n.).
a)kh/lhton: schol. a)ni/aton, a)katapra/u+nton.—a)/nqos=a)kmh/n: cp. Ant.959ta=s mani/as deino\n... | a)nqhro/n te me/nos (n.).

kataderxqh=nai, inf. expressing result, without w(/ste: cp. Ant.1076lhfqh=nai (n.). Though the malady is his own, he can be said ‘to look upon it,’ in the sense of experiencing it: cp. O. T.832pro/sqen h)\ toia/nd' i)dei=n | khli=d' e)mautw=| sumfora=s a)figme/nhn.
a)oido/s=e)pw|do/s, one who uses e)pw|dai/, incantations, in healing: see on O. C.1194.

ti/s o( xeirote/xnhs, sc. e)sti/n. (There is no art. before a)oido/s, because the insertion of o(\s was an afterthought.) This is a climax; since, when gentle e)pw|dai/ failed, the next resort was to drugs or surgery: Ai.581ou) pro\s i)atrou= sofou= | qrhnei=n e)pw|da\s pro\s tomw=nti ph/mati. xeirote/xnhs i)atori/as does not mean definitely, ‘one who uses a skilled hand in healing,’ i.e., a xeirourgo/s, surgeon, as distinguished from a physician; it rather means properly, ‘a practical artist’ (as dist. from an amateur) ‘in healing’; but, at the same time, the xeiro in the compound serves to suggest the tomai/ employed by the surgeon. This is quite Sophoclean. Cp. Thuc.6. 72i)diw/tas, w(s ei)pei=n, xeirote/xnais a)ntagwnisame/nous, ‘having been pitted like amateurs, as one might say, against masters of the art’ (where the dat., and not xeirote/xnas, is clearly right).
xwri\s *zhno\s=‘with the exception of Zeus’: not, ‘without the help of Zeus’ (schol. ei) mh\ o( *zeu\s bou/loito).

qau=m' a)\n po/rrwqen i)doi/mhn: ‘I should look upon him, from afar, as a wonder,’—i.e., ‘I should marvel as soon as he came within my ken.’ He means that he might scan the horizon long enough, in the vain hope of such a prodigy appearing.—Others join po/rrwqen with q<*>ma: ‘I should behold him as a wonder from some distant region’: i.e., the place which contains him must be distant indeed. Hermann further supposed a question: ‘am I likely to see such a wonder coming from afar?’—The phrase thlo/qen ei)sorw=n in Ph.454 is not similar: see n. there.
This passage consists of lyrics delivered by actors (a)po\ skhnh=s). As the Chorus takes no part in it, it is not technically a kommo/s, which is a qrh=nos koino\s xorou= kai\ a)po\ skhnh=s.

The lyric structure is complex, but not obscure. The passage falls into two main parts, separated by the five hexameters in 1018—1022 (w)= pai= tou=d' a)ndro\s...ne/mei *zeu/s). I. The first part consists of 1004—1017, in which the first three verses correspond metrically with the last three. II. The second part consists of 1023—1043. (It is equal in length with the first part, though the traditional numbering makes it appear longer.) Here, the first four verses correspond with the last four. Then the central portion of part I. corresponds with the central portion of part II. Thus: (1) 1st strophe, 1004—1006,=1st antistr., 1015—1017. (2) 2nd str., 1007—1009,=2nd antistr., 1027—1030. (3) 3rd str., 1023—1026, =3rd antistr., 1040—1043. The dactyls in 1010—1014, and 1031—1040, could also be regarded as forming a fourth strophe and antistrophe.—For the metres see Metrical Analysis.

e)a=te/ m), e)a=te … eu)na=sqai. A restoration of this corrupt passage turns chiefly on the following points. (1) The corresponding verses of the antistrophe (1016 f.) may be taken as showing the true metre. (2) L's variant for eu)na=sai in 1005, viz. u(/staton, may therefore be received. eu)na/sai (a^), from eu)na/zw is impossible, since, like eu)na=sai (eu)na/w), it could only be transitive. (3) In 1006 the MS. du/stanon is clearly wrong; it may have been either a gloss on du/smoron, or a corruption of u(/staton. (4) Hermann's reading in 1006, e)a=q' u(/staton eu)na=sqai, is strongly confirmed by the metrical correspondence with 1017, molw\n tou= stugerou=; feu= feu=,—a verse of undoubted soundness.

pa=| … yau/eis: a remonstrance against being touched at all. Cp. Ph.817a)po/ m' o)lei=s, h)\n prosqi/gh|s. Hyllus seeks to place him in a more comfortable position,—as Heracles himself soon requests (1025).—A comparison with the antistrophic verse Ph., 1027, qrw/|skei d' au)=, qrw/|skei deilai/a, shows the loss of a syllable here. Hermann follows Seidler in repeating pa=|, which is the simplest and most probable remedy.

a)nate/trofas, from a)natre/pw: schol. o(/ ti a)
 h(suxa/sh| tou= kakou= toutou, pa/lin kinh/sas a)ne/treyas. Cp. Hist. An. 8. 24 (p. 605 a 11) ka)
 h)=| kaqara\ (ta\ u(/data), a)natre/pousin au)ta\ oi( i(/ppoi tai=s o(plai=s, ‘trouble’ them. For the perf., cp. Andoc. or. 1 § 131 a)lith/rion au(tw=| e)/trefen, o(\s a)nate/trofen e)kei/nou to
 plou=ton (‘overthrown’). Aeschin. or. 1 § 190 po/leis a)natetrofo/tas: or. 3 § 158 th
 po/lin a)/rdhn a)natetrofo/ta. In Soph. O. C.186te/trofen is from tre/fw: but the classical use of that perf. is ordinarily confined to the intrans. sense ( Hom. Od.23. 237te/trofen a(/lmh).

o(/ ti kai\ mu/sh|, anything that has closed the eyes, i.e., any part of the pain that has been lulled to rest. This is simpler than to supply no/son with a)nate/trofas, and to take o(/ ti as acc. of respect (‘in so far as...’). Cp. Vesp. 92 h)\n d' ou)=n katamu/sh| ka)\n a)/xnhn.

po/qen e)/st), ‘whence are ye?’ Of what stock? Can ye be indeed of Hellenic race, and yet so heartlessly ungrateful? Cp. Od.17. 373po/qen ge/nos eu)/xetai ei)=nai;—Hermann explains po/qen e)ste/ as=‘whence do ye appear to aid me?’ (unde mihi auxilio adestis?):—a complaint that they do not appear. He compares Od.2. 267sxedo/qen de/ oi( h)=lqen *)aqh/nh: but might better have cited Il.16. 800sxedo/qen de/ oi( h)=en o)/leqros. The version is tenable in itself, but is not well suited to the context. Heracles is addressing the men who are actually around him,—the Greeks (some of them his own mercenaries) who have brought him from Euboea. Cp. the very similar passage in Ph.1203 ff.: a)ll), w)= ce/noi, e(/n ge/ moi eu)=xos o)re/cate....ci/fos, ei)/ poqen, | h)\ ge/nun, h)\ bele/wn ti, prope/myate. He is not making a merely rhetorical appeal to the absent,—‘all those who had been benefited by him,’ as the schol. says. In that case, he would not say, pa/ntwn *(ella/nwn a)dikw/tatoi a)/ndres: he had toiled for all Hellenes.

ou(\s refers to *(ella/nwn, not to a)/ndres. If the acc. be right, kaqai/rwn here=‘ridding of pests.’ In this sense, the verb is properly said of places (1061 gai=an kaqai/rwn): but the bolder use here seems possible, and is not excluded by e)n po/ntw|, since the thought is of the gain to seafarers. <*> I hesitate, then, to receive the tempting oi(=s (‘for whose good’).

e)n po/ntw|: cp. Eur. H. F.222 ff., where Amphitryon denounces the ingratitude of Greece towards Heracles:—ou)d' *(ella/d' h)/|nes), ou)d' a)ne/comai/ pote | sigw=n, kaki/sthn lamba/nwn e)s pai=d' e)mo/n, | h(\n xrh=n neossoi=s toi=sde pu=r, lo/gxas, o(/pla | fe/rousan e)lqei=n, ponti/wn kaqarma/twn | xe/rsou t' a)moiba/s, ‘as a reward for purging sea and land.’ Cp. ib. 400: ‘he went into the uttermost parts of the deep, making peace for the oars of men.’ Pind. N.1. 63(of Heracles) o(/ssous me\n e)n xe/rsw| ktanw/n, | o(/ssous de\ po/ntw| qh=ras a)i+drosi/kas.
kata/ te after polla\ me\n: cp. Ant.1162sw/sas me\n... | labw/n te (n.).

dri/a, from the same rt as dru=s, drumo/s, de/ndron, do/ru (Curt. Etym. § 275): the only sing. found is (to\) dri/os.—w)leko/man, impf. of o)le/kw ( Ant.1285), expresses the wearing effect of continual labours: cp. Ph.252diwllu/mhn: ib. 686 w)/lluq).

kai\ nu=n … ou)k e)pitre/yei; ‘and now will no one turn fire or sword upon me,’— i.e., ‘come to my rescue’ with it? The repetition of ou)k with the verb gives a passionate emphasis: see n. on Ant.6(ou)k o)/pwp), after ou)de\n ga\r ou)/t' a)lgeino\n etc.).—The reading a)potre/yei has better authority (cr. n.), but seems untenable. It has been explained as, (1) ‘not-avert,’ =‘apply’: (2) ‘divert (from other uses),’ ‘turn wholly against me.’
tw=|de=e)moi/: cp. 305 n.
pu=r: thus Philoctetes prays to die even by fire ( Ph.800).
e)/gxos =ci/fos: cp. 1032, Ai.95 etc.

1016 f. The MS. reading, a)para/cai kra=ta bi/ou, is explained as, ‘to sever the head from life,’—i.e., to destroy life by striking the head from the body. This extraordinary phrase is surely not Greek. It has been supported by a corrupt verse of Eur. , Helen. 302, smikro\n (smikro\s Badham) d' o( kairo\s a)/rt' a)palla/cai bi/ou: where Keil reads a)/rqr), Nauck kra=t), and Hermann sa/rk). But, whatever be read there, a)palla/cai bi/ou is widely different from a)para/cai bi/ou. I hold, with Paley, that Wakefield's bi/a| ought to be substituted for bi/ou, which might easily have arisen from tou= stugerou=.—Cp. Il.14. 497a)ph/racen de\ xama=ze | au)th=| su\n ph/lhki ka/rh.
tou)/rgon to/de, the task of lifting the sufferer (who is lying propeth/s, 976) into a position of greater ease (1025 pro/slabe koufi/sas).

mei=zon is proleptic with a)nh/kei, ‘has risen, so as to be greater’: cp. Dem. or. 2 § 8 h)/rqh me/gas. The usu. constr. of a)nh/kein, as=‘to reach’ a certain standard, <*>s with ei)s, as if here we had ei)s mei=zo/n ti.
h)\ kat e)ma\n r(w/man, with mei=zon: O.C. 598 mei=zon h)\ kat' a)/nqrwpon (n.).

soi\ ga\r e(toi/ma, sc. r(w/ma, ‘for strength is at thy command,’ e)s ple/on h)\ di) e)mou= sw/|zein, ‘in too large a measure for the saving of him by my means,’ i.e. ‘so largely, that you have no need to save him by my means.’

The MSS. give soi/ te ga\r o)/mma | e)/mpleon h)\ di) e)mou= sw/|zein. The correction of e)/mpleon (‘full’) to e)s ple/on is due to Meineke, and is confirmed by the following h)\ with the inf.: cp. O. T.1293mei=zon h)\ fe/rein: Eur. Hec.1107krei/sson' h)\ fe/rein kaka/.

The MS. words, soi/ te ga\r o)/mma, are unquestionably corrupt. This is shown by two things: (1) o)/mma is incongruous with the context; strength, not keenness of sight, is in question; and, even if it were suitable, it could not be reconciled with any probable emendation of the following words. (2) te is unmeaning and impossible. I believe that I have found the solution by the slight change of soi/ te ga\r o)/mma into soi\ ga\r e(toi/ma. The corruption began by oi/ma passing into o)/mma. How easy this would have been, may be judged from Il.21. 252, ai)etou= oi)/mat' e)/xwn, where Philetas read o)/mmat), as in Il.8. 349, *gorgou=s o)/mmat' e)/xwn, Aristarchus read oi)/mat).
In the Appendix are given the proposed explanations of the vulgate, and various conjectures.

laqi/ponon d' o)duna=n: cp. El.1002a)/lupos a)/ths: I. T. 450 doulei/as... | ...pausi/ponos. The adj., found only here and in Ai.711, recalls the epic la^qikhdh/s. It is proleptic predicate with e)canu/sai, ‘to effect that his life shall forget,’ etc. The reference of bi/oton to Heracles would be clearer if we could read e)/sti oi( (not e)/stin oi(, cp. 650): but moi is confirmed by e)/ndoqen, ‘from my own resources’ (cp. 730 oi)/koi n.).
qu/raqen, by the help of others: cp. Eur. H. F.713w(s qu/raqen ei)ka/sai (i.e. without personal knowledge).—The MS. o)du/nan … bio/tou is tenable, but less probable, and much less forcible.
toiau=ta ne/mei *zeu/s, i.e., so grievous a doom. Not, ‘such healing is of Zeus alone.’

ta=|de: he indicates the place at which Hyllus is to take hold of him.— ta=|de/ me … pro/slabe koufi/sas, literally, ‘lend a helping hand in raising me thus’: the pron. depends on the partic. only. For this sense of the verb, cp. Legg. p. 897 D kai\ e)me\ th=s a)pokri/sews u(mi=n... di/kaion proslamba/nein, ‘it is right that I, too, should help you with the answer.’ pro/slabe/ me could not mean literally, ‘lay hold on me,’ which would be proslabou= mou (cp. Ar. Lys.202, etc.). koufi/sas denotes the act in which, when done, the help will consist. For this quasi-proleptic use of the aor. partic., cp. Plat. Gorg. 516B to/de toi/nun moi xa/risai a)pokrina/menos.
i)w\ dai=mon: the movement causes a new access of pain. Cp. Ph.1186ai)ai=, ai)ai=, | dai/mwn dai/mwn. O. T.1311i)w\ dai=mon.
qrw/|skei denotes the shooting spasms: cp. 1083 dih=|ce: Ph.743die/rxetai, | die/rxetai.—deilai/a: the ai is long here, though sometimes short ( Ant.1310 n.).
a)poti/batos=a)pro/sbatos: cp. 1214 potiyau/wn (n.). The personified no/sos is ‘unapproachable’ in the sense that no healer can successfully cope with it. Cp. 1093 a)/platon...ka)prosh/goron.

*palla/s. Athena was always a guardian goddess to her half-brother, Heracles; of whom she says in Il.8. 363 ff., teiro/menon sw/eskon u(p' *eu)rusqh=os a)e/qlwn: | h)= toi o( me\n klai/eske pro\s ou)rano/n, au)ta\r e)me\ *zeu\s | tw=| e)palech/sousan a)p' ou)rano/qen proi+/allen. She was constantly represented in Greek art as present with Heracles during his labours, or as honouring and comforting him in seasons of repose. Sometimes she gives him a flower or a wreath; sometimes a refreshing draught. And, after the close of his mortal toils, it is Athena Nikè who escorts him to Olympus. (Cp. n. on Ph.728.) The art-literature of the subject will be found in Roscher, Lex., p. 2215. Attic black-figure vases often illustrate this relationship,—one which was the more welcome to Athenians because Heracles was essentially a Dorian hero.

fu/tor), Dindorf's correction of fu/sant), gives an incomparably better verse than Fröhlich's to\n fu/sant' oi)/ktir). It is very improbable that oi)/ktir) would have been corrupted into the aor. partic.; but a rare word, such as fu/tor), would easily have become fu/sant). Dindorf is clearly right in holding that the n of fu/twr would be short, though metrical convenience might sometimes cause it to be lengthened in such compounds as a)mpelofu/tora (Anth. 6. 44), which could not otherwise come into a hexameter. He might have added that the verse, a)qa/natoi de\ *pte/rwta, dia\ pterofu/tor' a)na/gkhn, is prefaced by Plato with the remark that it is ou) sfo/dra ti e)/mmetron,— a comment which, as W. H. Thompson observes, may apply to the u_ no less than to the de^ (Phaedr. p. 252 C). Hesychius has fu/tores: gennh/tores. For the spelling oi)kti/ras, cp. 464 n.
a)nepi/fqonon: schol. a)neme/shton, e)f w| ou)dei/s se me/myetai w(s patrokto/non.
e)ma=s u(po\ klh=|dos: ‘under the collar-bone’ must denote a stab in the upper region of the breast: it cannot mean decapitation. For u(po/ with gen., in a local sense, cp. Ant.65 n.

e)xo/lwsen, an epic word ( Il.18. 111), here partly suggested by the thought of the venom working in his veins. Cp. 1142 e)kmh=nai. The v.l. e)xo/lhsen (schol.) was intended to mean, ‘has used the hydra's gall against me’: but the Attic sense of xola=n was ‘to be mela/gxolos.’
au)/tws: for the smooth breathing, see n. on O.T. 931.
gluku\s; cp. O.C. 106 i)/t), w)= glukei=ai pai=des a)rxai/ou *sko/tou (n.).

au)qai/mwn: nom. for voc., like w)= tla/mwn (O.C. 185). This adj., found only here,=o(/maimos, o(mai/mwn ( O. C.330 n.), au)qo/maimos (ib. 335), as denoting the fraternal tie. But au)/qaimos, as used in O.C. 1078, is merely ‘kinsman.’—It is as the son of Zeus that he invokes Hades.
w)kupe/ta|, an epic epith. for a horse ( Il.8. 42), or a bird ( Op 210). -fqi/sas (i^); 709 n.

oi(/ais, not oi(/as, is clearly right here. e)lau/nein can take a cogn. acc. denoting the course on which one is driven, as Nub. 29 pollou\s to\n pate/r' e)lau/neis dro/mous: but when it means ‘to vex’ or ‘harass,’ the troubles inflicted are expressed by the instrum. dat., as in the examples cited by Dindorf: Ai.275lu/ph|...e)lh/latai: Eur. Andr.31kaxoi=s e)lau/nomai: Eur. Ion1620e)lau/netai sumforai=s.

w)= polla\ dh\ k.t.l. This speech, down to v. 1102, is translated by Cicero in Tusc.2. 8, where the fact that the poets recognise pain as an evil is illustrated by the laments of Philoctetes, Heracles and Prometheus.

Cicero's version is essentially that of an orator; the true test for it would be declamation. But even a reader can feel its sonorous vigour, and its Roman gravity; Cicero succeeds as Lord Derby succeeded in much of the Iliad. The rendering of the Greek is very free, sometimes inadequate, but always manly, and highly terse; indeed, the 57 lines of the original become 45; in one place, eleven verses (1079—1089) are reduced to four (vv. 30—33).

qerma\: qermo/s was said (1) of a hot or rash temperament ( Ant.88): (2) of a rash deed, as in Plut 415 w)= qermo\n e)/rgon ka)no/sion kai\ para/nomon | tolmw=nte dra=n. Here qerma\ is not ‘rash,’ but expresses intense conflict with deadly peril; as we speak of ‘a hot fight.’

kou) lo/gw| kaka\ fitly follows qerma/, the word which recalls the moment of dire stress. His trials had been fiery, and grievous, not in report or name alone. No lo/gos could express to others what the e)/rga had been to the doer. In El.761 ff. a similar antithesis is implied: toiau=ta/ soi tau=t' e)sti/n, w(s me\n e)n lo/gw| | a)lgeina/, toi=s d' i)dou=sin, oi(/per ei)/domen, | me/gista pa/ntwn w(=n o)/pwp' e)gw\ kakw=n: grievous enough to hear; but far worse to see. For ou) lo/gw|, cp. Ai.813kou) lo/gw| dei/cw mo/non: El.1453ka)pe/deicen ou) lo/gw| mo/non. Thuc.6. 18a)mu/nesqai ou) lo/gw| a)ll' e)/rgw| ma=llon.

The MS. reading, kai\ lo/gw| kaka\, is certainly wrong, for two reasons. (1) When the required sense is, ‘grievous to tell,’ kaka/ becomes, for Greek poetical idiom, too weak; we need such a word as deina/ or a)lgeina/. This objection does not apply to a phrase of ironical form, such as ou) lo/gw| kaka/. (2) Idiom would require kai\ le/gein rather than kai\ lo/gw|. Cicero, no doubt, read kai\ lo/gw| (‘O multa dictu gravia, perpessu aspera’); but that proves nothing. In Ant.4ou)/t' a)/ths a)/ter was the only reading known to Didymus (c. 30 B.C.).

xersi\ refers to deeds of prowess: nw/toisi to feats of sheer strength, as when he took the place of Atlas, or carried the Erymanthian boar to Mycenae.—Cicero's version, Quae corpore exanclavi atque animo pertuli, has caused the inference that his text contained an equivalent for animo. Wecklein suggests that he read ste/rnoisi (cp. 1090), but misunderstood it. Perhaps, however, Cicero felt his rhetorical antithesis to be warranted by the idea of mental anguish implied in moxqh/sas.
kou)/pw: kai/ here=‘and nevertheless’; cp. Ant.332 n.

a)/koitis h( *dio\s (for the place of the art., cp. 732), since the a)rgale/os xo/los *(/hrhs ( Il.18. 119) was the prime source of all his troubles. Hera caused Eurystheus to be born at Argos a little before the birth of Heracles at Thebes ( Il.19. 114 ff.), and afterwards gave the hero into his power. But she also persecuted Heracles directly, as when she sent the serpents to his cradle ( Pind. N.1. 40), or drove him by storms to Cos ( Il.14. 253 ff.).
prou)/qhken, of setting a task: Ant.216 n.
*eu)rusqeu\s is not elsewhere named in the play: cp. 35.
oi(=on to/d)...a)mfi/bl. kaqh=yen=oi(=on to/d' a)mfi/blhstro/n e)stin, o(\ kaqh=yen: cp. 184.
dolw=pis, ‘with deceitful face,’ smiling on him while plotting evil.

*)erinu/wn … a)mfi/blhstron: cp. Ai.1034a)=r' ou)k *)erinu\s tou=t' e)xa/lkeusen ci/fos; The epithet u(fanto\n marks that the ‘net’ is the robe: just as, in Aesch. Ag.1580, u(fantoi=s e)n pe/plois *)erinu/wn, it marks that a real robe is meant. (So an eagle is pthno\s ku/wn, Aesch. P. V.1022.) A net would properly be described as plekto/n rather than u(fanto/n (cp. Pollux 7. 139 diktuoplo/kos).
prosmaxqe\n, ‘plastered’ to his sides: cp. 768 a)rti/kollos.—e)sxa/tas … sa/rkas, i.e., not only on the surface of the body, but to the inmost parts. Cicero renders the phrase by viscera.

pleu/mono/s t' a)rthri/as: ‘the suspenders of the lungs,’ i.e., the bronchial tubes which convey air to the lungs. For the sing. pleu/mwn in a collective sense cp. Plat. Tim.p. 84 D o( tw=n pneuma/twn tw=| sw/mati tami/as pleu/mwn. As to the word a)rthri/a, see Appendix.

r(ofei=, ‘drains,’ ‘empties’ (of air): his breath is arrested by the spasms: cp. 778 sparagmo\s...pleumo/nwn a)nqh/yato. Though the grammatical subject is a)mfi/blhstron, the agent is properly the venom itself; cunoikou=n, since this interruption of the breath is frequent. For this use of r(ofei=n, cp. Ar. Ach.278r(ofh/sei tru/blion (empty it). Cicero well renders, Urgensque graviter pulmonum haurit spiritus.
xlwro\n, fresh, vigorous; cp. Theocr. 14. 70 poiei=n ti dei=, a(=s (=e)/ws) go/nu xlwro/n (‘youthful’).—Not ‘discoloured’ (decolorem sanguinem, Cic. ).
a)fra/stw|, ‘indescribable,’ unutterably dreadful; not, ‘inexplicable,’ i.e., of unknown origin.
xeirwqei\s: cp. 279 n.

kou) … ou)/q). It is unnecessary to change ou)/q) to ou)d). The sequence ou)...ou)/te is foreign to Attic prose; and an Attic poet would presumably have avoided it where ou) was followed by only one negative clause: e.g., in O. C.702ou) nearo\s ou)de\ gh/ra|, etc., ou)/te is improbable. In Theognis 125 ou) ga\r a)\n ei)dei/hs a)ndro\s no/on ou)de\ gunaiko/s, where the MSS. have ou)/te, ou)de\ stands in Aristotle's quotation of the verse (Eth. Eud. 7. 2). But when, as here, several clauses with ou)/te follow ou), an Attic poet might imitate the frequent Homeric usage: e.g., Od.4. 566ou) nifeto\s ou)/t' a)\r xeimw\n polu\s ou)/te pot' o)/mbros. So ib. 9. 136 f. ou) is followed by two clauses with ou)/te, and in Il.6. 450 f. by three.
lo/gxh pedia/s, the spear of the warrior on a battle-field; as when Heracles fought with Laomedon of Troy, with the Amazons, or with Augeas king of Elis ( Apollod.2. 7. 2).

strato\s *giga/ntwn: after sacking Troy, and ravaging Cos, Heracles went to Phlegra (sometimes identified with Pallenè, the westernmost headland of the Chalcidic peninsula), and helped the gods to vanquish their Earth-born foes. In Pind. N.1. 67Teiresias predicts what Heracles shall achieve, o(/tan qeoi\ e)n pedi/w| *fle/gras *giga/ntessin ma/xan | a)ntia/zwsin. In the Gigantomachia on the pediment of the Megarian Treasury at Olympia, Heracles fought at the right hand of Zeus (cp. Ausgrabungen, vol. IV. pl. 20 b). Early Attic vase-paintings of this subject associate him with Zeus and Athena (Roscher, Lex., p. 2211).
qh/reios bi/a seems to be a general phrase, including both the Centaurs (qhrw=n, 1096) and the wild beasts (1092 ff.). Cicero understood it of the former only, non biformato impetu | Centaurus.

a)/glwssos profits by the suggestion of gh= in the adjective *(ella\s ( Ph.256*(ella/dos gh=s). The ba/rbaros has no ‘language’ properly so called: to the ear of the Hellene, he merely twitters like a bird (n. on Ant.1002). Cp. Pind. I.6. 24ou)k e)/stin ou(/tw ba/rbaros ou)/te pali/gglwssos po/lis, ‘barbarous or strange of speech.’

ou)/q' o(/shn: the division of mankind into Greeks and barbarians is exhaustive; but the range of earth traversed by Heracles extended beyond the dwellings of men (cp. 1100 e)p' e)sxa/tois to/pois). It seems unnecessary, then, to regard this third clause as merely a rhetorical summary of the other two.
gai=an: antecedent attracted into relative clause: O. C.907 n.

qh=lus for qhlei=a, as in the Homeric qh=lus e)e/rsh ( Od.5. 467): O. C.751 n.—Nauck's correction of ou)=sa into fu=sa is indispensable, if a)ndro\s be retained; the alternative would be to read a)nh\r, which is less probable. For the cogn. acc., cp. Ai.760a)nqrw/pou fu/sin | blastw/n.—mo/nh … dh\: Ant.58 n.
kaqei=le, brought low, destroyed, as in Ai.517(of death).

fasga/nou di/xa: the warrior laments that he has not fallen in combat; cp. Aesch. Eum.627(of Agamemnon's death) kai\ tau=ta pro\s gunaiko/s, ou)/ ti qouri/ois | to/cois e(khbo/loisin w(/st' *)amazo/nos.

genou=, show thyself: gegw/s and e)th/tumos cohere, making an equiv. for gnh/sios: hence there is no awkwardness in having two forms from gi/gnomai. Cp. 1158: Ai.556dei= s' o(/pws patro\s | deiceis e)n e)xqroi=s oi(=os e)c oi(/ou )tra/fhs.—to\ mhtro\s o)/noma: she is such in name only (817).
presbeu/sh|s, prefer in honour: Eur. Hipp.5tou\s me\n se/bontas ta)ma\ presbeu/w kra/th.—ple/on is, in strictness, redundant; cp. Legg. 887 B protima=n braxulogi/an ma=llon h)\ mh=kos.
ei)dw=, which Nauck changes to i)/dw, is in accord with usage (cp. e.g., 678, O. C.889o(/pws ei)dw=: Ph.238w(s ei)dw=).

ei) tou)mo
 k.t.l. The constr. is, ei) ma=llon a)lgei=s, o(rw=n tou)mo
 lwbhton ei)=dos, h)\ (to\) kei/nhs (lwbhto
 ei)=dos) e)n di/kh| kakou/menon. For the omission of to\ before kei/nhs, cp. 929 to\ kei=se deu=ro/ t) (n.).— kakou/menon as in Ph.228, O. C.261.

Cicero represents this passage by a single verse, Iam cernam, mene an illam potiorem putes. Hence Nauck rejects v. 1069. But the inference is most unsafe, as another instance will show. The passage beginning with i)dou/ (1079) and ending with e)cw/rmhken (1089) shrinks, in Cicero's version, to three lines and a half, viz., Videte cuncti: tuque, caelestum sator, | Iace, obsecro, in me vim coruscam fulminis! | Nunc, nunc dolorum anxiferi torquent vertices: | Nunc serpit ardor. Thus Cicero wholly ignores vv. 1085 ff.: he ignores vv. 1080—1084 also, except in so far as their general sense is blended with his version of 1088 f., dai/nutai...e)cw/rmhken. Yet the Greek text there is clearly sound.

i)/q), expressing entreaty, is similarly combined with to/lmhson in Ph.480 f.: i)/q), h(me/ras toi mo/xqos ou)x o(/lhs mia=s, | to/lmhson, k.t.l.—polloi=sin oi)ktro/n: cp. O. T.1296oi(=on kai\ stugou=nt' e)poikti/sai. Cicero: Miserere! Gentes nostras flebunt miserias.

w(/ste parqe/nos: the schol. compares Il.16. 7, where Patroclus weeps h)u+/te kou/rh | nhpi/h.— be/bruxa might seem strange in such a comparison; yet cp. 904, where bruxa=to is said of Deianeira. The fitness of the word is more evident in 805, as in O. T.1265, and Ai.322, tau=ros w(s bruxw/menos. For the perf., cp. me/muka (muka/omai), me/mhka (mhka/omai).
a)ste/naktos: as Ajax was a)yo/fhtos o)ce/wn kwkuma/twn ( Ai.321).

ei(po/mhn, not ei(/peto, though to/nd' a)/ndra precedes: cp. O. C.6 n. The imperf., which was read here by a scholiast of the Ajax (cr. n.), is certainly preferable to e(spo/mhn, though the aor. would also be right, if he was viewing the past as a whole. If e(spo/mhn were read, ai)e\n would go with a)ste/naktos: though a)ei/ is not necessarily incompatible with an aor. ( Ph.1140 n.).

ei(po/mhn kakoi=s: cp. Eur. Phoen.408pw=s d' h)=lqes *)/argos;... | ou)k oi)=d): o( dai/mwn m' e)ka/lesen pro\s th\n tu/xhn. So a)kolouqei=n tw=| lo/gw| ( Plat. Phaedo107B), toi=s pra/gmasin ( Dem. or. 4 § 39), i.e., to follow their lead.
e)k toiou/tou: cp. 284 n.

kai\ nu=n … sth=qi … ske/yai d'. The first clause is introduced by kai/, the second by de/ (instead of te), as in Ant.432xh(mei=s i)do/ntes i(e/mesqa, su\n de/ nin | qhrw/meq' eu)qu/s. The effect of de/ is to throw the second clause into relief by a slight rhetorical antithesis (as if me/n had followed sth=qi). This expressive d) should not be changed to q).

dei/cw ga\r: the ictus on ga/r does not spoil the rhythm, because the chief stress falls on the verb: cp. O. C.1540xw=ron d), e)pei/gei ga/r me tou)k qeou= paro/n. Below, in 1247, the case of ou)=n is similar.

e)k kalumma/twn = e)kkekalumme/non, since e)k here=e)/cw, ‘outside of’: cp. Od.15. 272ou(/tw toi kai\ e)gw\n e)k patri/dos (sc. ei)mi/), ‘I am an exile.’ The sense is different in Aesch. Ag.1178, e)k kalumma/twn | ...dedorkw/s, where e)k=‘forth from.’

1081 It is best to retain ai)ai=, w)= ta/las, ai)ai=, L's reading. Hermann and others, taking ai)ai= w)= ta/las as a dochmiac, read e)e/ or e)\ e)/ instead of the second ai)ai=, placing it in a line by itself. Dindo<*>f formerly read ai)ai= ta/las (deleting w)= and the second ai)ai=), as an iambic dipodia: but his latest text gives ai)ai=, a)= ta/las (as a dochmiac). Nauck requires bacchii, and suggests i)w/ moi, ta/las, feu=. Wilam. (Hermes XVIII. 246) says—(1) ai)ai=, w)= ta/las, dochmius: (2) ai)ai=, interjection: (3) w)=nac ...pai=son, ‘acatalectic anapaestic trimeter.’ A brief interjection of this kind could take almost any metrical form; and, in the absence of a lyric context, the metre here cannot be defined with certainty. Cp. El.1160—2.
e)/qalyen is trans., me being understood, as after e)/mprhson in Ph.801(n.).
a)/ths: cp. 1104.

o(/d' au)= should be taken with e)/qalyen, because (1) o(/d) fitly stands in the first clause, and (2) dih=|ce thus gains force by its abruptness: cp. 1088 f. If a point were placed after a)rti/ws, o(/d) would still be better than o( d). —dih=|ce, a word used by medical writers, as Wakefield pointed out; e.g., Hippocr. Morb.1. 5u(f' e(wutw=n o)du/nai diai+/ssousin a)/llote a)/llh/| tou= sw/matos.—a)gu/mnaston: cp. Eur. fr. 683 mw=n krumo\s au)th=s pleura\ gumna/zei xolh=s;—diabo/ros: distinguish dia/boron (pass.) in 676. Cp. Soph. Ph.7no/sw| ...diabo/rw| (n.).

de/cai m): cp. Ph.819w)= gai=a, de/cai qana/simo/n m' o(/pws e)/xw.—Dindorf is probably right in regarding these two lines as anapaestic dimeters, each short of a foot (braxukata/lhktoi): cp. El.1160 ff. Hermann, writing *(/aidh instead of *)ai+/dh, made them iambic verses with spondees in the second place (i)sxiorrwgikoi/).
e)/nseison suggests the force with which the brandished bolt leaves the Thunderer's hand; e)gkata/skhyon, its descent upon the victim's head.
dai/nutai: cp. 771.
h)/nqhken: cp. 1000 a)/nqos (n.): Ph.258h( d' e)mh\ no/sos | a)ei\ te/qhle (n.). For this rare perf., cp. Thuc.2. 49e)chnqhko/s.
w)= xe/res: cp. Ph.1004w)= xei=res: ib. 1354 w)=...ku/kloi (n.).

w)= nw=ta kai\ ste/rn). Quoting from memory (with w)= ste/rn) instead of these words), the rhetorician Apsines (c. 240 A.D.) cites this passage (Spengel Rhet. 1.400) as an instance of pathetic apostrophe,—subjoining it to another example from Sophocles, viz. Soph. O. T.1391.Dindorf notes this (ed. 1860).
u(mei=s de\ kei=noi: for de/ cp. O. T.1097(n.). This reading is not better than u(mei=s e)kei=noi, but has better authority, because the de in L (cr. n.) was not likely to have been interpolated.

kaqe/staq), not merely ‘are,’ but ‘have come to be.’ For kaqesta/nai in this sense, see on Ant.435.The form of expression is due to the emphasis on u(mei=s: ‘yours is the plight to which those arms have come.’ It is a compressed way of saying, toiou=toi u(mei=s kaqe/state, e)kei=noi dh\ (o)/ntes) etc. For e)kei=nos referring to the past, cp. O. C.1195su\ d' ei)s e)kei=na, mh\ ta\ nu=n, a)posko/pei: for its juxtaposition with u(mei=s, ib. 138 o(/d' e)kei=nos e)gw/.

*neme/as, a valley in Argolis, about three miles S.W. of Cleonae, four and a half S. E. of Phlius, and eleven N. of Argos. The lion is described by Hesiod ( Th.331) as koirane/wn *trhtoi=o *nemei/hs h)d' *)ape/santos, Treton and Apesas being mountains which partly enclose the valley. It was in *trhto/n (‘the caverned’) that the monster had his den. Pindar calls Nemea the xo/rtoi le/ontos (Ol. 13. 44); also *dio\s a)/lsos (N. 2. 9), from its temple of Zeus, in a cypress-grove.

a)la/stora ( O. C.788 n.), as Hesiod calls him ph=m' a)nqrw/pois ( Th.329).— a)/platon=a)pe/laston, unapproachable: cp. Pind. P.12. 9a)pla/tois o)fi/wn kefalai=s.—a)prosh/goron, lit., ‘not affable,’— boldly applied to the intractable beast with which men can establish no relations. The word has here much the sense of a)pro/soiston: cp. Soph. O. C.1277to\ duspro/soiston ka)prosh/goron sto/ma. Vergil's description of the Cyclops has been quoted ( Aen.3. 621), Nec visu facilis nec dictu affabilis ulli; but Polyphemus could speak.

bi/a| kateirga/sasqe: Heracles throttled the lion, which was invulnerable: Eur. H. F.153o(\n e)n bro/xois e(lw\n | braxi/ono/s fhs' a)gxo/naisin e)celei=n. This was the first of his labours; and thus he won the lion-skin ( Pind. I.5. 47).

*lernai/an q' u(/dran: see 574 n. Eur. H. F.419ta/n te murio/kranon, | polu/fonon ku/na *le/rnas, | u(/dran e)cepu/rwsen, | be/lesi/ t' a)mfe/bal' i)o/n. This a)=qlos—usually made the second—is closely connected with the first; it is wrought in Argolis; and it completes his equipment by giving him the poison for his arrows. In both these labours, as in others, he is the a)leci/kakos.

1095 f. The next two exploits are also linked. Sentby Eurystheus in quest of the ka/pros (qh=ra 1097) that haunted Mount Erymanthus in north Arcadia, Heracles passed over Pholoè, a wild upland district on the borders of Elis. Here he was entertained by the Centaur Pholos, and routed the other Centaurs who flocked to demand a share of his host's wine.

difua=: Diodorus (4. 69) applies this word to the Centaurs. Cp. Pind. P.2. 47: Ixion and Nephelè begat a son Centaurus; o(\s | i(/ppoisi *magnhti/dessin e)mi/gnut' e)n *pali/ou | sfuroi=s: e)k d' e)ge/nonto strato\s | qaumasto/s, a)mfote/rois | o(moi=oi tokeu=si, ta\ matro/qen me\n ka/tw, ta\ d' u(/perqe patro/s.—a)/mikton, with whom it is impossible to hold humane intercourse; Eur. Cycl.429a)/mikton a)/ndra: cp. a)mici/a ( Thuc.1. 3).
i(ppoba/mona, usu., ‘mounted on horses,’ and so some take it here as=‘mounted on horses' legs’; but it is more simply explained as ‘moving like horses.’
qhrw=n: cp. 556.
u(bristh/n, a)/nomon: intemperance and violence were essential attributes of the Centaurs (excepting Cheiron): cp. 565. Eur. H. F.181tetraskele/s q' u(/brisma, *kentau/rwn ge/nos.

*(/aidou tri/kranon sku/lak): a three-headed Cerberus seems to have been the usual type in early Ionian art; while on Attic black-figure vases of the middle and later style he is two-headed: see Roscher, Lex.p. 2205. Hesiod, the first poet who names Cerberus ( Th.311), gives him fifty heads.

*)exi/dnhs qre/mma, as in Hes. Th.310: but in Soph. O. C.1574 he is the offspring of Tartarus and Earth. In Il.8. 366 ff. Athena saves Heracles when Eurystheus sends him e)c e)re/beus a)/conta ku/na stugerou= *)ai+/dao: cp. Od.11. 623.—Pluto said that Heracles might take Cerberus, if he could do so without using any weapon. The hero succeeded, and having shown his living prize to the terrified Eurystheus, restored it to the nether world. ( Apollod.2. 5. 12§ 8.)
xruse/wn: in tragic dialogue xru/seos usu. suffers synizesis, but there are several exceptions, such as fr. 313: fr. 439: Eur. Ion1175.

The golden apples, brought from the garden of the gods, originally meant the winning of immortality. Hence this a)=qlos properly comes after the Cerberus, though the latter is sometimes made the last ( Eur. H. F.427).

dra/konta mh/lwn fu/lak). The garden was in the far west, where Atlas supports the sky, beyond the stream of the Oceanus ( Hes. Th.215). When Zeus espoused Hera there, a wondrous apple-tree (mhle/a) sprang up. This tree was committed to the care of maidens called Hesperides, daughters of Night ( Hes. Th.211), sweet singers; and it was guarded by a terrible dragon, coiled round the stem ( Eur. H. F.397, Paus.6. 19. 8). Heracles slew this dragon with poisoned arrows (Apoll. Rh. 4.1396 ff., where the monster is named *la/dwn).

e)p' e)sxa/tois to/pois: for e)pi/, cp. 356. So Hesiod Th.518pei/rasin e)n gai/hs. Eur. Hipp.742*(esperi/dwn d' e)pi\ mhlo/sporon a)kta\n a)nu/saimi ta=n a)oidw=n, | i(/n' o( pontome/dwn porfure/as li/mnas | nau/tais ou)ke/q' o(do\n ne/mei. The garden was sometimes placed among the Hyperboreans as by Apollod.2. 5. 11, and prob. by Aeschylus in the *promhqeu\s *luo/menos, Strabo 4, p. 183: sometimes in Libya, or in Spain.

mo/xqwn, a general word, including both the tasks done for Eurystheus (the a)=qloi proper),—such as the five just enumerated,—and other enterprises, such as the warfare against Laomedon and the Giants (1058). In the temple of Athena xalki/oikos at Sparta Pausanias saw polla\ me\n tw=n a)/qlwn *(hrakle/ous, polla\ de\ kai\ w)=n e)qelonth\s katw/rqwse (3. 17. 2). As to the cycle of the ‘twelve labours,’ and its probable origin, see Introduction, § 2.
e)geusa/mhn: schol. e)peira/qhn. Cp. Ant.1005e)mpu/rwn e)geuo/mhn (n). Eur. H. F.1353kai\ ga\r po/nwn dh\ muri/wn e)geusa/mhn.
xerw=n, valour (488); for the gen., cp. Andoc. or. 1 § 147 tropai=a tw=n polemi/wn...a)pe/deican. Cicero well renders, Nec quisquam e nostris spolia cepit laudibus.

a)/narqros, like e)knene<*> me/nos, since his whole frame has been unhinged and unnerved; so Eur. Or.227o(/tan m' a)nh=| no/<*>os | mani/as, a)/narqro/s ei)mi ka)sqenw= me/lh.—katerrakwme/nos: cp. Aesch. P. V.1023(the eagle rending the flesh of Prometheus) diartamh/sei sw/matos me/ga r(a/kos: Lycophron 1113 kai\ pa=n laki/zous' e)n fonai=s yuxro\n de/mas.—tuflh=s, caeca, unseen: fr. 533 to\ d' e)s au)/rion a)ei\ | tuflo\n e(/rpei. Cp. Eur. Med.1200(the fatal robe consuming Glaucè's flesh) sa/rkes d' a)p' o)ste/wn w(/ste peu/kinon da/kru | gnaqmoi=s a)dh/lois farma/kwn a)pe/rreon.
a)ri/sths, since Alcmena, daughter of Electryon and Anaxo, belonged on both sides to the Perseidae, and so traced her descent from Zeus himself.
w)nomasme/nos: it is not necessary to supply go/nos from 1106: cp. fr. 84 katarkei= tou=de keklh=sqai patro/s.—au)dhqei\s: cp. 736: Ph.240au)dw=mai de\ pai=s | *)axille/ws.
to\ mhde\n w)=: cp. Ai.1275h)/dh to\ mhde\n o)/ntas: Ant.234 n.
ka)\n mhde\n e(/rpw: the adv. is emphatic; cp. 773: El.1014sqe/nousa mhde/n. Powerless as he is to seek her out; he is still able to execute his vengeance if she be brought to him.
xeirw/somai: 279 n.
ka)k tw=nde: Eur. Med.458o(/mws de\ ka)k tw=nd' ou)k a)peirhkw\s fi/lois | h(/kw: also w(s e)k tw=nde ( Soph. Ai.537, etc.).
i(/n' e)kdidaxqh=|<01> a)gge/llein, with grim irony: see on O. C.1377.

kakou/s ge is far better than Cobet's kakou/rgous, which, indeed, would mar the point. The ge is very expressive: it means, ‘when guilt is to be chastised, I am strong even in weakness,—even unto death.’
qanw\n, since he thinks of his life as already closed: cp. 1137 ktei/nasa.
w)= tlh=mon *(ella/s: cp. Eur. H. F.877me/leos *(ella/s, a)\ to\n eu)erge/tan | a)pobalei=s: and ib. 135.

sfalh/setai, not sfalh/sei, since w)= tlh=mon *(ella/s is rather an exclamation than an address. sfalei=s' e)/sei would be an easy correction (cp. O. C.816luphqei\s e)/sei), but is needless. —The poet may have preferred this verb to the more natural sterh/setai as more forcibly expressing a disaster (cp. 297, 719). Elsewhere the genitive after sfa/llomai always denotes, not a person. but a thing (do/chs, tu/xhs, xrhma/twn, etc.).

pare/sxes followed by parasxw\n is somewhat inelegant, but it should not too hastily be pronounced spurious: cp. 967 (ba/sin, after ba/sis): Ph.1219stei/xwn followed in the next v. by stei/xonta (n.).
nosw=n o(/mws: cp. O. C.666 n.
di/kaia: 409.

do/s moi seauto/n, give thyself to me, i.e., listen to what I would say, mh\ tosou=ton du/sorgos (w)\n) w(s da/knei qumw=|, without being wrathful in the degree to which thou art (now) stung by passion; i.e., in a less wrathful mood than that to which thy present anger excites thee. du/sorgos agrees with the subject to do/s, rather than with seauto/n, since do/s moi seauto/n ( Ph.84 n.) is equivalent to piqou= moi. qumw=| is best taken with da/knei only, though it might go with du/sorgos also. For da/knei, cp. 254. —Prof. Campbell, reading the subjunct. da/knh|, construes w(s mh\ tosou=ton da/knh| k.t.l., ‘that you may not be so exceedingly vexed with rage, being grievously distempered.’ But w(s should then precede mh/.
With the conjecture toiou=ton (masc.), the sense would be, ‘not in the mood to which thou art stung by anger.’ This would be simpler, but is unnecessary.
ou) ga\r a)\n gnoi/hs: the suppressed protasis is ei) mh\ <*>hs: cp. O.C. 98 n.

e)n oi(=s xai/rein proqumei=, in what a situation, under what circumstances, you desire a triumph,—the intended victim being already dead: cp. Ai.971e)n kenoi=s. e)n oi(=s is used as in 1122: for oi(=s, instead of o(/tois, in the indirect question, cp. O. C.1171 n. There is no class. example of xai/rein e)/n tini as=‘to rejoice in a thing,’ the regular constr. being xai/rein tini/ or e)pi/ tini: in El.1343ou)=n, not e)n, is right: and in Aesch. Eum.996, xai/ret' e)n ai)simi/aisi plou/tou, e)n=‘amidst.’ trufa=n e)/n tini occurs, but is not exactly similar.
ka)n o(/tois a)lgei=s ma/thn, and under what circumstances you are bitter without cause,—i.e., against one who is really innocent.
poiki/lleis, of riddling speech, as in 412 ti/ pote poiki/las e)/xeis; He does not understand the allusions in xai/rein and a)lgei=s.—pa/lai expresses impatience: cp. Ph.589 n.

th=s mhtro\s...fra/swn k.t.l.: cp. n. on 928: Ph.439a)naci/ou me\n fwto\s e)cerh/somai, | ...ti/ nu=n kurei=.—nu=n e)stin: some edd. give nu=n e)/stin: but the verb is here merely the copula, not substantive (‘exists’).
oi(=s q' h(/marten: e)n is carried on from the first oi(=s to the second, as in 423 to polloi=sin from poi/ois e)n a)nqrw/poisin.

kai\ paremnh/sw: kai/ gives an indignant emphasis to the verb,—‘hast thou indeed...?’ cp. Ant.726(n.) oi( thlikoi/de kai\ didaco/mesqa dh\ | fronei=n...; It could also mean, ‘even,’ ‘so much as’; but this would be hardly so forcible. —For ga\r in an angry question, cp. O. C.863.
paremnh/sw, of incidental mention; Her.7. 96tw=n e)gw/, ou) ga\r a)nagkai/h| e)ce/rgomai e)s i(stori/hs lo/gon, ou) parame/mnhmai.

patrofo/ntou, fem., as the poets use swth/r ( O. T.81 n.), foneu/s ( I. T. 586), xilionau/ths (ib. 141), *(/ellhn ( Heracl.130), etc. The word ought to mean, ‘slayer of her own father’; but here its reference is decided by the subject of the principal verb, as in Od.1. 299(e)/ktane patrofonh=a). Cp. El.558pate/ra fh\s ktei=nai (‘my father’). A still bolder use occurs in Eur. Or.193, where the sense of patrofo/nou matro/s is relative to h(ma=s in 191, while the subject of the principal verb is o( *foi=bos.
w(s klu/ein e)me/, the last person who ought to hear it. The emphasis on the pron. is, however, very slight; cp. 1220: O. T.1045w(/st' i)dei=n e/me/: Ph.299(n.).
e)/xei ga\r ou(/tws, sc. e)kei/nh. This suits the context better than to make e)/xei impersonal (‘the case stands thus’).
ou) dh=ta (siga=n pre/pei), toi=s ge pro/sqen h(mart., by reason of them, in view of them: for the caus. dat., cp. Thuc.3. 98toi=s pepragme/nois fobou/menos tou\s *)aqhnai/ous.

a)ll' ou)de\ me\n dh\ e)rei=s (o)/ti sigan pre/pei) toi=s g' e)f' h(me/ran, by reason of this day's deeds. Heracles has said, bitterly, ‘Silence is indeed unfitting, in view of her crimes.’ Hyllus replies, ‘It is so also in view of her deeds to-day,— as you will admit, when you know all.’ His father must learn that she has died, and that she was innocent.
a)ll' ou)de\ me\n dh\, rejecting an alternative, as in Ai.877, El.913.(Cp. a)lla\ me\n dh/ in 627.)

toi=s … e)f' h(me/ran=toi=s sh/meron pepragme/nois. The sense of e)f' h(me/ran is usu. ‘for the day,’ as in Her.1. 32tou= e)p' h(me/rhn e)/xontos: Soph. El.429th=s e)f' h(me/ran bora=s. Here the phrase is perhaps tinged with a sad irony,—‘this day's portion of evil.’ Cp. O.C. 1079, where kat' a)=mar=‘to-day,’ though ib. 682 kat' h)=mar means, as usual, ‘daily.’
kako\s, by defending her; he is a true son of Heracles (1064 ff.) only i<*> he abhors his mother.
le/gw: cp. Ph.591, Ant.245.
a)rti/ws neosfagh/s: the same phrase occurs in Ai.898: cp. Ant.1283(te/qnhke...) a)/rti neoto/moisi plh/gmasin.

e)qe/spisas, as having announced what no human wit could have foreseen, —since Deianeira, as Heracles supposes, is happy and triumphant. So Theseus says to Oedipus ( O. C.1516), polla\ ga/r se qespi/zonq' o(rw= | kou) yeudo/fhma.—te/ras implies incredulity.
dia\ kakw=n, ‘in ill omened words,’ not because she has died, but because his vengeance has been baffled (1133). Schol. : a)/piston ga\r dia\ dusfh/mwn w(/sper e)manteu/sw.

ou)deno\s pro\s e)kto/pou: i.e., by no one coming, from without, into the place where she was: hence, ‘by no external hand.’ Hyllus knew that she had been alone in the qa/lamos when she did the deed (927—931). We need not suppose, then, that e)/ktopos means merely a)/llos (which it could not do); nor, again, that it means ‘foreign to Trachis.’ These two explanations, which miss the mark on each side, have been fused in L's gloss, u(po\ a)/llou ce/nou.
1133 The emphasis on e)c e)mh=s xero/s excuses the form of expression, (te/qnhke) pri\n qanei=n. Cp. Ai.110, where the stress on nw=ta foinixqei\s similarly excuses qa/nh| (after qanei=n in 106).
deinou=, ironical, as in Ai.1127deino/n g' ei)=pas: Ph.1225.
kath=rcas: cp. Plat. Prot. 351E kata/rxeis tou= lo/gou. —h(=|: cp. 553 f.

a(/pan to\ xrh=m), ‘this is the sum of the matter.’ For this use of to\ xrh=ma, as meaning ‘the state of the case,’ like to\ pra=gma in Ph.789, cp. Vesp. 799 o(/ra to\ xrh=ma: ta\ lo/gi) w(s perai/netai. The phrase is best taken as a nom., with to/de e)sti/n understood: cp. O. T.1234 f.: Eur. fr. 255 a(plou=s o( mu=qos, mh\ le/g' eu)=. Eur. Itmight, however, be an acc. in appos. with the sentence.
mwme/nh: cp. O. C.836 n.
