ktei/nasa: cp. 1111 qanw\n: Ai.1126di/kaia ga\r to/nd' eu)tuxei=n ktei/nanta/ me;

ga\r justifies xrhsta\ mwme/nh. —ste/rghma occurs only here. Its formation from ste/rg-w is anomalous, since the word ought to be ste/rgma: but the same may be said of ste/rghqron (instead of ste/rktron): and qe/lghtron was in use along with qe/lktron. [Lidd. and Scott cite qe/lghma from Suidas s.v. bouk<*>lh/sas: but Bernhardy (ed. 1853, vol. I. p. 1017) reads qe/lghtron there, without noting a variant.] The objection to ste/rghma from the form is not, then, decisive. As to sense, ste/rghqron, like fi/ltron, is ‘an instrument for producing love’; while ste/rghma, like fi/lhma, ought to denote an effect. But here, again, we must allow for the freedom of poetical diction. The analogy of kh/lhma, ‘a spell’ ( Eur. Tro.893), by the side of kh/lhqron (Bek ker Anecd. p. 46. 25), is not a strict one, since kh/lhma is properly, ‘an effect of charming’; still, such an analogy may have influenced a poet who found ste/rghma more convenient than ste/rghqron. Hyllus presently refers to this charm as toiw=|de fi/ltrw| (1142): which rather suggests that a word in the sing. number was used here also. Cp. 575 khlhth/rion: 685 fa/rmakon. (In 584 f. the plurals fi/ltrois, qe/lktroisi describe the class of remedy: they do not directly denote the unguent.) For these reasons I refrain from changing ste/rghma, with Nauck, to ste/rghqra.
se/qen, objective gen. with ste/rghma.

dokou=sa, imperf. partic. ( Ant.166 n.), =o(/te e)do/kei. The position of the clause, w(s prosei=de tou\s e)/ndon ga/mous, which would properly precede a)ph/mplake, is made possible by the strong emphasis on ste/rghma...dokou=sa prosbalei=n: ‘It was a love-charm that she thought to apply (though she failed), when she saw,’ etc. The leading idea of the sentence is here expressed by the participial clause (592 n.).

tou\s e)/ndon ga/mous: cp. 843 ne/wn...ga/mwn, and 460 (n. on e)/ghme). ‘The new union (=the new paramour) in the house there,’—a way of indicating Iolè, whom he abhors (1233), without naming her. Cp. the euphemistic th=s...kat' oi)/kous in O. T.1447.—The new turn given to the thoughts of Heracles by vv. 1141 f. averts them wholly from Deianeira; and he speaks no word of pardon.
kai\ gives a scornful tone to the question: cp. O. C.263 n.
tosou=tos, so potent: Plat. Symp. 177C tosou=tos qeo/s.
e)kmh=nai: cp. Ar. Eccl.965*ku/pri, ti/ m' e)kmai/neis e)pi\ tau/th|;
i)ou\ i)ou\, as in O. T.1071(Iocasta) O. T., 1182(Oedipus).
du/sthnos: for the nom., cp. 986.

oi)/xomai. From the beginning of his torments, Heracles has felt that they could end only in death (cp. 802: 1001: 1111). Why, then, should he now speak as if he realised his state for the first time? The answer seems to be that, though the ultimate prospect is unchanged, his doom acquires a new terror in the light of its supernatural source. Hitherto he has believed himself the victim of human malice: it might leave no hope, but still it fixed no term. Now he knows that he is in the grip of a)na/gkh: his moments are numbered. Henceforth he thinks only of the end.

fe/ggos ou)ke/t' e)/sti moi: cp. Theocr. 1. 102 h)/dh ga\r fra/sdh| pa/nq' a(/lion a)/mmi dedukei=n.—cumfora=s i(/n) e(/stamen: cp. 375 n.: O. T.1442i(/n' e(/stamen | xrei/as.—i)/q), w( te/knon: for the pause, and the absence of caesura, cp. 27 n.
ka/lei … ka/lei de\: cp. Ant.806 n.
o(maimo/nwn, brethren ( O. C.330 n.): Hyllus was the eldest of the family (56).
*)alkmh/nhn: 1105 n.

ma/thn, since Zeus had been cruel to her son. Cp. Eur. H. F.339(quoted by Wakefield), where her mortal husband, Amphitryon, says, with the same meaning, w)= *zeu=, ma/thn a)/r' o(mo/gamo/n s' e)kthsa/mhn.

teleutai/an … fh/mhn … qesfa/twn, my last (dying) utterance of them. Cp. O. T.723fh=mai mantikai/: ib. 86 tou= qeou= fh/mhn fe/rwn. e)mou= with pu/qhsqe: cp. O. T.333ou) ga\r a)\n pu/qoio/ mou. The schol. wrongly took e)mou= with tel. fh/mhn, as= th\n peri\ th=s teleuth=s mou fh/mhn.

The oracles can be only the two which are told to Hyllus (1159—1171). If there had been others, they also must have been confided to him, as representing the absent kinsfolk. Heracles wishes to gather his family around him at a solemn farewell,—to convince them, by the qe/sfata, that he is in the hand of Zeus,—and, with that sanction, to lay his last commands upon them all.
a)ll' … a)ll): cp. Ph.524 n.
ou)/te is followed by de\ (1153), as in Aesch. Suppl.223 ff., Xen. An.6. 3. 16(=6. 1. 16 of some edd.), Plat. Rep. 389A, etc. Cp. 143 n.
e)pakti/a| *ti/runqi: see on 270.

sumbe/bhken, impers., it has come to pass: the subject to e)/xein (au)th/n) can easily be supplied, and the whole phrase =tugxa/nei e(/dran e)/xousa. — For w(/ste, cp. Arist. Pol.2. 2. 5kai\ sumbai/nei dh\ to\n tro/pon tou=ton w(/ste pa/ntas a)/rxein.— Not, ‘she has come to terms (with Eurystheus), so that she should dwell,’ etc.

Sophocles glances here at parts of the story which do not come within the scope of the play. Alcmena, daughter of Electryon king of Mycenae, had been betrothed to her first cousin, Amphitryon, son of Alcaeus king of Tiryns. Amphitryon accidentally killed his uncle, Electryon, and then fled from Tiryns to Thebes with his betrothed. At Thebes Alcmena bore Heracles to Zeus. Heracles afterwards went to Argolis and served Eurystheus,—with the hope that his toils would purchase a return to Tiryns for the exiled Amphitryon and Alcmena ( Eur. H. F.19). When these toils were over, Heracles dwelt in freedom at Tiryns with his family, including Alcmena,—Amphitryon being dead ( Diod.4. 33). He afterwards slew Iphitus, and then sought a refuge for his household at Trachis (39). But, in the course of the fifteen months since he departed for Lydia, Alcmena had returned to Tiryns, (Eurystheus having no cause to fear the aged widow,)—and had taken some of her grandchildren with her, in order to lighten the burden on the hospitality of Ceÿx.— cullabou=s), here simply=labou=sa meq' e(auth=s: cp. O. T.971 n.

to\ *qh/bhs a)/stu. Thebes, the birthplace of Heracles (116), and his early home (510), was a place where some of his children might well find friends. Sophocles has perhaps taken a hint here from his elder contemporary, the logographer Pherecydes, who related that, after the death of Eurystheus, Thebes became the home of the Heracleidae; fr. 39 (Müller Frag. Hist. 1. p. 82) *(/ullos de\ kai\ oi( a)/lloi *(hraklei=dai kai\ oi( su\n au)toi=s a)poqano/ntos *eu)rusqe/ws katoiki/zontai pa/lin e)n *qh/bais.—a)\n … ma/qois: sc. ei) pu/qoio: since he has been so long abroad.

o(/soi pa/resmen. The plural includes those who had accompanied Heracles from Euboea: cp. 1194 cu\n oi(=s xrh/|zeis fi/lwn. We are not obliged to suppose that any son besides Hyllus was at home; though verses 54 f. implied that. Nauck rejects v. 1156 because (1) Hyllus could not say o(/soi, and (2) Heracles has not yet asked him to do anything.
e)cuphreth/somen: cp. O. T.217 n.

su\ d' ou)=n a)/koue: there is no emphasis on su/ (as if it referred to the absence of the others): rather the sense is, ‘Well, then (since you are ready to help), hear the task.’ For this use of d' ou)=n, cp. O. T.669 n.

tou)/rgon=o(/ ti draste/on e)stin: cp. Ph.26tou)/rgon ou) makra\n le/geis.—e)ch/keis, you have reached a point, a situation: cp. O. T.1515a(/lis i(/n' e)ch/keis dakru/wn: ib. 1158 ei)s to/d' h(/ceis. —e)mo\s without pai=s: cp. 1205: Ai.547ei)/per dikai/ws e)/st' e)mo\s ta\ patro/qen. The stress falls on the participial clause (592 n.).
ga\r is merely prefatory.

pro/fanton e)k patro\s: this oracle, given by Zeus at an unspecified time, and place, is not mentioned elsewhere in the play. Nor is it noticed by any other writer. Sophocles may, however, have found it in some earlier treatment of the fable.

tw=n e)mpneo/ntwn, Erfurdt's correction of pro\s tw=n pneo/ntwn, is the most probable. e)mpnei=n as=zh=n ( Ph.883) is frequent, while pnei=n has that sense only in the Homeric pnei/ei te kai\ e(/rpei ( Il.17. 447, Od.18. 131). u(/po might, no doubt, have arisen from po[te/], but is presumably genuine: it closes a verse in 1077, O. T.949, Ph.334 Ph., 583, El.553: and it is associated with qnh/|skw in O. T.1246, Ph.334, El.444.The combination of pro/s with u(po/ cannot be defended as=‘to be slain by no one on the part of (pro/s) the living.’ Paley, quoting Eur. Or.407e)k fasma/twn de\ ta/de nosei=s poi/wn u(/po; describes fantasma/twn as Nauck's conjecture; but that word stands in most of the more recent MSS., and in Porson's text.
a)ll' o(/stis: for the ellipse of the antecedent (e)kei/nou), cp. Ai.1050dokou=nt' e)moi/, dokou=nta d' o(\s krai/nei stratou=. Eur. Ion560h)= qi/gw dh=q' oi(/ m' e)/fusan;—*(/aidou … oi)kh/twr: 282.

o(/stis … pe/loi: if we suppose that Nessus was alive when Zeus spoke, then this is oblique for o(/stis a)\n pe/lh|, as O. T.714(in a prophecy) o(/stis ge/noit) for o(/stis a)\n ge/nhtai. But if Nessus was then dead, it is oblique for o(/stis pe/lei.
qh\r (556) is in appos. with *ke/ntauros.
zw=nta/ m' e)/kteinen qanw/n: as the dead Hector brought death on Ajax ( Ai.1027). For other examples of this favourite antithesis, cp. O. T.1453 n.: Ant.871 n.: Ai.901: El.808.

tou/toisi k.t.l. The mantei=a kaina\ denote the oracle given at Dodona twelve years before this time, saying that at the end of the twelfth year Heracles should have rest. This is the oracle to which allusion was made in 44, 164 ff., 824 ff. The other and earlier oracle (1159 ff.) had predicted the agency: this Dodonaean oracle, ‘recent’ in a relative sense, predicted the time. The two oracles ‘agree,’ because each verifies the other. The thing has come to pass by the right agency at the right time.

sumbai/nont' i)/sa, ‘coming out in agreement with them,’—yielding the same result,—viz., that this is the predicted end. For sumbai/nein, cp. 173 n. The idea is emphatically repeated in toi=s pa/lai cunh/gora, ‘pleading on the side of the older oracle,’—upholding its truth. Cp. 814 cunhgorei=s.

a(\ tw=n o)rei/wn k.t.l. The *sellw=n a)/lsos is the sacred precinct at Dodona, including the temple of Zeus, with its temenos; its limits have been traced by Carapanos (Dodone, pp. 16— 23): see Appendix, note on this passage, § 2.

The name *selloi/, or *(elloi/ (akin to *(/ellhn, *(ella/s), denoted a prehistoric tribe, dwelling at and around Dodona: see Appendix, § 4. The priests of Zeus, furnished by this tribe, are said to have been called to/mouroi, from Mount Tomāros (Orphic Argon. 268 *tomari/as e)/klue fhgo/s), which towers above Dodona on W.S.W. In early times these priests were the direct interpreters of the oracle; hence the *selloi/ are called u(pofh=tai in Il.16. 235.Afterwards, when the cult of Dionè was associated with that of Zeus, the office of interpretation was transferred to the priestesses called Peleiades (172: Strabo 7. 329). Here, as in 171 f., the poet says that the oak gave the oracle; but he does not here mention the expositors. He mentions the *selloi/ only to define the a)/lsos.
o)rei/wn refers to the site of Dodona in a valley, more than 1600 feet above sea-level, surrounded by hills. See Appendix, § 1.

xamaikoitw=n, a trait of barbarism, surviving as a mark of sanctity. According to Philostratus (Imag. 2. 33), the Selli were ‘men of a rude life’ (au)tosxe/dioi/ tines), who held that their austerities were pleasing to Zeus. Cp. Il.16. 235a)nipto/podes xamaieu=nai: Eur. fr. 355 e)n a)strw/tw| pe/dw| | eu(/dousi, phgai=s d' ou)x u(grai/nousin po/das. Callimachus Del.284 calls them *pelasgoi\...ghlexe/es.

ei)segraya/mhn, i.e., wrote for his own use in the de/ltos (157). Cp. Her.8. 135, where Greeks accompany the Carian Mŷs on his visit to the oracle of Apollo at Ptôon, w(s a)pograyome/nous ta\ qespiei=n e)/melle: then Mŷs snatches the de/ltos from them, and makes an abstract for himself (suggraya/menon). Ar. Av.982(xrhsmo\s) o(\n e)gw\ para\ ta)po/llwnos e)cegraya/mhn. At Dodona, in later times at least, the inquirer gave his question in writing to the Peleiades, and received a written answer: many of the leaden plates thus used have been found (Carapanos, pp. 68—83): Appendix, § 6.

xro/nw| tw=| zw=nti: the past can be described as dead ( Ai.141th=s nu=n fqime/nhs nukto/s); the future, as unborn ( O. C.618xro/nos teknou=tai...h(me/ras); the present is here called zw=n, not merely in the sense of parw/n, but with the thought that this is the moment for the oracle to become operative.
e)festw/twn, ‘imposed’ as a doom: cp. Il.12. 326kh=res e)festa=sin qana/toio.—telei=sqai, fut., with pass. sense, as in Od.23. 284, etc.

to\ d) refers to lu/sin telei=sqai: ‘but that (the promised release) was, it seems, only my death.’ Cp. Plat. Rep. 357A e)gw\ me\n ou)=n...w)/mhn lo/gou a)phlla/xqai: to\ d' h)=n a)/ra, w(s e)/oike, prooi/mion.— qanei=n: for the simple aor. inf., though the ref. is to the future, cp. Soph. Ph.503paqei=n (n.).
sumbai/nei, are coming true: cp. 173 n.

e)pimei=nai … o)cu=nai, to wait on, (so as) to sharpen. (In Thuc.3. 26, e)pime/nontes...peu/sesqai, the fut. inf. stands as after prosdokw=ntes: it does not, like o)cu=nai here, express the result.) Cp. Soph. Ai.584glw=ssa/ sou teqhgme/nh. For the aor. inf. of e)pime/nw, cp. Hom. Od.11. 350tlh/tw... | ...e)pimei=nai e)s au)/rion. The delay is viewed as a whole, not as a process.— Others, less well, make sto/ma the subject to o)cu=nai: ‘Do not wait for my words to goad thee.’
au)to\n, of thine own accord.
ei)kaqo/nta: as to these forms, see O.T. 651 n.

e)ceuro/nta is illustrated by the words au)to\n ei)kaqo/nta. He is not to wait until this law has been brought home to his mind by a rebuke. He is to ‘find it out’ in the light of his own reason. eu(ri/skein often expresses the result of reflection. O. T.441<*>au=t) o)nei/diz) oi(=s e)/m) eu(rh/seis me/gan (i.e., when you look deeper). Her.7. 194logizo/menos o( *darei=os eu)=re/ oi( ple/w a)gaqa\ tw=n a(marthma/twn pepoihme/na: id. 1. 125 fronti/zwn de\ eu(/riske/ te (v. l. eu(ri/sketai) tau=ta kairiw/tata ei)=nai, kai\ e)poi/ee dh\ tau=ta.
Cp. Eur. fr. 219 trei=s ei)sin a)retai\ ta\s xrew/n s' a)skei=n, te/knon, | qeou/s te tima=n tou/s te qre/yantas gonei=s | no/mous te koinou\s *(ella/dos.
a)ll), w)= pa/ter: a)lla\ here prefaces assent, as Ph.48 Ph., 524.

tarbw= me\n k.t.l. The sense is: ‘I am alarmed, indeed, at the issue to which you have brought me,—a choice between disobedience, and a blind promise; but I will obey.’ lo/gou sta/sin toia/nde, ‘such a situation in our converse’: e)pelqw/n, ‘having advanced,’ i.e., having been drawn on to it, by the progress of the dialogue. It may be noted that the sing. lo/gou suits this sense of sta/sis: if the meaning had been, ‘strife of words’ (the sta/sis glw/sshs of O.T. 634), we should have expected rather the plur. lo/gwn, as in Soph. Ph.1460ei)s e)/rin lo/gwn. For this general sense of sta/sis, status, cp. Phaedr. p. 253 D o(...e)n th=| kalli/oni sta/sei w)/n.

Throughout the dialogue (1114—1156), Hyllus has been gentle and respectful. If, then, sta/sin means ‘strife,’ e)pelqw/n must mean merely, ‘having advanced up to it,’ i.e., ‘come to the verge of it.’ But the clause with me/n, opposed to pe<*>somai de/, ought to express something which tells against obedience (as the fear of a blind promise does); not something which tells in favour of it, as the fear of strife would do. The same objection applies to conjecturing e)pelqei=n (‘I am afraid of being drawn into such a strife’).
e)/mballe: see on Ph.813e)/mballe xeiro\s pi/stin.
w(s pro/s ti/: w(s=‘in your intention’: cp. O. T.1174w(s pro\s ti/ xrei/as; Ph. 58 plei=s d' w(s pro\s oi)=kon.

e)pistre/feis: the primary notion is that of turning some constraining force upon a person,—bringing it to bear on him: so, ‘press,’ ‘urge,’ upon him: schol. e)pa/geis moi. It is a stronger equiv. for e)piskh/pteis.—Not, ‘regard’ (Musgrave): this would be pi/stews e)pistre/fei (midd.).

ou) qa=sson k.t.l.: Ai.75ou) si=g' a)ne/cei mhde\ deili/an a)rei=; O.T. 637 ou)k ei)= su/ t' oi)/kous su/ te, *kre/on, kata\ ste/gas, | kai\ mh\ to\ mhde
 a)/lgos ei)s me/g' oi)/sete; Eur. Bacch.343ou) mh\ prosoi/seis xei=ra, bakxeu/seis d' i)w/n, | mhd' e)como/rcei mwri/an th
 sh
 e)moi/; ib. 792 ou) mh\ frenw/seis m), a)lla\ de/smios fugw
 | sw/sei to/d); For ou) mh\ with fut. ind., cp. 978.
oi)/seis, sc. xei=ra decia\n: but the choice of the verb may have been influenced by pi/stin.
o)/mnu … ka/ra: so o)mnu/nai qeou/s, *stugo\s u(/dwr ( Il.14. 271), pe/don ( Eur. Med.746), etc.

e)ceirh/setai; This is clearly the right punctuation; for Hyllus is most anxious to know what will be asked of him. Heracles evades the question by replying, to\ lexqe
 e)/rgon,—i.e., o(\ a)
 lexqh=|: just as in Ai.528, e)a
 mo/non to\ taxqe
 eu)= tolma=| telei=n, the partic.=o(\ a)
 taxqh=|.—With a full stop at e)ceirh/setai, the sense would be merely, ‘and this promise shall be given.’
e)pw/moton (427) here = o(/rkion (schol.), to\n o(/rkou e)gguhth/n ( Suid. s. v.). Cp. Soph. Ph.1324*zh=na d' o(/rkion kalw= (n.).

e)kto\s e)/lqois, sc. tou= o(/rkou; cp. Plat. Symp. 183B e)kba/nti to
 o(/rkon.— phmona\s eu)/xou labei=n: the usual sanction of a solemn oath; cp. Lys. or. 12 § 10 w)/mosen e)cw/leian e(autw=| kai\ toi=s paisi
 e)parw/menos, labw
 to\ ta/lanto/n me sw/sein.
ou) mh\ la/bw: for the pause cp. 1146.

to\n *oi)/ths *zhno\s … pa/gon; cp. Ph.489ta\ *xalkw/dontos *eu)boi/as staqma/. The change of u(/yiston to u(yi/stou is a plausible one. Pausanias mentions statues of *zeu\s *(/uyistos at Corinth (2. 2. 8), Olympia (5. 15. 5), and Thebes (9. 8. 5); the title occurs, too, in an Attic inscr. (C. I. G. 497—506), and was frequent in poetry. I prefer, however, to keep the reading of the MSS., because, here, we seem to need an epithet for pa/gon rather than for the god. Cp. 436 tou= kat' a)/kron *oi)tai=on na/pos | *dio\s katastra/ptontos.

The place traditionally known as the ‘Pyre’ was probably somewhere near ‘the proper summit of Oeta’ (Leake, Northern Greece, vol. II. pp. 19 f.), now Mount Patriótiko, about eight miles W.N.W. of Trachis. A Pyra is marked in Kiepert's Atlas von Hellas (ed. 1872, map 5), where the greatest height of Oeta is given as 2152 mètres, or about 7055 ft. It is mentioned by Theophr. Hist. Plant. 9. 10. 2 (th=s *oi(/ths a)mfi\ th\n *pura/n): cp. Liv.36. 30, and Soph. Ph.1432.
quth/r (613), slightly emphasised by ge, implies that he is familiar with the place.
staqei\s: cp. 608.

e)ntau=qa properly refers to e)mbalei=n (1197), but, since the inf. is so long delayed, is more conveniently taken with e)ca/ranta, in the sense of e)ntauqoi=: cp. El.380e)ntau=qa pe/myein. For the sense of e)ca/ranta, cp. 799 a)=ron e)/cw.
kai\ can be prefixed to cu\n oi(=s, k.t.l., since au)to/xeira implies tai=s seautou= xersi/.

The pyre is to be built with (1) oak, sacred to Zeus (1168); and (2) the wild olive, which Heracles himself had brought to Greece: Paus.5. 7. 7komisqh=nai de\ e)k th=s *(uperbore/wn gh=s to\n ko/tino/n fasin u(po\ tou= *(hrakle/ous e)s *(/ellhnas. Pindar, in treating that legend, uses the generic word, e)lai/a, O. 3. 13. Pliny H. N. 16. 89 Olympiae oleaster, ex quo primus Hercules coronatus est: where he also mentions that, near Heracleia in Pontus, were quercus duae ab Hercule satae.

kei/ranta, like Il.24. 450dou=r' e)la/ths ke/rsantes. In Attic prose, kei/rein, ‘to shear,’ is said only of cutting off hair, or devastating land. The prose word here would be ko/yanta.—e)ktemo/nq), cutting it from the stump, close to the ground: Il.12. 148a)/gnuton u(/lhn, | prumnh\n e)kta/mnontes (‘at the root’). In Lys. or. 7 § 19 e)ce/temnon ta\ pre/mna refers to cutting the roots of an olive out of the ground.— a)/grion e)/laion: the ko/tinos was also called a)/grios e)/laios ( Pind. fr. 21), a)grie/laios, or a)grielai/a. The epithet a)/rsena expresses its sturdy vigour. Acc. to Theophrastus (Hist. Plant. 4. 13) the ko/tinos lives longer than the e)lai/a. Ovid says, Ure mares oleas (Fast.4. 741).

pollo
=polu/n, as Ant.86pollo
=polu/: the only instance of this Ionic form in tragedy.— sw=ma tou)mo
 is repeated, the sentence having become so long: cp. nin in 289, after e)kei=non.
peuki/nhs: cp. 766 piei/ras druo/s (n.).

prh=sai, made emphatic by place and pause: cp. Ant.72qa/yw.— go/ou … da/kru, the tear that belongs to, accompanies, lamentation; as da/krua and go/oi are so often associated ( Eur. Or.320, I. T. 860, etc.). (Not, ‘a mournful tear,’ as opp. to da/kru xara=s.)

ei)si/tw, abs., ‘come in,’ ‘find a place’ there: cp. Phaedr. p. 270 A to\ ga\r u(yhlo/noun tou=to...e)/oiken e)nteu=qe/n poqen ei)sie/n<*>. We ought not to supply se, as if the sense were, ‘come into thy thoughts’ ( Phaedop. 58 E ou)/te...me...e)/leos ei)sh/|ei).

The ordinary e)kfora/ was attended by wailing; but these obsequies, like those of the priests in Legg. 947 B, were to be xwri\s qrh/nwn kai\ o)durmw=n. Cp. Manoah's words in Samson Agonistes (1708), ‘Come, come; no time for lamentation now.’
a)ste/naktos: cp: 1074.— ei)/per ei)= k.t.l.: cp. 1158.

menw= s' e)gw\ k.t.l., ‘I will await thee with my curse’; i.e., ‘my curse will be in store for thee,’ attending on thee thenceforth. (Not merely, ‘I will await thee in the nether world,’ to punish thee when thou comest <*>hither.) Cp. 1240 qew=n a)ra\ | menei= s). So Ant.1075loxw=sin...*)erinu/es.—a)rai=os, here, ‘bringing a curse’: cp. I. T. 778 h= soi=s a)rai/a dw/masin genh/somai. (But in O.T. 1291, ‘under a curse’).
ei)saei\, because the power of the Erinyes over a mortal did not end with his life: it was their part, o(martei=n, o)/fr' a)\n | ga=n u(pe/lqh|: qanw\n d' ou)k a)/gan e)leu/qeros. ( Aesch. Eum.340.)
baru/s, as in O. T.546dusmenh= te kai\ baru/n.

1203 The hiatus ti/ ei)=pas is supported by the MSS. here, but appears as uncongenial to the poet's style as in Ph.917, oi)/moi, ti/ ei)=pas; Here, as there, ti/ m' ei)=pas seems inadmissible. It could mean only, ‘What hast thou said of me?’ —and we can hardly justify this as meaning, ‘hast thou said that, if I refuse, I shall be no true son?’ The alternative is to insert d): cp. O.C. 332 te/knon, ti/ d' h)=lqes; See Append. on Ph.100.
o(poi=a draste/) e)sti/n, sc. ei)=pon. The reply passes over ei)/rgasai, and refers to ei)=pas: cp. 423, where polloi=sin a)stw=n answers the earlier of two queries.

ei) de\ mh/, sc. dra/seis.—gen<*>u=, ‘become’, as if by adoption (ei)spoi/hsis) into another family. Cp. Lys. or. 13 § 91 to/n te go/nw| pate/ra...to/n te poihto\n pate/ra. So Oedipus to Polyneices, O.C. 1383 su\ d' e)/rr' a)po/ptusto/s te ka)pa/twr e)mou=.
oi(=a/ m' e)kkalei=, ‘what dost thou call upon me to do.’ For the double acc., cp. Euthyphr. 5 A au)ta\ tau=ta prokalei=sqai au)to/n.

palamnai=on is not weak after fone/a, because, as used in poetry, it often implies the defilement (a)/gos) of blood-guiltiness,—meaning, ‘accursed wretch,’ rather than merely ‘slayer.’ Cp. Aesch. Eum.448a)/fqoggon ei)=nai to\n palamnai=on no/mos, k.t.l. Hence, like mia/stwr, it can denote also the avenger of guilt ( I. T. 1218). Photius had this in view when he explained palamnai=os by foneu\s h)\ miaro/s. Properly the word means merely ‘a man of violent hand’: cp. Ph.1206pala/man, n.
ou) dh=t' e)/gwg), a)ll): the same formula as in O. T.1161, Ph.735.

w(=n e)/xw (kakw=n) paiw/nion refers more especially to bodily sufferings; while i)ath=ra tw=n e)mw=n kakw=n is rather, ‘physician of my woes’ generally. After w(=n e)/xw, tw=n e)mw=n is awkward; but it is partly excused (1) by the slight pause which might follow paiw/nion, and (2) by the emphasis on i)ath=ra. It might, indeed, be suggested that kakw=n belongs to tw=n e)mw=n only, while w(=n e)/xw should be taken separately, ‘what I suffer’: this, however, is less natural. Hermann's emendation, w(s e)/xw (‘considering my state’), is possible, but slightly weak.
fobei= pro\s tou=to: cp. O.T. 980 su\ d' ei)s ta\ mhtro\s mh\ fobou= numfeu/mata.
fqo/nhsis is found only here. Cp. Plat Phaedo61D a(\...tugxa/nw a)khkow/s, fqo/nos ou)dei\s le/gein. Ion530D ou) fqonh/seis moi e)pidei=cai.

plh/rwma (nom.), sc. genh/setai: —cp. Eur. Hec.574oi( de\ plhrou=sin pura/n, | kormou\s fe/rontes peuki/nous. Though plh/rwsis would have been more natural, plh/rwma, expressing the result, is equally correct here.

1214 (plhrw/sw), o(/son ge (plhrw/saim)) a)\n mh\ potiy.: cp. O. T.347ei)rga/sqai q), o(/son | mh\ xersi\ kai/nwn (sc. ei)=xes ei)rga/sqai). Hyllus will help to hew the wood, but not to build the pyre. The pyre was kindled by Philoctetes, or, acc. to another version, by Poeas ( Ph.802 n.).— potiyau/wn: tragic lyrics admit poti/ (fr. 225), and its compounds (1030 a)poti/batos: Aesch. Theb.94potipe/sw, etc.). But tragic dialogue presents no other example, except Aesch. Eum.79poti\ pto/lin.

kou) kamei=, 2nd pers. sing. midd., thou shalt have no difficulty, tou)mo\n me/ros, on my part (acc. of respect: cp. Ant.1062to\ so\n me/ros, n.).—Most editors take kamei= as 3rd pers. sing. act.: ‘and my part of the work shall not flag.’ But kamou=mai is the regular fut.: indeed, the only trace of the act. form is in Hesych., kamw=: e)rga/somai.

a)rke/sei kai\ tau=ta, even this: so Ph.339oi)=mai me\n a)rkei=n soi/ ge kai\ ta\ s), w)= ta/las, | a)lgh/maq).—pro/sneimai: the midd. is noteworthy, as we should have expected pro/sneimon: cp., however, Ar. Av.563prosnei/masqai de\ prepo/ntws | toi=si qeoi=sin tw=n o)rni/qwn o)\s a)\n a(rmo/tth| kaq' e(/kaston,—where, as here, the act. might have been expected. The accentuation prosnei=mai (cr. n.) represents a wish to read the aor. inf. act. as an imperative.
braxei=an, small (O.C. 586 n.): makroi=s, large ( Ai.130, etc.).
didou/s, sc. au)ta/: cp. O. C.475neopo/kw| mallw=| labw/n (n.).
*eu)rutei/an: cp. O. T.267tw=| *labdakei/w| paidi/ (n.).
parqe/non, an unmarried woman: cp. 1225.

e)peika/zein has here much better authority than a)peika/zein: cp. 141 n.— w(/s g), as a correction of w(/st), is preferable to w(s, not only as accounting for t), but because e)me/ is added: cp. Eur. Alc.801w(/s g' e)moi\ xrh=sqai krith=|: Plut. 736 w(/s g' e)moi\ dokei=n.
e)piskh/ptw with double acc., like keleu/w tina/ ti: so I.T. 701 pro\s decia=s de th=sd' e)piskh/ptw ta/de.
patrw/|wn o(rki/wn, the oath imposed on thee by thy father.
prosqou=, associate with thyself: cp. O. C.404 n.
da/marta. This passage concerning Iolè and Hyllus (1216—1251) was rendered indispensable by the plot, if the poet was to avoid a contradiction which must otherwise have perplexed the spectators.

Iolè figured in legend as the wife of Hyllus. Their son, *kleodai=os (called *kleoda/ths by Theopompus, fr. 30), was mentioned by Hesiod (schol. Ap. Rh. 1. 824), and was recorded in the pedigree of the Spartan kings, being the grandfather of Aristodemus ( Her.6. 52Her., 8. 131). Hyllus and Iolè had also a daughter, *eu)ai/xmh, known in Messenian story ( Paus.4. 2. 1).

But, in this play, Iolè is the paramour of Heracles, and indirectly the cause of his death. How, then, could Hyllus wed her? His own words (1233—1237) express what a Greek would feel. It was necessary, then, that the marriage should be imposed upon him by his dying father's inexorable command.

Cp. Apollodorus 2. 7. 7 § 13 e)nteila/menos *(/ullw|...th\n *)io/lhn a)ndrwqe/nta gh=mai: as if Hyllus were younger than Sophocles here imagines him. Ovid, Met.9. 278, of Iolè: Herculis illam | Imperiis thalamoque animoque receperat Hyllus. Acc. to Pherecydes, it was for Hyllus, not for himself, that Heracles had first asked the hand of Iolè (schol. on v. 354).
a)llos … a)nti\ sou=: cp. Ai.444ou)k a)/n tis au)/t' e)/maryen a)/llos a)nt' e)mou=.—o(mou=, prep. with dat., in the sense of ‘near’ (O.T. 1007), a specially Attic use ( Ph.1218Append.).
la/bh|, in this command, is clearly right: the mere wish, la/boi, would be unsuitable. Cp. 331 n.
a)ll' au)to/s, k.t.l.: this third clause reiterates the sense of the first, prosqou= da/marta: cp. 433 n.

tou=to … le/xos=tou=to kh=dos, cogn. acc. to kh/deuson (‘contract this marriage’): cp. Arist. Pol.5. 7. 10khdeu/ein o(/tw| qe/lwsin.— Not, ‘cherish this bride,’ as in Eur. Med.888khdeu/ousan is said of Medea ‘tending’ Iason's new wife.
piqou=, not pei/qou: it is a peremptory summons: cp. 470 n.
pisteu/sant)=piqo/menon, as in 1251. These are perhaps the only clear examples of pisteu/w as=‘to obey,’ though a)pistei=n as=a)peiqei=n was frequent.

e)moi\, not moi, because the pron., though it has no strong emphasis, implies, ‘to me, your father.’ A son's obedience should be complete.— smikroi=s, dat. of respect: cp. Ph.342pra=gm), o(/tw| s' e)nu/brisan: Eur. fr. 1051 xrh/masin lelei/mmeqa.—sugxei=, obliterates, as if it had been traced in sand: cp. Soph. O. C.609 n.

to\ me
 nosou=nti k.t.l. Cp. 543 ff. qumou=sqai me
 ou)k e)pi/stamai | nosou=nti kei/nw|... | to\ d' au)= cunoikei=n th=|d' o(mou= ti/s a)
 gunh\ | du/naito...;—w(=de … fronou=nta, in a state of mind so deplorable as is argued by the bare suggestion of such a marriage. This is not an ‘aside’; but the speaker's amazement precludes a direct reply.
w(s e)rgasei/wn: cp. O.T. 625 w(s ou)x u(pei/cwn ou)de\ pisteu/swn le/geis; For the desiderative verb, see Ph.1001 n.

ti/s ga/r poq), the indignant exordium, is immediately followed by the relative clause concerning Iolè, h(/ having a causal force,—as we might say, ‘What! when she...’ etc. Cp. n. on O. C.263ka)/moige pou= tau=t' e)sti/n; oi(/tines ba/qrwn k.t.l. Then, instead of tau/thn or th/nde, as antecedent to h(/, the speaker bitterly says, tau=t), ‘all this,’—the horrors which, for him, are embodied in Iolè. Cp. O. T.1492a)ll' h(ni/k' a)\n dh\ pro\s ga/mwn h(/kht a)kma/s, | ti/s ou(=tos e)/stai, ti/s pararri/yei, te/kna, | toiau=t' o)nei/dh lamba/nwn; It would miserably enfeeble the passage to alter tau=t).
The ethic dat. moi implies, ‘as I have seen.’
qanei=n, without tou=: cp. Ant.1173ai)/tioi qanei=n (n.): mo/nh metai/tios means that she alone shared the blame with Heracles (cp. 260 n.).
soi\ d) is more probable than soi/ t) here, where the antithesis is marked.
w(s e)/xeis e)/xein: Dem. or. 3 § 8 e)xo/ntwn w(s e)/xousi *qhbai/wn: Soph. O. C.273i(ko/mhn i(/n' i(ko/mhn: O.T. 13<*> n.

o(/stis mh\ … nosoi=: the optat., on a<*> count of e(/loit' a)/n: the relative clause is equiv. in sense to a protasis, ei) mh\ nosoi=: see on O. C.560.For the form nosoi= (instead of nosoi/h), Ph.895 n.
a)lasto/rwn: O. C.788 n. Such a marriage would imply that some a)/th had deranged his mind ( Ant.622).
toi=sin e)xqi/stoisi: cp. O. T.366toi=s filta/tois (Iocasta): El.594e)xqroi=s gamei=sqai (Aegisthus).
o(mou= added to sunnai/ein, as in 545 to cunoikei=n.

w(s e)/oiken, ou) nemei=n, instead of ou) nemei=. The verb which ought to have been principal is attracted into the relative clause. Cp. Her.4. 5w(s de\ *sku/qai le/gousi, new/taton a(pa/ntwn e)qne/wn ei)=nai (instead of e)sti\) to\ sfe/teron. Id. 6. 137w(s de\ au)toi\ *)aqhnai=oi le/gousi, dikai/ws e)cela/sai (instead of e)ch/lasan). Sophist. 263 D panta/pasin, w(s e)/oiken, h( toiau/th su/nqesis...gi/gnesqai (instead of gi/gnetai) lo/gos yeudh/s. Phileb.20D to/de ge mh/n, w(s oi)=mai, peri\ au)tou= a)nagkaio/taton ei)=nai (instead of e)sti\) le/gein [for ei)=nai can hardly depend on the word a)na/gkh higher up]. I. T. 52 kaqei=nai (instead of kaqh=ke) after w(s e)/doce. But Aesch. Pers.188tou/tw sta/sin tin), w(s e)gw\ )do/koun o(ra=n, | teu/xein, is more complex, as the fusion is between (1) e)do/koun (3rd plur.) teu/xein, and (2) e)/teuxon, w(s e)gw\ e)do/koun o(ra=n. In Latin, too, this natural laxity occurs: Offic. 1. 7 § 22 ut placet Stoicis, quae in terris gignantur ad usum hominum omnia creari (instead of creantur).
Paley would get rid of the irregularity by making w(s exclamatory (‘how!’): but this is impossible. The text is clearly sound, though it has been much suspected (cr. n.).
nemei=n … moi=ran: moi=ra is the share of respect due to a person: cp. Plat. Crat. 398C mega/lhn moi=ran kai\ timh\n e)/xei: and Soph. O. C.277Append. For nemei=n, cp. 57 ne/moi...w)/ran.

qew=n a)ra\ (like qew=n *)erinues, Ant.1075), —the vengeance sent by the gods, in answer to the father's imprecation (1202). In this objective sense, the Curse is itself the agent of retribution: cp. O. T.418deino/pous a)ra/: Aesch. Theb.70*)ara/ t), *)erinu\s patro\s h( megasqenh/s: and the Eumenides call themselves *)arai/ ( Aesch. Eum.417). Sometimes, again, the *)ara/ is distinguished from the power which it calls into action: Soph. El.111po/tni) *)ara/, | semnai/ te qew=n pai=des *)erinu/es. A transition from the latter idea to the former may be seen in Soph. O. C.1375 f., where Oed. summons his own imprecations to be his cumma/xous.

w(s e)/oikas (instead of w(s e)/oiken), as in El.516: so Helen. 497 w(s ei)/casin.—fra/seis, wilt ‘show,’ ‘make it clear’ (by acts, or words, or both). After such words—Hyllus means—some violent outburst of madness may be expected. fra/zein, ‘to declare,’ does not necessarily imply speech: Her.4. 113fwnh=sai me\n ou)k ei)=xe, ou) ga\r suni/esan a)llh/lwn, th=| de\ xeiri\ e)/fraze. Aesch. Ag.1061su\ d' a)nti\ fwnh=s fra/ze karba/nw| xeri/. There is a shade of mournful irony in fra/seis (‘make it plain enough’), which is lost in the conjecture fanei=s.—For the double -eis, cp. Soph. Ant.682w(=n le/geis dokei=s pe/ri.

a)p' eu)nasqe/ntos … kakou=, lit., ‘from a lulled plague,’ i.e., from the repose allowed to me by its subsidence. This is simpler than to understand, ‘after the plague had been lulled,’ when a)po\ would be used like e)k (Theocr. 15. 106 a)qana/tan a)po\ qnata=s).—The v. l. a)peunasqe/ntos would be rather a gen. absolute. a)peuna/zein does not occur.
e)s polla\, ‘with regard to’ them: cp. n. on 1211.
klu/ein: i.e., as to the marriage. The question as to the pyre has been settled (1215).

dussebei=n. He regards Iolè as virtually the destroyer of both his parents (1233): it is not eu)sebe/s for him to marry her. Heracles replies that the supreme duty is to do a father's pleasure (cp. 1177).

pra/ssein … pandi/kws, to do these things ‘with full justification,’ i.e., as a duty imposed by a father's solemn command.—Others explain, ‘command me absolutely’: but pandi/kws could not mean pantelw=s: see on 611.—For the place of ou)=n in the verse, cp. O. C.1205, Ph.121.
e)/gwge, ‘that I do’; cp. Ai.104 Ai., 1347 Ai., 1365.
poh/sw. He will marry Iolè. But he will call the gods to witness that it is his father's doing, and not an act of his own choice.

to\ so
 qeoi=si deiknu\s e)/rgon: the e)/rgon is not, strictly, the marriage itself, but the act of Heracles in prescribing it. Hence the words, ‘showing thy deed to the gods,’ mean properly, ‘pleading, before the gods, the constraint which you have put upon me’: not, ‘protesting that my act in marrying Iolè is really your act.’ Accordingly we have deiknu\s to\ so
 e)/<*>on, not deiknu\s to\ e)/rgon so
 (o)/n). The text has been suspected (cr. n.) only because it has not been fully understood.
kalw=s teleuta=|s, after threatening disobedience (1230 ff.).
ka)pi\ toi=sde: i.e., crown the promise with the deed. Cp. Ai.813kou) lo/gw| dei/cw mo/non: | ta/xos ga\r e)/rgou kai\ podw=n a(/m' e(/yetai.— taxei=an, adverbial: cp. O. T.617 f.

pri\n e)mpesei=n k.t.l.: his fear is not so much of the pain, or of increased difficulty for his bearers, but rather of the illomened cries which would be wrung from him on the brink of death. See on 1260.
sparagmo\n (778)
oi)=stron: a similar combination occurs in Aesch. fr. 163 e)k podw=n d' a)/nw | u(pe/rxetai sparagmo\s ei)s a)/kron ka/ra, | ke/nthma lu/sshs, skorpi/ou be/los le/gw.
a)/g) is said to all the bystanders, rather than to Hyllus alone: cp. 821 i)/d), n.

e)gkonei=t): cp. Ai.811xwrw=men, e)gkonw=men: ib. 988 i)/q' e)gko/nei, su/gkamne. The derivation of the verb is uncertain: the only part of it used by Homer is e)gkone/ousai.—ai)/resqe: this literal sense of the midd. ai)/romai is much rarer than the figurative; see, however, El.54, Il.20. 247, Eur. Cycl.473.
au(/th, instead of tou=to: cp. O. C.88tau/thn e)/lece pau=lan (n.). He does not mean, ‘this is the rest promised by the oracle’ (1170): but merely,—‘this is the true release for me.’
teleuth\ … u(sta/th, like e)/sxaton te/rma ( Eur. Andr.1081), extremus finis ( G. 4. 116). He has no presentiment of immortality.
a)ll): cp. 1179 n.
ou)de\n ei)/rgei like ou)de\n kwlu/ei. Cp. 344.
teleiou=sqai: cp. O. C.1089teleiw=sai: but El.1510telewqe/n. Both forms were current in Attic prose.
e)pei\ keleu/eis: he again disclaims responsibility: cp. 1247.

As Hyllus spoke the last two verses, he gave a sign to the bearers (964) to come forward and resume their places beside the litter. These five anapaestic lines are spoken by Heracles while that order is being obeyed. Then the words of Hyllus, ai)/ret), o)padoi/ (1264), mark that the procession is about to move.
a)/ge nun. Either nun or nun would be fitting here, but the former is better: it refers to the consent of Hyllus. The scholiast read nun (a)/ge ou)=n).

pri\n a)nakinh=sai th/nde no/son, ‘before thou hast aroused this plague,’ i.e., ‘allowed it to arise,’—by delay. The attacks recur at intervals; and he wishes to reach the pyre speedily (1253). The meaning is not that vehement laments might bring on the pain.

Other views are:—(1) a)nakinh=sai is intrans., ‘be roused.’ But this use is unexampled, and cannot safely be inferred from the intrans. u(pokinei=n ( Her.5. 106, etc.), or parakinei=n as=parako/ptein, parapai/ein, delirare. (2) The subject to the inf. is no/son, and the object is se understood. But a)nakinh=sai clearly refers to rousing the pain, not to troubling the mind: cp. 974 mh\ kinh/sh|s...o)du/nan: 979 ka)kkinh/seis...no/son.

w)= yuxh\ sklhra/: this phrase has a bad sense in Ai.1361; just as the epithet kratero/frwn, given to Heracles in Il.14. 324, is applied in Hes. Op.147 to the xa/lkeion ge/nos.—Cp. Hom. Od.20. 18te/tlaqi dh\ kradi/h: Aristophanes parodies such passages, Ach.483 ff. pro/baine nu=n, w)= qume/...a)/ge nun, w)= ta/laina kardi/a: as Voltaire said of like apostrophes in Corneille, ‘nous ne sommes plus dans un temps où l'on parle à son bras et à son âme.’

xa/lubos liqoko/llhton sto/mion. This has been explained:—(1) ‘A curb of steel, set with sharp stones’—to make it more severe. (2) ‘A curb of steel, ornamented with costly stones.’ (3) ‘A steel clamp for binding stones together.’ See Appendix.

I take the words in a way different from any of these. xa/lubos sto/mion, the ‘curb of steel,’ is, as all agree, the strong selfrestraint which is to keep the lips closed. Then liqoko/llhton introduces a new image. The lips, thus firmly closed, are set as stone to stone in masonry. Thus the whole phrase means ‘A curb of steel, to keep the lips set as stone to stone.’ The use of liqoko/llhton to describe the effect of the ‘curb’ has been assisted by the suggestion, in sto/mion, of sto/ma.

a)na/paue boh/n. Pythagoras said that a dying man,—like one who is putting out to sea,—should avoid words of ill omen: —kata\ to\n u(/staton kairo\n parh/ggelle mh\ blasfhmei=n, a)ll' w(/sper e)n tai=s a)nagwgai=soi)wni/zesqai met' eu)fhmi/as (Iamblich. Pyth. § 257).

w(s with tele/ous) (fut. part.), marking the intention (cp. 160): e)pi/xarton, predicative: (‘as being about to do a compulsory deed with a feeling of joy.’) The end has been imposed by fate; but it brings victory over pain.

The unanimous tradition assigned verses 1264—1274 to Hyllus. Verses 1275—1278 were given by some to the Chorus, and by others to Hyllus. From the indication in L at v. 1275 (xoro\s gra/fetai u(/llos), and from the schol. there (xoro/s: tine\s u(/llos), it may be conjectured that the attribution of 1275—1278 to the Chorus was the prevalent one. This was only natural, as the Chorus usually closes the play. A majority of modern editors, however, give vv. 1264—1278 wholly to Hyllus; and they seem right.—See Appendix.

o)padoi/, ‘attendants,’ ‘followers,’—the men who have come with him from Euboea (964). In Ant.1108Creon addresses his servants as o)pa/ones. —mega/lhn me\n e)moi\ k.t.l.: the meaning is, ‘Pardon me for helping my father to destroy himself; and note that the real cruelty here is that of Zeus, who allows his son to perish thus.’

suggnwmosu/nhn (=suggnw/mhn) a word found only here; cp. Ant.151qe/sqai lhsmosu/nan.—ei)do/tes qew=n meg. a)gnwmosu/nhn e)/rgwn k.t.l., ‘recognising the great harshness of the gods in the deeds,’ etc.: for the double gen., cp. Andoc. or. 3 § 33 th
 ... a)sfa/leian h(mw=n th=s e)panafora=s. For a)gnwmosu/nh, prop. ‘want of considerateness,’ cp. Dem. or. 18 § 252 pantaxo/qen me
 a)/n tis i)/doi th
 a)gnwmosu/nhn au)tou= kai\ th
 baskani/an (‘unfairness and malevolence’): ib. 207 th=| th=s tu/xhs a)gnwmosu/nh|, its ‘cruelty.’ The likesounding words end two successive verses, as parh/|nesa and sunh/|nesa in Soph. Ph.121 f.
For Nauck's reading of this passage, see Appendix.
klh|zo/menoi is more than kalou/menoi: it implies invocation and praise: cp. 659.
e)forw=si, i.e., look calmly down upon them; just as in El. 825 tau=t' e)forw=ntes | kru/ptousin e(/khloi: cp. Aesch. Ag. 1270 (Cassandra complains of Apollo) e)popteu/sas... | ...katagelwme/nhn.

ta\ me\n ou)=n me/llont) k.t.l.: Hyllus means:—‘No one, indeed, commands a view (e)fora=|) of the future (and so it is possible that Zeus may yet make some amend); but, as to the present situation, it is miserable for us, shameful for Zeus (e)kei/nois), and supremely cruel for the victim.’
The words ta\ me\n ou)=n me/llont' ou)dei\s e)fora=| unconsciously foreshadow the apotheosis of Heracles. This is the only hint of it in the play.
xalepw/tata d' ou)=n. Here d' ou)=n marks the return to the foremost subject of his thoughts. ‘Be the pity or the shame what it may, there can be no doubt who suffers most.’ Cp. Ant. 688 n.

These four verses are addressed by Hyllus to the leader of the Chorus, and give the signal for moving from the orchestra. With parqe/n), compare w)= parqe/noi in 211. The Chorus has been silent since 1113; and it seems dramatically right that its silence should be maintained in this last scene. The young maidens of Trachis may well leave the son of Heracles, at this solemn moment, to sum up the lesson of his father's fate.

If the verses are given to the leader of the Chorus, then parqe/n) will be taken in a collective sense, as referring to the other choreutae; cp. 821 w)= pai=des. Prof. Campbell understands a reference to the maidens of the household (205); but this seems less natural. In either case, the singular number would be unusual.
Another view is that parqe/n) means Iolè. But she is not present: and, even if she could be thus summoned forth, her presence would be unfitting.

e)p' oi)/kwn (see cr. n.) is clearly right. e)pi\ is often thus used with the gen., of position: Plat. Charm. 163 B e)p' oi)kh/matos kaqhme/nw|: Thuc. 4. 118 me/nein e)pi\ th=s au(tw=n.—The Vulg. a)p) oi)/kwn has been explained in three ways, each of which appears untenable:—(1) ‘Do not stay behind,—leaving the house,’ i.e., ‘leave it.’ (2) ‘Do not fail from the house,’—i.e., ‘stay there.’ (3) With parqe/n): ‘O maiden from the house, do not stay behind.’

qana/tous, Deianeira's violent death (for the plur., cp. O. T. 497 n.). The bold use of mega/lous is softened by the poetical plur., which brings out the notion of a ‘great’ or ‘awful’ calamity. me/gas is often nearly equivalent to deino/s, as in me/ga ti paqei=n (Xen. An. 5. 8. 17), etc.

ph/mata … kainopaqh=, the strange and terrible sufferings of Heracles. This adjdoes not occur elsewhere: but Aesch. Theb. 363 has kainoph/mwn as=‘new to woe.’ (For the bad sense of kaino/s, cp. 867, 873.) The second part of the compound is akin in sense to ph=ma: cp. 756 n.—The v. l. kainopagh= was a prosaic conjecture, suggested by such words as neopagh/s.
With *zeu/s the schol. supplies e)/pracen: but it seems truer to supply e)sti/n. ‘There is nothing in all this that is not Zeus’: i.e., he is manifested in each and all of these events.
